properties.text: 2— V.30  I called this morning at the Banking House of Corcoran and Riggs, then at the Bank of the Metropolis and next at the Office of J. J. Nourse to deposit, an order from the Speaker of the House for four hundred dollars, which I took in gold and deposited with three hundred dolls in Bills at the Bank of Metropolis upon which I drew a check of 501.25 payable to J. J. Nourse for City Corporation 6. per cent with a brokerage of one quarter of one per cent. Thence I attended at the House A person by the name of Isaac Cole had been here with a subscription paper for the Building of a Methodist Episcopal Church near Dover Mills Baltimore County— I requested him to call here to-morrow— At the House Edwin H. Ewing from Tennessee, elected in the place of Joseph H. Peyton deceased took his seat and was introduced to me by his Colleague—Milton Brown— Francis A. Cunningham—offered a Resolution with a preamble declaring the Negotiation with Great Britain relating to Oregon Territory terminated and that it is the imperative duty of Congress to adopt immediately such measures as will fully protect our Citizens whom now do or may hereafter inhabit that Country and effectually maintain our just title to the whole of the Country of Oregon— McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means objected to the introduction of this Resolution Henly and Wentworth moved a suspension of the Rules to receive this Resolution which was refused by yeas and nays 73. to 89. Soon after a Question arose as to the day appointed for the consideration of the Bill from the Committees on the Territories for extending our Jurisdiction over the whole Territory of Oregon— Garrett Davis moved a suspension of the Rule to introduce a resolution that the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union should be discharged from the consideration of that Bill and its ten sections be recommitted to seven of the standing Committees of the House— The House refused the suspension of the Rules—a Debate followed concerning the publication of the tenth volume of the Laws. Reports from Committees were called Hugh A. Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs Reported a Bill to provide for the organization of two Regiments of Riflery—he moved its referrence to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and made the special order for next Tuesday— A long Debate followed, at the close of which I took a part in it by a Speech which I fear gave satisfaction to no part of the House when I finished James J. Faran of Ohio moved the suspension of the Rules to offer a Resolution but the House without hearing it read immediately adjourned. W. H. Seward Late Governor of New York came to me at my seat and inquired if I should be at home this evening. I said I should. he promised to call on me and did so with Mr. Robinson who now reports the proceedings of the House for the New York Tribune— I had a long conversation with them in which Mr. Seward declared his full approbation of my speech in the House but some doubt whether it would meet the concurrence of the Whig Party— In coming down the stairs from the House Mr. John W. Houston a Whig member of the State of Delaware had introduced himself to me and told me that he concurred entirely with the sentiments which I had just delivered— This is probably the last great movement of my political Life—it will pass through a fierly ordeal the result of which as concerns myself I leave to the great disposal of events—

19. VI.  This day was devoted to the funeral services at the interment of William Taylor member of the House of Representatives from the state of Virginia. They were performed according to the usual custom upon the decease of Members of Congress a Committee of Arrangements were appointed by the Speaker consisting of Dromgoold of Virginia Dunlap of Maine McKay of North Carolina Abbott of Mass Hungerford of N.Y. Vantz of Ohio and King of Georgia. Eight Pall Bearers appointed by this Committee were Arnold of Rhode Island Sykes of New Jersey, Ritter of Pennsylvania Chapman of Maryland Black of South Carolina Martin of Tennessee, Houston of Alabama and Boyd of Kentucky attended the corps which was transported into the Hall of the House of Representatives, at 1/2 past 12 o clock. The members of the Senate preceeded by the Vice President and their Secretary came into the House in procession. the Vice President taking his seat at the right hand of the Speaker in his Chair and the Senators being accommodated with seats in the aria fronting Clerks Table. The President of the United States and the members of the Cabinet the Judges of the Supreme Court the Commander in Chief of the Army and other distinguished Officers, Military and Naval occupied seats, in common with the members of the House— A Methodistical Prayer was made by Mr. Milburn the Chaplain of the House of Representatives and a Presbyterian Discourse with some small notice of the Deceased was preached by Mr. Tustan the Chaplain of the Senate after which the Coffin was taken from the Hall and the members of Congress in a procession of Hackney Coaches, went to the Congressional Burying Ground near the Navy Yard where the Body was deposited in the temporary Sepulcher awaiting the usual monument erected over the remains of Members of Congress who die at the seat of Government— I rode in a carriage with Mr. Benjamin Thompson member from the fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts. John F. Scamman member from the first Congressional District of Maine and another member whose name I did not discover— After the deposit of the Body we returned to the Hall of the House of Representatives where the speaker resumed the Chair with about eight or ten members present and immediately adjourned the House till to-morrow. This is the routine of Congressional Funerals it was passed three oclock before I reached home walking from the Capitol—

Tuesday 20. January 1846—  Mr. Thomas Sandford, was here again this morning an Old Man prosecuting a Claim the origin of which goes back to the last year of the last Century— He has been here once before last week, and now came with sundry Documents in support of his Claim he belongs to Fall river in the state of Massachusetts and in the year 1834 a Petition was presented to the House from him by Tristam Burgess of Rhode-Island referred first to Committee on Commerce and afterwards to the Committee on Ways and Means who reported against it in 1836. Among the Documents which he now produces is a Letter from Commodore Isaac Hull which may possibly have the effect of obtaining a favorable dicision on his Claim— I promised him therefore to call up his old Petition and have it again referred to the Committee of Ways and means—which I accordingly did. At the House which I found in session the Committees were called for Reports and sundry Bills of which notice had previously been given were introduced by individual members after which, on motion of Hannibal Hamlin Chairman of Committee of Elections the House took up with two reports from the majority and minority five to four on the contested election between Edward C. Cabill and William. H. Brockinbro. for the seat of the Representative from Florida Mr. Cabill made some explanation concerning the reports in the newspapers of the former proceedings of the House upon this case Harper of Ohio a minority member of the Committee of Elections, moved a postponement of the case till tomorrow but was resisted by Hamlin, of Maine who insisted upon taking up the case which was carried 95 to 83. A. H. Chapman of Virginia moved and it was resolved that William H Brockinbro who contests he seat of E. C. Cabell have leave to be heard at the Bar of the House The majority and and minority reports of the Committee of Elections were read, with several unsuccessful attempts to suspend the reading. The majority Report concluded with two Resolutions first, that Cabell was not entitled to his seat and that Brokenbro is. the minority report reverses these positions— Hamlin, Chipman, and SJones debated the first majority Resolution till the adjournment of the House at a quarter past three oclock.— There is much excitement by the news yesterday received of the breaking up of the Peal Ministry in England, and the prospect of a new Ministry headed by Lord John Russell—

21. VI.  There was a fall of snow last night and this morning about six inches deep— In the course of the morning the weather cleared up after some rain and a light frost— At the House Howell Cobb of Georgia was appointed on the Committee on Accounts in the place of William Taylor deceased. George W. Jones of Tennessee offered a Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, for a return of impost Duties received in the year ending 30th. June last with a parrelelstatement of what would have been the proceeds of Duties on the same Articles and all others at an ad valorem rate. Laid over for Debate— Sundry communications from the Navy Department were laid by the Speaker before the House The Florida contested Election was resumed and the Resolutions of the majority Report of the Committee debated chiefly between the members of the Committee till a motion was made by Alexander D. Simms of South Carolina to strike out the Resolution and recommit the case to the Committee to take further evidence relating to the Election I enquired of the Speaker whether the House had not yesterday Resolved that the contestant Brockenbro should be heard in support of his Claim? the Speaker answered that he was. I then suggested that it might be proper to hear the Parties upon the case as it now stood and if that should leave the House unable to decide the Question the motion of Mr. Simms might then be agreed to— Mr. Cabell then moved to suspend the hour rule in favor of Mr. Brockenbro, and Mr. Dobbin moved that it be also suspended in behalf of Mr. Cabell— I objected that the Rule could not apply to Mr. Brockenbro not being admitted as a member of the House nor of course to Mr. Cabell his competitor but was answered that at the last Congress it was decided by the House that the Rule should be applied to both the Parties in the contest between John W. Jones and John M. Botts. The Question was then taken upon the motion to suspend the Rule and lost by yeas and nays 89. to 74. not two thirds. The House then adjourned. There was a Bridal Party in the day time to the house of Mr. F. P. Blair six miles from the City and they went in the evening including my Grandaughter to the Drawing-Room at the Presidents House. I spent the evening at Mr. Markoe’s House by the invitation of Mr Joseph. R. Ingersoll—with a large Party of Gentlemen—

22. VI.30.  It was close upon midnight last evening when I came home from the Party invited by Mr. Joseph R Ingersoll at the House of Mr. Markoe There had been a luxuriant supper and a numerous assemblage— Mr. James Thompson member of the House from Pennsylvania disappointed by his Hackney Coachman took a seat with me in my Carriage and Fuller took him to his lodgings at Mrs. Hamilton’s in Pennsylvania Avenue— This morning Mr. John Otis of West Barnstable was here proposing still to remain here some weeks in the prosecution of further Claims of the Heirs of his brother William Otis deceased— He inquired if he would stand any chance to obtain employment as a Clerk to any of the Committees of either House of Congress I answered that none of the Committees of the House were allowed to employ Clerks unless by especial note of the House which was very rarely granted. I believed that the Committees of the Senate were more freely indulged. I could give him no encouragement to hope for employment by any of the Committees of the House. He said he was acquainted with none of the Senators except Mr. Webster and with him very slightly— At the House, the resolution offered yesterday by George W. Jones of Tennessee calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for the Amount of Duties imported in the last year to the 30th. June 1845. and the equivalent by an ad valorem duty was adopted without opposition. The Speaker laid before the House a Letter from B. B. French representing his embarassment with regard to the execution of an Order of the House of the 13th. instt. requiring him to distribute among the Members of the present House the copies of Captain Fremont’s Report which an Order of the last House of Representatives had directed should be distributed among it. Members of the 28. Congress— Thereupon James Thompson of Penn moved a Resolution that the Clerk forewith distribute the report of Fremonts expedition acending to the Order of the House of the 13th. January inst a Debate followed whether by the Resolution of the last House there was not vested in the members of the last House a property in the Documents directed to be distributed which it was not competent to the present House to take away and appropriate to themselves— Joseph R. Ingersoll and Schenk of Ohio opposed Thompson’s resolution and Schenck moved as an Amendment to it that five thousand extra Copies of Fremont’s report be printed, for the use of the members of this House and that the Resolution of the 13 instant be rescinded. Cullen Sawtelle of Maine enquired of the Clerk if he had information or knowledge that any member of the last Congress had sold to a Bookseller in Washington Books which he had received in distribution by an Order of the House. Rathburne objected to this Question as not in order The Speaker said he had made enquiry of the Clerk who had answered that he had no such information Sawtelle moved a previous Question Joseph Morris of Ohio moved to lay the subject on the table which was refused The previous Question was carried Schenck Amendment was rejected by yeas and 76 to 106 and Thompsons Resolution was carried also by yeas and nays 94 to 80— Sawtelle then moved a Resolution for the appointment of a Committee of five with power to send for persons and papers to enquire whether any members or members of the 28 Congress had sold Fremonts Report or any other remnent ordered by Congress to be distributed and to Report to the House the name or names of such traders and the facts respecting the sales. The Resolution was extended to the case of members of all other former Congresses and to other Doc and was adopted without opposition. The Florida contested election was then resumed Mr. Cabell the sitting member made two proposals first that the House should take the Question without further Debate and secondly if the contestant should not agree to that they should go back to the People of Florida to settle the contest by a new election both of which Mr. Brockenbrough declined and delivered his own Argument in support of his Claim Mr. Cabell took the floor and the House adjourned by yeas and nays 108 to 64— Mrs. Maury Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal spent part of the evening here—

30. V.15.  Further evidence appears of the flinching of the Polk Administration upon the Oregon Controversy with Great Britain— In the Union newspaper of last Tuesday—there was an Article, strongly intimating, that if a proposition should be made on the part of Great Britain to take theof the 49. degree of Latitude as the Boundary to the Pacific Ocean, describing it as the offer made by me it might now be accepted. In the Debate in the Senate on Wednesday this Article was referred to, by Mr. Miller a Senator from New Jersey as very clearly indicating that Mr. Polk has no fear of war to arise from this Question Edward. A. Hannagan Senator from Indiana rose and averred upon his responsibility that this Article had never been seen by President Polk before its publication and was not approved by him— The Union of this day admits the fact, but repeats the opinion expressed in the original Article— At ten o’clock this morning I attended a meeting of the Select Commitee on the Smithsonian Bequest present six Members—Owen, Adams, Jenkins, Sims—Davis, Wilmot—absent Marsh of Vermont who afterwards told me that it was because he had forgotten the time of the Meeting—Some progress very little was made in the discussion of Mr. Owen’s Bill, in the Sixth Section provision is made for a superintendant to take charge of the ground, Buildings and property belonging to the Institution—and also for the Appointment of a Professor of Agriculture, Horticulture and Rural economy and also for a distribution among the people of the Union of Fruits, Plants, Seeds and Vegetables to be collected by this Superintendent with the Professor, and Gardiners, practical Agriculturists, and Labourers to be hired from time to time by him, as may be necessary— I moved to strike out this Section, which consider as a cumbersome expensive, and useless burden upon the Institution— It was connected also with a further project, declared in the seventh Section, for the appointment of a Normal Branch of the Institution, with an indefinite number of professors of common School and other scientific Instruction—all which I proposed to expunge from the Bill— The discussion was desultory, and before taking the Question upon it some Amendments of detail to the Sixth Section were proposed and debated until the meeting of the House when the Committee adjourned to next Friday. At the House the Committees were called for Reports—many of which were made, but none of any material importance. Stephens of Georgia presented resolutions from that state claiming re-imbursements for sundry expenses incurred by that State in the late Wars with the Indians, commonly called the Florida War. Committee of the Whole on State of the Union—Tibbatts in the Chair. Joseph P. Hoge of Galena Illinois and William Wick of Indianapolis Illinois in two successive hour Speeches supported the giving of the Notice and took to task the latter with merciless sarcasm, the contrast of bullying and of sneaking off the South Carolina politicians with John C. Calhoun at their head. He ridiculed their clamours about war, though he admitted, that War might terminate in the result of this Controversy and Andrew Johnson of Tennessee took the floor but the Bill was laid aside and a Bill from the Senate to establish certain post roads in the State of Texas was taken up— Erastus. D. Culver of Greenwich New York, made an hour Speech against the Bill on the grounds of unconstitutionality insisting that the Annexation of Texas to this Union by mere Act of Congress was UnConstitutional null and void and would be so decided he had no doubt by the Supreme Court of the United States if the Question could be brought before them. He reviewed with severe censure all the proceedings of the Democratic Party and of the Administration in the rise, progress and consummation of that iniquitous measure— He adverted to the deception practised upon the People of the North at the Baltimore Convention by the substitution of James K Polk for Martin Van Buren as the candidate of the Party for the Presidency of the United States, and in the adoption of two Resolutions one for the Annexation of Texas and the other declaring the right of the United States to the whole of Oregon to 54.40— as clear and unquestionable and now after completing the Annexation of Texas falling back and manifesting the design to abandon if not the whole a large portion of Oregon even to the mouth of Columbia river with the free navigation of it— Culver was several times called to order by southern members—and especially in a very insulting manner by McConnell of Alabama but the Chairman steadily and resolutely declared him in order to the great annoyance of the interrupting members who dared not however take an appeal from his decisions— Culver finished his Speech without losing his temper and McConnell sputtered a few sentences in reply to him of personal insult of which he took no notice— The Committee of the Whole then reported the Bill and with the help of the Previous Question it was passed without Amendment and without further opposition. Walter Hellen went to an evening Party at the House of Gov. Marcy the Secretary of War, and we were amused by the reading of a review of the Life of Capt Kidd in a number of Littell’s Living Age

10— V.30—  The child Arthur, has suffered a long agony. We had again a Letter, from Elizabeth. C. Adams, stating that on Sunday, he still breathed but with the prospect, that every hour, would be his last.— Our suffering, is little less protracted, and finds no comfort, but in resignation. Mr. Hoyt was here this morning, with a friend of his from Philadelphia named Hopkins— Mr. Hoyt left with me a minute of several Claims at the Pension Office, which I took there and left with Mr. Edwards the Commissioner requesting him to examine them and report to me his decision, upon them—which he promised— Mr. Brainard came and requested me to sit for a Daguerreotype likeness at Plumbes Gallery Concert Hall in the Pennsylvania Avenue where I promised to go at eleven o’clock tomorrow morning— At the House Robert McClelland, of Michigan presented resolutions of the Legislature of that State declaring the right of the United States to the Oregon Territory, to Latitude 54–40— Laid on the Table and ordered to be printed— A Message was received from the President, in answer to a Call of the 19th. December last, for copies of correspondence between this Government and Great Britain within the last two years, in relation to the Ashburton Treaty, free navigation of the river St John’s and the disputed Territory fund, with copies of Documents from the Department of State. Referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— Reports were also received from the Secretary of the Treasury, with returns of importations and Impost Duties and from Secretary of War, with returns of Militia— The Committees were called for Reports, many of which were made—chiefly upon Private Claims, favourable and adverse. John H. McHenry of Kentucky reported from the Committee on the District of Columbia, a Bill to enlarge the powers of the several Orphans Courts of the District— It related to the distribution of Property. Joshua R. Giddings of Ohio moved an Amendment, of an additional Section declaring, that Slaves shall no longer be deemed in Law to be property—within the District of Columbia and was supporting, his Amendment by beginning an Argument, when McHenry objected to the Amendment, as not in order for irrelevancy— The Speaker a pro-slavery representative from the free state of Indiana buckled close to the Slave mongers, decided, that the Amendment was irrelevant, and therefore, not in Order— Giddings appealed from this decision—and began an Argument in support of his Appeal— William. M. Treadway of Virginia, inquired if the appeal was debatable. The Speaker answered that it was— Richard Brodhead, from Easton, Pennsylvania moved to lay the Appeal on the Table—which was carried— This decision undoubtedly wrong, serves but to show the transcendent power here exercised, over the House, by the Slave Representation, of the South— The bill was passed— George Rathbun, reported from the Committee on the Judiciary, a Resolution, calling on the Secretaries of War and the Navy, to report whether any of the Officers, Military or Naval, were employed as Clerks in the Department or otherwise and receiving double compensations and the Amount of such payments if made— He reported also a resolution, declaring that no alteration in the naturalization laws is necessary, for the preservation of the rights, interests, and morals of the People; or for guarding the Ballot Box, against every improper influence— This resolution, directed point blank, against the resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, which had been referred, to the Judiciary Committee and was itself referred, to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Rathbun moved that five thousand extra copies of the Report should be printed which was laid over for a day— Lynn Boyd, from the Committee on the Territories moved to be discharged from the consideration of a large number of the Memorials, and Remonstrances, against the annexation of Texas, and that they be laid on the Table—which was done— Robert Smith, of Illinois, from the Committee on Roads and Canals, reported, a Bill for completing the Cumberland road through Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois, and to Jefferson City, Missouri— Referred, to the Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union— Morgan L. Martin, delegate from the Wisconsin Territory, presented, a paper, signed by himself, and Augustus C. Dodge, Delegate from the Territory of Iowa, requesting leave to record on the Journals of the House, their suffrage, in favor of the Resolution of notice, adopted yesterday, by the House, which was agreed to— A Message was received from the President, with the Annual returns from the Mints. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Richard Brodhead in the Chair, on the Appropriation Bill, for Fortifications, amounting to one million of dollars, which after some small Debate, was laid aside, to be reported to the House. The Bill of Appropriations for Pensions, was taken up next— This gave rise to a long Debate, upon an Amendment, proposed by Tibbatts, of Ky without deciding which, the Committee rose, and reported the Fortification Bill, which was passed, and the House at half past three o’clock adjourned— Mr. Hoyt was here in the evening, to inquire if I had received answers from the Commissioner of Pensions, in the cases, which I had submitted to him from Mr. Hoyt’s minutes— I had not. Mr. Hoyt is to leave the City tomorrow.

19— V.30—  Dr. John Baldwin, one of the largest claimants for the Mexican indemnities, was here this morning— A message from the President, upon this subject, was received at the House yesterday, and laid before it by the Speaker this day, and was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— The subject is full, of iniquitous mystery.— Two instalments of the Indemnity, stipulated by the Mexican Government, were paid, to an Agent, of the American Government, named Voss—and receipted for, by him. And have never been received, by the Government here, nor has any satisfactory account, been given, how the money, has disappeared— Dr. Baldwin, told me, that an Executive Document, of the last Congress, No 144. contains, a Report upon the subject, disclosing, some extraordinary facts, relating to it— But he explicitly charged, Waddy Thompson, then Envoy Extraordinary, and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States, in Mexico, with having, in Concert, with the Agent Voss embezzled the money, and divided it between them— I told Dr. Baldwin, that I could hardly hear, and still less credit, such a statement, that if there was any foundation for it, I considered it incumbent; upon the Administration, of this Government itself, to investigate it, to the bottom, and if not to recover the money, at least to expose, and if possible, to punish the delinquents— I am afraid that I can apologise, to my conscience, for failing, in the performance, of my own duties on this subject, only, by the prostration of my strength, and the disability, of decaying age— As I was entering my carriage, to go to the House, I met at the door, Mr. Heman Lincoln, with a missionary by the name of—and a young Chinees Man, with whom, I had not time for an interview— At the House, on motion of Archibald Atkinson of Virginia, the Committee of Naval Affairs, was instructed to inquire into the expediency, of having completed, and fitted for service, the ship of the Line, New-York, and the Frigate St. Lawrence, now in the stocks, at Gosport, in Virginia— James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina, from the Committee of Elections, reported in favor of John Runk—as a Member of the House from New Jersey, against the memorial, of Isaac. G. Farlee, concluding with the Resolution, that Runk, is entitled to his Seat. Lucien. B. Chase of Tennessee, made a minority report, from the same Committee, against Runk—and in favor of Farlee, both the Reports, were laid on the Table, and ordered to be printed— John. P. Martin of Kentucky, from the Committee, on Milage, reported a Bill, prohibiting the allowance of travelling Fees, for any Senator, for attendance, at any called Executive Session of the Senate, unless, for actual travel— This Bill, roused a sharp debate and the House, manifested, a large majority, for driving it through at once, but the morning hour expired.— and the House went into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union upon the Indian, Appropriation Bill, John. R. J. Daniell in the Chair— Amendments were moved, by Hugh White of New York, and Martin delegate from Wisconsin, which were reported to the House, and one by Thomasson of Kentucky, against the Choctaw Academy, which was rejected; and the Bill was passed by yeas and nays 150. to 10—of which last number, I was one— Dr. John M. Thomas, was here this evening, and prescribed, for a new complaint, of inflamatory symptoms, in my Legs—

24— V.15.— Shrove Tuesday.  At the House, the reading of the Journal, of Saturday last was dispensed with. A practise of evil tendency, creeping into the House— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, moved to reconsider the vote, to lay on the Table, the Bill, to grant the Patent, to Dr. Charles. G. Page, an Officer, in the Patent Office— This motion was postponed for future consideration. This was the day for the presentation of Petitions, but the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on yeas and nays 106 to 67. Thomas Smith of Illinois, in the Chair—and took up the River and Harbour Bill— Felix G. McConnell, after breathing a blast against the Bill itself, moved to lay it aside, and take up another—which Motion, was rejected— The Amount of the Appropriation, is $1,348,450—besides an indefinit Sum, for the purchase, of the Louisville and Portland Canal— McConnell, moved to strike out, the first Section of the Bill, and sputtered a speech, of about 10. minutes, when his Motion was rejected.— Robert. B. Rhett, moved to strike out, all after the enacting clause, and delivered a diatribe, against the whole system of internal improvements, to which, Thomasson of Kentucky replied— Crosier of Tennessee, proposed an Amendment, an appropriation of $250,000. to complete the Canal; round the Muscle Shoals, of the Tennessee River— He complained, that the North Western Members, of the Committee of Commerce, had lavished too much Money, upon the Lakes, and that a grant, made several years ago of four hundred thousand Acres of Land, to the State of Alabama, to dig a Canal, round the Muscle Shoals, had not accomplished the object— Houston and Chapman of Alabama expatiated, upon the faithful application of that grant, but admitted to be sure, that it had not accomplished its purpose, but McConnell charged the State, with gross mis-management, and waste of that Fund— Schenck of Ohio, made an hour speech, in favor of the Bill, animadverting to the composition of the Committee of Commerce, and defending them, against the censure of Crosier— He complained also, that the Annual Message of the President, had totally omitted all recommendation, not only of Public improvement, but even of Harbour defences.— The Committee rose, and the Speaker communicated to the House, reports, from the Post Office, Navy, and Patent Office Departments: The Report from the Commissioner of Patents, was ordered to be printed; referred to the Committee on Patents. It comes this year from Edmund Burke, late a member of Congress from New Hampshire, appointed in the place of Henry L. Ellsworth, removed, for extraordinary service in the Department. The House adjourned soon after three— In the evening at 7. o’clock, I attended at the Convention, for the observance of the Sabbath,—In the vestry of the 1st. Presbyterian Church in 4 1/2 street— Of which the Revd. Mr. Sprole, is the Minister— My neighbour Albion. K. Parris, went with me.— There were nearly two hundred persons present— Delegates, from the Presbyterian, Methodist, Baptist, and Episcopalian Churches, in the District of Columbia, but no Roman Catholics, Quakers, nor Unitarians— Mr, Parris, was chosen Chairman, and the Committee appointed, for organizing the Meeting— They reported a list of Officers, nominating me as President, with several vice-Presidents, and Secretaries, the first of whom was Matthew St. Clair Clarke. A business Committee was appointed, who retired and Reported, rules for the proceedings, and fifteen Resolutions, for discussion— They were immediately debated, and with some Amendments adopted, and agreed to be reported, to an adjourned Meeting of the Convention, in the Church at 10. o’clock tomorrow morning— It was past 10. o’clock, when with Mr. Parris, I returned home.

25— V—  At ten this morning, I attended again, the Convention, for promoting the observance of the Sabbath, at the first Presbyterian Church, on four and a half street— At the Meeting last evening, a Delegation, from the Congressional Prayer meeting, were invited, to participate, in the proceedings of the Convention, and several of its members, attended this day— There has been it seems, for several years, an Association of Members of Congress, who hold occasional meetings, for uniting in Prayer; to which, I have never been invited, and the existence of which, I had not till now known— The Resolutions, reported from the Meeting last evening, were now produced, and adopted, with certain Amendments—but the Convention sat till two o’clock, and when the hour of twelve, the time for Meeting, at the House of Representatives, I was obliged to leave, the Chair of the Convention, and repair to the House— Among the reports of the Committees was one, by Robert M. T. Hunter, Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, of a Bill to retrocede, the County of Alexandria, to the State of Virginia. Another Bill reported by William. W. Paine of Alabama, from the same Committee, was to repeal an Act requiring one of the Judges of the Circuit Court, of the District of Columbia to reside in Alexandria. This Bill was read three times and passed without opposition. Alexander Ramsay of Pennsylvania, reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, a Bill for the commencement of Fortifications, at New Bedford Mass. Isaac E. Holmes, Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs, reported a Bill, to reduce into one Act, the several Acts, concerning Naval Pensions, and to repeal some others. He reported also from the Committee on the Rules, a new one, that upon Bills making Appropriations of money, for internal improvements, a separate vote of the House, may be taken, upon each item separately— Tibbatt’s moved to lay it on the Table, which was rejected, by yeas and nays, 69. to 95—and the Rule was adopted 98. to 75. and finally passed 106. to 71.— A motion to reconsider was rejected 86. to 95. The River and Harbour Appropriation Bill, was taken up in Committee of the Whole, on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair. W. W. Paine, of Alabama, spoke an hour, against the Bill, generally and specially— Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, spoke in favor of it— Quarter past three the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— At seven o’clock this evening, I attended, at the adjourned Meeting; of the Sabbath Convention, at the first Presbyterian Church, in four and a half street where I presided— The resolutions, reported by the business Committee, were finally acted upon, amended and adopted. The House was crowded with Auditors, whom I addressed in a short speech— Several other addresses were made—a Committee for preparing and publishing, a Report of the proceedings of the Convention was appointed, and between ten and eleven o’clock, the Convention adjourned— Mr. Lawrence a reporter, for the Baltimore Sun newspaper, requested me, to write out my Address, for publication in that paper. Mr. Parris, returned home, with me—

26— VI.  I employed, all the morning till the time, for the meeting of the House, in writing and, with the help of my Grandaughter, the substance of my remarks at the meeting of the Convention last evening—which I gave to Mr. Lawrence, the Reporter for the Baltimore Sun, who called for them, this afternoon— At the House, W. W. Paine, of Alabama, on pretence of making a personal explanation, delivered a second Speech, against the River and Harbour Bill—to which Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, again replied— James. C. Dobbin, of North Carolina, from the Committee of Elections, gave notice, that he would call up to-morrow, the Reports of that Committee, of the contested election, of John Runk from the State of New Jersey— Thomas. F. Vinton, gave notice, that he would move an Amendment to the rule adopted yesterday, by extending it, to all Bills for Light Houses, Fortifications and Impost Duties— Laid over for consideration hereafter— Felix. G. McConnell, moved a resolution, that no Member should be allowed to speak, more than ten minutes on any Private Bill, which the Speaker, must be considered, as a notice, being a proposition, to change the rules, which must be laid over, for one day— Communications were received from the War and Navy Departments— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas. Smith of Indiana in the Chair, on the River and Harbour Bill— Supported by Robert McClelland of Michigan, and opposed by Robert. C. Rhett of South Carolina, each for his hour. Charles Hudson of Massachusetts, commenced a Speech, and was soon called to order, first by Shelton. F. Leake, and next by George. W. Hopkins both of Virginia, for irrelevancy— The Speaker declared Hudson both times, to be in order. Hopkins appealed from his decision, which was sustained, 60. to 40. but no quorum voting, whereupon the Committee rose, Tibbatts moved a call of the House, but they preferred to adjourn, which they did—

27. V.  At ten o’clock this morning, I attended a Meeting of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian Bequest, present Owen, Chairman, Adams, Simms, Jenkins, Marsh, and Jefferson Davis—absent Wilmot.— The Chairman, conformably to the order, adopted at the last meeting had prepared a Report, to be submitted with the Bill, to the House— It contained a statement, of the embezzlement of the Fund, by investing it in the stocks of the states of Arkansas, Illinois, and Michigan— I had moved, to have this statement made and provided for in the Bill—but excepting Mr. Marsh, no other member of the Committee, would consent to it. They were unwilling to uncover the nakedness of the States— They consented however with reluctance, to have it made in the report, which Mr. Owen had rather awkwardly done, with an expression of the opinion of the Committee, that there would be, no ultimate loss, to the United States, of the Funds thus invested— I moved to strike out of the Report, this expression of confidence, which I could not honestly avow— It was accordingly struck out—leaving a bare statement of the Facts, to be made— The Chairman, was directed, in presenting the Report, and Bill, to move that they should be printed, and made the special order of the Day, for the second Tuesday, in April— The Committees upon this subject, of the House, have heretofore, been unanimous, in the Reports— All which have been made by me— But the House, has never been prevailed upon, to take them into consideration— In this Committee, no two members, excepting Mr. March, and myself, have agreed in opinion, with regard to the future management of the Fund— I doubt, if there will be more harmony in the House, for never was there, a benevolent and charitable purpose, more unfortunately endowed, than that of James Smithson, intrusted, to the good faith, and intelligence, of the North American Congress—  In the House, John S. Chipman of Michigan, a member of the Committee of Elections, moved to take up their Reports, upon the New Jersey contested election— The House preferred to go, into Committee of the whole, on Private Bills, by virtue of the rule that on the first and fourth Friday, of each month, this being the fourth, the calendar of Private Bills, shall be called over, and those to the passage of which no objection is made, shall be first considered, and disposed of— Thirteen Bills were thus reported to the House, and passed; and a Bill granting a Pension, to Orris Crosby, was objected to, by Simms, of South Carolina— Whereupon Wentworth of Illinois, if his objection should be persisted in, he would object, to every other Bill which should be called up— Which he accordingly did, till a debate arose, which finally compelled the Committee to rise— Hannibal Hamlin, moved to go into Committee again—but without success— Stephen Douglass of Illinois, Chairman of the Committee on Territories, moved to go into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, upon the Oregon Territorial Bill— Which motion also failed— After the receipt of several Communications from the Executive Departments, Cobb of Georgia, moved to go again into Committee of the Whole on private Bills, but on taking the Question, there was no Quorum, voting, and the House adjourned— Mr. John. A. Rockwell, of Connecticut and his brother, an inhabitant of Norwich, passed part of the evening here—

28. VI.  A Snow storm began last night, and continued, and violent all this day— At the House, Alexander. D. Simms, of the fourth Congressional District of South Carolina, in the form of a personal explanation, assigned his reasons, for objecting yesterday, against the passage of the Bill, for the relief of Orris. Crosby, which arrested the progress of the Committee of the whole, in clearing out the Private Calendar— John Wentworth of Illinois, who had yesterday, objected to every Bill, after that in favor of Crosby, and thereby, broken up the Committee of the Whole, made a counter explanation and an Argument for the Bill, in favor of Crosby. But there was no Question, before the House, and the two personal explanations ended in smoke— Edmund. W. Hubard presented resolutions, from the Legislature of Virginia, requiring of Congress, to provide by law, for the satisfaction, of all Virginia Military Land warrants for Revolutionary service, now unsatisfied. Referred to the Committee on Public Lands—numerous Reports were received from the Committees— Alexander Harper of Ohio, presented resolutions of the Legislature of that state, against any increase, of the rights of postage— Referred to the Committee on Post Offices, and Post Roads— Robert. Dale. Owen, Chairman of the Select Committee, on the Smithsonian Bequest, presented a Report and Bill, as a substitute of that, which he had introduced; and moved, that the Report be printed— That the substitute be referred to the Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, and printed separately, in the form of a Rule, and be made a special order of the day of the second Tuesday, in April next— A division of the Question was called, upon which Mr. Owen. urged the propriety, and necessity, for the credit of the Country to make it a special Order, for a not distant day— The Resolution was carried, by a vote of more than two thirds—and the specific assignment, for discussing the Bill, was made. The House then went into Committee of the whole, on Private Business— Rathbun of New York in the Chair— The Bill, granting commutation, of half pay, to the legal Representatives, of Colonel William Grayson, of the Revolutionary Army, was again debated. Speeches in its favor, were made by James. A. Seddon, Thomas H Bayly, Joseph Johnson of Virginia, and Garrett Davis of Kentucky and against it, by Henry. S. Clarke, of North Carolina— Samuel Gordon of New York moved to lay the Bill aside, to be reported to the House, with a recommendation that it do not pass— I moved to strike out those words, but the Chairman thought, it was sufficient, to strike out the word not— The Question was taken by Tellers, and carried 64 to 60— The Bill was reported accordingly, and the House adjourned without taking the Question upon it— I rode to and from the Capitol on account of the snow—

1. V.—  The snow continued, with little intermission, through the last night, and this day— I rode, not without difficulty, to the second Presbyterian Church, on New York Avenue— Where were assembled, the present Minister, Mr. Matthew Hale. Smith, about twenty men and two women— He performed the usual morning service, according to the forms of the Presbyterian Church, and preached a short Sermon from Hebrews. 6.18. “That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation who have fled, for refuge, to lay hold upon the hope, set before us. 19. Which hope, we have as an anchor of the Soul, both sure and steadfast, and which entereth, into that within the veil”— This Discourse scarcely gave me an opportunity to judge, of the character and power of Mr. Smith as a pulpit orator. What I have seen of him, has given me a very favorable, opinion of him, as a man— He gave notice that owing to the inclemency of the weather, the Church would not be open, for Public Worship, this afternoon— But that there would be a service in it, on Wednesday evening— The Storm continued so severe, that I did not attempt to attend any Church, after dinner;—but employed the time in reading a Poem, on the Immortality of the Soul—Canto first— This work, in manuscript, was sent to me, by its Author, through the hands of Mr. Brinkerhoff—of Ohio—with a request, that I would read, and give my opinion of it— It was said to be written by the Author of a volume, given to me last Spring, by Mr. Knox, on the Philosophy of the plan of Salvation— I have intended, and promised Mr. Knox to read it—but have not yet performed the promise— The Poem is in the form of blank verse—in the construction of which the Author, is very unskilful— It is accompanied with Notes, more voluminous, than the Poem itself, and consists, in the first Canto, of a series of inquires, to ascertain, what is the Soul— The second Canto, which I had not time this day to read, is intitled, “The work of the Soul”—and the notes, beginning with the doctrine of Plato, dive into all the mysteries, which belong to that, incomprehensible subject— I dread to approach it, and never enter upon it, without remembering, the reprobate spirits in the Paradise lost—“Who find no end, in wandering mazes lost”—

2— V—  The above is an effusion, of my nightly waking hours— When without ability to sleep, or energy to rise, time hangs heavy on me, and I seek consolation, in the jingling of rhyme— This happens to me very often, though I have scarcely ever, made any record, of these my thick coming fancies— I propose however to do so, by way of experiment, for a few days, yet left me. This morning we retrieved the arrears, of this Diary—and I then attended at the House— I found them in Session and Felix G. Mc Connell, had made an explanation about his Speech, two or three days since, assailing, the Legislature, of his own State for mis-managment and waste, of the proceeds of the Sale of 400,000. acres of Land, granted by Congress, to aid in the construction, of a Canal, round the Muscle Shoals, of the Tennessee river— The Speaker said this was the day for calling the states and Territories, for resolutions, commencing with the Territory of Iowa, and going upwards to the state of Maine—but James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina called up a Report, of the Committee of Elections, in the contest for the seat of John Runk as a member from New Jersey— John Wentworth of Illinois, urged the call for resolutions, it being the first time, during the present Session, that it was to commence from the west but the House chose to postpone the call for resolutions, and to take up the contested election.— The report of the majority closed with a resolution, that Isaac. G. Farlee, is not entitled to a Seat, in this House, as a representative from the state of New Jersey— Hannibal Hamlin, from the minority of the Committee of elections, moved to strike out all after the word resolved, and insert that John Runk, is not entitled to a seat upon this floor; that Isaac. G. Farlee, having received a majority, of the legal votes of the legally qualified voters, of the third Congressional District of New Jersey, is entitled to his Seat, upon this floor— Farlee was admitted to a seat on the floor, with the privilege to speak, in support of his claim. The Reports of the majority and minority of the Committee of elections were read— It appeared, that John Runk, was declared to have been elected, by a majority, of 16. votes, but Farlee represented, that this nominal majority was obtained, by the votes of 36. Students, at the Theological Seminary at Princeton, and of 5. Students, at the College, at the same place— The Question then was whether the votes of the students, were by the Laws of New Jersey, legal, and valid the debate was maintained, by Harper and Dobbin, in favor of the students, and resisted by Hamlin and Chipman— All members of the Committee of elections— I found it so dull and tedious, that I left my Seat, and went into the Senate Chamber where I heard a Speech of Sydney Breese, Senator from the State of Illinois upon the Oregon Question, in favor of giving the notice, of termination, to the Convention of 1827. and stubborn, in support of the right to the parallel of Latitude 54–40. The hour rule, of the House, has not been adopted, in the Senate— Soon after three, I returned to the House, where Chipman of Michigan was still speaking, but stopt immediately, for a motion to adjourn, which was carried— I rode to and from the Capitol— The heaviest, of this, and of many winters, subsided, this afternoon, and began to clear off cold—

3— V–30—  Mr. Henry Johnson, one of the Senators from the State of Louisiana, with a friend from that state named,This gentleman came, with a request, of my opinion as to the construction, in an article of the Florida Treaty so-called, signed on the 22d. February 1819. and finally ratified on the 22d. of February 1821. It related to contested Land Titles, in that region of Country claimed by us, as ceded in the Louisiana Treaty of 1803, and by Spain, as not included in that Treaty— That is, west Florida, east of the Mississippi to the Perdido— These Land titles, have been in litigation from the time of the conclusion of the Florida Treaty, and now, a statement of my recollection is requested, as to an understanding, between the negotiaters of the Treaty Don Luis De Onis and myself, at the time. I told this gentleman, that I should very readily, give my recollections upon the subject, but they would have no sort of bearing, for or against any claims to land titles— That the Treaty must of course speak for itself, and at the distance, of 27. years, I could have no confidence, in my own memory, upon points so critical, in the conduct of the negotiation, I could say at once, that Mr. Onis and myself, had commenced the negotiation, by discarding all previous controversy, respecting the right of Jurisdiction, of either party, in the disputed Territory— The King of Spain, had made up his mind, to cede to the United States, all his claims, and rights, to the whole of it, and we considered it altogether useless, to debate any further concerning the previous title, to it— Mr.left for me, a Memorial to the Committee of private Land claims, of the House of Representatives, presented in April 1838. by Richard S. Cox, and Theodore H. McCaleb Council for the Petitioners, with sundry Documents annexed, which I am to examine— I took to the Pension Office for the examination of the Commissioner a Letter from Elijah Clark Esqr. with a return certificate of Pension due to the Heirs of Betty Wheat, and a claim of Jonathan Sargent—and then went to the House, where the Speaker had laid before the House, a report from the Clerk, estimating the cost; of supplying the Reporters with the printed Documents, for the remainder of this Session at about three hundred dollars. The contested election, from New Jersey, between John Runk the sitting member and Isaac. G. Farlee, was resumed. John S. Chipman of Michigan, finished his speech, in favor of Farlee, and was followed, by Timothy Jenkins, of the 20th. Congressional District of New York, on the same side. They were answered, by E. D. Culver, of New York, Robert Toombs of Georgia, and Robert. C. Schenck, of Ohio—with an overwhelming superiority of talent and of Argument, on the other side— John. W. Tibbatts, of Kentucky moved the Previous Question. and passed four o’clock the House adjourned— Mr. Richard D. Cutts, and his sister Mary, were here this evening— My wife was quite unwell and confined to her bed—

4— V–30—  To Mirth— A Sonnet.—  Mr. Heman Lincoln called here this morning, and inquired if my Lecture upon Faith, which he had once heard me deliver, had been published— I said it had not— He expressed a desire to read it, and I lent him the fair manuscript copy of it— At the House, the contested election from New Jersey, was the first subject acted upon— After a call of the House, during the course of which I took my seat, and answered at the second call—one hundred and eighty names were returned— The previous Question moved yesterday by Tibbatts was rejected, by Tellers 68 to 75— The resolution reported by the majority of the Committee of Elections was that Isaac G. Farlee is not entitled, to a Seat in this House, as a representative from the State of New Jersey, but they did not report, that the sitting member, was.— Hannibal Hamlin, from the minority of the Committee, moved to strike out, that Farlee is not entitled to a seat in the House, and to insert, that John Runk is not entitled to a Seat on this floor— That Isaac G. Farlee having received a majority of the legal votes, of the legally qualified voters, of the third Congressional District of New Jersey is entitled to a Seat on this floor— Yancey inquired, if the Question could not be divided, the Speaker answered, that by a positive rule of the House, a motion to strike out and insert, was indivisible— Morse of Louisiana, then asked to be excused from voting in as much as he could vote that Runk was not entitled to the Seat but not that Farlee was— The first Question was upon Hamlin’s amendment, which was rejected by yeas and nays, 76. to 112—then on the Resolution reported by the majority of the Committee, that Farlee is not entitled to the Seat, which was carried 119. to 66— Hamlin then moved that John Runk, is not entitled to a Seat, in this House, and called the previous Question, and yet, attempted to make a Speech— Hopkins of Virginia, moved to lay the whole subject on the Table, which was rejected 93. to 99— The previous Question was then carried, and Hamlin’s motion, that John Runk, is not entitled to his Seat, was lost, 96. to 96—the Speaker deciding the tie, by voting in the negative— Bayly of Virginia then said; that he had agreed with his Colleague Pendleton, called away by urgent business to Baltimore this morning, that if his Bayly’s vote, should turn the scale, he would not give it, Yet he did vote against Runk, and thereby, made the tie— He said he should not have voted if he had known, that the vote would be so close, and this is a sample, of what Mr. Bayly holds to be the obligation of good Faith— But for the decision of the Speaker his vote would have turned the scale, but the promise itself, was unwarrantable— William Sawyer of Ohio complained, of a Letter published in the New York Tribune, purporting to be, from the Reporter a Letter writer, of that Paper, on the Floor of the House The Clerk read Letter, which was, extremely abusive, and scurrilous, upon Sawyer and one or two other members— Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved, that the Reporters and Letter writers, for the New York Tribune (without naming them) be expelled from this House, and he moved the Previous Question— Washington Hunt of New York moved to lay the resolution on the Table.— Winthrop, raised a question of order, and denied the right of the House, to expel the Reporters— The Speaker overruled the point of order— Garrett Davis, moved to refer the subject to a select Committee— Hilliard moved to adjourn— Hunt withdrew his motion to lay on the Table, and the vote by yeas and nays to expel the Reporters and Letter writers for the New York Tribune, was carried 119. to 48. Robinson, is one of them, and was named as well as the other by Sawyer, but not in the Resolution itself— The House adjourned about four o’clock— Revd. Mr. M. Brown formerly President of the Jefferson College, at Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, was here this evening and left with me, a Letter, soliciting, a contribution, in behalf, of that Institution, which I visited, in November 1843. on my return from Cincinnati— Mr. Brown, has since resigned, the Office of President of that College, and was succeeded, by the Revd. Robertof Baltimore— I do not feel a call, to comply, with a request for a contribution, believing, that the College, ought to support itself, or be supported, by the people of Pennsylvania— My wife was ill, and confined all this day to her bed—

5— IV— VI—  I received this morning, a very mysterious confidential Letter, dated New York March the 3d. from William Rysom a total stranger to me, together with two duodecimo volumes published in London 1840. and entitled The Book of Family Crests—a work upon Heraldry—of which I know scarcely anything, and concerning which, I am unable to answer the questions of the writer. He seems to think that there is a deep plot involved in this publication, but knows as little as I do, what it is. He insinuates that it concerns, a legitimate descendant from Charles Edward once the Jacobite pretender— at the House, when I took my seat, the House was proceeding, in a call, occasioned by a motion, of David. S. Reid, to reconsider, the vote of yesterday deciding the contested election from New Jersey in favour of John Runk, the sitting member, by the casting vote, of the Speaker— Immediately after I took my seat a motion was made to suspend further proceedings on the Call for which I voted— Winthrop came to my seat and told me, that the motion to reconsider was a concerted measure, to reverse the decision, under the voluntary absence, of some Democratic members to secure, a reversal of the decision, without changing their votes—and thus turning Runk out of his seat. The majority of the House refused to suspend the call till a number equal to that, of the yesterday vote, was returned, whereupon Mr. Reid, withdrew his motion to reconsider, and Runk holds his Seat— Dromgole from the Committee Ways and Means, reported sundry articles of Amendment to the proposed sub-Treasury Bill—referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— McKay, Chairman of the same Committee reported the Annual Post Office appropriation Bill— Sundry Reports, on Private Claims, were received and Armistead Burt, of South Carolina reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, a Bill to found a Military Asylum, for the relief and support of Invalid Soldiers of the Army— Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina, reported from the Committee on Naval Affairs a call on the Secretary of the Navy, for retrenchments in that Department; which was adopted— The River and Harbor Bill, was resumed, and Tibbatts moved a resolution, for closing the Debate on that subject, which resolution was laid on the Table, by yeas and nays 88. to 33. Afterwards, the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on this Bill Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair. McKay, moved to postpone it and take up an Appropriation Bill but the Chairman stated that Hudson was entitled to the floor, and McKay’s motion was not considered— Hudson had been called to Order for discussing the Tariff, in the last Debate on this Bill— The Chairman had pronounced him, in order, and an Appeal had been taken from that decision— It was now confirmed by the Committee and Hudson finished his hour speech— John Pettit of Indiana, followed, in his speech of an hour, abusive enough, upon Hudson, but in support of the Bill. Frederick P. Stanton of Memphis, Tennessee, then took the floor, the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— We had evening visits from the Revd. Dr. John Codman of Dorchester, and from Mr. George Sykes, a member of the House from New Jersey, with three of his friends from that State— My wife continues ill, and unable to leave her bed—

6— VI.  To Miss.  At the House, the reading of the Journal of yesterday was dispensed with— James McDowell late Governor of Virginia, appeared and took his seat, as a Member of the House—from the eleventh Congressional district, of Virginia, elected, in the place of William Taylor, deceased.— James. C. Dobbin, of North Carolina, moved a resolution, to pay, out of the fund for pay and mileage for members, milage and pay, to Isaac. G. Farlee from the commencement of the Session, to the 4th. inst while he was contesting the Seat of John Runk— This motion, gave rise, to several rather whimsical incidents— It has been usual, in cases of contested elections by vote of the House, to allow pay and mileage, to the persons contesting, who fail, in establishing their right to the Seat—but these decisions, have often been influenced by Party feelings, as was the case now— Farlee, in the last Congress, had voted against making the allowance, to John. M. Botts, in his contest with John. W. Jones—and now, Robert Schenck, moved to amend the Resolution offered by Dobbin, so as to grant the same allowance, to Botts, for the contest in the last Congress— The Speaker, got rid of this amendment, by deciding, that it was out of order.— John. H. Ewing of Pennsylvania, then moved to amend the resolution, by making the money payable out of the Treasury, but this two was evaded by the Speaker— The Previous Question was moved and carried by yeas and nays, 105. to 46. to pay Farlee— But no allowance was made for Botts—although Schenck, moved to suspend the rules, to offer a resolution, in his favor; but this was refused by yeas and nays, 62. to 110. Tibbatts of Kentucky moved to suspend the rules, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the River and Harbour appropriation Bill, but the House refused— Isaac. E. Holmes, moved as a privilege question, that when the House adjourn it should be over to Monday— The yeas and nays and Tellers, were successively called for, and refused—and Holmes motion was carried by a large majority— The House then went into consideration of Private Bills not objected to— The Bill for the relief of Col. William Grayson. Henry. S. Clark, of North Carolina, withdrew, his objection against the passage of the Bill, but another member, objected, and it went over The House went into Committee of the whole—Julius— Rockwell—in the Chair, on Private Bills, four of which, were laid aside to be reported, without objection, and forty three, were called and objected to— Samuel Gordon moved that the Committee should rise, in which no quorum voted, the Committee rose, and reported that fact, to the House— Preston King moved to adjourn, which was carried— No visitors this evening—

7— V–30.  I received this morning a letter from my Son, enclosing his account for the quarter to the end of the last year. and also a Letter from William S. Russell, dated at Plymouth, the 4th. instt., with a copy of my Hymn, for the 22nd. of December— This copy, gives the date of 1806. but Mr. Russell, supposed, it to have been composed, in 1802. the year, in which I delivered the Anniversary Discourse, in commemoration of the landing of the Pilgrims— Mr. Russell says, he has a work in preparation to be called “Recollections of the Pilgrims, and sketches of Plymouth”—in which he wishes to insert this Hymn,—concerning which he makes some inquiries— He seems not to be aware, that it is published in Mr. Lunts Christian Psalter, which has been adopted, by the first Congregational Church and Society in Plymouth, no. 640— Mr. Kavasales was here, still under the frown of the Secretary of the Navy, with little prospect, of redress— Mr. James P. Espy, was also here, with a small model, of his ventilating instrument, and with, one of his publications, upon his theory of storms— He proposes, to claim some public compensation, from Congress, for his inventions and discoveries in meteoroligy and expects a report from the Committee on Naval Affairs for which he is desirous of engaging my support— He promised to call again, next Monday— Mr. George Sykes a Member of the House from New Jersey, called here with three other citizens of that state— I had a visit from my Colleague, Mr. Charles Hudson— I had received from Col. Joseph G. Totten Chief Engineer, a Letter enclosing one, to Thomas. C. Amory, of Roxbury, notifying him, of his conditional appointment, as a Cadet, at the Military Academy at West Point— I had also received, a Letter, from the Commissioner of Pensions, with a Pension Certificate, in favor of Susanna Lancy, for arrears, due to Betty Wheat, at the time of her decease, This certificate had already been sent, by me, to Elijah Clark, who had sent it back, with some inquiry whether the Pension, was not payable, to other persons, children of Betty Wheat, I referred it to the Commissioner who returned it to me again, with assurance, that it could be paid, only to Susanna Lancy.— I enclosed it again to Mr. Clark, and rode to the Capitol, where I deposited in the Post Office, my Letters to Mr. Amory and to Mr. Clark, and one to Mr. Clark, enclosing the certificate, and also one to Mr. Totten, acknowledging, the receipt, of his Letter to Mr. Amory— I walked home from the Capitol— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and we had short evening visits, from Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal—

8— VI.  I attended Public Worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where the Revd. Dr. John Codman, of Dorchester, performed the service, gave out the 100. Psalm— Before Jehovah’s awful Throne and preached from Isaiah 26.3. “Thou wilt keep him, in perfect peace whose mind is staid on thee, because he trusteth in Thee”— The Discourse was upon peace— When I heard him name his text, I had some suspicion, that it would bear a Political complexion— There are rumors of War prevailing about the Country, fomented, for political purposes, and in some parts of the Country, they have produced, a pious combination, of Ministers of the Gospel, to preach for peace, not in the spirit of the Gospel, but for purposes, altogether worldly— But Dr. Codman, had no such intention. his exhortations were to peace with God—peace of mind— He is Minister of a congregational Church at Dorchester, adjoining the Town of Quincy. Of the Calvanistic creed, and partly educated at Edinburgh in Scotland— He is a man of most estimable private character, and of good understanding not however remarkably eloquent, or eminent as a Preacher— I heard him again in the afternoon at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, where the Rev. Matthew. Hale. Smith, is now the Pastor, and was with him in the Pulpit, performing the services jointly with him— His text was, Romans 15.4—“For whatsoever things were written aforetime, were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope”— The emphatic word of this text was hope, derived from the Scriptures—the exposition of which formed the subject of the Discourse. Miss Cutts was here this evening.— The snow has nearly disappeared, and the Spring is setting in— I have read the Poem in blank verse, upon the Immortality of the Soul, and upon the worth of the Soul— It is accompanied with notes, more voluminous than the verse— Part of which I have read.

9. V–30.  To Conscience— A Sonnet—  Mr. Cooley, and Mr. Shepherd from Baltimore, came to invite me to deliver a Lecture before a Military Company of Volunteers in that City, called the Baltimore Blues— Mr. Cooley said of fifty years standing, the most ancient Military Company there— I declined upon the ground of inability, to perform the service— Professor James. P. Espy, called on me again, and presented to me a copy, of his Book on the Philosophy of Storms, a large Octavo volume with a separate Pamphlet in folio being a first report on meteoroligy, adressed to the Surgeon General of the United States Army with numerous Charts, exhibiting the direction of the winds, in the Sorms of the year 1843— Mr. Espy left with me also a Letter soliciting my aid, in support of an application which he has before Congress, for compensation, to him, for his invention of conical ventilators made for Ships, of one of which, he brought with him, a small tin model, and explained to me, its operation. He claims, a sum of $50000. for this invention—and has a Letter, of 9. January 1844 from A. P. Upshur shortly before that time Secretary of the Navy and at that time Secretary of State, expressing the opinion, in unison with that of Capt Beverly Kennon, that the right to use it, in our Navy, would be cheaply purchased at that price. He has also similar certificates, from Mr. John. Y. Mason, some time Secretary of the Navy, and from Captains William Ramsay, and Charles Wilkes, Lieut Henry Eld, and Dr. Thomas Harris, of the Navy. At the House, this was one of the days for the reception of Petitions, but none were presented—and since the rule, for receiving petitions, at the Clerks table, and having them committed to appropriate Committees, the practise of presenting them publicly, is going into disuse— Several resolutions, from the Legislatures of the States, relating entirely to local concerns, were however, presented and refered George C. Dromgoole from a Select Committee, reported a Bill, to purchase, from Mrs. Madison for $25.000—the unpublished manuscript papers, of her deceased Husband, in her possession— R. P. Herrick of New-York, presented a Memorial from the national reform association, of the United States relating to the Sales of public Land— It was refered to the Committee on public Lands, but the House refused, to order it to be printed— James. I. McKay, of North Carolina, moved a resolution, to close the debate, in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, on the River and Harbour Appropriation Bill, at 1/2 past two, next Wednesday, but the resolution, was laid on the table, by yeas and nays 96. to 77— The House then went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Thomas Smith of Indiana, in the Chair— And took up that Bill Andrew Johnson of Tenn moved an Amendment, and Thomasson of Kentucky made a speech— Felix. G. McConnell upon pretence of a privilege question, introduced a Bill, of which he had given notice, to grant to the head of a family, man, maid or widow, a homestead, not exceeding 160. Acres of public Land— Samuel Gordon of New York State, moved to lay it on the table, but McConell obtained its reference to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Charles J. Ingersoll moved a resolution, that the House would adjourn tomorrow at three oclock, to attend the funeral of Gen John. P. Van-Ness, who died last Saturday evening, having been formerly a Member of this House, from the State of New-York and recently, Mayor of the City of Washington— The House adjourned without taking the question in this motion— We had an evening visit from Mr. George Sykes, a member of the House of Representatives from New Jersey with two of his friends, from that State—

10— V.30—  To. Lieutenant George Thom.Corps. of Topographical Engineers of the United States—  In the House, a motion made yesterday, that the House should adjourn this day at three o’clock, to attend the funeral of Gen John P. Van Ness, was after a call for the yeas and nays laid on table, without taking them— John Wentworth of Illinois, moved to close the debate in Committee of the whole, on the River and Harbour Bill, at two o’clock P.M. next Tuesday, which after sundry motions to substitute next Friday, and to lay the resolution on the Table, was finally carried, by yeas and nays 106. to 66— Thomas. J. Henley of Indiana, moved that 35000. copies extra, of the report of the Commissioner of Patents, without the list of Patents, and 7,000. copies of the whole Report, be printed, 2000 copies of which, to be at the disposal, of the Commissioner— Objection being made to this resolution, Henley moved, and carried a suspension of the Rules, and it was received.— John Wentworth, moved to strike out 35000, and insert 100.000, but afterwards substituted 50.000. Andrew Stewart moved to lay the Resolution on the Table; which was lost— Henley said he was apprehensive that some gentlemen, were under the impression, that the Report contained matter relating to the Tariff, which, he was assured it did not, and he sent to the Clerk, a Letter from Edmund Burke the Commissioner, disclaiming all reference to Party politics— The previous Question was moved— Garrett Davis, moved a proviso to limit to three thousand dollars, the profit to the printer, and stated that, the profit on the printing, would be about $20.000. Wentworth’s motion, was rejected by yeas and nays— Garrett Davis, moved again to lay the resolution on the Table, which was again rejected, and it was carried by yeas and nays 127. to 55. The river and Harbour Bill was resumed, in Committee of the Whole, on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair.— James. J. Faran of Ohio, and Samuel Gordon of New York, made speeches in favor of the Bill— Meredith. P. Gentry, took the floor, but the Committee rose.— The Speaker presented several communications, from the executive Departments— William. L. Yancey of Alabama, moved to go into Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, again, to take up the River and Harbour Bill, but there was no quorum on the vote— Henley moved that when the House should adjourn to meet tomorrow at eleven o’clock which was carried— Three successive motions were then made to adjourn— All rejected by yeas and nays, without a quorum, but the fourth trial succeeded 58. to 54. and the House adjourned till 11. o’clock tomorrow— I went into the Senate Chamber, while the dull debate on the Harbour Bill was sleeping in the House, and heard the close of a Speech, by George Evans of Maine, against our title to Oregon, beyond Latitude 49. North, faintly asserting it South of that Line—ardent in its efforts, to refute the arguments, of the New York Senators, in favor of the title, to 54.40. and closing by saying that he did not know whether to vote for giving the notice to terminate the Convention of 1827. or against it— No visitors this evening—

12. V—  Much of my time is consumed, in preparations for distributing, the Congressional Documents, of which an extra number are printed for distribution among the people— I have heretofore always, made out, at the commencement of every Session, a list of the names of the persons to whom I send them consisting, of my Son, of the Editors of the Newspapers printed in my Congressional District, with one or two at Boston the Councillors, and Members of the Legislature of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, from the Counties, and Towns, composing the District, being twenty two Towns, the whole County of Norfolk, four Towns in Plymouth County, and five in Middlesex— At this Session however, I have long delayed to make out this list— This I have however, now completed, but have an accumulation of Documents, to transmit. I have added to my list, a number of names— The usual number of Documents, furnished to each Member of the House is from twenty five to forty, but at this, and one or two preceding Sessions the number ordered to be printed of certain favorite Documents allow to each Member upwards of 100. I have therefore been obliged to make a double list for the small and the greater number— At the House, W. W. Campbell of New York, one of the four from the City, moved the appointment of a Select Committee, to report if any alterations should be made in the Consular system of the United States, with leave to report by Bill—otherwise— A Committee of five was appointed, consisting of W. W. Campbell, R. F. Simpson of South Carolina, Charles. J. Ingersoll, James. McDowell, the new Member from Virginia, and Robert. C. Winthrop— Mr. McDowell, who was the late Governor of Virginia, came and renewed acquaintance with me at my seat, he having heretofore visited me, about ten years ago. He is from Western Virginia, and a man of splendid talents. William. G. Brown, of Virginia, moved an instruction to the Committee on Pensions, to inquire into the expediency of making more ample provision, for the indigent soldiers, and Pensioners of the Revolution— George Ashman, of Massachusetts, moved an instruction to the Committee on the Judiciary to consider of measures, to enable claimants against the United States, to obtain justice, now denied them— The object is, to institute a Judicial Tribunal corresponding with the Court of Exchequer in England— A measure often attempted, and not likely to succeed— Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, asked leave to introduce a Bill, to authorize every poor man, in the U.S. who is the head of a family to enter one-hundred and sixty Acres, of the Public domain, without money and without price— A race for popularity, to outrun McConnell; but the leave, was not yet granted— Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, reported for the Committee of Foreign Affairs, a Bill, making Appropriations, for the payment, of two instalments, of the Mexican Indemnities, provided for by the Convention of January 30th. 1843. between Mexico and the United States— These are the instalments paid from the Mexican Treasury, to the Agent of the United States Voss, and for which, according to Mr. John Baldwins statement to me, the Agent Voss, and Waddy Thompson are jointly or se. . .ly yet to account to the Treasury of the United States— After sundry other affairs, of minor interest, the River and Harbour Bill, was again taken up, in Committee, of the whole on the state of the Union— Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair— Albert Constable of Maryland, made an hour speech, in favor of the Bill generally, under an Appropriation for Havre De Grace, in particular— John. F. Collin of the 11th. Congressional District of New York, John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut, Washington Hunt, of New York, Robert. C. Winthrop, made speeches, all in favor of the Bill— Winthrop’s speech, was in his highest style of eloquence. The Committee rose, Jacob Thompson of Mississippi presented a Memorial, from the Legislature of that State, asking a grant of Land for the use of schools.— Refered to the Committee on Public Lands— The House adjourned, till 11. o’clock to-morrow morning— Evening visit from Lieut. George Thom, to whom, Mary Louisa gave the lines I had written for him—

I received some days ago, a pacquet of Newspapers, called the Polynesian, published weekly, at Hono Looloo. Chn? Hawayian Islands, heretofore called Sandwich Islands— Of which paper J. J. Jarves, is the Editor and this morning a second parcel, the two containing a file of the paper, from the commencement of the year 1845. to the 7. June, of the same year— This is the Island upon which Cook, lost his life, by the hand of a Savage Cannibal— Its present civilization, is one of the wonders, of the age.— A man by the name of Noah Wilson, came this morning, with a proposal, to take a Lease of the vacant Lot in the rear of my house fronting upon G. Street— I am to have it measured, and give him an answer hereafter— At the House, I found Samuel Gordon, of New York complaining, in a personal explanation of having been misrepresented in the New York Herald, but I did not ascertain upon what R.
