W. Roberts and Jefferson Davis, both of Mississippi, presented Memorials, from the Legislature of that state, craving grants of Public Lands for one purpose, and another.— Robert C. Schenck, of Ohio presented a Petition fromCounty Indiana, for an appropriation, for the improvement of the Maumee river— Hugh. A. Haralson, of Georgia, Chairman of the Military Committee gave notice, that he would move next Wednesday to go into Committee of the whole on the Bill reported by that Committee for the public defenses, and that he would call the yeas and nays, on that motion, until the Bill should be taken up, and acted upon— John. R. J. Daniel moved to go into Committee of the whole, on private Bills, which the House refused, but went into Committee on the state of the Union, on the River and Harbour Bill— Archibald Yell of Arkansas, gave notice of his intention to move, a proviso, to be added, to the item for removing the raft in the Red river— James. Thompson of Pennsylvania, Bradford R. Wood of New-York, and Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio, made Speeches in support of the Bill— That of Vinton embracing an Argument for the constitutionality of internal improvement appropriations— Stephen Adams of Mississippi opposed the Bill, and Luther Severance, of Maine supported it— Stephen Douglass of Illinois ostensibly did the same, but his Speech was a firely hot blast for Oregon and 54.40. Howell Cobb of Georgia, E. H. Ewing of Tennessee, and Seaborn Jones of Georgia offered amendments, to Bill the Bill— Joseph R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of $3000 for a Survey and investigation of the river Delaware, to construct See Harbours. It was five o’clock when the House adjourned to 11. o’clock tomorrow morning— Evening visit from Capt. John. C. Casey of the Office of the

14. VI Commissary General of subsistance—  I received this morning two Letters, one, from Jonathan Amory, of Roxbury and one from Thomas Isaac Coffin his Son, acknowledging, the receipt of his conditional warrant of admission to the Military Academy at West point— In the first entry of his name at the Department of War, there had been an error— It was entered. Thomas C. Amory his real name is Thomas. Isaac Coffin Amory This error is to be rectified at the Office of the Chief Engineer At the House, a Bill was passed, regulating the value, of certain European coins. Charles. J. Ingersoll, from the Committee of Foreign Affairs, reported a Bill, to provide for the enforcement of certain provisions, in the Treaty with Prussia and some others. He reported also, the correspondence with the Spanish Minister, concerning discriminatory tonnage duties, referring to a Bill, reported on the 16th. last January and made the special order, for the 21st. of next April— A preemption Bill reported by Thomas Smith of Indiana, from the Committee on the Public Lands, was referred to the Committee of the whole, after some struggle by Smith—and Charles W. Cathgart from the same state to drive it through, without examination— Sundry private Bills were reported, and Robert Smith of Illinois, from the Committee on Roads and Canals reported a resolution, to make, the Bill appropriating $400.000 for the continuation of the Cumberland road, in the states of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois the special order for the 23. instt. but failed to carry the resolution, by a vote of 69 to 52. not two thirds. The river and Harbour Bill, was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith in the Chair, and was debated by John. W. Houston the member from Delaware, Edward. D. Baker, of Illinois, James. A. Seddon of Virginia, each of whom offered an Amendment for additional appropriations, and by Thomas. H. Bayly of Virginia, and Andrew Stewart of Pennsylvania upon the Constitutionality of internal improvements after which the Committee rose, and the House, adjourned to Monday next at twelve o’clock— We read this evening in Littells Living Age, the lamentable tale of the Life of Laman Blanchard—by Sir Edward Bulwer Lytton—

15. VI.30.  This morning I finished reading the Book of Joshua; having read two Chapters a day from the first of December last— I attempted the composition of some lines, suited to the day, but without success— It is impossible to foresee at any time the hours of poetic inspiration— I attended at 11. o’clock the service of Public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where Mr. Milburn, the Chaplain of the House of Representatives, preached from Genesis, 49.10—“The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a law giver from between his feet, until Shiloah come, and unto him shall the gathering of the people be”— This text requires an exposition more comprensive than is embraced, by the learning or the capacity of Mr. Milburn— Very few preachers of the Gospel, are competent to it, though it appears to be a favourite topic, with many of them.— Historically speaking it requires much explanation; it is usually understood as refering to the advent of Jesus Christ— And why is he called Shiloah? And why is it said, that the Sceptre shall not depart from Judah, until he come? I walked to, and from the Capitol, and after dinner at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, heard Mr. Matthew Hale-Smith preach from Romans. 9.16. “So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God, that sheweth mercy.” This Chapter contains the principal argument of Saint Paul to establish the doctrines of election and pre-destination— Mr. Smith observed, that in the Epistle of Peter, it is said “That there are in the writings of the Apostle Paul, some things hard to be understood”—and that this remark is especially applicable to this passage, of the Epistle to the Romans.— It seems to import, that the mercy of God, is not obtainable by the will or the exertions of man, but that it is merely the result, of the arbitrary will of the Creator— The Apostle appears aware, that the doctrine is susceptible of great objection. In the preceding context, he says [“]It is written Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated,[”] and then he enquires [“]what shall we say then is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid, for he saith to Moses I will have mercy, on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion, on whom I will have compassion,” and in the subsequent context—he adds “thou wilt say then unto me, why doth he yet find fault, for who hath resisted his will[”] and to this he replies, Nay, but O man who art thou, that repliest against God, shall the thing formed, say to him that formed it, why hast thou made me thus? This may be called cutting the gordion Knot, but is no answer to the objection— The whole Chapter deserves deep meditation—

16. VI  I went this morning, to the Office of Col Totten the Chief Engineer, to have rectified, the name, of Thomas Isaac Coffin Amory, to whom, a warrant of Cadet, at the Military Academy at Westpoint, had been sent— I found it already done, and answered the Letters, of this young gentleman and of his Father— From the Engineer Office I proceeded to the Capitol, and found, the House of Representatives in Session.— The reading of the Journal of Saturday, had been dispensed with, and they were in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith in the Chair upon the river and Harbour appropriation Bill. Edward. H. Ewing of Nashville Tennessee, was arguing the Constitutional power, of Congress to establish and maintain a general system of internal improvement— He quoted from the Federalist, and pronounced a magnificent panegyric, upon the purity of character, of Alexander Hamilton, His hour closed, while he was discoursing, upon the necessity of Appropriations for the improvement of the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers— He was followed by Asa Biggs, with an argument against the Constitutionality of appropriations for internal improvement, and gave notice, that he should move an appropriation for re-opening Roanoke inlet, at or nearhead in North Carolina one hundred thousand dollars.— Thomas Perry of Maryland, moved an additional section to the Bill, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to transfer, to the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company all the stock of the United States in that Company, upon suitable conditions— Mr. Perry too has Constitutional scruples, about the power of Congress, to make internal improvements, and said he should discriminate in his votes, between the items, which in his opinion were, and those which were not within the pale of the Constitution. Richard. P. Herrick of New York, moved an appropriation $5000— for the improvement of the Navigation of the Hudson River, at what is called the over— John H. Ewing of Pennsylvania, made an hour speech, in favour of internal improvement, and in reprobation, of the annexation of Texas.— George Rathbun, of New York, spoke in favor of appropriation on the Harbours of the Lakes, and against the purchase of the Louisville and Portland Canal. John A. McClernand of Illinois, defended, the Democratic Party, against the charges of inconsistency and discordance, made by Ewing of Pennsylvania, and then referring to the Oregon Question noticed the coincidence between the Resolution offered by Robert C. Winthrop to refer the subject to Arbitration and the subsequent proposal from the British minister to the same effect— Mr. Winthrop very solemnly disclaimed any knowledge, of the intention of the British Government to make this proposal, when he offered his resolution Mr. McClernand, was strongly opposed to the appropriation proposed in the Bill of $75.000. for the Harbour of Saint Louis— The substituted member from Florida, Brockenbrough, made an hour speech against the Constitutionality of appropriations for internal improvements, and bitterly complained, that Florida, which has cost the Union more than fifty millions of dollars, had not had her share, of the Public monies— Jefferson Davis, of Mississippi piped out his hour, to the same tune, complaining that all the money of the people, was raised at the South, and expended at the East, the direct reverse of which, is much nearer the truth— It was now past five o’clock— Joseph A. Woodward of South Carolina, took the floor, motion was made for the Committee to rise; no Quorum The Committee rose and reported the fact, motions to adjourn and for a call of the House, were alternately made, and rejected, till past seven o’clock, when a motion for a call was carried— I saw there were hours of idleness, and no business for the night, in prospect, answered at the call of my name, and immediately left the House and came home— The call was continued, till half past nine o’clock, when a number of members, were brought to make their excuses in the House, which then adjourned, to ten oclock tomorrow morning— When I got home, I found my dear wife very ill, in bed— Dr. Thomas was sent for, came, and prescribed, with a promise that she would be better to-morrow— We had evening visits from Mr. Healey, Mr. Doubourjal and Mr. Carter Lee—

Saint Patricks day— I had received from W. E. Robinson, for himself, and Peter Brady, G. D. Dowlin, Edmund Stubbs, John Boyd and Thomas Donahue, an invitation to attend as a guest, at a public dinner this day, at Carusi’s Salon, in honor, of Ireland’s patron saint, which I declined in consideration, of my infirm health and recent domestic affliction— At the House, which met at 10. o’clock Tibbatts moved to dispense with the reading of the Journal, but Dromgoole objected, and it was read.— He then said, that there was a statement in the Journal: that all the Members who came into the Hall last evening, ending the call, were brought in, in custody of the Sergeant at Arms, which he believed was not the fact. The Clerk read the Journal, which stated, that the Sergeant at Arms, came into the Hall, with the following named members, giving their names.—Dromgoole said he wished to separate the names to distinguish those who came in, voluntarily and those, who were really brought in by the Sergeant at Arms—to save the House, from the payment of the fees, whereupon Atkinson, and several others, denied, having been brought in, by the Sergeant at Arms, and the Speaker said, the Journal would be corrected and so the petty-pride, of the delinquents, was spared the mortification of appearing upon the record, as prisoners to the Sergeant at Arms— Houston of Alabama, at the discipline of the call of the House, had not been completely carried through last night, several members, whose names went on the Journals, as absentees, in custody and on trial, had yet to be excused—he was for resuming the process, but the Speaker said that an adjournment put an end, to all unfinished proceedings in a call of the House— The river and Harbour Bill, was then resumed, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Thomas Smith in the Chair, Joseph. A. Woodward of South Carolina, made an hour speech, against the Constitutional power of Congress—to appropriate money for internal improvements, followed by James. B. Bowlin of Saint Louis Missouri, in a volunteer, and quite unneccessary defence of the West against the charge, of plundering the public Treasury, and retorting the charge, not against South Carolina, whence it came, but upon the East more odious to South Carolina, than the West itself— Tibbatts of Kentucky and McClernand, of Illinois, had some altercation, about appropriations for the benefit of the West— Cocke of Tennessee supported the Amendment moved by his Colleague Crozier, about the Muscle Shoals, and Daniel P. King of Massachusetts, moved three additional appropriations within that state— Joshua. F. Bell. of Kentucky offered an Amendment but had not time to make a speech, the hour of two, having arrived which had been previously fixed, for voting upon the proposed Amendments, and taking the Bill out of Committee from that time till about five o’clock a multitude of Amendments, were proposed and adopted or rejected in Committee, as the humor of the majority directed— When the Committee rose and the House adjourned— We had evening visits from General and Mrs. Jesup, and from an old acquaintance whom I had not for a long time seen Carter Lee—

18— V–30—  My wife continued ill, confined to her bed all day yesterday, but is this day convalescent though not yet able to leave her chamber— The Senate, have expelled from their Hall the reporters, of the newspaper published in this City called the daily Times—for certain charges against certain nameless Senators, of having corrupt dealings with the British Minister Pakenham, for a compromise of the Oregon Question— A few days since the House of Representatives, expelled from their reporters seats, the correspondents of the New York newspaper called the Tribune, for exposing to ridicule the manners, and not the character of William Sawyer a Member of the House from Ohio. This sickly sensibility, to the animadversions of the Press, manifested by arbitrary acts, of power, unchecked by Judicial controul, seems to be common, to all deliberative assemblies; and always terminates, to their disadvantage— This morning Mr. Sawyer, of Ohio made a personal explanation, with reference to a report of his speech yesterday, in the National Intelligencer of this day, and was followed by his Colleague Mr. Delano, also, with a personal explanation— John. P. Martin of Kentucky from the Committee on Mileage, reported a resolution to discharge the Committee of the whole, from the further consideration of the mileage Bill, which was adopted— James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, then moved an Amendment to the Bill, to retrench the pay, of every Member of the House, for every day of his absence from it, and even, for every absence failure to answer upon any call of the House, or of the yeas and nays— Thomas Perry, of Maryland, moved to lay the Amendment on the Table; which the House refused— Archibald Yell of Arkansas, moved to amend Bowlin’s Amendment, by reducing the pay, of members, to six dollars, a day, and for every twenty miles travel— Also an additional section, to remove the seat of Government of the United States, from the year 1850. to a place near Saint Louis, in the State of Missouri— Bowlin accepted this, as a part of his Amendment, and George W. Jones of Tennessee, moved to substitute instead of Saint Louis, Jeffersonville in the State of Indiana, on the avowed ground, that if the seat of Government, was to be removed, it should be into a free State; whereupon George. C. Dromgoole of Virginia, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the river and Harbour Bill—which was done.— The voting upon the amendments was resumed— A multitude of Amendments were proposed. Some of them, in derision, and for very unwarrantable sport Among them, one by George Fries, of Ohio, grossly and personally insulting, to his Colleague Schenck, which occasioned an altercation, and a retort from Schenck, upon which a full hour of the House was wasted, and the time disgracefully lost— The yeas and nays were taken upon numerous Amendments, the first, upon a provision, of five thousand dollars, for removing the obstructions—from the Harbour, at Providence Rhode Island; upon which Lynn Boyd of Kentucky, called for the yeas and nays, and it was carried, 99. to 96. The appropriation of $15.000, for removing the obstructions of Newark Bay New Jersey, was also carried, by yeas and nays 98. to 89— Crozier of Tennessee, had moved, an item of $100.000., for the Muscle Shoals, which was lost by yeas and nays, 65. to 125. and thereupon, Crozier, who had voted for the appropriation of $5000. for Providence Harbour, moved a reconsideration of that vote, which was lost by yeas and nays 95. 102. This is a specimen, of the slave monger system, of internal improvements— 1/2 past 3. o’clock the House adjourned— Evening visit from Mr. Abel Shawk. who requested me, to call and have my portrait taken by Daguerreotype Machine, at Plumb’s Gallery—in the Pennsylvania Avenue, at 11. o’clock to-morrow morning—to which I assented—

19. V—  I received this morning a Letter from Mr. Sleeper with two voluminous manuscripts of the correspondence, of George. W. Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio De Janeiro, with the Secretary of State Buchanan, concerning the Slave Trade— On my way to the Capitol this morning I stopped at Plumb Gallery where several Daguerreotype likenesses were taken of me by the improved Machine, of Mr. Abel Shawk, and I promised to call again tomorrow morning for some others to be taken, one of which for myself At the House the voting by yeas and nays upon many items, of the river and Harbour appropriation Bill, was resumed— Under the new rule, of taking a separate vote, on the engrossment of a Bill, for every item of appropriation, if required, by one fifth of the Members present. Lynn Boyd, called for yeas and nays on an item of five thousand dollars, for the improvement of S.Bay on Lake Ontario. Carried 103. to 83— Again on an item of $7000. of the improvement of Oak Orchard Harbour, state of New York. Carried 94. to 87— Again $40000. for the improvement of St Clair flats, on Lake Michigan— Carried, 117. to 70— $40.000, for improving of Michigan City; carried 99. to 81— For the improvement of Little Fort Harbour, on Lake Michigan $12.000— For improving the Harbour at Saint Louis Missouri, $75.000— For removing obstructions in Newark Bay New-Jersey $15.000. For improving the Harbour at Havre de Grace Maryland, $20000.— All of which were carried. when Seaborn Jones of Georgia, under a surfeit of yeas and nays, and of internal improvements, rose and said, that Mr. Colquit one of the Senators from Georgia had lost a child, the funeral of which to take place, this afternoon, the Delegation from Georgia, wished to attend, and he therefore moved the House to adjourn, which was carried, without opposition— This evening, with Mrs. John Adams, Walter Hellen, and Mary Louisa, I attended a Concert, at Carusi’s Saloon, given by Leopold De Meyer, the performer of wonders, upon the grand Piano—assisted by an indifferent Singer named Wood— The House was crowded, and the performance, said to be, quite extraordinary— De Meyer, has the reputation, of being one of the finest performers, of the age. He was at his own request, introduced to me, after the performance was over, and I thanked him very sincerely, for the entertainment of the evening—

20— VI.  My morning’s meditation before the dawn of day— On my way to the Capitol, I called again at Plumb’s Gallery, and he took four Daguerreotype Likenesses of me, one of which, he afterwards sent me, as a present— At the House, the River and Harbour Bill, was at last disposed of, before which the Speaker presented to the House, a Letter from the Secretary of War the report of Capt. J. Allen, of the first Regiment of Dragoons of his expedition last Summer to the heads of the Des Moins Blue Earth, and other rivers, in the north west, called for, by a resolution of the House; referred to the Committee on Military Affairs— The first Question taken by yeas and nays, on the River and Harbour Bill, was upon an item of $25.000 for improving Hog Island Channel at Charleston City—South Carolina— The call for the yeas and nays was by W. W. Woodworth, of the 8. Congressional District of New York merely for retaliation upon the members from South Carolina, for voting against, all the other appropriations; The vote was 82 to 86, and the appropriation, was lost by the votes of the South Carolina Members themselves, James. A. Black, Richard. F Simpson, Joseph. A Woodward, Alexander D. Simms, Armistead Burte and Robert. Barnwell. Rhett, all voting against it Six out of seven— Isaac. E. Holmes, of Charleston, did not vote— If the South Carolina Members had voted for the appropriation, it would have been carried 88. to 80, without Holmes vote— The chalice, was thus effectually returned, to their own lips— The next item $50.000. for the improvement of Savannah Harbour, and the naval anchorage, near Fortwas carried 166. to 77—and then an item of $4.450 for the improvement of Great Wood hole Harbour Massachusetts by a vote of 100. to 89— The purchase, of the stock of the Louisville and Portland Canal, was rejected 56 to 131— The item, for continuing the improvement of the Hudson River, above and below Albany $75.000, was carried, 102. to 79— and for the improvement of the Ohio river, above the Falls at Louisville $80.000. by 112 to 72—and below the Falls of Louisville and of the Mississippi, Missouri, and Arkansas rivers $240.000. by 118. to 67.— Hilliard of Alabama moved to reconsider the vote rejecting the item of $25.000, for the Channel at Charleston, but it was refused, 73. to 100— The Question upon the engrossment of the Bill was then taken, carried and the Bill was passed, after a motion by George. S. Houston of Alabama, to lay it on the Table; rejected; 86. to 109, and the passage of the Bill was carried 110. to 91.— The title of the Bill, was, “An Act making Appropriations for the improvement of certain Harbours and Rivers”— W. W. Paine of Alabama, moved to Amend the title, to read “An Act making appropriations, for works of internal improvement, within the States[”]— Rhett called for the yeas and nays on this notable amendment, which was rejected 81. to 117. The title was then suffered to pass without call for yeas and nays— Tibbatts moved a re-consideration of the vote, by which the Bill was passed, which the House refused, and the House adjourned, over to next Monday. A singular visitor by the name of Reese Price from Cincinnati.— was here this evening— A self constituted Prophet of spurious inspiration, who foretold a general revolution of Governments, throughout the World, Mr. John Connell, Major James. D. Graham, and Isaac Hull Adams, spent also, part of the evening here—

21. VI—  Mr. Kavasales called upon me this morning, and produced a Letter from Com. Reed, to Charles. J. Ingersoll, who had written to Capt Reed, recommending him, to him to take Mr. Kavasales with him as Chaplain, he being about to embark, as Commander of the Squadron, on the coast of Africa, and in the Mediterranean— Capt Reed answers, that he would with pleasure take Mr. Kavasales, as his Chaplain, but that the Commanders are not allowed, to name all the Officers, who go out with them, and he thinks the application to the Secretary of the Navy, in behalf of Mr. Kavasales would be more effective, coming from an other quarter— I took this Letter with me, to the Navy Department, but the Secretary Bancroft, was in Cabinet Council at the Presidents, and I could not see him— I mentioned to the Chief Clerk, the Letter from Commodore Reed, to Charles. J. Ingersoll, and earnestly recommended, that Mr. Kavasales, who is now upon furlow should be ordered to accompany Capt Reed, which the Clerk assured me, he would report to the Secretary. I then took, to the Commissioner of Pensions a Letter from Elijah Clark of Brighton, making inquiries concerning the Pension Claim, of Ann Weston, and one from Wm. K. Hoyt, of New-York concerning the Claims of Ann Pearsee, Elizabeth Lutz, Maria Blouvelt, widow of Lieut. P. Powles and Mary Winship— Mr. Edwards, told me that he had answered, in relation to these cases, several weeks ago— I found that one of them, was an application to Congress— I went out to Mr. Stone’s House, on the College Hill, where I found, that he had not yet commenced, upon the Bust which he proposes to take of me— But I saw that of Miss Maria Bache, and a very fine marble Bust of Stone himself, by Powers, and sent by him from Florence— I walked home, and was joined on my way by a student at the College, by the name of Tilson, from Vermont— The present President of the College, is Mr. Bacon— In the evening, Mr. Hellen, and Mary Louisa, went to Leopold De Meyer’s second Concert— My wife is still confined to her chamber— No visitors—

22. IV— V.30.  At the House, on Friday last, my Colleague Mr. George Ashman, whose seat is immediately before mine, told me that this was his daughters birth-day— He had written her a Letter of congratulation, and was very desirous, of enclosing with it, an autograph of mine—whereupon I immediately wrote, and gave him, the lines of which the following are a copy—  To Miss Lucy Hooker Ashman—  daughter of Hon George Ashman, of SpringfieldMassachusetts, on her birth day 20. March 1846.aged 14—  I wrote also two others, copies of verses, which I will not here repeat, one, for Miss Camp of Owego, and the other for Miss Cornelia B. Joy of Ovid, both in the state of New York, for autographs— Ovid, seems to be a place, well suited for poetic inspiration— This day I attended Public worship, at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where Mr. Tustan, the Chaplain of the Senate, officiated, and the preacher was a stranger and from his accent I infer an Irishman, His text, was from 1. Corinthians, 10.3. “And did all eat, the same spiritual meat. 4. And did all drink, the same spiritual drink, (for they drank, of that spiritual rock, that followed them, and that rock was Christ)”— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and Walter Hellen dined out at his mother’s— After dinner, at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, Mr. Matthew. Hale Smith preached, from Ecclesiastes. 7–10. “Say not thou, what is the cause, that the former days, were better than these, for thou dost not enquire, wisely, concerning this”— Mr. Smith said, that this text, was applicable, to the present time, for the best of all reasons, that the former days were not better than these—

23— III. VI.  Happiness— A Sonnet—  I awaked between two and four in the morning, and unable to sleep again, racked my brain for verses, till the dawn of day permits me, to rise— This is one of the physical developements, which returns upon me, frequently, in the Spring of the year; continues some times for weeks together until a close approach to distraction breaks it off— The above search for happiness, is one of its symptoms; which wasted the hours of this morning— At the House, this was the day for the presentment of Petitions, and the Speaker called, on the state of Rhode Island and then on Massachusetts I had a Memorial, from the Massachusetts Historical Society, which I desired to present. And before I could do so, Hugh Haralson of Georgia—Chairman of the Military Committee, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and to take up the Bill to raise two Regiments of Riflemen reported by him, very early in the Session— I stated to the Speaker, my wish to present the Memorial, from the Massachusetts Historical Society, and reminded him that he had called the state of Massachusetts for petitions, but he would not hear me, and said he had called the State of Massachusetts, by mistake— The House went into Committee, and took up the Bill, to raise two Regiments of Riflemen, and for other purposes John. I. McKay of North Carolina, in the Chair— Thomas Smith of Indiana, moved to Amend the Bill, from reducing it from two Regiments to one. The Bill was debated, by William Sawyer of Ohio—Jacob Brinkerhoff of the same State, Felix. G. McConnell of Alabama, Lynn Boyd of Kentucky, Hannibal Hamlin, of Maine, James. A. Black of South Carolina, Haralson of Georgia, Archibald Yell of Arkansas Edward D. Baker of Illinois—John. S. Chipman of Michigan—E. W. McGaughey of Indiana, until Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina, took the floor moved an Amendment, and then, the Committee to rise— A Message was received, from the President, which was received with ears all erect, expecting, some new Oregon Negotiation, and an instant demand that it should be read, terminating in a general laugh, when found only to be a correspondence, concerning the payment of certain Duties Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means— Haralson, offered a resolution to close all debate, on the Bill to raise two Regiments of Riflemen— But a motion was immediately made, amid shouts of no, no, no, from all parts of the House, to adjourn, which was carried without opposition. Evening visit from Mr. Hogan— A young man, the son of an old acquaintance, but whom I had not before known—

24— IV— V.30—  I have received from Albert Gallatin, the first volume of the transactions, of the American Ethnological Society—Of which he is President, located at New York, and the objects of which, are declared to comprise inquiries, into the origin, progress, and characteristics, of the various races of Man.— I have also received, from Mr. John Jay, Domestic Corresponding Secretary of the New York Historical Society, a volume, containing, the pro-ceedings of that Society, for the year 1845—and have only to lament, that I have neither time or capacity, to give a proper attention to their contents. Before repairing to the House, this morning, I went to the Pension Office, with a Letter from Alonzo Taft, which I left with Mr. Edwards, containing inquires concerning certain Papers, which Mr. Taft says, he put into my hands, in September 1842— Mr. Edwards promised to inquire and report to me, whether those papers were at the Pension Office, or not— My own recollection of them, is quite indistinct— I then proceeded to the Capitol, where at the House, the reading of the Journal was dispensed with. The resolution offered by Hugh. A Haralson, last evening, at the adjournment, to close the debate, for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen, and for other purposes, at three o’clock this day; and after an ineffectual motion of R. W. Roberts, to lay it on the table, was adopted without a division— Haralson immediately moved to go into Committee which was carried. Felix. G. McConnell moved to lay the Bill aside, and take up another, but the Chairman McKay, declared this not in order— A debate ensued, and continued, until 3. o’clock, when the voting commenced, upon the Amendments proposed to the Bill; one of which was rejected and another adopted— While the process was going on of taking these votes by Tellers, Robert. C. Winthrop came to my seat, and told me, he should vote for this Bill.— I said I regretted again to part from him, for that I had come to the determination to vote against it— The Senate not having acted upon the Bill for giving Notice to the British Government of the termination of the Convention of 1827, and the balance, of probability now being, that the Senate would not pass it at all. He said that a message had been received in the Senate, from the President in answer to a Resolution of that body, offered some days since, by Mr. Dayton, in which the President, declares explicitely, that in his judgment the present position of the Country does require, an addition to its armed force— Hereupon I rose and moved that the Committee should rise, to enable me, to move in the House, a reconsideration of the vote, by which it had been determined, to take the Bill out of Committee, at 3. o’clock this day— An immediate, and violent opposition, was made to my motion, with loud calls to order— I asked leave to state my reason, for the motion I had made; but the objections and calls to order, continued and increased, during which, I made out, to give my reason, which was, that a message had been received in the Senate from the President, which in all probability would decide my vote and perhaps that of the House, upon the Bill— The struggle, against granting me the leave, to assign my reasons was so vociferous, and peremptory that the Chairman McKay, without taking the Question upon it, said, that he had been mistaken, in supposing that the Committee had assented to give me the leave, and ordered me to take my seat—which I did— Tellers were then called upon my motion for the Committee to rise, and 82 Members, were reported by the Tellers, in the affirmative— This was a majority of the voters present, and the Committee rose— The Chairman, said, that the Resolution in the House, did not require that the Question upon the Bill should be taken this day, that it might be still debated in the House. I replied, that it came to the same thing that if the Bill should be reported, the previous Question would be called and the Question upon the Bill immediately taken. The Committee having risen, I made my motion for reconsideration of the vote, for taking the Bill out of Committee this day— Thomasson of Kentucky and Albert Smith of New York, immediately moved to adjourn— George W. Jones of Tenn. enquired of the Speaker if I had voted for the Resolution, which I now moved to reconsider? The Speaker said that this Question would be in order, when the motion to reconsider, should come up I had voted against the Resolution, and according to the Rules of the House, was not competent, to make the motion to reconsider, but my object was attained by the rising of the Committee and the adjournment of the House, which immediately followed— We shall know the purport of the President’s message to the Senate, before taking the final vote on the Bill In the evening a Mr. Leffenwell and another person from New Jersey, made us visits, merely of curiosity

25— V.30.  Morning visit from Mr. Robert Owen, who told me, that he should leave the City to-morrow, about to embark for England, where he proposed, to use his best exertions for procuring the amicable adjustment, of the differences, existing between the Government of that Country, and the United States, and he enquired if I had read an article signed by him, in the National Intelligencer of this morning— I had seen his signature but passed over the article taking it for the repetition of one published some days since— He told me the substance of it, which was, that a final settlement should be made, with the least loss of time, on the base of the 49. degree of Latitude to the Pacific with Van Couver’s Island to the British, and the free navigation of the Columbia River for ten years— He hoped that I would concur with him in this opinion— I told him, that I wished him all possible success in his exertions to preserve the peace between the two Countries, which I believed, to be in no sort of danger, but that as to the terms of settlement, the whole range of my ideas both as to right and expediency, were directly the reverse of his— That I believed our right, to Latitude 54–40 on the South Sea, was perfect, with the single exception of actual possession; that Great Britain had no right there, of permanent possession, at all; that with regard, to War and Peace, considered in the abstract, I agreed with him, and with all benevolent and humane, throughout the World, I held it in utter abhorence—as much so, as the Roman mother’s in the days of Horace and of Augustus Caesar.— But that there are and always have been, as long as the race of men has existed, times and occasions, of dire necessity for War—and philosophically speaking, I believed that War, was not a corrupter, but rather a purifier, of the moral character of Man.— That peace was the period of corruption to the human race, and I asked him, if he recollected the passage, of the Paradise Lost, in which the Ark Angel Michael, after the fall of Adam, foretells to him, the fortunes of his posterity, in War and Peace, after describing to him all the horrors of War, draws before him a picture of his condition in Peace, and such it is, that Adam in contemplating it says—  Mr. Owen, did not recollect the passage in Milton; probably never having read it. but he expatiated upon his anticipations of the universal revolution, started by him, and now in progress, and which will soon, transform and exalt the nature of Man, to be gouverned, by the laws of God, and not by circumstances, and the Laws of Man— He thought that his purposes and mine were the same, the ultimate improvement, and exaltation of the nature of Man and his condition, upon earth, but the means by which we believe this revolution is to be effected are widely different. Mr. Owens visit, delayed my departure for the Capitol, so that when I reached the House, I found them in session, having laid on the Table, my motion to reconsider, the vote for taking the Bill out of Committee yesterday, no longer necessary and they were already in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, taking the Questions on the several Amendments to the Bill for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen— A substitute for the Bill itself, had already been adopted, by authorizing the President, at his discretion, to increase the number of Privates in each Company, of the existing Regiments, of Dragoons, Artillery, and Infantry to any number not exceeding 80. The enlistment to be, for three years, unless sooner disbanded, by the President— The Bill was thus reported to the House.— Joseph McDowell of Ohio, moved to lay it on the Table, which was rejected by yeas and nays 32 to 149.—and then the Bill was passed, by yeas and nays 164 to 15. Bowlin of Ohio moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the Bill to raise a Regiment of mounted Riflemen and for establishing Military Posts on the route to Oregon.— The House accordingly went into Committee Preston King in the Chair—but instead of Bowlin’s Bill took up at motion of McKay, the Bill to supply deficiencies, and appropriations, for certain objects made for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30. 1846. Upon which a debate arose, and sharp altercation between W. W. Paine of Alabama, and R. C. Winthrop about the Hartford Convention, blue-lights and the party warfare of 1812. till at 4. o’clock the Committee rose, McKay moved a resolution to close debate on this Bill, at 3. p.m. tomorrow, and the House adjourned— No evening visitors, but we read, Benetts New-York Herald, and Shakespeare at Paris from Littells Living Age—

26. V.30—  Long morning visit, from E. Rees. Price Esqr. of Cincinnati, and conversation with him, concerning his imaginary revellations and inspirations— He believes that a universal revolution, in the Gouvernments of this World, is at this moment in progress.— though as yet, imperceptible, to all but himself— That it commenced, on the equinoxial day, of this month; that all the present Governments, of the earth, are to be overthrown, that of the United States, first, that of Great Britain next, and the rest, in regular succession— In their place, is to arise, a new order of Governments at the head of which, he supposes himself, destined, by revellation to preside, and in which there will be no Department of War, as War is to cease upon earth— He explained to me, in considerable detail, the particulars, of this revolution, and said, he had been subject, of occasional revellations, from the year 1827. having never before, that time, had any religious impressions, of any kind— He illustrated, his imaginary revellations, by numerous references, to Scripture Prophecies, from those of Jacob, in the Book of Genesis, to those of John the Evangelist in the Isle of Patmos; like whom he said, he had been in the Spirit from the Lords Day— He quoted passages from the Books of Isaiah, of Daniel, of Zechariah, of Malacchi, and of the Apoch-lips always naming the Chapter and verse and repeating the prophecies, in the words of the scriptures— His discourse was consistent, in all its details rational and apparently sincere— He said he was alone in the world, that he had no credit in his own Country, not even in his own family, that his wife and children with whom he lived in perfect harmony did not believe him; that of his neighbours, some thought him an imposter, and some a monomaniac, not dishonest in his intentions, reasonable, upon all subjects but one, and on that perfectly insane— All this he knew, but he nevertheless, did believe himself not at all times, but on particular occasions, gifted with inspiration from above. That although no one believed him now, he had no doubt, the time would come, and that not distant, when the truth of what he said, would be universally know and understood— I told him, that I did not believe him an Imposter and would not call him a monomaniac, but, I believed him labouring under a mental delusion, but, that he had sufficient capacity of reason left, not to take offense, at my candid avowal, of this opinion. He said that far from taking offense, he thanked me for it, and for the kindness with which I had listened to him—and then took his leave— I then went to the House, where I found the Clerk, reading the Journal of yesterday— The Speaker laid before the House a report from the Secretary of War, with a survey of Green Bay, a statistical report from the Treasury Department, and the Naval Register for the year 1846— The resolution offered by McKay for closing debate on the Bill of deficient appropriations at 3. oclock this afternoon, was carried, after an ineffectual attempt to lay it on the table, and another, to postpone its action, till tomorrow— The House immediately took it up, in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Preston King, in the Chair— Then came a long and desultory debate, upon various items in the Bill— Abraham R. McIlvaine of Pennsylvania, objected, to an item of transporting troops into Texas, answered by Douglass of Illinois, much annoyed, at the introduction of Anti Slavery into this, or as he said, all other debates, in this House, Brockenbrough, moved an additional item for the benefit of Florida. Garrett Davis, complained, of the precipitation with which this Bill, was to be hurried through the House, and, that there had been confidential communications, from the Secretary of War, to the Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, which he, declined communicating to the House— Which was expressly admitted by Haralson— Davis pungently replied by pointing out the base subserviency to the Executive, of the Chairman of the Military Committee, in holding secret communications, with the Secretary of War, and refusing to disclose them to the House. And he then turned to Isaac E. Holmes Chairman of the Naval Committee and enquired, if he too had received any communications from the Secretary of the Navy— Which Holmes very explicitely denied, and declared, that considering himself as the organ of the House, and not of the Executive, he never would receive as Chairman of the Committee of the House, any confidential communication from the head of our Executive Department— Holmes added, that the Committee had called upon the Secretary of the Navy for a statement, of what further sums, for defence, would be required in that Department, and had received a very short reply, asking for ten additional Steam ships— That the Committee considered this quite unsatisfactory, and a call for more specific details, had been referred to estimates, laid before the Senate; that the Committee had received copies of these, which they would lay before the House, as the organ not of the Executive but of the House— George Dromgoole, who was mellow, sported some buffoonery with Davis, and Chipman of Michigan, chattered a few minutes, till 3. o’clock, when the debate was to cease. The Committee then rose— Rathbun moved to reconsider the debate to close the debate at 3. P.M. this day, which the House refused 86. to 96. A Bill from the Senate, about Contracts on water rotted hemp was passed, per saltum McKay moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union again, but without taking the Question, the House adjourned— Evening visits, from Charles Bradbury of Boston, from three English Quakers, by the name of Stacy— Foster, and a third, not recollected, and from a German by the name of Glück employed in the Survey of the Coast— Mr. Bradbury, is an old acquaintance from the time of my residence at Newburyport—as a student at Law, but has been for many years a resident of Boston— He is now here, on an occasional visit of business— The three English Friends, are travellers, upon a tour of observation in the West India Islands and in this Country, upon Anti-Slavery principles— Mr. Glück, is a native of Germany, employed, in the Survey of our Coast—

28— V—  Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, and I told him I had called at the Navy Department, on the day, he was last here—that I did not see Mr. Bancroft, who was at the President’s in Cabinet Counsel; that I had requested the Chief Clerk, to solicit the Secretary in my name, that Mr. Kavasales, might be ordered to go as Chaplain, with Commodore Reid, who is going out to command a squadron, on the Coast of Africa and in the Mediterranean— And I stated to him, the contents of the Letter from Commodore Reid, to Mr. C. J. Ingersoll, declaring the Commodore’s willingness to take Mr. Kavasales with him as Chaplain— That the Chief Clerk had assured me, that he would make report of my solicitations, to the Secretary, and that I had since received an answer, from Mr. Bancroft that there had already been made, application, for an order to this Station, but that the subject would be duly considered— This was all I was authorized to say, Mr. Kavasales thanked me for my interpolation in his favour, which I do not flatter myself will be successful— I received the evening before last, a Letter from Mrs. F. W. D’Arusmont—heretofore this much known, by the name of Fanny Wright—with it was enclosed, a manuscript Lecture, numbered 15— One of a course, which she proposes to give, at this place, and asks my advice, whether to carry this purpose into execution or not— Madam D’Arusmont, had appeared in the world, with pretensions, as a political and Anti-Religious reformer— And her reputation, had suffered much from her course of life— She said in her Letter, that she proposed to leave this City, this morng. to return, for an indefinite period of time to Europe— I called at her lodgings, at Mrs. Beeler’s between 4 1/2 and 6. Streets, and returned, her manuscript Lecture, declining to advise her, whether to deliver it or not—I believe I had not seen her, for more than 20 years.—and felt the melancholy impression, upon observing, the ravages, of time, and of evident, adversity, upon her personal appearance— At the House, the reading of the Journal was again dispensed with.— Jacob. S. Yost of Pennsylvania, reported from the Committee on Engraving, a resolution for printing the Maps, transmitted to the House, with the Report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office— Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, made a personal explanation, and the House went into Committee of the whole, and took up the private Callender, upon which sundry Bills, were reported to the House, some with recommendation of their passage, and some to be rejected— The last of these, was the Bill for the relief of the Heirs of Col. William Grayson, against which— Henry. S. Clark, of North Carolina, renewed the objection, which he had withdrawn, when the Bill was last before the Committee— It was rejected, on the Question of engrossment, by yeas and nays, 61. to 65. and the House adjourned—to 12. o’clock on Monday. A resolution had been offered, for meeting hereafter, daily at 11. o’clock A.M. but it was laid on the Table— No evening visitors—

29— V.  Yesterday morning I commenced reading the 1. Book of Samuel, the last of the ruling Judges of Israel, and this morning, read the account, of the extraordinary capture of the Ark and Covenant, by the Phillistines. At this reading of the Bible, I have been curious, to mark, the Historical incidents, connected with this Ark of the Covenant, containing, the volume of the Law—written by the finger of God, and delivered to Moses on Mount Sinai. In the 25th. Chapter of Exodus, is contained the command of God, to make this Ark, and the 16th. verse, of that Chapter, is in the following words, “And thou shalt put into the Ark, the testimony, which I shall give thee” In the subsequent parts of that Book, are contained the instructions for keeping this Ark, in the Tabernacle of the Congregation, which was carried, with the Israelites, in their Journeys through the wilderness— In the 31st. Chapter, of Exodus, and the 18th. verse, it is recorded, “That God gave unto Moses, when he had made an end of communing with him, upon Mount Sinai, two Tables of Testimony; Tables of Stone, written with the finger of God”— But while Moses was with God in the Mount, the children of Israel rebelled, and made a molten Calf of gold which they worshipped, as the Gods, which brought them out of the Land of Egypt, upon discovering which, when Moses came down from the Mount, in his indignation, he casts the Tables out of his hands, and brake them, beneath the Mount— In the 34th. Chapter of Exodus, the Lord, commanded Moses, to hew him two Tables of Stone like unto the first, on which he wrote the words, that were in the first Tables— In the 40th. Chapter of Exodus, it is recorded, that in the first month in the 2. year, on the first day of the month, the Tabernacle was reared up, in the Wilderness and Moses, took and put the Testimony into the Ark— In the 18th. Chapter of Joshua, after the conquest of Canaan was completed, it is said, “That the whole Congregation of the Children of Israel assembled together at Shiloah and set up, the Tabernacle of the Congregation there[”]— In the subsequent war, with the Phillistines, as appears by the 4th. Chapter of this first Book of Samuel and the 4th. verse, That the people sent to Shiloah, and brought thence the Ark of the Covenant, between the cherubims and the two Sons of Eli, Hopni and Phinehas and in the battle of the Phillistines it was taken— Carried into the House of Dagon; at Ashdod, successively transferred to Gath.— and thence to Ekron was 7. months in the Country of the Phillistines, then brought to Beth Shemesh and thence to Kirjath Jearim and there remained twenty years, till the days of David. Its subsequent History, I shall if it please God, notice hereafter— In the Hall of the House of Representatives, I heard the Chaplain of the House Mr. Milburn preach, from 1. Kings 2.2. part of the verse. “Show thyself a man”—it is the beginning of the injunction of David, on his death bed, to his son Solomon, and was commented upon, by the Preacher, with some eloquence, but not to me with much edification— The Hall was well filled, and a Choir from one of the Methodist Churches, sung two Hymns— Isaac Hull Adams dined here, and after dinner at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, I heard Mr. Matthew Hale Smith preach from James. 1.27—[“]Pure religion, and undefiled, before God, and the Father is this, “To visit the fatherless, and widows, in their affliction and to keep himself unspotted from the world”— James, is the Apostle of good works and not so high authority to the Calvinistic creed, as Paul. Mr. Smith is a Calvinist but believes also, in the inspiration, of James—

30. V.  A few painful symptoms of rheumatism. I found yesterday, the papers, which had been put in my hands, in Oct 1842, by Alonzo Taft, and took them to the Navy Department, where I saw the Secretary Mr. Bancroft, and left them with him. He placed them in the hands of the Chief Clerk of the Department, and promised immediate attention to them— They had been committed to me, during the recess of Congress— I had brought them with me, at the commencement of the Session then ensuing, and had been mislaid upon a file of papers, from that time to this— An instance of forgetfulness on my part, which has seldom happened, as I have made it a practise, specially to note Papers entrusted to me during the recess of Congress, to be used during the subsequent Session— I lament this delinquency of my memory, and gratefully reflect, that it has not oftener occured— On the 24th. of this month, I received a Letter dated on the 20th. at Boston, from Alonzo Taft reminding me of the papers which he had entrusted to me in 1842, and enquiring what had become of them— I took his Letter to the Pension Office, the Commissioner of which J. L. Edwards reported to me, that they were not to be found either in that Office or at the Navy Department. I found them now accidentally in searching for other papers—and the discovery of them administered to me. A mingled feeling of mortification and of pleasure— At the House; this was the day, for the call of the states for resolutions and the House went immediately, into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and took up the Bill, making appropriations to supply deficiencies in the appropriation Bills of the last year. The Questions were taken, upon various Amendments, after which the Bill was reported to the House, followed by further desultory debate, and was finally passed by yeas and nays 108. to 38. Abner Lewis of New York moved to re-consider the vote of last Saturday, by which the Bill for the relief of the heirs of Colonel William Grayson was rejected on the question of engrossment— The motion was laid over for consideration— The House, at the motion of George. C. Dromgoole, went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Joseph Johnson, in the Chair, and took up the Sub-Treasury Bill so-called.— The Bill was read through, after several motions, to supercede, the rule requiring that it should be so read, and then taken up by sections— A debate upon it was commenced, by Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, continued, by William W. Wick, of the same State. Shelton F. Leake of Virginia and John. S. Chipman of Michigan—who had spoken only about five minutes, when a quarter to five the Committee rose, and the House adjourned. No evening visitors—

31. V.  An almost sleepless night and much of the morning wasted, in writing verses— Mr. Otis Drury of Boston, came, to claim my assistance in a claim, which he has upon the Government— Some weeks since, there were shipped, by a Quarter Master here, in the Schooner Joy, belonging to Mr. Drury, thirteen pieces of Canon, to be transported to Pensacola, for this Government— On the 2d. of this month, the vessal was stranded on Cran Island near Norfolk, Virginia, and there remains, with the Canons, still on board— Mr. Drury, has been to Norfolk, and comes here, to claim an average, upon the loss, for the proportion, of the value of the guns, and for the charges of recovering them, and transporting them, to Pensacola, according to the original Contract— I went with Mr. Drury, and introduced him to the Secretary of War, Marcy, and to the Quarter Master General, Jesup; to them he stated his claim, and I left him, to agree with them, upon the measures to be pursued, for the fulfilment, of this contract with the Government, after which, I took him to his lodgings, at Coleman’s Hotel; and proceeded to the Capitol, where I found the House in session— Alex. D. Simms, of South Carolina, had moved a resolution, that the daily hour of adjournment, of the House, should hereafter be, to 11. o’clock, A.M. until other was ordered. Winthrop objected— Simms moved, a suspension of the rules— Carried by yeas and nays 105. to 52. and the resolution was adopted— The Speaker, laid before the House, a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury stating, the withdrawal, of the deposit of Public monies, from sundry Banks and individuals, and the Amount, of the present deposits in many others 34. in number— Dromgoole, moved a resolution, to close the debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the union on the sub-Treasury Bill next Thursday, at 1. o’clock— Sundry amendments were proposed and rejected, and the resolution was adopted The House immediately went into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, Joseph Johnson in the Chair and took up the Bill— Chipman of Michigan concluded the Speech which he yesterday commenced, in support of it— Joseph. R. Ingersoll followed for an hour against it and Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina replied to him— Charles. J. Ingersoll, who had offered an Amendment to the Bill with two or three preliminary whereas’s made a random Speech of an hour, in support of them—and Milton Brown, in less than an hour demolished them all; demonstrating the glaring blunders of which they were composed— John. H. McHenry of Kentucky took the floor, the Committee rose and the House adjourned to 11. o’clock tomorrow morning— My wife dined abroad, at Mr. Frye’s We had evening visits from Mr. Healy, Dubourjal, and Mr. John Connell—

Morning visit from Mr. Heman Lincoln. He has been here for some weeks as Agent, for the Baptist Board of Foreign Missions; and is in frequent communication with the Indian Division of the War Department here concerning the relations between our Government and the Indian Tribes and there is a constant interposition of this Association, in the negotiation and execution of their Treaties with the United States— He told me a long story, of Treaties made in the years 1835. and 36. with the Ottoway and Chippeway Tribes, and the discordant movements between the Baptist Missionary on that station and Roman Catholic Priests, in competition with them for the conversion of the Tribes to the Christian Faith;—It is a melancholy contemplation that these pious purposes, in profession common to them both, are more strongly marked by jealousy and hatred of each other, than by their success, in Christianizing the heathen Savage— More characteristic, of the boundless ambition of the Papal power, than of the progress, of the Kingdom of Christ upon Earth— At the House, John. H McHenry, asked leave to give notice, of a long complicated and quite useless, addition to the rules, for, proceedings in Committee of the whole to which objection being made, he moved to suspend the rules, to enable him to give the notice; which the House refused, At Dromgoole’s motion, the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, J. R. J. Daniel of North Carolina, in the Chair, and took up, the Sub-Treasury Bill— Which was debated by Henry Grider of Kentucky Washington Hunt of New York, and Garrett Davis of Kentucky against the Bill and John H Harmanson of Louisiana Wm. Sawyer of Ohio—Daniel of North Carolina who yielded for the time, the Chair to McDowell of Ohio and George W. Jones of Tennessee, till at a quarter before five the Committee rose and after an abortive effort, to adjourn, till ten oclock, tomorrow, they adjourned till eleven— A remarkable explosion took place this day, in the Senate, upon the Oregon Notice Question— Thomas H. Benton came out for 49. against Lewis Cass, of Michigan, and the 54.40. men, He was replied to, with great bitterness by Hannegan of Indiana— The Administration Democrats, are splitting up into fragments— There is a great probability, that the Whigs will do the same, and a new organization of Parties, be formed on the basis, of the Oregon Question— Evening visits from Mr. George Sykes, with Mr. Stephens and Mr. Ryder two of his Constituents from New Jersey— The debate in the House this day was so dull, that I escaped from it, and gave a sitting of an hour, to Mr. Johnson, in a Committee Room below for my Portrait—

2. V.  I forgot to mention that Mr. Richard. I. Morsell, came last evening, and made his Annual payment of three hundred dollars conformably to his contract, with me, of the 31st. March, 1840— I should have mentioned also, that Mr. Heman Lincoln yesterday returned to me, the Manuscript Lecture upon Faith which I had lent him, and of which he told me, he had taken a Copy, as I had given him permission to do— At the House, the reading of the Journal of yesterday was dispensed with, a bad practise which I strongly apprehend, will become a general one— They went immediately into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, Daniel of North Carolina in the Chair, and took up the Sub Treasury Bill— Garrett Davis of Kentucky finished the Speech which he had commenced yesterday, and Dromgoole, who had introduced the Bill replied to all its oponents leaving only ten minutes to Barkly Martin of Tenn in the course of which he found an opportunity of quoting my authority, in favour of the Bill by referrence to my vote, in favour of General Gordon’s Amendment offered to a Bill, in 1834, which Amendment he represented, as identical with the Bill now before this Committee— I rose, and asked him to allow me, but one moment, to explain my reason for that vote— But he said he could not spare it from his allotted 10. minutes, and after some pleasantry, I surrendered my claim, for liberty to explain— I had voted for Gordons Bill as an Amendment to one still more obnoxious, intending if the Amendment had prevailed, finally to vote against it— This is a very common, but very disingenous practise, of adducing, a former vote upon an Amendment, as a substitute for a different provision, and concluding from it, that the voter is pledged in favor of the Amendment when substituted— At one o’clock, the time for closing the debate, came; and a multitude of Amendments were voted upon by the Committee, many of them, rejected, a few adopted, and the Bill was reported to the House— The previous Question was immediately started, and the Bill finally passed, by yeas and nays, 123. to 67— Dromgoole moved, a ridiculous alteration of the, title, itself as long, as a moderate sized Bill, it was rejected, and the title first proposed adopted, and at half past three, the House, adjourned— The smart and spicy debate, between Thomas. H Benton, and Lewis Cass, in the Senate, was this day, continued, and concluded, leaving the Parties, precisely where they were when commenced, between 49. and 54–40. Mr. W. G. Robinson the expelled reporter, for the New York Tribune, was here this evening, with Mr. Dempster the Musician, who entertained us, with several melancholy, and one lively Song.

3. V—  As the Spring advances, I am suffering with flying shoots of rheumatism, which disturb my nightly rests, and encroach upon my rising hour— It unsettles also, my mind, and fills it, with teeming fancies which never come to maturity— “AEgri-somnia” At the House, Archibald Atkinson of Virginia—offered a resolution, calling on the Secretary of the Navy, for a Report on the pay and emoluments of the Marine Corps, which was carried by a suspension of the rules. Albert Constable of Maryland presented sundry resolutions, of the Legislature of that State, and the House went into Committee of the whole, and took up the Bill, to provide for the continuation, of the Cumberland Road, in the States of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois— W. W. Wick of Indiana, moved as an Amendment, to substitute a Bill, reported from the committee on Roads and Canals, granting to those several states, Land instead of money, to pay for the continuance of that Road.— This Bill with this, and sundry other Amendments, was very earnestly, and tediously debated, between the Western, and Southern members—till the Committee rose, and Lynn Boyd of Kentucky offered a Resolution, to close the debate in Committee in half an hour, after it should again be taken up— Vinton of Ohio moved to lay this motion upon the Table, but there was no quorum voting, and after two, or three, failures, of motions to adjourn, it was carried, about four o’clock by yeas and nays 59 to 55— In the Senate, the War between the degrees of Latitude, in Oregon, was continued and Daniel Webster, gave notice, that next Monday, he would speak, in defence, of his Ashburton Treaty; against sundry collateral attacks made against it, in the Oregon debates— Mr. W. Hogan, was here this evening, and mentioned to me, that the Union Newspaper of this day, contained a Letter, from Robert Greenhow, in defence of his History of Oregon and California against a furious assault, of Thomas. H. Benton, upon it in his Speech, two days ago in the Senate, and Mr. Hogan afterwards sent me the Paper— There is an onerous coalition or as Rhett of South Carolina, would call it a disastrous conjunction, upon this subject, between the Senators, Benton, Webster, and Calhoun—the final results of which are yet in the womb of time.

Mr. Wilson, came here this morning, about the Lot, adjoining, that in which their House stands, which I had conditionally promised, to let him have upon a Lease for a Garden— I had since, determined, not to let him have it, but he says, that in the confidence of my promise he had proceeded to make the repairs, which I had required, and had actually, sown the seeds, of vegetables, in the ground— Though I thought he had no right to do this, to avoid a quarrel with a neighbour, of all things the most odious, I told him, I would endeavour, to make arrangements upon which, we might agree, and he promised, to call again, in the course of next week— Mr. John Sergeant, brought his Bill for Binding 20 Vol. of Pub. Doc. which I paid—3. Vol. of which, are yet to be delivered— At the House, the resolution moved yesterday by Lynn Boyd to close the debate, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Cumberland Road Bill, in half an hour after it shall be again taken up, was resumed. Mr. Ashman, had moved to lay it on the Table, which was now refused, and Boyd, substituted two hours, instead of half an hour, for further debate, yeas and nays 94. to 63. The House then went into Committee of the whole, on the Private Calender 79. to 36— Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair— It was taken up at the point, where the Committee had stopped this day last week, upon which Private Bills were debated— A Bill for the relief of William Culver, was discussed and laid aside to be reported— The next Bill, was for the allowance, of a bounty, on the Fishing Schooner Success—lost at Sea, twenty, before completing her voyage of four months— It was opposed by Samuel Gordon of New York—Daniel of North Carolina—Bowlin of Missouri and George S. Houston of Alabama and supported by Hamlin of Maine, Daniel. P. King—W. W. Campbell—J. A. Rockwell, of Connecticut and Robert McClelland of Michigan— The policy of the Fishing Bounties was controverted, chiefly between the East and West, till the Committee dwindled down, till com-pelled to rise, for lack of a quorum. A Motion to adjourn was made, upon which the yeas and nays were called, and refused, and about two o’clock, the House adjourned, and thus it is that they transact the business upon the days assigned, for the consideration of Private Claims—and fortunate exposition of the Laws delay— I had spoken yesterday to Morgan. L. Martin the Delegate from the Territory of Wisconsin of a paragraph in a Newspaper mentioning the assassination of Finley J. Hamilton of Green Bay— He said he had a Letter from his daughter, dated the 12th. of last month, three days, after the event, and telling all its circumstances, and stating, that Mr. Hamilton, was yet living and while there was Life there was hope— He said he was well acquainted with Mr. Hamilton, who had married the daughter of Mr. Boyd, who was and had been for twenty years a neighbour of Mr. Boyd and intimate with his family— Mr. Lewis Rall, from Cincinnati Ohio, an Agent for Sundry Claimants for Pensions and Bounty Lands— He asked my advice and assistance, with information, to obtain the Claims, and I referred him first, to the Commissioner of Pensions—James. L. Edwards.

5. V—  I attended Public Service, this morning, where Mr. Tustin the Chaplain of the Senate, made the prayer and Dr. Junkin, President of Lafayette College at Easton Pennsylvania preached, from John 3.1. “There was a man of the Pharisnamed Nicodemus a ruler of the Jews. 2. The same came to Jesus by night, and said unto him Rabbi, we know that thou art a Teacher, come from God, for no man can do these miracles that thou doest except God be with him— 3. Jesus answered and said unto him verily, verily I say unto thee, except a man be born again, he cannot see the Kingdom of God 4. Nicodemus saith unto him, how can a man be born when he is old can he enter the second time, into his mothers womb, and be born. 5. Jesus answered verily, verily I say unto thee, except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter, into the Kingdom of God. 6. That which is born of the Flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the Spirit, is Spirit. 7. marvel not that I said unto thee, ye must be born again. 8. The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh and whither it goeth, so is every one that is born of the Spirit 9. Nicodemus answered an said unto him, how can these things be— 10. Jesus answered and said unto him, art thou a master of Israel, and knowest not these things.” This text comprises the whole Roman Catholic and Calvanistic—doctrine of re-generation— A creed, upon which the most rigorous reformer from Popery, did not separate from the Church of Rome. It is the most mysterious of all the Doctrines of Christianity, though, if illustrated, by the exclamation of being born of water that is, by baptism & of the Spirit, and by the figurative exposition of the blowing of the wind, I understand as meaning by the Kingdom of God, nothing more than Faith in the Divine Mission of Jesus Christ, and obedience to his commands— Dr. Junkin’s exposition was more comprehensive and included much of the metaphysics of Calvin— After dinner I attended at the 2. Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Matthew Hale Smith, the present Minister commenced his course of Sermons, addressed to young persons, by taking for his text Psalm 119.9. “Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto, according to thy word”— Mr. Smith gave notice that there would be a third Service, at 7 o’clock this evening, at that Church, and that his Sermon of next Sunday afternoon, would be addressed to young women. The pews of the Church, were filled, more than I think I have ever seen them before. Mr. William. A. Mosely of Buffalo Member of the House from the 32d. Congressional District of New York a man of intelligence, courteous deportment and pleasant conversation, was here this evening— We had also evening visits from Richard. D. Cutts and his Sister—

6— V—  Mr. Lewis Rall of Cincinnati was here this morning— At my recommendation, he went to the Office of Commissioner of Pensions and left with him, the documents in support of the Claims of several persons, to Pensions, and Bounty Lands, requesting Mr. Edwards to report upon them to me within a term of about twenty days, during which he proposed to visit Boston and return to this place— He requested also, my attention, to these Claims in his absence, and left a List of them with me— They are 23 in number, but the Vouchers in support of them, are all in the hands of Mr. Edwards— At the House, the call for Petitions, was overlooked and the Committees were called for Reports— An attempt was made to obtain a suspension of the rules for the introduction of Resolutions, but without success— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, reported from the Committee of Elections there request to be discharged from the consideration of a Petition from the Citizens of Dover, in New Hampshire, remonstrating against the right of the Members now sitting, from elected by general Ticket, in violation of the Constitution of the United States, and of the District Law of Congress— Culver, moved, that the Petition be recommitted, to the Committee of Elections, with motions to enquire and report whether the sitting Members from New Hampshire were duly elected and if not, that their Seats be vacated. He supported his motion by a Speech, but Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved to lay the whole subject on the Table which was carried by yeas and nays 94. to 55— Among the multitude of Reports from the Committees was a Bill, by Rathbun, from the Committee on the Judiciary creating the Office of Assistant Secretary of State, and for other purposes.— After the Reports from the Committees were all made, the House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Robert McClernand of Michigan in the Chair, and took up the Bill, for the continuance of the Cumberland Road— Numerous Amendments, were proposed, and adopted or rejected, till a Bill appropriating Land instead of Money; was substituted instead of the Bill reported, by the Committee on Roads and Canals, and was reported to the House, 83. to 35— Dromgoole moved to lay on the Table rejected, 74 to 84— There was some entanglement by an appeal, from a decision of the Speaker, upon a point of order, which was sustained, by the House, After which the House adjourned— Mr. Daniel Webster took three hours of this day in the Senate with a Speech in defence of his Ashburton Treaty, to be continued tomorrow— General Daniel Parker died last night about Six o’clock—

7. V—  I have been suffering, for several days, with shoots of flying rheumatism, which disturb my repose in the night, and are now afflicting me with hoarseness and sore throat—which subsided however much in the course of this day— Mr. Bacon President of the Columbia College with Mr. and Mrs. Hall, a Sister of Mrs. Bacon, residing at Charlestown Mass. were here this morning. Also Mrs. Stebbins and Mr. Joseph Harrod on their way from New Orleans to Massachusetts.— Mr. Webster, finished in three hours this day his Speech of self vindication, and glorification of his Ashburton Treaty, against the assaults of Charles. J. Ingersoll—in the House and of Daniel. S. Dickinson Senator from the State of New York— More than half of the Members of the House of Representatives, having deserted their Seats to hear him— Most of the day in the House, was consumed in taking the Questions by yeas and nays upon the Cumberland Road Bill, and the Amendments proposed to it. It began by a Call of the House, in the process of which 168. Members answered to their names, and further proceedings were then dispensed with. The first Question was upon the Substitute reported from the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, for the original Bill, this substitute consisted, of a grant of Lands, instead of an appropriation of money for the continuance of the Road; with an Amendment offered by Garrett Davis, of a grant of 500.000 Acres of Land to several states of the Union in consideration of similar grants, already made to others of the States.— There was a very captious debate, whether the substitute and the Amendment, jointly forming the report from the Committee, should be divided so as to take separate Questions on its two parts— The Speaker decided that they could not— The House rejected the Report from the Committee, by yeas and nays 77. to 103. and then the original Bill itself there 70. to 106— Rathbun moved a re-consideration and the Previous Question. Schenck moved to lay the Motion to reconsider on the Table, which was refused and then the motion to re-consider was rejected— The Bill is therefore dead. The House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. McClernand of Illinois, in the Chair, and after some struggling, and two Appeals from the Chairman, the Bill was taken up, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen, and to erect Military Posts, on the route to Oregon After some debate upon small trifles of Amendment Lewis. C. Levin, of Pennsylvania, moved an Amendment provided “that the Officers and Soldiers, of said Regiment shall be Americans by birth” and he made a native American hour Speech— He was answered, by George C. Dromgoole, of Virginia in a mellow Speech, also of an hour, Sarcastic and ludicrous—after which, the Committee rose, and the House adjourned.

8. V—  I have been, several days, occupying my Leisure, in answering a Letter from Joseph Sturge of Birmingham, in England, complaining, of my Speech, on the Oregon Question, and charging me, with inflaming the temper of my Countrymen, to War.— Sturge is a Quaker, and a leading Member of the English Abolition Society— His motives are good, and his character, highly respectable— I have therefore, disclaiming all intention to kindle War, upon this Question, and professing a full concurrence with him, in abhorrence, of all agressive War I have marked the distinction, which should be made between that sentiment, and the unqualified denunciation of War, peculiar to the Doctrines of the Society of Friends, to which I cannot subscribe The Question of War and Peace, is identical, with the Question of Right and wrong— War for the Right, can never be justly blamed. War for the Wrong can never be justified.— In the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, Jacob Brinkerhoff, moved to go into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, but withdrew the motion at my request, to introduce, a Resolution calling on the President, to cause to be communicated to the House if not incompatible with Public interest Copies of the Correspondence, of George William Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro with the Department of State, relating to the Slave Trade, in Vessels, and by Citizens of the United States, between the Coast of Africa and Brazil— Which resolution was adopted without opposition. The House then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Reuben Chapman of Alabama in the Chair, and took up the Bill from the Senate, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen and for the erection of Military Posts for the safety and protection of Immigrants, on the route to Oregon— Sundry Amendments were proposed, and the debated resumed, upon the proviso moved by Mr. Levin, that the Officers and Men of this Regiment should be native Americans The Native American principle was strenuously sustained by W. W. Campbell, and Thomas. M. Woodruff members from the City of New York elected during the popular triumph in that City, on the Native American Party— But that Party finds no favor in this House.— They were encountered, by F. P. Stanton of Tennessee, Chipman of Michigan McConnell of Alabama, and sundry others. Hugh White of New York, moved that the Officers should be selected from the present Officers of the regular Army, and George W.
