Hopkins moved the establishment of a Post route— Both which propositions gave rise to desultory debate, till the Committee rose, McClernand, of Illinois, moved a resolution, granting the use of the Hall tomorrow evening for the Tutors and Pupils of the New York Institution for the Deaf and Dumb.— On taking the vote there was no quorum, and the House adjourned— Evening visits from Mr. Hogan and Mr. Goldsborough

Dr. Thomas called here this morning— My health is wretched, and he prescribes from time to time, for ills, not within the reach of remedy—and for which the only medicine is Patience and resignation— I write verses, to beguile the time and attend the House to witness evils, greater than my own— This morning I found, Henry. William. Hilliard. of the 2d. Congressional District Alabama making a personal explanation of his Speech yesterday in defence and glorification, of Daniel Webster, and which had been sharply taken up, by his Colleague, William. L. Yancey. of the 3d. Congressional District of the same State, whose malignant invective, far transcended the panegyric of Mr. Hilliard. His explanation, only gave occasion to Yancey to renew, with more envenomed bitterness, his charges against Webster—who is at this time pursued, with a rancour, perhaps never surpassed, by any persecution, ever, practised in this Country against any Public Man. It is one of the features of the present times, which I most deeply deplore—  After some discussion, upon the Appeal, by Mr. Ashmun, from the decision of Hopkins acting as Speaker, ruling out of Order Ashmun’s proposed Amendment to the Resolution offered by Thomas H. Bayly, for copies of the correspondence, in 1841. between the President of the United States and the Governor of New York, relating to the case of McLeod, Howell Cobb of Georgia, moved to lay the Appeal on the Table, was carried, by yeas and nays, 105 to 62, and Bayly’s motion, passed under the Previous Question without a division— James Dixon of Connecticut, moved a re-consideration, of the vote, of yesterday adopting the resolutions presented by Charles. J. Ingersoll— Objections were made, that a re-consideration, could not be had, upon, a Document, which had passed out of the possession of the House— Ingersoll’s resolutions having been transmitted to the President— The Speaker decided that a Copy only of the resolution having been transmitted to the President the resolution itself was still in the possession of the House and might be re-considered— McClelland of Illinois appealed from this decision, which after debate was sustained by the House. Dixon then supported his motion by an hour speech, Daniel of North Carolina, moved to lay Dixon’s motion to re-consider on the Table, Dixon withdrew his motion which was renewed by Lynn Boyd, with a Call for the Previous Question— This he withdrew at the request of Yancey, between whom, and his Colleague Hilliard the controversy of Praise and Blame, concerning the character and good name, of Daniel Webster, was renewed, with aggravated malignity, on the part of Yancey— Howell Cobb renewed his motion to lay Dixon’s motion for reconsideration on the Table, Daniel moved to go into Committee of the whole on Private Bills, but Haralson moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, which was carried Rathbun in the Chair, and the Bill from the Senate to raise a Regiment of mounted Riflemen and for the erection of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, for the protection of Emegrants was taken up, with the limitation yesterday adopted, of one hour for debate— Sundry Amendments were proposed—among which one by Felix G. McConnell to insert the word twenty before the word one, so as to make it a Bill to raise twenty-one Regiments, instead of one— Three other Members besides McConnell voted for this Amendment. Hugh White, of New York, moved that all the Officers, for the new Regiment should be selected of the regular Line, of the United States Army which was carried 78 to 71. Lewis. C. Levin of Philadelphia moved that the Officers and men, should be native Citizens of the United States— Rejected— Stanton moved to raise two Regiments instead of one. Rejected. Sundry other Amendments proposed, were also rejected and the Bill was reported with the Amendment proposed by Hugh. A. White, on which Amendment, the yeas and nays were taken in the House, and it was carried 89 to 82. George Fries, of Ohio moved a re-consideration but the House adjourned without taking the Question upon it— Evening visits from Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal—

11— V  The National Intelligencer of this morning re-publishes, from the Union Newspaper of last Friday, the report of the debate in the House, on the day before, upon Charles. J. Ingersoll’s resolutions, against Daniel Webster, under the allegation, that the reporter of the Intelligencer Stansbury was engaged that day, in the Senate—(This is a mistake—it is the Intelligencer of Monday the 13th. that the republication from the Union is contained)—and in the House, this morning Mr. Winthrop, made a personal explanation, upon the report in the Intelligencer of yesterday, of his Speech, on this Subject, made on the day before— It related to the charge of Mr. Yancey, against Webster, of being a pensioned Agent, of the Manufacturing Interest—which Winthrop had said, was not in a just sense a true charge.— Yancey, had taken occasion to sneer, at those words—“not in a just sense,” and Mr. Webster, now explained, the words as meaning—in every just sense, and in every unjust sense, and in all senses whatsoever, and he now told, the story of the subscription of one-hundred-thousand dollars raised, from certain persons, his friends, in Boston, and invested in stocks for his benefit. His narrative was not very clear, but amounted to this, that Mr. Webster, had sold, certain valuable Western Lands at prices not exceeding their actual value, the monies for the payment of which, were raised, by this subscription of his friends, and invested by the provision of an Annuity, for life. Made without his sanction or knowledge, and announced to him here, last month— This transaction, Mr. Webster considers, highly honorable to himself, and Mr. Winthrop concurs in that opinion— Upon this explanation, Yancey, commented, with merciless severity, and questioned, Winthrop, till he shrunk from the enquiries, with loathing and disgust; remonstrating, against such torturing scrutiny into the private affairs of a Public Man— Jacob Brinkerhoff called for the orders of the day, and the debate on the Bill from the Senate, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen, and for the construction of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, for the protection of Emegrants, was resumed— George Fries of Ohio had yesterday moved, to reconsider the vote, adopting Hugh White’s Amendment that all the Officers of the Regiment, should be selected from the United States Army, which Motion to re-consider was rejected, by yeas and nays, and after some further struggle the Bill was passed, 137. to 35— Cobb of Georgia moved a re-consideration, with a view to strike out this Amendment; which raised further debate, upon an assertion that there were now 90. supernumaOfficers, Finally the re-consideration was rejected by yeas and nays 85 to 95— Private Bills, were then taken up, and motion to re-consider the vote, rejecting the Bill, for the relief of the Heirs of Col. William Grayson, was again rejected, by yeas and nays 82. to 67— Three Private Bills were passed and after some debate upon the 4. it was also passed and the House adjourned— No evening visitors—

12— V—  In the Hall of the House of Representatives the Revd. B. F. Barrett, Pastor of the Society of the New Jerusalem in the City of New York, preached from Matthew 13.31. Wherefore [“]Another parable put he forth unto them saying, the Kingdom of Heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed which a man took and sowed in his field 32. Which indeed is the least of all seeds, but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the Birds of the Air come and lodge in the branches thereof.” The Sermon, was an exposition of the doctrine of regeneration, as understood and represented by Emanuel Swedenborg. He did not enlarge; upon the correspondences, between the material and the spiritual world, which form the special character of the Swedenborg creed— He said little or nothing, of those millions of spiritual Beings, which Milton in the Paradise Lost says—“Walk the earth, and commune with us when we wake or when we sleep.[”] These lines appear to be the foundation of the spiritual system of Swedenborg but Mr. Barrett did not enlarge upon that part of the system. His argument was, from this Parable likening the Kingdom of Heaven to the growth of a mustard seed, proved that regeneration, could not be effected by a sudden, and instantaneous operation but must be accomplished by slow and gradual progress, like that of the process from the sowing of the seed, to the complete formation of the tree, and the ripening of the fruit borne by it— Mr. Barrett was not eloquent, nor animated. The auditory was rather thin and Mr. Milburn Chaplain of the House made the prayer— There was no singing— After dinner, at the 2d. Presbyterian Church the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached from the second Sermon of his course, addressed to young women—from 1. Timothy 5–2. “Entreat the younger women, as sisters”— His Discourse, was plain, practical, and sensible;—distinguishing the virtues, and graces, peculiarly appropriate, to young women— The Address was earnest, affectionate and impressive occasionally to the drawing of tears— He gave notice, that on the next Sunday afternoon, his third Discourse, would be specially addressed to married persons— In his exhortations to young women, I thought they would have been more effective, if he had omitted, to include in his censures the reading of novels and dancing— These I suppose, are considered, as so inadmissible to all, Clergymen, of the Calvanistic Creed, that no Clergyman of that Denomination, can forbear to press them upon the conscience of his hearers— But the morals of the Age prevail so universally, over the discipline of that Church, that I believe it would be more profitable to the success of their Preachers, if they should forbear to notice them, altogether— The censorial power of the Church must, to have any good effect, accommodate itself liberally to the Spirit of the Age— I began reading this morning the 2. Book of Samuel, why so called I do not know, and think somewhat strange in as much as the death of Samuel, is recorded in the 25th. Chapter, of the first Book that bears his name— The 2nd. Book, is confined entirely to the History of David after the death of Samuel and of Saul— The life and History of Samuel, is remarkable, as forming the link between the History of the Jews as a Republic and a Monarchy—

13— V—  I received on Saturday last, a check from the Speaker of the House, for 500. dollars— I had left at the Bank of the Metropolis, on the same day, a check for the balance of my account there, with my book to be balanced— I omitted, to present the Speakers check at the Bank this day, but called at the Bank of Washington, and received a Dividend, of 105. dollars—the Interest due on the 1st. of this month on the Washington City Corporation Stocks 6. per cent, standing there in my name— At the House, of Representatives, John P. Martin of Kentucky moved to dispense with the reading of the Journal of Saturday, to take up the Mileage Bill— Motion lost and the Journal was read— Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from the Bill relating to licences for Canal Boats, to take it up in the House.— Objection being made, he moved to suspend the rules, but failed— Mr. Ashmun with leave, made a personal explanation, with relation to Yancey’s violent invective against Daniel Webster, to which Mr. Yancey at this time made no reply. The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and took up, the Bill to protect the rights of American Settlers in the Territory of Oregon, until the termination of the Joint occupation of the same— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine in the Chair, The Bill, extends the jurisdiction of the Territory of Iowa over the whole of Oregon, without limitation of Boundary, beyond the Rocky Mountains— John. H. McHenry of Kentucky moved to insert the words, south of 49. degrees north.— This gave rise to a long debate in which I took part—observing that if the limitation was south of 54.40. I would vote for it, but was willing to leave it without specific limitation to the north— I refered again to my former voucher of the first Chapter of Genesis, as the foundation of Titles to Lands and produced, Grocius and Blackstone as refering to the same identical authority—Genesis 1.26–30.— I produced also, in the 1. Vol. of the Laws of the United States page 448. the commission of George III to Governor Wright of Georgia of the 20. January 1764. reciting his commission of the 4th. of May, 1761. to the same person, revoking the first commission, extending the Boundaries of that Colony to the South Sea, and establishing, the boundaries of the second (“as far as our Territories extend”[)]—Great Britain having in the interval, by Treatise with France and Spain, bounded, her Territories, on this Continent by the Mississippi— I presented also the diversities of expression in the Nootka Sound Convention, in our Convention with Great Britain in 1818. and 1827. to shew, that Great Britain, had not a shadow of right, to any exclusive Territorial Jurisdiction on the shores of the Pacific Ocean— The Committee rose, without coming to a Question Several Executive communications were received.— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures a request to be discharged from the consideration of two memorials, and that they be refered to the Committee of Ways and Means—which was done and the House adjourned— The Senate agreed to take the Notice Question next Thursday.

14— V—  Mr. Reverdy Johnson one of the Senators from the State of Maryland had sent me, a small box, containing a pair of thread Gloves, with a polite Letter from Miss Ellen M. Cockey of Jno. and Thomas . . . Forest Baltimore Co. Maryland requesting my acceptance of them, as the workmanship of her own hands which I consider as a summons to my gallantry for a complimentary answer— I took this morning my answer to Joseph Sturge of Birmingham England to the Department of State, with a request, that it might be forwarded, to Mr. Lewis McLane, our minister in England, to be transmitted by him, to Mr. Sturge— I had a long conversation with Mr. Buchanan, upon various topics of Public concernment, and especially upon the occasional expenditure of the secret service money, and upon Mr. Buchanan’s desire, to obtain an Act of Congress constituting an Assistant Secretary of State— I stated to him my objections to this measure, upon general consideration and the imminent danger, of finding, in a Department with two heads a house divided against itself— I particularly referred him, to the result of an experiment, to establish an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, at the first organization of the present Government of the United States and the crosses, between Alexander Hamilton and Tench Coxe, till the Office of Assistant Secretary was abolished— At the House this was the day, fixed for the consideration of the Bill for the disposal, of the Smithsonian Bequest but at the motion of the Chairman of the Select Committee Mr. Owen, it was postponed to this day week, and a Bill relative to the duty on Java Coffee already fixed for that day, was postponed for another week— John. R. J. Daniel, of North Carolina, made a personal explanation, to correct what he stated to be erroneous Reports in the Intelligencer and Union Newspapers, of a Speech made yesterday by him in Committee of the Whole— William. L. Yancey, made also an explanation, in reply to that of Mr. Ashmun yesterday— Lynn Boyd of Kentucky moved a Resolution to close the debate, on the Bill to protect the rights of American Settlers in Oregon, Thursday next at 2 o clock P.M. which after sundry abortive motions for amendment, was adopted— That Bill, was then taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair— While the House was in Committee, a message was received from the President, supposed to be an answer, to Charles. J. Ingersoll’s Secret Service call, upon which there was a prodigious curiosity to have it immediately read. But the Speaker, knowing it was not so, only took the Chair, to receive the message, and immediately redelivered it to Hamlin. Vinton of Ohio, Cobb of Georgia, and Holmes, of South Carolina, continued the debate, Milton Brown took the floor, and the Committee rose, McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported the new ad valorem Tariff Bill— Objections to its reception were made and withdrawn— It was read only by its title. Andrew Stuart, moved that it be rejected—Jacob Collamer of Vermont—called for the reading of the whole Bill, the rule of the House being, that the first reading of a Bill, shall be for information— The Speaker decided, that the practise, of the House was, for the first reading to be by the title— From this decision Stuart appealed; which he afterwards withdrew. The rejection of the Bill was refused. it was read a second time by the title, I inquired if the Speaker had decided, that to read a Bill by its title, was reading it for information, as required by the rules of the House.— The Speaker said he had— I said, then the decision is directly in the face of the rule, you could as well pass the Bill now. It was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Joseph Grinnell of the Committee on Commerce, reported a Bill supplementary to the Act for the relief of sick and disabled seamen, and for other purposes, which was read and Committed, and the House adjourned. General Winfield Scott, was here this evening—and told me, that General Daniel Parker, who died, a few days since, was one of the two persons, who as General Scott, had informed me, on the day before Christmas 1844. were present, in February 1819. when I called upon General Andrew Jackson, to show him the Florida Treaty, then about to be concluded, and of which he then expressed his approval. In 1844. Jackson, had positively denied this fact which I had, as positively and repeatedly asserted. Scott told me, that these two persons, had separately informed him, that they were present, at this meeting, between Jackson, and me, in February 1819. but that he was not then at liberty, to disclose to me their names. He said he was intentionally obscure, as he was now, with regard to the survivor of the two persons— But I told him I knew who he was, his name having been given to me, by Waddy Thompson, our late Minister to Mexico— Whereat, General Scott was much amazed— But I did not give him the name, following his example, of being “intentionally obscure”— Mr. Samuel. L. Gouverneur, had furnished me with several original Letters, from General Jackson to President James Monroe, amply confirming, my statement of Jacksons approval, of the Florida Treaty which he in 1844. with such brazen face denied—

I purchased this morning at the Exchange Office of Corcoran & Riggs a certificate of five hundred dolls of Washington City Corporation 6 per cent Stocks, at 1/2 of one per cent premium, for which I paid with $200 of Virginia Bank Bills, 100 dollars in half Eagles, one hundred and five dollars, in a Check in the Washington Bank, twenty six dollars and sixty cents, in 7. Napoleons, and a Check of seventy dollars and ninety cents on the Bank of the Metropolis— Amounting in all to $502.50— While musing for a suitable answer, to Miss E. M. Cockey, for her present, of a pair of gloves, I received a note, from Miss Sarah M. Benton, daughter of Mr. Thomas Hart Benton, a Senator from the State of Missouri, with her Album, in very flattering terms requesting me, to write in it some memento, of remembrance— Such repeated calls, from quarters, whence I have the least reason to expect, diversify, the public cares, already too burdensome, upon my mind, and tax severely my hours of sleep—“With knacks, trifles, nosegays, things of strong prevailment, with unhardened youth”—and form a motley composition of my life— Sarah Wilson the daughter of Noah Wilson, came to enquire my determination, concerning the Lease, of the Lot behind my house, for a garden, to her father, which I agreed he should have for the present Season— The Lot to be measured hereafter and for 15. dollars— At the House— Yancey of Alabama made a personal explanation in reply to that of Mr. Ashmun, in denial of the charge, made by Mr. Yancey against Mr. Webster, that he was a pensioned Agent of the Manufacturers— A message was received from the President, with a Report of the Secretaries of War and Navy, concerning a Fire proof Building, for those Departments— Requiring an appropriation of $200.000. to commence the work for the present year— The Army Register for 1846— was received with a Letter from the Secretary of War— The vote of yesterday, to close the debate in the Oregon Territory Bill, to-morrow was re-considered and Friday next, was substituted in its place— The Oregon Territorial Bill, was resumed in Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, and Milton Brown, made an hour Speech, rather fretful, than sharply pointed, against President Polk— Giles of Maryland, and Paine of Alabama succeeded, the latter of whom, rather tartly replied, to the strictures of Milton Brown upon the President— James. A. Seddon, from the 6th. Congressional District of Virginia—Richmond followed, and Gordon of New-York, after which Joseph R. Ingersoll took the floor, the Committee rose without a quorum and the House adjourned— Evening visits from Mrs. Thornton, Mrs. Talbot, and her daughter Mary, and from Mr. Wm. Hogan Jr.

16— V—  Mr. Kavasales, called on me again this morning, and told me, that, he was about to go to Hartford in Connecticut, to Petition the Legislature of that State, to change his name to that of Fisk, in honor of the late President of the Methodist College at Connecticut, under whose charge, he was educated— He requested me, if I should see the Secretary of the Navy Mr. Bancroft, I would mention to him, again his desire, to be ordered to the Squadron to the Mediterranean or to the Navy at Brooklyn— At the House, after the reception of several Reports from Committees they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, and took up the Bill, to extend the Laws of the Territory of Iowa, over that of Oregon, and for other purposes— Joseph R. Ingersoll of Philadelphia, delivered a Speech, in opposition to the whole Bill— Bradford R. Wood, of the 13th. Albany Congressional District of New York, offered a substitute of the first Section of the Bill— John. S. Phelps, of Missouri, spoke in favor of the Bill, and John. A Rockwell of Connecticut, made objections, both against the Bill and against the Amendments proposed to it— W. W. Wick of Indiana, Seaborn Jones of Georgia, and Pollock of Pennsylvania, Reuben Chapman followed— Reuben Chapman of Alabama took the floor the Committee rose and the House adjourned— We were all invited to an evening Party at Dr. Harris—but Mary Louisa only went, and Mr. Archibald Campbell, spent part of the evening with us—

Mr. Nathaniel. M. Davis, of Plymouth was here this morning.— He is a brother, to Mrs. Bancroft, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, and during his visit here, lodging at her house— On the 4th. of this month I invited Mr. William. H. Prescott, and Mr. C. Sumner of Boston then on a visit to this City to dine with us, on next Wednesday.— But they were engaged to leave the City on Tuesday. I forgot to mention this at the time— At the House this morning, a message from the Senate was received, with their concurrence, in the Resolution of the House, for giving Notice to the Government of Great Britain of the termination of the Convention of 1827. for the non occupation of the Oregon Territory—with an Amendment, somewhat modifying the form of the notice, and of the additional resolution recommending further negotiation— Immediately after which, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, the Oregon Territorial Bill was taken up—Hamlin in the Chair—and debated until 2. o clock, to which time the resolution of the House had already limited the debate— Then came the votes on the proposed Amendments— Of which there were many, occasioning no small desultory debate, notwithstanding the rule— They were almost all rejected, and with them, a Section authorizing the President to raise two Regiments of Mounted Men— An appropriation was reduced, from $300000. to $100.000—and among the rejections was a section offered by Robert C. Winthrop that the involuntary servitude, except for crimes, shall not exist, in the Territory of the United States, to which the Bill relates— Lost 52. to 67— The Bill was reported, and motion to adjourn was first rejected, then renewed, and carried, after an unsuccessful attempt, to adjourn over till Monday— No evening visitors—

In my ruminations of this morning, I composed a Fable, with the title of Caesar and Pompey— One of the symptoms of my desease is an itching for the composition of rhymes, which I trust will pass away, in the course of a few days, but which while it lasts, is among my worst sufferings; for it flies from subject to subject as the rheumatism in my body, flies from limb to limb— Dr. Thomas was here this morning, and ordered new prescriptions, for others, which afford me, little or no relief— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal, the Bill to extend the Laws of Ohio, over that of Oregon and for sundry other purposes, was resumed— The Amendments reported by the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, were adopted without division, the Bill passed to a third reading and under the impulse of the Previous Question, was passed, by the yeas and nays called for by Robert. C. Winthrop—103. to 64. Winthrop Grinnell, and Julius Rockwell, of the Massachusetts Delegation voting against it— It was passed before I reached the House, and therefore I did not vote upon it at all— No member from Massachusetts voted for it— Stephen Douglass of Illinois, who, like me, was not in his seat, when his name was called, asked leave to vote; but it was refused— James Thompson of Pennsylvania moved a re-consideration, and the Previous Question— Douglass, asked for the yeas and nays in the Question; but they were refused, and the re consideration, rejected— The Amendment of the Senate to the Joint Resolution of Notice was taken up, and Robert Dale Owen, moved to concur with it, with an Amendment—and he moved a previous Question— Owens Amendment was carried by yeas and nays, 99. to 87. and the Senate’s amendment, thus amended, by 114 to 41— Pettit moved to re consider and the Previous Question— The re-consideration was refused— The House then passed to the consideration of Private Bills— Three of which were passed, after some debate. Two more were passed, after the failure of a motion to adjourn, and then the House did adjourn over to Monday—

19. V.  I wrote this morning an answer to the Letter of Miss Ellen. M. Cockey—received with her present of a pair of gloves At 11. o clock this morning, I heard in the Hall of the House of Representatives, the Revd David McConaught D.D. President of the Washington College Pennsylvania, preach from Hebrews 10–38— “Now, the just shall live, by faith”— A Discourse not much above, common place, Calvanism, upon faith— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us— At 4. o clock in the afternoon I heard the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, at the 2d. Presbyterian Church preach from Hebrews 13.4. “Marriage is honorable, in all” It was the 3d. of his intended four Discourses, and was specially addressed, to married persons— He gave notice, that the fourth and last Lecture of the series, would be delivered, next Sunday, in case of fair weather, and would be addressed to Parents— The House was very crowded, the auditory very attentive, and the Lecture, sensible, and edifying— In the evening, at the Unitarian Church, I heard the Revd. Henry W. Bellows of New York, preach, from Revelation, 2.4. “Nevertheless I have some what against thee, because, thou hast left, thy first love— 5. Remember therefore from whence thou art fallen, and repent, and do the first works”—and for a second text, Luke, 8.5—[“]A sower went out to sow his seed and as he sowed, some fell by the way side, and it was trodden down, and the fowls of the air devoured it— 6. And some fell upon a rock, and as soon as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moisture 7—And some fell among thorns: and the thorns sprung up with it, and choked it 8. And other fell on good ground and sprang up and bear fruit, an hundred fold”— Mr. Bellows composition is in the first style of elegance, and in his exposition of this text I could not, but be amused, in comparing his with that of the preacher to the Tuscororo Indians, near Niagara, which I heard near Niagara in July 1843— Mr. Bellows argument, was, that moral excellence, the practise of doing good, was the great object, of the Christian dispensation— His Sermon, was one of the most eloquent, that I ever heard, but was, said, not to be equal, to that which he had delivered, at the same Church, this morning— The House was well filled, but not over flowing— Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal, paid us eveg. visits—

The morning employed, in writing verses, in the Album of Miss Cordelia Frye— Professor James H. Espey, called on me this morning, and invited me, to go with him, and examine his instrument fixed on the top of the Capitol to ventilate, the Senate chamber—which I did—but understood none the better, its operation— Mr. Espey proposes, to fix a similar machine on the top of the Capitol at the other wing, for the ventilation of the Hall of the House of Representatives— At the House, the Bill making additional appropriations, to supply difficencies, in the appropriations Bills of the last Session, was received from the Senate, with Amendments Referred to the Committee on ways and means. This was the day fixed for the consideration, of the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, which at the motion of Mr. Owen, was postponed until tomorrow The re consideration of the vote asking a conferrence with the Senate, on the Oregon Notice Resolution having been yesterday carried the question now returned and it was again carried under the previous question by yeas and nays 126. to 50— The vote was taken before I reached the House and my name was therefore not recorded, upon it. Charles. J. Ingersoll—Robert Dale Owen, and H. W. Hilliard were appointed the conferrees on the part of the House— In Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, George. S. Houston of Alabama in the Chair, the Bill reported from the Committee on Indian Affairs, to regulate Trade and intercourse, with the Indian Tribes, in the Territory of Oregon, and to preserve peace, and cultivate friendship with and among the Indians, was resumed— Allen. G. Thurman of Ohio, Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, and James A. Seddon of Virginia, proposed and debated sundry Amendments to the Bill, as did Timothy Jenkins of the 20th. Congressional District of New York, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and John W. Tibbatts of Kentucky— The Bill after much opposition was reported to the House, and postponed to the 2d. Monday of May. The House then adjourned by yeas and nays 98. to 67— No evening visitors—but the warm influences of Spring produced more than their usual operation upon my nervous system

22 V—  I wrote this morning, verses, in the Album of Miss Sarah McDowell Benton, and took the Book, to the Senate chamber, and delivered it to her father, to be returned to her; which he promised to do— Mr. Kavasales was here, and mentioned that another person had been appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, as Chaplain to Commodore’s Reids Ship, about to sail for the Mediterranean, and he requested, that if I should see Mr. Bancroft, I would solicit for him, to be stationed at the Navy Yard here, or at Brooklyn Long Island, or at the Line of Battle Ship North Carolina, at Norfolk, which I very readily agreed to do— At the House, the Bill to establish, the Smithsonian Institution, “for the increase and diffusion of knowledge, among men”—was taken up, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Armistead Burt of South Carolina, in the Chair— It was read through for information and then taken up, by sections for amendment— George. W. Jones of Tennessee, moved to strike out the first Section, that is to reject the Bill. Robert Dale Owen, delivered an hour Speech, in support of the Bill, dwelling chiefly upon the parts of it, appropriating Funds, to the education and training of teachers for Normal Schools—throughout the Union. In my opinion the worst feature of the Bill—Jones objection, was chiefly to the organization, of the Trustees of the Fund as a Corporation, which he contended was not within the Constitutional power of Congress, to create— After Owen’s Speech, Jones withdrew his motion to strike out the first Section, and moved to amend, by a Section authorizing the whole Bequest, to be returned, to the Heirs at Law, or next of kin, or residuary Legatees, of Smithson, or their authorized Agents, whenever they shall demand the Same— That is to say to deliver to them the State Bonds, of the state of Arkansas Illinois, and Michigan, upon which neither interest nor principal, is, or is soon likely, to be paid— This is Mr. Jones’ favourite mode, of disposing of a Fund, accepted by the Congress of the United States, with the pledge of their faith, that it should be appropriated to the purposes, prescribed; by the donor— This motion was discussed, by the mover, by Joseph R. Ingersoll, by F. P. Stanton of Tennessee, by William Sawyer of Ohio and by Jefferson Davis of Mississippi— After which the Committee rose without coming to any conclusion. Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union from the consideration of the Bill relative to Licences to Canal Boats, the motion was carried and the Bill debated in the House till Samuel Gordon, moved that it be recommitted to the Committee of Commerce. On the question put there were ayes 47. noes 48. no quorum and the House adjourned—

23— V—  I received some time since a Letter from George. W. Holley Guardian of Peter Augustus Porter, son of the late General Peter B. Porter, late of Niagara Falls, requesting a Letters of introduction for Mr. Porter who is going to Berlin to connect himself with its University for the purpose of continuing his studies He was graduated last Summer, with honor, at Harvard University— Mr. Holley requests me to send the Letters under the care of Mr. Abbott Lawrence Boston, before the first of next month, when Mr. Porter proposes to embark. I wrote Letters therefore, to Mr. Louis McLane, our Minister, and Colonel Thomas Aspinwall our Consul at London, and to Mr. William. R. King, Minister and Mr. Robert Walsh Consul, at Paris. I would also, have written to Mr. Henry Wheaton our Minister at Berlin but that he has been recalled, it is said at his own request— At the House, Lynn Boyd, moved a resolution to close debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, in half an hour, after after taking it up in Committee.— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, pleaded for an hour and a half, James Graham of North Carolina, moved to lay the resolution on the Table, which was done— And the House went into Committee again, Armistead Burt in the Chair, and resumed the consideration of the Bill.— Charles. J. Ingersoll, informed the House that the managers of the conference upon the Notice disagreement, had unanimously agreed upon a Report, but that it could not be communicated to this House, until it should have been acted upon by the Senate— George. P. Marsh of Vermont, made an hour speech upon the Smithsonian Bequest Bill— One of the best Speeches, ever delivered in the House, but not much in support of the Bill— His desire, is, to apply a very large portion, of the annual interest, upon the Fund, to the establishment of a public Library— Isaac. E. Morse, of Louisiana, to whom, Owen replied, and was followed by John. S. Chipman of Michigan, against the Bill— The Committee rose, and Owen moved a resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole. Joseph. R. Ingersoll moved to amend by inserting three hours, but the resolution itself was laid on the Table, 93. to 44. Owen asked if a resolution allowing an hour and a half would be acceptable, I requested him not to renew the question in any form, as I wished to offer a substitute for the whole Bill— Objection was made to this, I moved a suspension of the rules which was carried— I proposed my substitute, which I had prepared this morning, it was referred to the Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, and ordered to be printed— The consideration of the Bill was then postponed to next Monday and the Bill relating to licences to Canal Boats, was taken up—and supported by a Speech by Mr. Joseph Grinnell— A message came from the Senate that the Senate had agreed to a Report of the Managers of the conference on the Oregon Notice resolution— The Report was then produced and read by Charles. J. Ingersoll, Chairman of the Committee of conference on the part of the House, on which Gentry of Tennessee made some remarks— John. A. McClernand of Illinois, asked to be excused from voting and assigns his reasons, which were it would be an instruction to the President, to compromise, on the Columbia River, and then withdrew his request to be excused— The Report of the Committee was accepted 142. to 46. George. W. Jones of Tennessee moved to reconsider, and the Previous Question—the reconsideration was refused without division and the House adjourned— We spent the evening with a party at Mr. W. W. Seatons Junior Editor of the National Intelligencer and Mayor of the City of Washington—

24— V—  I enclosed this morning, to Mr. Peter Augustus Porter, at Boston to the care of Mr. Abbott Lawrence, the letters of introduction which I had yesterday written, at the request of Mr. Holley, Mr. Porters Guardian, and dispatched it by the Mail— I received from Mr. William S Russell of Plymouth, dated on the 21st. instt. a Letter of inquiry—concerning the first settlement at Weymouth, called Wessagusens, with a Copy of a Letter of my father, of the 18th. May 1822, to the Printer of the Old Colony Memorial, on the subject— These enquiries, I am very imperfectly prepared to answer— At the House, J. I. McKay, Chairman of the Committee ways and means, reported, a recommendation, to concur with the Amendments of the Senate, to the dificency appropriation Bill— The Bill and Amendments, were referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, McKay, by instruction of the Committee of Ways and Means moved, to print a thousand extra copies of the new Tariff Bill, but upon objection being made, withdrew the motion. The Canal Boat Licence Bill was then taken up—and Mr Joseph Grinnell concluded his speech, interrupted yesterday, against the Bill, with the offer of a substitute Joseph. R. Ingersoll, spoke, against the substitute, without favoring the Bill and James Pollock, of the 13th. Congressional Dist. Pennsylvania, concurred with Ingersoll against the substitute but favored the Bill. McKay, closed a speech against both, by moving to lay the Bill on the Table, and calling the yeas and nays, his motion was rejected 41. to 105, The debate was continued, by Hamlin of Maine. McClernand, of Illinois, Brodhead of Pennsylvania, and Preston King of New York, Mr Grinnell’s substitute was adopted, and the Bill passed, and was sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. Jacob Thompson in the Chair. Post Office Appropriation Bill was taken up— The first item, was for transportation of the Mails three-million-and fifty-thousand dollars.— McKay to increase it twenty-five thousand dollars, for the Line of Mail Steamers, from New York to Bremen upon which followed a long debate, upon a contract of the Post Master General, for the establishment of his Line of Steamers— The Committee rose without coming to any conclusion. the Speaker laid before the House, a Report from the Secretary of the Navy, upon retrenchment and accountability which was laid on the Table, and the House adjourned— The Revd. Mr. Matthew Hale Smith Minister of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, was here this evening— Mrs. Ann Herren Jessup, daughter of the late Major William Craughan of Kentucky and wife of General Thomas S. Jesup of the United States Army, died this morning at the age of 48— An excellent woman, with whom and her family a very friendly intimacy has for many years subsisted with ours—

25— V—  To the Sun—eclipsed—A Sonnet—  These lines were written, on the occasion of the solar eclipse, which this day took place— By the invitation of Lieut. Maury, who has now the charge, of the Astronomical Observatory at the Depot of Chartes and Maps, attached to the Navy Department, in this City— I went there, to observe this eclipse, through the great Frauenhofer Refractor which is there established: But the atmosphere was so beclouded, that I lost the opportunity of the observation—and remained there; not more than half an hour— Lieut Maury told me, that the calculation of this eclipse, by Mr. Robert. T. Paine, had fixed, within two seconds, the time of its commencement.— a prediction more accurate, than any other, that he had ever known, ten seconds having been considered, the nearest approach to perfect accuracy, attainable, by Astronomical observers— I met there, Mr. Charles Ashley a Member of the United States Senate, from the State of Arkansas, with his wife, and several other Ladies— I proceeded from thence, immediately to the Capitol where I found the House in Session. McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, had renewed his motion, yesterday made, and withdrawn, to print a thousand extra copies, of the new Tariff Bill, which after several votes without a quorum, was carried, McKay moved also, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the dificient Appropriation Bill which was refused. And the House took up Private Bills, two of which were rejected, and adopted, one— Then went into Committee of the whole and took up a Bill, for allowing the Fishing Bounty to the owner and Crew of the Schooner Success, lost at Sea, twenty days, before she had completed her Fishing voyage, of four months. Mr. Grinnell, made a very efficient speech, in favor of the Bill, and was warmly supported by Luther Severance, of Maine— Samuel Gordon moved to report the Bill with a recommendation that it be rejected. I moved, as an Amendment to strike out the recommendation, and report the Bill—which, was carried— The Bill for the relief of Nathaniel Bird was after debate reported to the House. The Committee rose and the House adjourned—

26— V—  I attended Public Worship this morning and the Revd. Dr. Adams of New York City preached from Romans 15.4— “For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning that we, through patience and comfort of the Scriptures, might have, hope”— The discourse, was an argumentative exposition of the whole text, showing how the Scriptures, of the Old Testament were adapted to teach the Christian reader by patience and of investigation, and the comfort derived through the perusal and study of them may be encouraged, to entertain the hope, of salvation and blessedness, in the future life— It was very ingenious, impressive, and eloquent— After dinner, at the Second Presbyterian Church, this day had been fixed, by Mr. Smith, for the delivery of the 4th and last, of his series of Lectures. The one addressed particularly to Parents—and the weather was so unpropitious the day consisting of a succession of showers, that he postponed the delivery of this Lecture till the next Sabbath—and preached upon Isaiah, 55–10— [“]For as the rain cometh down and the snow, from Heaven and returneth not thither but watereth the earth and maketh it bring forth, and bud, that it may give seed to the sower, and bread to the eater; 11. So shall my word be, that goeth forth, out of my mouth, it shall not return unto me, void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper, in the thing whereto I sent it”— This was a very seasonable, discourse with reference, to the time of its delivery, and the analogies between the effects of the rain and snow described in the first verse, and the influences of the Holy Scriptures upon the happiness of mankind, ascerted in the second, were commented upon, and dilated sensibly, and judiciously by the Preacher— In the evening at the Unitarian Church I heard the Revd. Henry. W. Bellows of New York preach from John 15.11. “These things have I spoken unto you, that my joy, might remain in you, and that your joy might be full”— The drift of the Discourse was, that the mission of Christ upon earth was to promote, the happiness of mankind and that the text itself indissolubly connected the joy of the Redeemer, with the fullness of joy of his Apostles and of all his Disciples in all ages— It was full of instruction, and eloquence, but not quite so impressive, as that of the last Sunday evening— I met Mr. Bellows and his lady last Thursday evening at Mr. Seatons— On my return I found Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal here.

27. V—  In the British House of Commons, on the 20th. last month, Lord George Benti a Son of the Duke of Portland, charged me, by name, for blasphemously, he would say, calling to my aid the word of God, as a justification for lighting up fire-brands and unleashing the Hell hounds of war, on as he called it “our” Territory of Oregon, and he proceeded to say “that if it came to this, that the Bible should be quoted for the title of the Americans to the Oregon Territory, he trusted, he would be enabled to address the Americans in the language of British thunder, from the broadsides of a Line of Battle Ship (hear, hear) and that they would send, British Seamen to the Seaboard of America, to speak in terms, that could not be misunderstood, and make assirtion of our rights (hear, hear)” The report of this debate is re-published, in several newspapers of this Country, and particularly in the Baltimore Sun, of last Thursday, the 23d. instt. I deem it my duty to reply to this charge, and if possible in my seat in the House of Representatives— But if done at all, it must be done with great deliberation, and in a written Speech— I began this morning the draught of this speech and I pray to God, for resolution, decision, and discretion to go through the fiery ordeal, of accomplishing it— At the House, Charles. J. Ingersoll, asked leave to make a personal explanation upon which objection being made, he moved and carried a suspension of the rules— George. Ashmun said he wished to move an Amendment to Ingersoll’s motion, which the Speaker said, could not be done— The suspension was carried out yeas and nays 102. to 25, and Ingersoll, delivered a new written attack upon Daniel Webster, for corruption, and embezzlement of Public money, and, delinquency in the settlement of his accounts, as Secretary of State— He concluded, by asking for a Committee which he said, he could not institute to test the truth of his statements— Ashmun asked leave to reply, and upon objection made, the rules were again suspended 125. to 22. and Ashmun did reply by a defence of Mr. Webster, and retorted, charges against Charles. J. Ingersoll in which process, he was repeatedly interrupted by calls to order, but sustained by the Speaker, and grossly insulted, by foul language, of charges of lying and cowardice, from Ingersoll— In the course of this debate, the Speaker decided that when all the rules of the House were suspended, the Parliamentary Law of England, was, still obligatory upon this House— I called upon him for his authority, in making his decision, he said it was my own, appealing to a decision, which he said I had made, while presiding over the House, at the first Session, of the 26th. Congress. I denied having ever made such a decision, and he did not attempt to produce it— I cannot find upon the Journal of the House, of that Session, any Question decided by me, which the Speaker, could even construe, into a precedent, for his decision of this day— Upon Mr. Ashmun’s pressing some of his charges against Charles. J. Ingersoll, he went over, to implore the assistance of his brother Joseph, to extricate him, from trouble; which he did, as far as he was able, with great propriety, and sensibility— This discreditable scene, closed, with a resolution offered by Mr. Schenck of Ohio, for the appointment of a Committee, of five members, to investigate the Question, how and in what manner, and by whom, Charles. J. Ingersoll had obtained secret documents, from the Department, of State, and report to the House, as soon as practicable the result of their investigation and by the appointment of another Committee also of five members, to inquire into the truth of the charges made by Charles. J. Ingersoll, against Daniel Webster with a view to founding an impeachment against him— The appointment of both Committees was carried and both have power to call for persons or papers, books and vouchers. Howell Cobb of Georgia, moved that all debate in Committee of the whole on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, should cease in two hours, after it should be next taken up—but this was rejected after an abortive attempt to lay it on the Table— Two Messages from the President were received, with reports from the Secretary of War, relating to Treatise with the Choctaw Indians— The Messages were laid on the Table and the House adjourned— I took a walk after dinner.— The weather oppressively warm— We had evening visits from Mr. Mosely member of the House from the Buffalo District of New York, and Mr. Osburn, one of his Constituents— Mr. Mosely, has recovered.

28— V—  I prepared this morning, a draught of a Bill, to be proposed, as a substitute for that, reported by the Smithsonian Committee, parts of which, are to me so exceptionable that I should prefer postponement, of the whole subject, to another session, rather than see it adopted— At the House, the Committee appointed by the Speaker, of inquiry upon Charles Ingersoll’s, invasion, upon the secresy, of the Department of State, was announced to be, Robert. C. Schenck of Ohio, James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina, Abraham. R. McIlvaine of Pennsylvania, Allen. G. Thurman, of Ohio, and John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut, and the Committee of investigation upon the conduct of Daniel Webster as Secretary of State is John Pettit of Indiana, Samuel. F. Vinton of Ohio Jefferson Davis of Mississippi Daniel P. King of Massachusetts, and, David Wilmot of Pennsylvania.— Mr Thurman, asked to be, and was, excused from serving, as he was under the necessity of being absent in the course of a few days, and F. P. Stanton of Tennessee was appointed in his place— The use of the Hall was granted, for an exhibition of the blind pupils from the institutions of Boston, Philadelphia, and Virginia this evening— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Armistead Burte in the Chair, on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill Simms of South Carolina, opposed the Bill, in every shape and form, it could assume.— He held Congress had no power by the Constitution to accept such a trust, and was for returning the money, to the Chancery of England— I made a desultary speech, in support of the substitute, proposed by me, for the Bill— They were both debated, till the Committee rose without coming to a conclusion, and other amendments were proposed. George. W. Hopkins of Virginia, moved a resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole, in one hour, after it should be next taken up, which was carried, by means of the Previous Question, and the House adjourned— Mr. John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut and his wife were here this evening—

29— V—  Mr. Ira Webster, a travelling book-sellers Agent was here, with certain Books for sale none of which were wanted by me— Mr. Kavasales called, and repeated his desire, for active employment again in his capacity as a Chaplain in the Navy— I had not seen the Secretary of the Navy since Mr. Kavasales was last here, but I promised him, I would call at the Navy Department, and speak in his favor to Mr. Bancroft before the end of the week.— At the House, after the passage of certain resolutions, relating to the Post Office establishment and from the Committee on Engraving, Robert Smith, of Illinois, asked leave to introduce a Bill of which he had given notice respecting the publication of the Laws in the Western States and Territories. But the leave was refused— The Committee of the whole on the State of the Union on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill Armistead Burte in the Chair— The Bill reported by the Committee, was debated, and several of its sections struck out at my motion. My own, offered substitute was rejected 57. to 74— William J. Hough of the 23d. Congressional District of New York, moved another substitute, to which George. P. Marsh, moved sundry Amendments, the most important of which was, a Section appropriating $25000— a year from the interest of the Fund, for the formation of a Public Library— These amendments were carried and the Bill thus amended, was reported to the House, there under the Previous Question, it was passed to a third reading by yeas and nays 81. to 76. and then passed 85. to 76— At both which times, I voted in the affirmative— Owen, voted against the engrossment, but voted for the final passage— Thus nearly the whole proceeds of the Bequest are devoted to the annual accumulation of a great national Public Library. The best disposal of the Fund, which it has been practicable to obtain and which, at least to a great degree will I hope escape the usual fate of all benevolent Institutions of being degraded, into mere, jobs, for hungry speculation— The usual motion for reconsideration of the vote passing the Bill, was made by Mr. Owen and rejected without a division. George. W. Hopkins moved to adjourn, to nine o clock tomorrow morning, with a view to adjourn immediately then, over to next Monday, for ventilation and the Summer dress for the Hall, as had already been agreed upon, and the House adjourned accordingly Evening visits from Mr. Buchanan Secretary of State and from Mr. William Hogan—

30. V.  At nine o clock this morning, I attended at the House of Representatives, where, John W. Tibbatts, presented a Memorial for the Institutions of Massachusetts Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Ohio, Virginia, and New York, praying for an appropriation for printing elementary and standard Books, for the use and instruction of the blind, to be deposited with the Executive of the several states, for distribution— He moved its referrence to a Select Committee and that it should be printed, but pending the question the House adjourned over to next Monday— I returned home, and received visits from Mr. Moorehead, one of the Senators from the state of Kentucky with a friend of his from the same state— I am endeavouring to take advantage of the few days of leisure allowed by the adjournment of the House, till next Monday to recover the arrears of this Journal, and to prepare, my answer to Lord George Bentinck, for which however, I fear I shall not have sufficient time— There is an amusing paper War, between the Administration Union Newspaper, and the Whig National Intelligencer, upon the Question, which party has won the victory upon the Oregon Notice Battle— The Union shouts victory, for the Administration— The Intelligencer whistles victory for the whigs.— Driven, horse, foot and Dragoons, from their cry of War, war, at the very sound of the word notice, now, when the measure is carried, by majorities of three to one, in both Houses of Congress, they trim their sail to the breeze, and shout hozanna’s to the Senate, for sugar in the pill, with soft words, and recommending further amicable negotiation, for adjustment of differences— The Intelligencer of this morning, has an editorial Article, from a respected correspondant, crowing like a six weeks cockrel, victory to the Whigs, and defeat and rebuke to the Administration No evening visitors—

1. V.  Morning visits, from Dr. Lewis Condict of New Jersey, and Colonel C. S. Todd, late Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of the Emperor Nicholas of Russia. The Colonel was appointed by President Harrison, during his short career, of supreme command. He was recalled upon the accession of Mr. Polk, rather ungraciously, in his own estimation— He has acquired, during his residence abroad, something more, of the free and easy deportment of the military Character His notices, of the present condition of Society, at St. Petersburg denote the ordinary vicissitudes, of human life, at St Petersburg since the days of Alexander, and of his alliance with Napoleon, besides the transition to the subsequent war between them— I called this morning at the Navy Department and had a long conversation upon various topics, with the Secretary George Bancroft— I solicited again, some active employment, for Mr. Kavasales, a native of Smyrna, and Chaplain in the Navy of the United States— The Secretary stated his objections to his appointment at any of the stations desired by him— I mentioned the causes of which had occasioned the unfavorable reports, of certain Officers in the navy, concerning Mr. Kavasales, and why they should not be recured, without much allowance, for unjust prejudices. I spoke also of the wish of Mr. Kavasales, that he would refer to Commodore Smith for a report, concerning his character, instead of taking that, of Captain Geisinger; which he promised to do— My further conversation with Mr. Bancroft, was respecting our present relations and differences, with Great Britain, and especially, of the contest, for the possession of Oregon. His remarks, convinced me, that what I have long suspected, that this controversy will be settled by humiliating, and pusilanimous concessions, to Great Britain, and sacrifices to the slave mongers, by the further plunder of Mexico— No evening visitors

2— V—  Dr. Frye was here this morning, and excepting the time consumed, in a long morning and another afternoon walk for exercise, I was occupied a greater part of the day with my Granddaughter, in retrieving part of the arrears of this Journal— I fear a desperate task— I continued to write also for my reply, to Lord George Bentinck a task still more desperate, in as much as it has brought me, to the Bull of Pope Alexander the sixth granting the whole, of this Western Hemisphere to Ferdinand and Isabella called by him Elizabeth and their Heirs and successors, Kings of Castille and Leon— I find it in Latin in the first Volume of Hazards state Papers, and it puts me to a puzzle, for a translation of those passages in it which assign the motives for the grant; that is to say the promotion, of the Christian Religion and the conversion of the Savages, to the Catholic Faith— Alexander the sixth be it noted, was one of the most detested Tyrants that ever handled the Keys of Saint Peter, and wore the triple Crown— This is the justifiable foundation for all the European Settlements, colonial on the two Continents of America We read this evening, the account of the Triumphal reception of Daniel Webster, at Boston, where he has gone upon a visit and the procession from the Railway Depot to the house of Mr. Paige, upon his arrival, while he is here, under the investigation of a Select Committee of five members of the House of Representatives with the professed view to his impeachment— And another Committee, is investigating the conduct of his accuser, Charles. J. Ingersoll with a view to his expulsion— No evening visitors—

3. V.  There was no preaching at the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning, the process of preparing the Hall not being completed— I received two notices, one from Mr. Thompson and the other from Mr. M Pon that the Revd. Mr. Furness would preach this day morning and evening at the Unitarian Church. I attended accordingly and heard him preach from John. 9.35. part of the last clause of the verse. “Dost thou believe in the Son of God”— The Discourse without noticing the context, or the occasion upon which he spoke these words, to the man whose blindness he had cured by directing him, to wash, in the pool of Siloam and whom the Jews had cast out, for believing in Jesus— Mr. Furness commented upon the text as a general question, addressed, to his own Auditory observing there was even at this day very little, real, and practical faith, in true Christianity among its professors; that faith was like a Sabbath day garment, put on, and cast off one day in the week, and then he proceeded, to define, what he thought was true faith, which he considered, as a life, of obedience to the commands of Christ and not of any more speculative, metaphysical doctrines or opinions— After dinner, at the Second Presbyterian Church, the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, delivered his fourth and last Lecture of a series, and which was addressed, to Parents—his text was, from Proverbs, 29.15. the last part of the verse, “A child left to himself, bringeth his mother to shame”— Mr. Dietz a member of this Society had applied to me, with a request, that I would preside at a meeting of the Society, to be held immediately after the close, of this course of Lectures, with a view, to pass a resolution of thanks, to Mr. Smith and a request to him of a copy of them for publication— To this I had consented and had prepared a resolution to be offered at the Meeting— But before the beginning of the Service this afternoon, Mr. Dietz came to my Pew and told me, that it had been agreed not to hold the meeting this afternoon— The Discourse, like the rest, of the series, was plain, sensible, and edifying, without attempt at pathetic eloquence— It consisted, chiefly, of observations upon the duty of Parents, with regard to the education of their children, and in exhortation, to that rigorous system, of parental discipline, prescribed, by the Proverbs of Solomon— A system undoubtedly best suited, to the Age, and Nation, over which he, ruled, but perhaps, best succeeded by a milder, and more affectionate system—at the present day— In the evening, I attended again at the Unitarian Church, and heard Mr. Furness of Philadelphia, from Luke 10–27—“Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy Soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour, as thyself”— The subject was treated, as usual, by considering this text, as embracing the whole duty of Man— It comprises the whole system, of Christianity, but I should be glad to hear, from a Man like Mr. Furness, his exposition, of what is meant by the love of God, so emphatically enjoined in this text, and so remarkably dis-tinguished, from the love of the neighbour, with which it is connected— What is the love of God, and how is it possible, that a worm of the dust should entertain and cherish, and above all manifest, the passion of Love, for the Creator of the Universe. Reverence, adoration, fear, seem to be the emotions, natural, to the relations, between Man, and his Maker, and these are the sentiments, which I believe to be embraced, by the command of Jesus, in the text— The love of the neighbour, measured, by the intensity, of self love embed in the nature of Man, is a different sentiment though perhaps derived from the same source.— and perhaps still more imperative upon the practise of human life—

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning and I told him the result of my interview with the Secretary of the Navy, since he was last here and mentioned the promise of Mr. Bancroft with which it had been concluded, that he would see what he could do for Mr. Kavasales, and particularly that he would call upon Commodore Smith for a report of his opinion and estimate, of his services and conduct and character, in his station, of Chaplain— I felt it my duty to advise him not to place much reliance upon this promise— I continue to the extent of my decaying powers, to drudge, upon the preparation of an answer to Lord George Bentinck without noticing the torrents of obliquy from the British Periodical Press and particularly from Blackwoods Magazine, the echo? from the thunder, of the noble Lord in the House of Commons— At the House, a Select Committee of five was appointed upon the memorial relating to the blind, presented last Thursday, by Tibbatts— Reports were called from standing Committees, of which many were presented and some debated, of little or no interest. I offered a resolution that the President of the United States, be requested to inform this House whether any Soldier or Soldiers, in the Army of the United States, have been shot for disertion, or in the act of diserting and if so, by whose order, and by what authority— The resolution was adopted without opposition— I offered it upon Newspaper reports, and Letters, from the Army of General Taylor, on the borders of the Rio Bravo, or del Norte, that he had shot, Deserters some accounts say three, others ten or twelve, in the act of crossing the river to Metamoros and these accounts are circulated in all the Newspapers, almost without remark of question or censure, as to the facts— The Chairman of the Military Committee manifested, some adat my resolution, but did not venture to oppose it— Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union, Preston King of New York in the Chair.— The bill for supplying the dificiencies of appropriation of the last year, returned from the Senate with amendments, was taken up, and debated, till after repeated failures of a quorum and a call of the House, to produce one, they were finally compelled to rise and report the fact to the House, and after a Call of the House, which produced a quorum, which again failed, an adjournment of the House, was finally carried without a quorum— About Sunset, I took a walk, making a large square, round Massachusetts Avenue—

5— IV.30—  This morning, Mr. Minot Terrill, with Mr. Abner P. Nash, both of Weymouth, called on me.— Mr. M. Terrill, had a Treasury note, for five hundred dollars, dated the sixth of March 1841. payment of which has been refused at the Treasury Department It is one of a parcel stolen from the Custom House at New Orleans, after it had been paid, and put again into circulation— It was received bone fide at its par value by Mr. Terrill, and I called at the Treasury Department, to make inquiry at— The Secretary Robert Walker, was not there, but I saw, the Chief Clerk, McClintock Young, who said there was a Bill now before Congress to authorize the payment, of these notes, which could not be made without an appropriation— I received the same information in the course of the day in a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Terrill and Mr. Nash, called again at four o clock in the afternoon, and left the City in the five o clock Cars for Baltimore— Mr. Terrill had not the Note with him but I told him, that if the Bill making appropriation for the payment should pass in Congress, I would give him notice of it; and he might then receive payment without difficulty— Mr. Asa Whitney was also here, and has a Memorial before Congress, for the construction of a Railway, to the Pacific Ocean— I promised him, that if his Memorial should come up for consideration, before the House, I would give him all the assistance in my power, for the accomplishment of his object On my way to the House, I stopped at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and had some conversation with Mr. Gales.— At the House, the call on the Committees for Reports was continued, after which the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Preston King in the Chair on the Bill to supply the dificiency in the appropriation of last year. A tedious debate ensued, on sundry of the Senates Amendments, till the Bill was reported to the House which concurred with them all, and the Bill was returned to the Senate— A report from the Secretary of the Navy relating to the Marine Corps and proposing sundry alterations in its organization was laid before the House by the Speaker and after some debate, referred to a Select Committee— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Jacob Thompson of Mississippi in the Chair on the Post Office Appropriation Bill, with the project of a Line of Mail Steamers, to Europe upon which there was another long debate, and to which I paid as little attention— At the last Session of Congress, the rate of postage, was considerably reduced, and a compensation of the Postmasters, was also, thereby reduced, so that numerous resignations, for want of sufficient compensation, had followed. As a remedy for this evil a “proviso” was introduced into the present Bill, which Cobb of Georgia moved, to strike out— The Members of the Post Office Committee, and two disputations Members, from Indiana, Pettit and Henley, differed so widely in opinion, upon this “proviso” that they debated it until for very weariness the Committee rose and the House adjourned.— Mr. Charles. B. King, was here this evening— The Steamer Cambria, stranded about midnight last Saturday on the Beach ofoff Cape Cod— She left Liverpool on the 19th. of April, but brings no very important news—

6— V—  I make but slow progress, in my draught of an answer, to Lord George Bentinck, by means of interruptions, from daily occurrences, operating upon the discharge of my public duties. Mr. McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, offered in the House this morning, a resolution, that after this day, the House would daily take a recess from two to half past three o’clock P.M, and hold afternoon Sessions, objection was made, McKay moved to suspend the rules, which the House refused— Charles J. Ingersoll, called up a Bill reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, concerning the duties on Java Coffee, and tonnage duties on Spanish vessels— A debate ensued, in which Mr. Winthrop took a prominent part, until George S. Dromgoole moved the Committee to rise, which they did, whereupon he offered a resolution that any Member of this House, who has been, or may be summoned, to attend as a witness before the Circuit Court of the United States, for the District of Columbia, now sitting in the City of Washington has the leave of this House, during the present Session, to attend as a witness, in said Court, if he shall think proper to do so. He stated, that he had received information from his Colleague Hopkins that he had been suppened, to attend as a witness in the Circuit Court, held in this City in a case now pending before that Court; that his Colleague had no personal objection to attending, but wished the House to decide whether he was at liberty to do so— A considerable debate followed, in which I took a part and had some sparring with Mr. Dromgoole, by objecting to the general terms of his resolution, and contending that if any Member of this House, wished for permission to attend as a witness he should in Court of Justice he should ask for it himself. finally Armistead Burt of South Carolina, offered an amendment, that this House having been informed, that Mr. Hopkins one of its Members has been served with the process of the Circuit Court of the United States, now sitting in this City to attend as a Witness in the criminal proceeding pending in that Court, resolved that Mr. Hopkins have the leave of this House, to attend the Court, in which I acquiesced, and it was finally adopted, by yeas and nays 76. to 44— The Bill for supplying dificiencies of Appropriation came again from the Senate with Amendments, to which the House disagreed, and sent it back— A message was received from the President in answer to the resolution calling for copies of the correspondence of George. W. Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro, relating to the Slave trade in Vessels and by Citizens of the United States, between the Coast of Africa and Brazil. I moved the referrence of the Message and Documents to the Committee of Foreign Affairs, but a motion was made, and carried, that they be laid on the Table, and the motion to have them printed was refused— Another message was received from the President in answer to the resolution [“]whether any soldier or soldiers, of the Army of the U.S. had been shot for disertion or in the act of diserting and if so by whose order and under what authority”— Dromgoole moved that the Message and papers be laid on the Table.— I moved their referrence to a Select Committee— Haralson moved their referrence, to the Committee on Military Affairs— They were laid on the Table. A third message from the President was received, relating to Claims of Chickasaw Indians—which was also laid on the Table. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Lynn Boyd in the Chair, on the Jarva Coffee duty Bill, the debate upon which, was resumed—and after some altercation the Bill was passed and the House adjourned—

7. V.  I prepared this morning three resolutions and immediately after the reading of the Journal asked leave of the House to present them— McKay, at the same time moved, to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, by suspension of the rules.— I asked him to wai his move to give me the opportunity to take the question on mine— He declined, but the House refused to sustain his motion. My resolutions were read, first “A call on the President for the names of every Soldier in the Army, shot, without trial since the commencement of the present Session of Congress, and the names of the shooters whether Officer or Soldier”— Second— “A request that the President would cause to be arrested and tried by Court Martial, for murder, every Officer or Soldier by whom, or by whose order, any Soldier, of the Army, has been put to death, without a trial”—third “An instruction to the Committee on Military Affairs to inquire into the causes of the recent increase of disertions from the Army, and to report whether any further legislation by Congress, be necessary or expedient on that subject.” Immediately after the reading of the resolutions, Holmes of South Carolina said “I object I will vote for them when the War with Mexico is over”— I moved to suspend the rules, to enable me to introduce the resolutions, and called for the yeas and nays— A number barely sufficient for taking the yeas and nays, supported me, and the suspension of the rules was refused 45 to 90. Mr. Giddings of Ohio, moved to reconsider the vote taken yesterday—ordering the report of the Secretary of War, communicated with the Presidents Message, to be printed— It was merely a formality for bringing before the House, and the Country the real character of this transaction the shooting of deserters without a trial— He then stated the facts according to the report from the Secretary of War— At almost every sentence of his Speech he was interrupted by calls to order. but he did succeed in producing the Message from President Monroe of 8th. January 1820. in answer to a resolution from the House of the 14th. December 1819. concerning the shooting of a diserter by order of Col William King, and the proceedings upon the trial of Col King by Court Martial his conviction upon the charge, and the final Report of the Committee on Military Affairs of the House, requesting the President to strike Col King from the roll of the Army— But he could proceed no farther, the Speaker who upon the first calls to order had ventured, to sustain him, as in Order, finished by yielding to the calls of the slave mongers and declared him not in order—and he was silenced— This transaction, shows the present temper of the House, with regard, to the dismemberment of Mexico, by the foul and detestable conquest of Texas— I bow in submission to the inscrutable decrees of Providence, but humbly ask, why sleeps the thunder in the skies? Stephen Adams of Mississippi asked leave to introduce a Joint Resolution for adjourning the Session on Monday the 13th. of July—objection was made— He moved to suspend the rules, which was lost by yeas and nays 101. to 62—a majority not quite of two thirds— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Jacob Thompson of Mississippi in the Chair. The Post Office Appropriation Bill, was taken up and debated at some length, but to which I paid not sufficient attention, to know what it was about, but the Bill was finally reported to the House, and passed—whereupon the House adjourned— The utter indifference and coolness not only, in the House of Representatives but of the whole people, to this shooting of diserters without trial, is a sign of the times, which affects me, with a profound melancholy at their degeneracy and corruption Never before has such a state of things existed in this Country and it betokens a depravity of Public Morals, which in my firm belief, cannot escape, the judgement of Heaven, upon the Nation— Evening visit from Mr. John Connell—

8. V.  Daniel Willard, a descendant from the Willard family of Massachusetts and a travelling Bookseller was here this morning with a volume of Historical Collections of Virginia— A large Octavo volume, by Henry Howe, published a Charleston, South Carolina this present year, of which I took a copy for three and fifty cents. At the House Tibbatts of Kentucky of the Select Committee reported a Bill appropriating three Townships of Land to procure a Library of Books, for the benefit of the Blind.— It was referred to a Committee of the whole House, by yeas and nays, 103. to 54. After a struggle by Tibbatts, to pass it without commitment— He insisted that the appropriation being of Land and not of Money, the rule of the House that all proceedings touching Appropriations of Money, shall be first discussed, in a Committee of the whole House, did not apply— This day had been fixed, for the consideration of the Bill reported by the Committee on the District of Columbia to retrocede the County of Alexandria, to the State of Virginia— It was accordingly taken up, first in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Stephen. A. Douglass of Illinois in the Chair, and was warmly debated— The Chairman of the Committee, Robert M. T. Hunter, made a Speech, scarcely noting, the insurmountable objection against, the power of Congress, under the Constitution of the United States, to make this retrocession— Several petty Amendments were proposed and adopted or rejected, but the chief opposition to the Bill, was made by W. W. Payne of Alabama, between whom and Thomas. H. Bayly member from the Accomac District of Virginia—a violent altercation, with charges of impertinence, and defiance ensued.
