James McDowell, the new member from Western Virginia made an eloquent Speech, in favor of the retrocession— A controversy between Eastern and Western Virginia upon the basis of Slave or free representation, was involved in the discussion, but the Bill was carried triumphantly through the Committee; reported to the House, and passed under the Previous Question, by yeas and nays, 95. to 66. A formal Motion for reconsideration was rejected and the House adjourned—

9— V—  I took a long walk last evening, around across the Tiber, and down to the Bridge over the Potomac, and after an almost sleepless night, find my reply to Lord George Bentinck languishing; so that I fear it will never be completed— I continued however to write, this morning, till the time for meeting of the House.— On my way to it, I stopped at the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company, and received the half yearly Dividend by a Check on the Patriotic Bank, for Virginia Money— At the House, a motion was made to dispense with the reading of the Journal of yesterday, which was refused— Garrett Davis of Kentucky moved to suspend the rules, to enable him to present, three resolutions, of enquiry, of the President, for information, concerning hostilities between the American and Mexican Armies, on the Rio Grande, and whether any Naval Commander of the United States, has Blockaded the mouth of the Rio Grande or Metamoras— The motion to suspend the rules, was refused by yeas and nays—64 to 85. This is a sequel, to my resolutions, of last week, smothered in the same manner— Douglass of Illinois, asked leave to make a Report from the Committee on the Territories, but it was refused— John Pettit of Indiana, Chairman of the Select Committee, upon the impeachment of Daniel Webster, reported a Resolution, authorizing the Committee to sit during the Sessions of the House, and to employ a Clerk.— The request to sit during the Session of the House was granted, but that to employ a Clerk was rejected as was that of Robert C. Schenck, from the Committee of Investigation on Charles. J. Ingersoll, for the same permission— Pettit then asked, to be excused, from further service, on the Committee— Private Bills were again taken up, and a Bill for the allowance of the Bounty, on vessels engaged in the Cod Fishery to the Owner and Crew of the Schooner Success, wrecked without completing her voyage, was passed, by yeas and nays, 80. to 72, after a refusal to lay it on the Table 71. to 83. The Bill, for the payment, of a Revolutionary Loan Office Certificate to Nathaniel Bird was also passed after a sharp debate—76 to 66— I took part in favor of both these Bills— After some further unimportant debate, the Speaker presented a Letter from David Wilmot, a Member of the Webster impeachment Committee asking to be excused from further service thereon being confined by illness.— He was accordingly excused, and Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio was appointed in his place— Committee of the whole House again, Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana in the Chair, on Private Bills, one of which, was reported with recommendations that it do not pass, and another, in favor of a bfor the Fishing Schooner Tancred; and after much snarling reported to the House, which thereupon adjourned—

10— V—  In the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning I heard the Revd. Dr. Welsh of Albany, preach, from 2. Kings 5.12. “Are not Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? May I not wash in them and be clean. So he turned and went away in a rage” The Discourse was a curious exemplification, of the manner in which Democracy and demagoguism have crept into the Pulpit in this Country— The story of the cleansing of Naaman the Syrian is one of the most beautiful narratives of the Old Testament, but this preacher from Albany, turned it to political account. Its object in the Scripture is by a miraculous event, to display, the superiority of the religion of the Hebrews, over that of the Heathen Nations even of the conquerors of the Jews.— This is the perpetual object of all the Scriptures of the Old Testament— Naaman, Captain of the Host of the King of Syria, was a great man with his Master and honorable, because by him the Lord had given deliverance unto Syria, he was also a mighty man in valour but he was a leper—A maurauding party of his Army had invaded the Land of Israel and carried off captive, a little maid, who waited on Naamans wife, and she said to her mistress would God, my Lord were with the Prophet, that is in Samaria, for he would recover him of his leprosy— So Naaman goes with a Letter from the King of Israel to the King of Syria with presents of immense value and the King thought, he sought to quarrel with him, but Elisha the prophet, went to the King of Israel, and requested he would refer Naaman to him. So Naaman came with his horses and Chariot and stood at the door of the House of Elisha, but did not condescend to see him, but sent a Messenger to him, directing him to go and wash in Jordan, and promising, that this would cleanse him from his leprosy— Thereupon Naaman flies into a passion and draws the comparison between the rivers of Damascus, and the waters of Israel.— selected by the Preacher for his text—and concludes by going away in a rage— Upon reflexion however by the advice of his Servants, he concludes to go and dip himself seven times in Jordan and is cleansed from his leprosy— He then returns to Elisha, the man of God, and acknowledges, that there is, no God, in all the Earth, but in Israel—and offers to Elisha magnificent presents; which he refuses. There is a sequel to the story, not less interesting than the tale itself, but of which Dr. Welsh took no notice, nor can I for want of time. But the Democracy of Dr. Welsh consisted in contrasting, the rank and pomp and grandeur of the Syrian Field Marshal, with the poverty and humility of the Hebrew Prophet— He commented much, upon the scorn, with which, the Grandee treated, the direction, of Elisha, and after many invidious contrasts, between the great and noble of the Earth, with the lowly condition of the Prophet, he finally concluded his Discourse by assuring his Auditory, that they might depend upon it, there was no aristocratic way to Heaven. After dinner I attended at the Second Presbyterian Church, where the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached from Psalms 77–19—“Thy way is in the Sea, and thy path, in the great waters[”]—a sermon, upon the condition of Sailors— Immediately after the close of the Service, a Meeting of the Members of the Society was held, of which I, was Chairman and presented a resolution of thanks, for his four Lectures addressed to young men, to young ladies, to married persons, and to parents—with a request, of a copy of them, for publication. The resolution was unanimously adopted, the ladies of the Society according to the practice of this church, voting as well as the men. The meeting, occupied not more than a quarter of an hour, and was then adjourned— At half past seven in the evening I attended at the Unitarian Church, where the Revd. Samuel. K. Lothrop, Minister of the Brattle Street Church in Boston, preached from Genesis 37. part of the 15 verse. “What seekest thou,” This is a question put by a certain man to Joseph, when he was wandering in the field sent by his Father Israel, in search of his brethren, who were feeding their fathers flock in Shehem but Mr. Lothrop dismissed all notice of this context, but taking the simple question “What seekest thou,” by itself and applying it, specially to his Auditory, said he would address each one of them, with that question, and inquire what they were seeking— He said it was probable, that the ready answer of every one would be, he was seeking for happiness—and then he proceeded to shew, that happiness, was not, in itself, the proper object of search for the Christian— That this proper object was, the development of his own character; the pursuits of life; of which happiness would be the ultimate result: the practise of the virtues, and the control of his own passions, which would lead to happiness, and which require An earnest examination and search, for practical application, to the duties of human life— On returning home I found Lieutenant Thom, of the Topographical Engineers here—on a visit to the ladies— Mrs. Smith left us yesterday to go to her sister Mrs. Frye’s

11— V—  War with Mexico—  A message from the President of the United States, to both Houses of Congress, was received this morning, after the House had been one hour in Session— It occupied about half an hour, in the reading, recommending, not in direct terms, but by circumlocution a declaration of War against Mexico.— It begins with a referrence to the state of the relations, between the two Countries, presented in the Annual Message, at the commencement of the Session, and then relates, the series of events, diplomatic and military, which have since occured, and brought on a state of hostility now existing between them. A voluminous correspondence, accompanied the message, When it was received, the House was in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Samuel Gordon, of the tenth Congressional District of New York, in the Chair, upon the Military Academy Appropriation Bill—against which William Sawyer of the fifth Congressional District of Ohio, was playing off, his democratic Artillery. On the receipt of the message, the Committee immediately rose.— The Message, and part of the accompanying Documents were read, and after some altercation as to the mode of disposing of them, they were ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— The House went immediately into that Committee at the motion of Hugh. A. Haralson, of Georgia Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs— George. W. Hopkins of Virginia, in the Chair— They immediately took up Bill No. 145, reported from the Committee authorizing the President to accept the service of volunteers, not exceeding fifty thousand men, with an Appropriation of ten millions of dollars.— A long debate ensued, numerous Amendments were proposed, a distinction between War and hostilities much discussed and numerous efforts made, to shape into a declaration of War, against Mexico, one of which finally succeeded— A motion was soon made, by Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio that the Committee rise, for a resolution to close the debate in two hours, upon which resolution the yeas and nays were demanded and refused— At the end of the two hours, the Bill was reported to the House, with the Amendment declaring War by a lying preamble adopted at the motion of Lynn Boyd, and was passed by yeas and nays, 174. to 14. Amos Abbott, and Robert C. Winthrop of Massachusetts voting for this declaration of War. Of the 14, besides myself, Ashmun, Grinnell, Hudson, and Daniel P. King were five— Benjamin Thompson and Julius Rockwell, were absent. There is one vacancy in the delegation from Massachusetts. Thus only one half of the delegation from Mass voted for this most unrighteous War. Garrett Davis of Kentucky, asked, to be excused, from voting, for which he assigned reasons, perfectly conclusive, against the War, and finally withdrew his motion to be excused, and voted for the Bill— Thomas. H. Bayly of Virginia, did the same— Elias B. Holmes of New York—Albert Smith of the same State also voted for the Bill, protesting against the preamble, as base, fraudulent and false— Which preamble contained the declaration of War— And thus the Bill was passed, and the House adjourned—  Washington Tuesday 12th.— May 1846—

12. V—  The proceedings of the House of Representatives, absorb all notice of any thing else occurring in the course of this day— After the reading of the Journal of this day—Robert C. Winthrop called for a correction of the Journal, in which his name had been entered, as against an Amendment proposed to the declaration of War, he having in fact voted in favor of it, which correction was made— Armistead Burt of South Carolina, said he was instructed by the Committee on Military Affairs to move for consideration of a Bill from the Senate, for the organization of a Company of Sappers, miners, and pontoniers Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, asked Burt to allow him first to move for an extra number of Copies to be printed of the War Message of yesterday— Burt declined, and the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—upon the Bill, with an Appropriation of $25000. for the present year; Joshua. R. Giddings opposed the Bill, with an hour speech, interrupted by frequent calls, to order, after which a motion was made for the Committee to rise, The Committee rose, and the Chairman, Moses Norris, said the Committee had directed him to report the Bill— Which was not true— Burt who had moved for the Committee to rise, stated the fact, and said the reporter had erroneously made reported— Douglass of Illinois said “let it go as it is,” to this I objected— George. W. Hopkins, acting as Speaker, decided that the report was to be received as it had been made— Burt moved the Previous Question and the Bill was passed by yeas and nays, 153. to 9— A formal motion to reconsider, without yeas and nays called for by Rathbun but refused, and the House went again into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Charles. S. Benton, of the 17th. Congressional District of New York, in the Chair, on the West Point Academy Appropriation Bill— Whereupon George Rathbun’s motion to abolish the Academy, as soon as the present Cadets shall have graduated, was debated and while William Sawyer of Ohio was speaking against the resolution, a message from the President was received, with a dispatch from General Taylor now commanding the Army, encamped on the Boarder of the Rio Del Norte— The Message was laid on the Table and ordered to be printed, and the House returned into Committee— After some further desultory debate the Committee rose, and McKay moved, to close debate in Committee in ten minutes, after the Bill should next be taken up in Committee which was carried by yeas and nays, 85. to 33. Allen G. Thurman moved to take a recess till 1/2 past 7. this eveg. Winthrop moved to amend it to take the recess till 10. o’clock this evening— After several unsuccessful motions to adjourn Thurman’s motion to take the recess was carried, 67. to 65— At the meeting after the recess, a Letter was presented to the House, from John Pettit Chairman of the Select Committee of Investigation for the impeachment of Daniel Webster, stating that after having been refused the service of a Clerk for that Committee by the House he had concluded, to refuse to serve any longer on that Committee and therefore asked again to be excused, and that another person may be appointed in his place— He was accordingly excused and Seaborn Jones of Georgia was appointed in his place— Pettit was the mover for this Committee, with the avowed purpose of impeachment, of Mr. Webster— Having carried that motion, the real purpose of which was, to force the production of the secret papers, in the Department of State, he takes the first opportunity to get excused from serving on the Committee, well knowing that no impeachable matte, will be obtained by the investigation but trusting, that the publication of the secret papers, would operate injuriously upon the reputation of Webster in the Public mind— The whole of this transaction affords an exemplification, of the manner, in which the secrets of this Government, are divulged, by the operation of factious Parties and malicious personal enmities— Message was received from the Senate, returning the Bill declaring war against Mexico, passed by them with Amendments—which were concurred in, almost without opposition—. . . A final formal vote of reconsideration was made and rejected, and between eight and nine oclock the House adjourned and I came home with a heavy heart.

13 V.  Morning employed, in writing, with a view to retrieve if possible the arrears of this Journal, which are growing like the leak in an unseaworthy Ship— At the House, Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs presented a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury in relation to the Engineers, for the Revenue Marine Service— Holmes moved to discharge the Committee of the whole House from the consideration of a Bill upon this subject, referred to them, and take it up and pass it, in the House—which was accordingly done, though in direct defiance, of a rule of the House, that all matters touching appropriations of money shall be first considered in Committee of the whole— This Committee of the whole, is in our theory of Legislation, the great security for the freedom of Speech, and of debate, upon all subjects before the House, but it is becoming little more than a dead Letter by this evasive practise, of referring subjects to the Committee, and then discharging the Committee from the consideration of them, without and consideration at all— This together with the other recent practise, of limiting the time, for debate in Committee of the whole, takes away, all the benefit of free debate intended, by that organization of the rules. The Committee was accordingly now discharged and the Bill was taken up in the House. It provides for the appointment of Officers in the Revenue Service, by the President by, and with the consent of the President.— Hitherto they have been appointed by the President alone— It establishes a new rank, of third Lieutenants, hitherto unknown in our Service, provides for additional Engineers, of Steamers, and increases the wages of boatswains gunners and carpenters—to thirty five dollars a month and one navy ration a day.— George Rathbun, moved to recommit the Bill, to the Navy Committee, with instructions to report a Bill to transfer the revenue Marine vessels to the Navy Department, which after desultory debate, was carried, 86 to 35— James. G. Hampton of New Jersey presented resolutions of the Legislature of that State, one of which was against any alteration of the Tariff— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Charles. S. Benton, of the 17th. Congressional District in the Chair, Military Academy Appropriation Bill was taken up, ten minutes allowed for debate were consumed by Samuel Gordon. Rathbun’s proposal to abolish the Academy was rejected 50 to 94. and the Bill was passed. The Army Appropriation Bill followed, the chief debate upon which was a proposal, to raise the pay, of Private Soldiers from eight to ten dollars a month— About four o clock the Committee of the whole rose without taking the Question and the House adjourned— The Marine Band of Music played in the garden of the President’s House. I walked out and entered the Garden just as they were closing their performances with the air of Yankee Doodle. After returning home, Mr. Larned, together with Mr. Tracey from Boston paid us evening visits.

14.  Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, and I had the unpleasant task to perform, of telling him, that the report of Commodore Smith, to whom at his request, the Secretary of the Navy Mr. Bancroft, had written for a report concerning Mr. Kavasales, was not so favorable as I had expected and hoped— That it contains no charge against him, of any specific misconduct, but merely an opinion of his incompetency, to exercise the functions of a Chaplain— I regretted this circumstance very much because it weakens the hope, of any kindness, on the part of the Secretary of the Navy. I believe him fully competent, to the duties of that Office, though perhaps well adapted, to exercise it on board of a Man of War at Sea— He wished me to intercede for an appointment at a Shore station which I promised him to do— I received a few days since a Letter from Dr. C. C. Cox of Easton, Maryland; inviting me to deliver a Lecture, before the Ladies of that place, to contribute to the purchase of an Organ, for a magnificent Episcopal Church, recently constructed there— I answered his Letter this day, declining the invitation on account of my health, and a repugnance to be absent from my Public duties for a single day— At the House, Erastus. D. Culver, of the 14. Congressional District of New York, offered a resolution, to instruct the Committee on Elections to inquire into the propriety and justice, of allowing, John Talliaferro the pay of a member while engaged in contesting the Seat of John Hungerford in a former Congress, the Seat having been awarded to Mr. Taliaferro. But the resolution was not received, nor was that of Richard Brodhead 10th. Congressional District of Pennsylvania, for printing extra Copies of the President’s war Messages, against Mexico, received on Monday and Tuesday last— Brodhead moved a suspension of the rules, but it was refused. The Military Academy Appropriation Bill, was passed 90. to 41— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the Army Appropriation Bill— Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair, which George. W. Jones of Tennessee and William L. Yancey of Alabama declined. The Army Appropriation Bill, was taken up. James A. Black of South Carolina moved an additional section fixing the pay of the troops the same as that now allowed to the Dragoon Regiments— Tibbatts moved as an Amendment to raise the pay of private Soldiers, from eight to ten dollars a month— Upon this Allen. G. Thurman, the 8th. Congressional District of Ohio made a violent Speech, in reply to that of Mr. Giddings made on yesterday— Leonard H. Simms, of Missouri, followed in the same strain— Charles Hudson, made a spirited speech on the other side, after which the Bill was laid aside and the Fortification Bill was taken up with Amendments from the Senate, which were concurred in, on which the Committee rose, and after a referrence of two other Bills to Committees, the House adjourned— I called this evening at the House of Mr. Bancroft, Secretary of the Navy— I found with him Mr. Walker Secretary of the Treasury— Mrs. Bancroft was riding out, and while I was there came in. Mr. Charles. J. Ingersoll came also, just as I was taking my leave and on returning home I found Mr. John Connell here

15. V—  My call at Mr. Bancroft’s last evening, was occasioned, by a poor insane man named William Winthrop Allen, who had me called out from my seat in the House yesterday morning and inquired, if I had received two or three months since, a Letter from him, with a Memorial, claiming the sum of thirty thousand dollars, as due from the United States to him. I did not recollect having received such a Memorial but inquired upon what ground he made this claim— He then told me a wild incoherent story, of a conspiracy against his life carried on for a series of years, as indemnity for which, he had applied to the Legislature of Massachusetts, which had refused to do him justice, and thereby gave him this claim upon the United States, whose duty it was to indemnify him by compelling the Legislature of Massachusetts to do him justice. I enquired how he came here, and drew from him the acknowledgment, that he had been placed by his friends in the Alms House, of the Town of Medfield, though he was a preacher of the Gospel, and a Teacher of School— That from the keepers of the Alms House, he had obtained a permission to go to Boston, and had availed himself of that opportunity to come here to prosecute his claim— I assured him, that he could obtain nothing by a memorial to Congress, and advised him to return immediately home— He thanked me for my advice and appeared well disposed to follow it—but he said he would call tomorrow, on Mr. Bancroft, who had been his Classmate, at Harvard University. Immediately after he left me at the House I spoke of him to Mr. Winthrop, and called at Mr. Bancrofts in the evening to notify him, of the visit he would receive from this poor man tomorrow. I proposed, that we should consult together upon the means, of prevailing upon him to return to Medfield— He is perfectly harmless, and eminently deserving of compassion— At the House, Columbus Delano asked leave to make a personal explanation, but objection was made and persisted in, till after moving a suspension of the rules, he withdrew his motion and gave it up. McKay moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the Army Appropriation Bill, John. R. Daniel of North Carolina moved to take up the Private Callender, which was carried— A Bill for the Heirs of Capt Larkin Smith, reported by the Committee of the whole for rejection, was rejected— Barkly Martin of Tennessee moved again the suspension of the rules to allow Mr. Delano to make his explanation which was carried— Delano complained, that his Colleague Thurman had misrepresented him, by charging him with having said, that the War with Mexico, was a “damnable War.” Thurman replied, and the debate fell into a mere question about the use of particular words, and ended in nothing. Then came up again, a Bill for the allowance, of the usual Bounty of the Fishing Schooner Tancred, lost at Sea, which was specially opposed by Daniel of North Carolina, and on the engrossment of which the vote was 82 to 80. Daniel then moved, a call of the House, which was refused and the Bill was passed 85 to 82, Committee of the whole on Private Bills again. Solomon Foot of Vermont in the Chair. Among the Bills taken up was one for the relief of Thomas Ap Catesby Jones, for certain expenses, for services of a diplomatic character at the Sandwich and Otaheite Islands— Garrett Davis, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, moved an Amendment, authorizing the Secretary of State under the direction of the President to settle and adjust the claims of Benjamin. E. Green for compensation as Chargé d’Affairs at Mexico, and William. M. Blackford for the same Office at Venezuela— Upon which a desultory debate followed, till about half past three the Committee rose for lack of a quorum and the House adjourned—

16. V.  Morning visit from the Revd. Mr. Lothrop Minister of the Brattle Street Church Boston. He is to preach again in the Unitarian Church tomorrow and he proposes to leave this City on his return homeward next Wednesday— Mr. Lewis Johnson was also here, with a Letter from Mr. Joseph Otis New Orleans, relating to the final distribution of the proceeds, of the claim left by the late William Otis, not yet completed. I gave to Mr. Johnson a Letter for him which I had received last evening, from Mr. John Otis of West Barnstable relating to the same interest. Mr. Johnson informed me, that his connexion with Mr. Callen of a joint Agency Office, had been dissolved in the month of January of the last year.— Morning visits also from Mr. Charles Hudson, with a Mr. Snell from Boston, who claimed an acquaintance with me of many years standing but which had passed away from my memory. At the House Daniel of North Carolina offered a resolution, to establish a rule, for compelling the Members to vote in Committee of the whole House, so as to secure a quorum by directing the Clerk that whenever there shall be no quorum voting to call over the roll, and to deduct a day’s pay for every member who shall not answer at the call of his name unless he shall make it appear to the satisfaction of the Speaker, that he was necessarily absent from the House— Objection was made. Daniel moved to suspend the rules, upon which the vote was 72. to 70— A majority but not two-thirds, whereupon Daniel declared his intention to persevere impressing this revolution, till he shall get a fair vote of the House upon it— The House had returned to the Senate, the Bill to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen and for the construction of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, with an Amendment providing that all the Officers of the Regiment should be selected from the regular Line of the United States Army. To this Amendment the Senate disagreed, and the House now at the motion of Haralson, receded from it 96. to 69— I had not reached the House when the vote was taken— Thomas. B. King of Georgia, moved a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for a statement of the condition of the revenue Service—which was carried. An Order to print ten thousand copies extra, of the War Message against Mexico was adopted at the motion of Charles. J. Ingersoll— Brodhead offered a resolution calling on the Secretary of State, for the accounts of Benjamin F. Green and William. H. Blackford as Secretaries of Legation and Charges d’Affairs or Bearers of Dispatches which was adopted with an Amendment proposed by me to specify the items of account objected to by the Department— Committee of the whole on Private Bills. Solomon Foot of Vermont in the Chair. Sundry Private Bills were discussed and laid aside to be reported for adoption or rejection. After which the Committee rose, and the House adjourned. Evening visit from Lieut Thom— When I took my seat in the House this evening I found on my Table, a beautiful nosegay of fresh flowers, with a card bearing the name of Mrs. John Pettit of Indiana and the words “For Hon John Q. Adams”— Mrs. Pettit is the wife of a very eccentric Member of the House from the State of Indiana. With her I have no personal acquaintance and with him no community of sentiment, or opinion— I think I never saw her, unless she may have been a visitor here on last New Years day— I hope it is no unworthy feeling, to be deeply affected, by testimonials, such as these— I therefore wrote immediately, to Mrs. Pettit, returning my thanks, with entire simplicity for her present—

17. V.  Notice had been given in the National Intelligencer of yesterday, that the Revd. Mr. Tustin, the Chaplain to the Senate, would preach in the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning— I attended there as usual, but instead of Mr. Tustin a stranger whose name I did not here preached from Gallatians 6.5. [“]For every Man shall bear his own burden,”—a text, which suggested to me many reflections, I hope not altogether unprofitable but far from pleasing or satisfactory, but upon which, the exposition of the preacher made so little impression, upon my mind, that it has left scarcely a trace upon my memory— Whether this, is chargable, upon the Revd. Sermonizer, or upon myself, I am unwilling to pronounce, perhaps upon both. My state of mind being very ill suited to give the due attention to any thing, not peculiarly exciting, from the Pulpit— In the Afternoon at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, I heard the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith from 2. Timothy 4.7. the last clause of the verse—“I have kept the Faith.” Mr. Smith, related the melancholy circumstances, under which the great Apostle of the Gentiles wrote, this Epistle, to his friend and convert Timothy. The note at the end of this Epistle states, that it was to Timotheus ordained first Bishop, of the Church of the Ephesians, and was written from Rome, when Paul, was brought before Nero, the second time. Mr. Smith said that it was written when he was under sentence of death. Upon what authority he said that, I know not, but there is internal evidence in the Epistle itself that it was written, before the sentence had been passed upon him— He complains, that upon his first Trial, he had been forsaken by all men,—but that he was delivered, out of the mouth of the Lion, and he expresses a confidence, that the Lord shall deliver him again and preserve him unto his Heavenly Kingdom— He urges Timothy to come shortly to him, and requests him to bring with him, his cloak, books, and parchments— Requests him especially to come before winter—and though he declares, he is ready to be offered, and the time of his departure, is at hand, there is nothing in the Letter, which intimates that the decision against him, had been pronounced. The principal argument of Mr. Smith was however upon the words of his text—“I have kept the Faith” and explaining by the context, the meaning of the words, he drew from them an exhortation to his Auditory, to follow the example of the Apostle, and keep the Faith, to the last moment of life, through every event that can befall the frailty of human nature— The Rev Mr. Lothrop of Boston preached at the Unitarian Church this morning and evening, but the weather was so uncomfortable, raining almost the whole day that I did not attend in the evening to hear him—

18. V.  Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, he still entertains the hope, of receiving an assignment to a shore station at Norfolk, in Virginia, or at the Navy Yard, at this place—and I promised to solicit it for him, if I should have an opportunity of seeing the Secretary of the Navy. Henry St John of the 6th. Congressional District of Ohio, at the House, by a suspension of the rules, offered a resolution which was adopted, calling on the Secretary of War, for a report at the earliest practicable period of the result of the examinations by the Officers of the Topographical Bureau, of the Harbour of Sandusky Bay, on Lake Erie, with a plan of the Chief of that Bureau, for the improvement of that Harbour. McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, moved a resolution for closing the debate, on the Army Appropriation Bill, at 2. o clock P.M. tomorrow— Which after abortive motions to lay it on the Table and to amend it, by substituting this day and next Thursday was adopted as proposed by McKay— David. S. Reid of the 3d. Congressional District of North Carolina moved to suspend the rules, for a motion to meet hereafter at 10. oclock A.M. The vote was 93. to 82. a majority but not two thirds to suspend the rules— The Bill to regulate trade and intercourse, with the Indian Tribes in Oregon had been fixed for consideration this day but was postponed, to the first Monday, in June, for the Senate to act in the meantime, on the Bill sent from this House, to protect the rights of American Citizens, in the Territory of the United States, west of the Rocky Mountains and for other purposes, commonly called the Jurisdiction Bill, which it is very doubtful whether the Senate will pass at all— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair, on the Army Appropriation Bill— Tibbatts’ motion, to increase the pay of private Soldiers, from eight to ten dollars a month, was further debated, but the discussion immediately slided into the justice and expediency of the War with Mexico, upon which Henry Grider of the 3d. Congressional District of Kentucky made an hour speech, complaining of the manner in which both Houses of Congress, had been forced into the Declaration of War with Mexico, by blending it with measures, necessary to extricate the Army under General Taylor, from the desperate position, into which they had been drawn, by the order to march at once, to the mouth of the Rio del Norte— A resolution, for continuing, the temporary provision, for the Mail service in Texas, was received from the Senate and passed after discharging the Committee of the whole to which it had been referred— A motion to adjourn, was rejected, without a quorum McKay moved to take up the Amendments of the Senate, to the Indian Appropriation Bill. I objected to doing any business without a quorum, and moved a call of the House, which was refused, but they adjourned— There were this evening many shouts of victory and two or three half cannonades of triumph for reports, that General Taylor had defeated the Mexicans, at the mouth of the Rio del Norte and totally destroyed the town of Metamoras on the south side of the river with a population of about nine thousand inhabitants and so defenceless that its destruction is said to have been accomplished in the space of half an hour—

19. V.  I have received a Letter from Charles Phillips dated on the 12th. inst. Secretary of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill; enclosing two printed papers one the first report of that Society of which Mr. Phillips is the Secretary of the 4th June 1845, and the other a printed Circular Letter of the 5th. of September 1845, signed by David L. Swain, eight Members of the executive Committee, and the Secretary— Mr. Phillips Letter, referring to page 275; of the Appendix, to the first volume of my Father’s Letters published by my Son.— The note B. thoughts on Government, states, that the manuscript of my Father, communicated in 1776. to the Legislature of North Carolina, has been recently presented to that Society by Miss Burke, a daughter of Mr. Burke who was in 1776. Chairman of the Committee appointed to project a Constitution, and afterwards Governor of the State— That he died in 1783, and that it is almost certain that from that year, up to 1845. the boxes which contained his papers remained unopened— They were then presented by Miss Burke to the Historical Society; and that among them was discovered one, endorsed in Governor Burkes hand-writing John Adams—Thoughts on Government— Mr. Phillips, on the part of the Historical Society tenders me a copy of this paper and remarking that the Society has been in existence only two years, in very obliging terms proposes to place my name on its records as its first honorary member— I am extremely gratified with the reappearance of these “Thoughts on Government.” though doubtless only a copy, of the Letter to George Wythe, published in my son’s collection, and many times before— At the House, we went immediately into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and resumed the consideration of the Army Appropriation Bill, that is to say, of the War with Mexico, which was continued till 2 o clock P.M. when the debate closed, and the voting upon Amendments commenced. Tibbatts modified his proposed Amendment, concerning pay emoluments, and bounties of volunteers— McKay objected to the Amendment as not in order— The Speaker decided accordingly, Tibbatts appealed from the decision, which was sustained by the Committee 97. to 25— After the adoption and rejection of sundry amendments, the Bill was reported to the House, and passed by 191. without one negative. The appropriation, is little short of seven millions. Sundry Bills relating to the disposal of the public Lands, were reported, and some other business of form transacted, when R. M. T. Hunter Chairman of the Committee of the District of Columbia, moved to fix Friday and Saturday of next week, for the business of the District, without deciding upon which, the House adjourned— The glorious news from the Army, received yesterday, was with some immaterial variations confirmed this evening— Of which we were informed this evening, by Lieutenant Thom—

20. IV.  I received this morning a check from the Speaker for three hundred dollars and Major C. J. Nourse, informed me, that he had ready for me, one Cincinnati Bond— I began writing an answer, to the Letter from Mr. Charles Phillips, Secretary, of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, but had not time to finish it— I have received also a Letter from W. D. Coolidge, Boston, inviting me to attend the annual Collation of the Unitarian Association, at that place— Which is to be, on Tuesday next— I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis, a check yesterday received from the Speaker— At the House, the speaker decided, that a resolution proposed yesterday by Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs for an Appropriation of money, to purchase a Book of tactic and the Articles of War, for the use of volunteers, was not in order, because every appropria-tion from the Treasury, must by the Constitution be made by Law, that is by Bill and not by resolution— This decision was correct, but these appropriations by resolution are so frequently occurring that this principle of the Constitution will very soon, be broken down entirely— It has already in more than one instance, been violated and was especially so, in one case, in the 27th. Congress, against which I remonstrated, in vain— The business of the Territories had been fixed, as the special order, for this and the two succeeding days—but was postponed to the three first Legislative days of June— Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania, moved to suspend the rules, to instruct the Committee on Military Affairs, to report a Bill increasing the pay of Volunteers from 7. to 10. dollars a month, and promising one hundred and sixty Acres of Land to every one who shall serve to the end of the War or die in the service. The vote for suspending the rules, was 70. to 75. Thomas Butler King, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported a Bill, for constructing twelve iron War Steamers of not less than twelve hundred, or more than sixteen hundred tons each,—of a speed not less than fifteen miles an hour and one iron Frigate to carry sixty heavy guns— With an appropriation of five millions of dollars— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union with the report and documents, to be printed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— James. B. Bowlin of Missouri in the Chair— Orvil Hungerford, of the 19th. Congressional District of New York, moved to strike out, an appropriation of two thousand dollars for a meteorologist, that is to say, for Dr. James. P. Espy, who in that capacity, has been quartered in the War Department— Hungerford objected, that it was not in order, in the Bill, inasmuch, as there was no, Law, authorizing the employment of a meteorologist— For several past years, the Appropriation has been made, in the form of a contingency for continuing Meteorological observations, for various Army Stations— The Speaker said that it was not for him, but for the House to decide, if the appropriation was not in order— A long debate was started, on the motion to strike out the word Meteorologist, the vote upon which, by Tellers, was 46 to 53. no quorum— I called for another count but the Committee rose, and reported rose and repor no quorum. A motion to adjourn was made and upon the call for yeas and nays withdrawn— McKay moved a call of the House— Refused 53 to 85, a large quorum, and the House went again into Committee— Hungerford’s motion to strike out Meteorologist, was lost 61. to 65— After some further debate the Committee, rose, and George. S. Houston, of Alabama gave notice, of a Joint resolution, providing for, a one sided commission, of American citizens, to adjust, and determine, the amount of claims, of citizens of the United States, against the Government of Mexico— Sundry other reports were received and sundry resolutions of state Legislatures and Private Memorials, were presented, till soon after three o clock the House adjourned— Major Graham and Mr. Calvin Colton paid us evening visits— Mr. Coltons Life and Times of Henry Clay, has been published several months in two Octavo volumes, and the exposure of the real bargain, offer’d by General Jackson to Mr. Clay in February 1825. remains without reply—

21. IV.  Mr. Kavasales was here this morning—but I had not seen the Secretary of the Navy, since he was here before and could give him no word of encouragement— The disposition of the Secretary, Mr. Bancroft, is in nowise congenial with his former profession, as a Minister of the Gospel— He in nowise favors the establishment of Chaplains in the Naval Service, and seems to think, that Seamen have nothing to do with religion, and that the abolition of all religious services, from the Navy of the United States, whether in the Land or on the Sea, might be the most expedient policy— At the House, a Bill was introduced by George Rathbun for making copies of papers, certified by the Secretary of the Senate, or the Clerk of the House of Representatives, lawful evidence in the Courts of Justice in the States, which Bill was passed and sent to the Senate— W. W. Payne of Alabama, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from the consideration of a Bill to amend and continue in enforce the Act to incorporate the inhabitants of the City of Washington which was done and the Bill was taken up in the House— The previous Question upon its engrossment, was rejected— R. M. T. Hunter moved an Amendment substituting another Bill, recommended by a convention of delegates of the people of Washington— Motions were made to lay the Bill on the Table, which were rejected The substitute moved by Hunter, was rejected by yeas and nays 60. to 99. Paynes Bill was passed and sent to the senate without filling the blank in it. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union George. W. Hopkins in the Chair, and the Civil and Diplomatic appropriation Bill was taken up upon the first Question, of a proposed amendment, there was no quorum voting— The Committee rose, and reported the fact, a call of the House was moved and rejected 84. to 47. Showing 131. members present—112. making a quorum. The House thereupon went again into Committee and resumed the debate— Grover of New York spoke three or four times, whereupon Dromgoole appealed to the rule that no member should speak more than twice to the same question without leave of the House, nor more than once, until every other member choosing to speak, shall have spoken. Motion was made that Grover should have leave to speak again. Vote 45. to 21. no quorum—whereupon the House adjourned—

22. IV.  Morning visit from Dr W. B. Webster of Kentville Nova Scotia. When I was there in September 1840. we passed a Sunday at that place—and in the afternoon of that day, I took a ride with this gentleman, and his brother, of four or five miles, to see a tract of Country, reclaimed, from the Sea, in the Town of Cornwallis— This is the second person, of those whom we met on that day, who has strolled thus far, on a visit to the States; without any other apparent motive, than curiosity— At the House, Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported back a Bill from the Senate, referred to that Committee, repealing the proviso in the Navy Appropriation Act limiting the number of petty Officers, Seamen, Landsmen, and boys, to 7500. with an Amendment,—which was passed, and the Bill returned, to the Senate— Robert McClelland of Michigan Chairman of the Committee on Commerce, reported a Bill for allowance of drawback, on articles imported from the British North American Colonies and exported to Foreign Countries which after some feeble obstruction was passed and sent to the Senate— The House was thin, and a quorum failing Meredith. P. Gentry of Tennessee, moved to adjourn over to Monday, to give the members of the House the opportunity to visit the great National Fair of American Manufactures, which commenced yesterday, but his proposition was rejected 65 to 93— Committee of the whole on Private Bills, Charles Hudson, in the Chair— The first and fourth Friday in each month, are assigned for the consideration of Bills, to which no objection is made, and if as they are called over any one member objects and persists in the objection to any Bill it must be passed by— Eight Bills were thus called, without objection. At last a Bill for the relief of Ann and L. Dana and Co. was called, and objected to by Wm. Sawyer of Ohio— It was passed over, and another Bill, taken up without objection after which Sawyer withdrew his objection, which George S. Houston of Alabama insisted he could not do, the Committee having no power to step backward. The Chairman decided that the Bill should be reported to the House, from which George. W. Jones of Tennessee appealed, and after three votes without a quorum the decision of the Chairman was sustained— Jones thereupon objected to all the Bills which had been laid aside to be reported, which the Chairman decided was not in order— Eighteen Bills were called up, and objected to. James A. Black of South Carolina moved the Committee to rise and report the Bill as passed upon—no quorum voting— The Committee rose and reported the fact John R. J. Daniel of North Carolina moved a call of the House Vinton of Ohio moved to adjourn— Refused 30. to 74— No quorum— Daniel’s motion for a Call was then rejected, and the House adjourned— Evening Party at Mr. Grinnells and Mr. Winthrop’s—to which I went alone the Ladies all sending excuses— I met there many strangers visiting the City to see the Fair, and otherwise— Among the rest Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Appleton, and others from Boston— I remained but a short time, being myself quite unwell—

23. IV.  I answered the Letter of Charles Phillips Secretary of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, at Chapel Hill, and accepted the offer, of a copy of my Father’s “Thoughts on Government”—and also that of being an honorary member of the Society. I answered also, W. D. Coolidge’s Letter Boston—inviting me to attend at the annual Collation, of the Unitarian Association, Boston next Tuesday—which I am of course obliged to decline— At the House, David. S. Reid of North Carolina moved to reconsider the vote, taken yesterday, to repeal the limitation, of last year’s navy appropriation Bill of Seamen to 7500. But the consideration of the motion was postponed. Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back a Bill from the Senate increasing the number of Paymasters in the Army—which was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— F. P. Stanton of Tennessee by direction of naval Committee asked leave to submit a motion to print five thousand copies extra of Thomas. B. Kings report on the increase of the navy and the building of twelve Iron War Steamers and an iron Frigate of sixty guns— John R. J Daniel objected Cornelius Darragh moved to suspend the rules to receive the motion, which was refused— The Private Callender was taken up at the motion of Daniel Chairman of the committee on Claims— The Bill for the allowance of Bounty for the Fishing Schooner Florilla, lost at Sea was read the third time, and on taking the Question by yeas and nays, the Speaker announced the vote 77. to 76 and declared the Bill to be passed— Daniel asked if the Speaker had voted and he answered no— Daniel enquired if he had voted whether it would have changed the result? he answered no— Now if he had voted against the Bill it would have made a tie and the Bill would have been lost— Sometime afterwards the Speaker said, that upon reexamining the vote, the Clerk had discovered that it had been a tie 77 to 77. and that he voted himself, making the vote 77. to 78. and rejecting the Bill— This is a perfect exemplification of the characteristic discriminations of John W. Davis, the present Speaker of the House of Representatives— If his vote would have rejected the Bill by making a tie, he would not have given it, but when the Bill was rejected, by a tie, he would have added his own vote, to make the assurance of rejection, doubly sure— Some question was made whether after the announcement, that the Bill was passed, it was not too late, especially by such a questionable procedure, to reverse the decision— Other objections were made, to the voting of the Speaker, but without any result, except to show his passion for the strongest side— The House adjourned between two and three o clock, and I walked round and visited the Fair— After dinner I walked again to the Capitol, where the Musicians of the Marine Band, were performing— I expected to find the ladies with the Carriage there but was disappointed, and had to walk home— Mr. Hague the astrologer was here in the evening with many mysterious prophetic givings out, which he promised, to explain to me, some day next week, but which as usual amount to nothing— An Indian of the Stockbridge Tribe, by the name of John Quinney was also here—

24— IV—  My strength was over strained yesterday, by the exercise of walking beyond my present powers, and the Summer heat has come on, rather prematurely— I never the less attended, this morning Public Worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives— The Preacher was a stranger but whether from being much indisposed, and suffering from the heat of the weather, I could pay so little attention to his discourse that I have no recollection, either of his text or of his commentary— I must say the same, of the afternoon sermon, which I heard at the Second Presbyterian Church, also from a stranger who supplied the place of Mr. Matthew Hale Smith— In the evening we had as visitors, Mr. Archibald Campbell, now Chief Clerk in the Department of War, Isaac Hull Adams, and Mr. Healey the Painter—who took leave of us— He intends to leave the City next Wednesday, goes first to New York, then to Boston, and embarks for France next August— He came to this Country last May was a twelve month commissioned by Louis Phillipe the present King of France, to paint for him three portraits, of the late President Andrew Jackson, of Mr. Henry Clay of Kentucky and of me— He arrived barely in time, to take the portrait of General Jackson, which he finished only four days before his death— He then went to Ashland, where he took the portrait of Mr. Clay, and then came to Boston and painted mine, in September last— They have all been exhibited, in the rotundo of the Capitol, with many others which he has painted during his Winter residence here— All remarkable pictures, and admirable likenesses— About two or three months since, he sent mine to Boston, to be engraved. Almost all the others are still in the rotundo Besides these, he has made also for the King of France copies of several other portraits of persons, distinguished in our Revolutionary History and among them of Gilbert Stuarts portrait of my Father, painted while he was President of the United States, which is at Quincy with the portrait of my mother by the same Artist— That of my Father, was borrowed of me by Mr. Healey and kept by him several weeks— Mr. Healeys companion Dubourjal has already left this place

25. IV—  I have received a Letter, from P. W. Chandler Treasurer of the Massachusetts Historical Society, informing me that two subscriptions have been opened for that Society one for the payment of a debt contracted, by the publication of the last volume of their collection and the other for the re-publication of some of the preceding volumes. Of this last he says the subscription already made is sufficient, but for the other, he solicits a contribution from me— I answered his Letter this day, requesting him to subscribe 50. dolls for me, and referred him to my Son for the payment— At the House this morng. Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved a suspension of the rules, to offer a joint resolution of thanks to Brevet Brigadier General Zachary Taylor commanding the Army of occupation, his Officers and men, for the fortitude, skill, enterprise, and courage, which have distinguished the recent, brilliant operations on the Rio Grande and a second resolution, authorizing and directing the President to cause to be paid to each non-commissioned Officer, musician and Private belonging to said army, on the 9th. instt. one month’s additional pay. to be paid out of any money in the Treasury, not otherwise appropriated— Robert. C. Winthrop declaring his cordial approbation of the resolutions enquired if any official despatches, relating to these victories, had been received and communicated to Congress— Brinkerhoff said there had not— He only wished to get the resolutions before the House until the dispatches should be received They were received twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union I had not reached my seat in the House Committee of the whole on the state of the Union George. W. Hopkins in the Chair, on the Civil and diplomatic Appropriation Bill Daniel. P. King moved to insert an item to supply the difficiency in the fund, for the relief of sick and disabled seamen, 25000. dollars—which after a long debate, was agreed to, 79. to 45 Then came an item for the erection and completion of the Marine Hospitals at Pittsburg, Louisville, and Cleavland. 50.000 dollars— Boyd of Kentucky moved to insert Paducah, after Louisville, without increasing the appropriation— This started a long debate, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi moved to add Natchez, with a long speech— Joseph. J McDowell named Cincinnati.— Other places on the western rivers were also suggested and debated, till, when they came to vote, there was no quorum— The Committee rose, on a motion for adjournment— 141. members voted. They went into Committee again— W. W. Woodworth of the eighth Congressional District of New York moved, to reconsider the vote, of last Saturday, rejecting the Bill for the relief of the owners of the Fishing Schooner Florilla, which motion was entered, and postponed— Daniel, of North Carolina, moved also to reconsider the vote of the same day, rejecting the Bill, for the relief of Alborn Allen. Also postponed. The Post Office Bill, from the Senate, was referred to the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, several Executive communications were laid by the Speaker before the House and they adjourned about three o’clock.

26. IV.  Mr. Frye was here this morning and brought two Letters from Captain Robert C. Buchanan to his mother, from the Field of Battle, in the Rio Grande— The second of them being written on a sheet of paper taken with the Camp equipage of the Mexican General Arista— The route of the Mexican Army was complete, and they retreated beyond the river— At the House, Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, was very impatient, to take up his resolution of thanks to General Taylor and his Army, which he had offered yesterday, but consented to wait for the Message from the President, with the Official despatches— The Civil and Diplomatic appropriation Bill was taken up and Lynn Boyd’s motion, to introduce an additional Marine Hospital at Paducah, came up again, and produced another stubborn debate. Crozier of Tennessee, Houston of Alabama, Stanton of Tennessee, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi, who renewed his motion to insert Natchez, Wentworth of Illinois, Darragh of Pennsylvania, James. F. Faran of Ohio, and James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, discussed, the insertion of various places, till Martin Grover, of New York, moved, to strike out the whole Section— He and Payne of Alabama, made speeches, against the whole system of Marine Hospitals as appendages to that of internal improvement. Howell Cobb of Georgia, carried a motion for the Committee to rise, and then the resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole, at one o clock, P.M. tomorrow— After which and some struggling the House adjourned—

27— IV—  Mr. Bird Chamberlain was here this morning with a new English translation of Homer’s Illiad in blank verse, by Wm. Mumford—a native of Mecklinburg County, Virginia born on the 15th. August 1775. and deceased at Richmond 21st. June 1825. How a man could have the courage, to write a translation in English blank verse after the rhymes of Pope, and the two translations of Cowper, I find it difficult to imagine; but I agreed to take a copy of the work, for the curiosity of the case, and for the benefit of Mr. Mumfords widow, by whom it is published twenty years after his death— Mr Schenck Chairman of the Committee of Investigation in the case of Charles. J. Ingersoll, but into my hands four interrogatories, in writing, on the part of that Committee requesting me to answer them, at my convenience— At the House Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs moved a call upon the President for all the Official Despatches from General Taylor, relating to the Battles of the 8th. and 9th. instt., which was adopted— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union George W. Hopkins in the Chair, on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— A debate followed and Jacob Collamer of Vermont in a calm, argumentative and efficient speech, replied to the Anti-Tariff invective, yesterday pronounced, by W. W. Payne, of Alabama— He was followed by Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania, who spoke till the time came for closing the debate— His Speech was as usual, highly animated and forcebal? in favor of Protective Policy Payne, by a low cunning common to all the Southern Anti-Tariffites affects to charge the Tariff as exclusively favorable to the interest of New England—but Stuart is a Pennsylvanian and Pensylvania has a far deeper interest in the Tariff Policy than New England— The debate being arrested, the voting commenced and sundry amendments were adopted— The item for the Marine Hospitals was struck out and two attempts, partially to re-insert it, were rejected— An appropriation for the sixth volume, of the fourth series, of the documentary History of the United States of 25.449. dollars, offered by R. C. Winthrop by direction of the Committee of Ways and Means, was carried, by being made payable, to Blair and Rives— Winthrop moved an item of $18000. for a Commissioner to Mexico whenever the President shall ascertain that he will be received— Rejected 50. to 81. There was an item of $5000. for the Salary of a Commissioner to reside in China, to which Jacob Thompson moved a proviso, that no part of this Sum shall be paid, without a Certificate on honor from the said Commissioner that he does reside in China; which after being amended at the motion of George Rathbun to read “That the salary shall not be paid unless the Commissioner shall actually reside in China” was adopted 74 to 40. This was a kick at Alexander. H. Everett, who fourteen months ago, embarked for China, went as far as Rio de Janeiro, and returned, from thence, on account of ill-health. He has ever since been living here receiving the salary, and promising to re-embark when his health should be sufficiently restored— John. P. Martin of Kentucky and Joseph. J. McDowell of Ohio, made clap trap motions, for reducing pay and travel of Members of Congress in the midst of which small work, the message with General Taylor’s Despatches, was received from the President, referred to the Military Committee, and ordered to be printed Haralson, reported a Bill to provide certain military tactics for the use of volunteers twice read and Committed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, again on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— More motions for bunkum, to reduce the pay and the mileage and to forfeit pay, for non-attendance—the most senseless of which were carried— Yell of Arkansas moved an additional section to the Bill to remove the seat of Government in 1850, to St Louis Missouri which the Chairman ruled, not to be in order— Bell of Kentucky, Stephen Adams of Mississippi and Bowlin of Missouri, moved sundry other retrenchment nonsense, till the quorum entirely failed, the Committee rose and the House adjourned— In the evening I attended at a large Party, given by Mr. Joseph. R. Ingersoll, at the House of Mr. Markoe given to Mr. Christopher Hughes, and his daughter, and a company of friends from Baltimore— The weather was excessively warm, and I was much indisposed, so that after being there a short hour, I was compelled to come home, before Mr. Hughes came in—

28. IV—  Mr. Chamberlain came again this morning, and brought me the two volumes of Mumfords Illiad for which I paid him five dollars and fifty cents I had received a Letter from D. G. Ingraham of Boston, asking for a copy of my correspondence, with the late William Tudor junior in May 1822, relating to the purchase, of his father’s Journals, for the Library of the Department of state.— These Journals, contain the most authentic account of the discovery of the Columbia River, by Capt. Robert Gray— I called at the Department of State this morning, and made enquiry of the Secretary Mr. Buchanan, concerning that correspondence, which was immediately found and of which he promised me a copy— I had also a conversation with him relating to the usages of the Department with regard, to allowing access to Members of Congress, to the secret Archives, of the Department. I found the practise had continued as it was during my time, but Mr. Buchanan expressed an opinion with which I concurred that it had now become necessary to establish some restriction upon the unlimited access, of Members of Congress, to all the secret papers of the Department— The recent abuse of that privilege, by Charles. J. Ingersoll, has shown that some such restriction will be indispensable, in future— At the House, Stephens of Georgia, offered a resolution for printing four thousand copies of the map of Texas, compiled by Lieut Emory— Rhett of South Carolina objected, saying he had heard, that the map was not correct— Stephens, moved, to suspend the rules, but the House refused— The Bill from the Senate for establishing Post routes and the mail service, in Texas, was reported by Hopkins from the Post Office Committee, with an Amendment, which was adopted, and the Bill was passed, and sent back to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Hopkins in the Chair on the Civil and Diplomatic appropriation bill. An Amendment to diminish the pay of the Officers of Government and the members of Congress and to increase that of volunteers, to ten dollars a month—was rejected, and the Bill reported to the House, with Amendments— Several of the Amendments were adopted, among which that relating to the mileage of Members of Congress. The appropriation for the Meteorologist was struck out by yeas and nays, 92 to 77. and the Bill was passed and sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, the resolution of thanks to General Taylor, and his troops were taken up.— James. A. Black of South Carolina, offered an additional resolution for pensioning, the wounded Officers and Soldiers and the widows and children of the killed; which was opposed by Burt of the same state as fixing upon the Country, a gigantic Pension system— The debate slided into a contest upon merits and demerits, of the West Point Academy Ashmun, objected to one of the resolutions containing an appropriation, as un-Constitutional Brinkerhoff appealed to a precedent, in which, there was no appropriation— I referred as I have done, many times before, to the express terms, of the Constitution, to show that no appropriation, of money, can be made, by resolution— Brodhead appealed to the precedent at this Session in the resolution for the admission of Texas; which I said was only one additional violation of the Constitution The Chairman, decided that no appropriation could be made by resolution. Charles J. Ingersoll said that Chief Justice Marshall had expressly decided that a joint resolution was to all intents and purposes, a Law. Boyd the Chairman said that his decision was otherwise, Chief Justice Marshall to the contrary notwithstanding— But Ingersolls assertion was not true— Brinkerhoff appealed from the decision of the Chair Black of South Carolina had done so already— Sawyer of Ohio and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi snarled about the West-point Academy— Luther Severance, made a speech in justification of his vote against the Declaration of War, to which Barkly Martin of Tennessee replied with usual slave-monger brutality— Giddings took the floor Hudson that the Committee rise; carried 89 to 34.— In the House Bayly offered a resolution the previous Question was called but Joseph J McDowell of Ohio, said he hoped, the gag would not be resorted to in this case. McKay offered a simple resolution of thanks, which after some slight Amendment was adopted unanimously and the House adjourned— Christopher Hughes, Robert C. Winthrop George Ashmun and William. A. Moseley dined with us— The weather oppressively warm

29. V.  Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, but I could give him no cheering intelligence, and had not seen the Secretary of the Navy, since he was here last— I received from the Secretary of State, a Letter with copies of my correspondence, with William Tudor junior in May 1822. relating to the manuscripts, of Mr. Ingraham— Mr. Buchanan says, that the four volumes, of the Journals, received from Mr. Ingraham’s widow at Boston are now in the Library of the Department, and that it does not appear, that the four volumes, said to have been left in France have ever been recovered— In the House yesterday, there were, three resolutions passed, one of thanks to General Taylor, his Officers, and men, one of sympathy with the relatives and friends, and one requesting the President to communicate the others to General Taylor and through him to the Army under his command— The three were passed, by one unanimous vote, without call, for yeas, and nays— This morning Armistead Burt offered a joint resolution, for the appointment of a select Committee to consist of three Members of the House, and two of the Senate—to attend the Annual examination of Cadets of the Military Academy at West point on the first of June next, and that the Committee be specially charged, to inquire fully and minutely into the condition of the Institution, all abuses if any, and the propriety of reducing, abolishing, or supporting and sustaining the same, and report to Congress at the present Session— After a short debate, and a motion to lay the resolution on the Table rejected 70 to 105, resolution was adopted 91. to 82, and sent to the Senate— I had not reached the House when this vote was taken— The Private callendar was taken up.— The House refused to reconsider the vote rejecting a Bill to authorize the issuing of a Patent to Charles. G. Page, and Examiner in that Office.— A motion to reconsider the vote rejecting the allowance of the fishing bounty, in the Schooner Florilla, lost at Sea, was again lost, by a tie vote 85 to 85. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, on the Bill from the Senate, supplementary, to the Declaration of War against Mexico, but at the motion of George Rathbun, was laid aside to wait for the printing of the Bill— Then a Bill was taken up from the Senate making alterations in the Pay Department in the Army.— Upon which a Cong debate ensued, till the committee rose and Haralson moved a resolution to close the debate in committee in half an hour after taking it up again, but the House adjourned without taking the Question, on the motion— I was so much oppressed by the heat of the weather that I was obliged to leave the Table at dinner and Dr. Thomas was called in by my wife— I was confined at home the rest of the day— My complaints are occasioned by the premature heat of the weather and some carelessness of diet, chiefly from eating Strawberries—

30. IV—  I continue much indisposed under the prescriptions of Dr. Thomas, but not confined to the House— I enclosed to Mr. D. G Ingraham, the copies of my correspondence with William Tudor junior, concerning the Manuscripts, yesterday received from the Department of State— I wrote also a few lines in the Album of Miss H. M. Chapman which I delivered to her relative Mr. S. F. Chapman—who called at the House to receive them— At the House, the resolution for closing debate, on the Bill making alterations in the Pay Department of the Army, in half an hour was taken up, and modified, to allow two hours, and then was adopted— Lynn Boyd, offered a resolution for the House to meet hereafter, daily, at 10. o’clock A.M. and take a recess from two to half past three P.M. The vote was 71. to 60. not sufficient to suspend the rules, but a majority, which in a few days, will carry the resolution— Some time was allowed for the consideration of Private Bills. That for the relief of Commodore Thomas Ap Catesby Jones, was passed, without taking the yeas and nays, which were refused. After disposing of two or three other private cases, the House went again into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, and took up the Bill to regulate the Pay Department of the Army. A long debate ensued, and a manggling altercation between, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi upon the comparative merits of West point pupils, and blacksmiths, and tailors for Army Officers— Washington Hunt of New York, had obtained the floor, but yielded it for an explanation, to Jefferson Davis who from that time kept a running fight with Johnson till the time for closing the debate, came and Hunt lost his chance of making a Speech— Andrew Stuart, renewed his attempt to get ten dollars a month pay for the Soldiers and volunteers, and Albert Constable of Maryland moved to strike out ten and insert twenty besides one hundred and sixty Acres of Land, which Shelton F Leake of Virginia moved should be located in Mexico After a variety of such Amendments, McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, moved to strike out the whole Bill and insert a very short one authorizing the appointment of three additional Pay Masters to serve as long as the increased number of the rank and file in the Army shall continue— This Bill was reported to the House and passed under the previous question, so expeditiously that Jacob Brinkerhoff sneerlingly inquired, if it would be in order to move that the Committee on Military Affairs should be abolished and a Legislator General appointed in its place. This was a fling at McKay Brinkerhoff being himself, a member of the Military Committee, but McKay took no notice of it— Haralson of Georgia moved to go into Committee again, upon other Bills, reported by the Military Committee but after sundry motions to adjourn and for a call of the House, the motion to adjourn was finally carried—

31. V—  The weather continues oppressively warm, and my debility keeps pace with it— I attended this morning public worship in the Hall of the House of Representatives where in the place of Mr. Milburn the Chaplain of the House a stranger preached from Hebrew 4.16. [“]Let us therefore, come boldly unto the Throne of Grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help, in time of need”— Whether from listlessness, incidental to the state of my health, or from a want of sufficient energy, in the performance of the Preacher, he left not, in my mind, an impression, distinct enough, to remember, the substance, or the drift, of his Discourse, which had at least the merit of brevity. In the Afternoon, I attended at the Second Presbyterian Church where the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached his farewell sermon, the text of which was, it seemed to me, quite singular, Matthew 26–65—“Then, the high Priest rent his clothes, saying, he hath spoken blasphemy, what further need have we of witnesses, behold now ye have heard his blasphemy.” Mr. Smith related the circumstances under which, this saying of the High Priest was spoken, and whereby the Assembly of the Scribes and the Elders and all the Council, pronounced sentence of death upon Jesus Christ, and the argument of his Discourse was, upon the wickedness of rash judgments, and after handling this topic very shortly, he concluded his Discourse, by taking leave of the Society his engagement, having been to supply the Pulpit for a limited time, which had expired— He mentioned, that he himself, was of the Denomination of the Congregational Church, the Society being of what are called new school Presbyterians— Mr. Smith is a very amiable man, and I regret that his connection with this Church is not of longer duration— We had evening visits from Mr. John Healey, Mr. Archibald Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams—

1 IV—  A Captain Gamonskie, a Polish Exile was here this morning, requesting assistance, which I was not able to afford him— I enclosed to W. K. Hoyt of New York, a Pension Certificate, for Mrs. Maria Blauvelt, with notice that the petition of Mrs. Ann Pearsee would be referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, of the House of Representatives, and I accordingly entered the petition, in the Clerks Office, and directed its referrence, to that Committee— At the House David. S. Kauffman, appeared as one of the Representatives of the State of Texas and was sworn in, by the Speaker and took his Seat, as a member of the House— The Speaker announced, the business relating to the Territories as the special order, for this day. Alfred Dockery asked leave to offer, three resolutions relating to Post Offices contracts. But they were not received— Two Bills were presented, from the Committee on the District of Columbia, and referred— Committee of the whole, James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, in the Chair, on Territorial business. The first Bill, taken up, was to aid, in the construction of certain roads, in the Territory of Wisconsin— There were a multitude of appropriations to which sundry others were added by Amendments and after several failures to vote for want of a quorum Haralson, Chairman of the Military Committee, moved to rise, to take up a Bill from the Senate, supplemental to the Act providing for the prosecution of the War against Mexico— Haralsons motion was rejected, and the Bill taken up, making appropriations, for improvements in the Territory of Iowa— As a sample of the mode of proceeding in the House McConnell of Alabama, moved an Amendment for breaking up the running gear of ruin and foul Legislation two-millions of dollars— It passed unnoticed— Sundry other Territorial Bills followed, among which, one, to direct the President of the United States to sell, the reserved mineral Lands, in the States of Illinois and Arkansas, and the Territories of Wisconsin and Iowa— I objected to using the word direct, as applied to the President— Upon which the phraseology was altered— The debate was continued till the Committee rose without coming to a conclusion, and the House adjourned— William. W. Seaton was this day re-elected Mayor of the City of Washington for the two succeeding years—

2. IV—  I received yesterday from Messrs. H. P. and W. C. Taylor several articles of the manufacture of Soap, as a present, with a very polite and obliging Letter These persons are manufacturers of that Article and among those, who are exhibiting articles, from there manufacture at the Fair in this City I answered their Letter this day and accepted their present not without reluctance, but considering it of too small, pecuniary value, to object against it, upon a principle— I was inclined to ask them to receive payment for it, but my wife shamed me out of that fancy and I merely accepted it with thanks— My principle has always been to refuse all presents offered to me as a Public Man, but where the value is very small I thought it would be ridiculous to make a point upon it— It has not always been easy for me to draw the line of distinction— Mr. Jefferson in a Letter to Levit Harris declared his principle to be the same, with that which I have always observed, and in conformity with it, he accepted from Harris a Plaster Bust of the Emperor Alexander, which might be worth ten dollars— At the House, Territorial business, Second day— Stephen A. Douglass, of Illinois, Chairman of the Territorial Committee moved a resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole on the Bill for selling the reserved mineral lands, in thirty minutes after it should be taken up in Committee, which was carried and Armistead Burt, moved a resolution to close the debate at one oclock this day; on the Bill from the Senate supplementary to the Declaration of War against Mexico— Garrett Davis moved to lay the resolution on the Table; which was refused, and the resolution adopted by yeas and nays, 93. to 66.— The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, immediately upon that Bill— Garrett Davis made an hour Speech not so much against the Bill, as against the Executive Administration for having placed General Taylor and his Troops, in the most imminent danger without providing for him seasonable re-inforcments. Whereupon, Burt moved that the committee should rise for a resolution to extend the time of debate—which was done.
