The further consideration of Territorial Bills, was then postponed to next Tuesday, and the time for the debate on the supplementary War Bill was extended to two oclock P.M. tomorrow— Then the House went into committee of the whole again, on the same Bill, and Haralson, and Jacob Brinkerhoff answered as well as they could, Garrett Davis’ onset upon Mr. Polk’s Administration.— After some further debate, the committee rose, a motion to adjourn was rejected and Jacob Thompson from the Committee on Indian Affairs, reported a Bill, relating to the Cherokee Indians.— Joseph Morris of Ohio, moved an instruction, to the Judiciary Committee, to report a Bill adopting the Laws of Maryland for the government and administration of the Dist. Columbia— After some debate on which the House refused to adjourn, then refused a call of the House and then adjourned—

3— V.  I received this day, a Letter, from Charles. A. Davis, of New York manifesting, an opinion, favourable to the repeal of the Tariff, to which he has been recently converted. His argument is, that the facilities of internal communication by the means of the Rail roads afford such advantages, to our domestic manufactures, that they no longer need, the protection of high-duties, to enable them to hold a competition with the manufactures of England I went this morning, to the Department of War, in behalf of Otis Drury, to hasten the settlement of his claim, and afterwards received a Letter from Archibald Campbell with a Letter from the Quarter-Master General Jesup, to Mr. Drury stating the necessity of some additional evidence for the settlement of the Claim— At the House, the Bill from the Senate supplemental the Declaration of War, against Mexico, was immediately taken up in committee of the whole on the state of the union, Tibbatts in the Chair, and was debated, by Joseph. J. McDowell, of Ohio and Charles. H. Carroll, of New-York Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina, and Thomas Smith of Indiana—together with Armistead Burt from South Carolina and Cornelius Darragh of Pennsylvania— The Bill proposed, the appointment of two additional Major Generals and four Brigadier Generals. McDowell of Ohio, moved to strike out two Major Generals and strike out insert one and Robert McClelland of Michigan moved to strike out four Brigadier Generals and insert two, both which motions were carried— Sundry other Amendments, were proposed most of which were rejected the most important of those which were adopted, was an additional Article of War, No. 102—authorizing the appointment of General Courts-martial, with power of capital punishment in Territories beyond the limits of the United States— The Bill was at length reported to the House, with numerous amendments, the previous question was put and carried and about four oclock the House adjourned— Evening visit from Isaac. Hull Adams—

4. V—  I had received a Letter, from Mr. Charles Nichols, requesting my assistance in soliciting an appointment of his Son Elijah Nichols, as an Officer in the Marine Corps— I called this morning, at the Navy Department, but the Secretary Mr. Bancroft was not present. I left with the Chief Clerk, Mr. Nichols Letter and also, a renewed solicitation for the assignment of a Shore station of Navy Chaplain to Mr. Kavasales— At the House Isaac. E. Holmes, Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, asked leave to make a report from that Committee, but objection was made and it was not received— James. B. Bowlin of Missouri asked the same permission, for the Committee on Private Land claims, to which Holmes objected, and that was not received The special order of the day was Territorial Bills, but it was postponed and the supplementary Bill to the Declaration of War was taken up with the Amendments reported by the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— The reduction of the Major Generals from two to one, was adopted by yeas and nays 107. to 64. and that of the Brigadier Generals from four to two, by 108. to 67— A proviso, that at the termination of the War with Mexico, there should be again only one Major General and two Brigadiers, was also carried 92. to 85.— The additional Article of War No. 102 was adopted 108 to 70— E. H. Ewing of Tennessee, asked to be excused from voting on the Bill and was excused, his reasons, not being very efficient— The Bill was passed, 119 to 53. Garrett Davis moved to postpone the special order for him to offer a resolution, declaring that all volunteers, to be raised, are militia, of the States, and that the States, have respectively the right to appoint their Officers; but his motion was rejected 53 to 108. The Territorial business was then resumed in committee of the whole Robert McClelland in the Chair, and after a desultory debate, and the failure for want of a quorum of a motion to adjourn to ten oclock, the House adjourned—

5— IV—  I received this morning a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy Bancroft, returning the Letter from Mr. Charles Nichols, and stating, that the name of his Son Elijah is registered an applicant for an appointment in the Marine Corps and observing, that vacancies very rarely occurred and the applications for appointments, are exceedingly numerous— Mr. Kavasales was again here this morning, and I informed him I had renewed his solicitation for an appointment to a shore station, but I could not flatter him, with much hope of success— At the House Augustus C. Dodge Delegate from the Iowa Territory, moved to go into Committee of the whole, on the Territorial Bills, special order of the day but John R. J. Daniel, of North Carolina moved to postpone the special order till Monday next which was carried— Haralson Chairman of the Military Committee, moved the appointment of a Member, on that Committee in the place of Archibald Yell, who has left the House, with a view to occupy a Military Station in the War with Mexico—said that another Member of the Committee, Edward. D. Baker, was gone, he believed for the same purpose, but not being certain of that, he moved only to fill the place of Mr. Yell— Daniel said he had made a similar motion early in the Session, to fill the place of a Member of the Committee of Claims, but the Speaker had decided that the motion must be made by the Member himself, by requesting to be excused, from service on the Committee Some further objection was made to Haralsons motion which he withdrew— The House went into committee of the whole on Private Bills, Lynn Boyd of Kentucky in the Chair—and this being the first Friday in the month, was one of the days, the fourth Friday being another, when those Bills only, are taken up, to the passage of which, no objection is made, and fifty-five Bills, were reported to the House without objection— There were several others passed over upon objection made by a single Member— In some instances the objection, after being made, was withdrawn, Robert McClelland of Michigan made a question of order, whether after an objection made, and other Bills passed upon, the Committee could go back, to withdraw, objections made— Some two weeks ago, the Committee had sustained the decision of the Chair that this retroaction was in order. but Boyd now decided that it was not, and his decision was not appealed from— Erastus. D. Culver, of the fourteenth Congressional District of New York said he had been informed that at a Caucus of the Democratic Members of the House, it had been agreed that no more Private Bills should be passed upon, at the present Session, and inquired if it was the fact? the Chairman declined to answer the question. Objection was made to 81. Bills. The Committee rose and after two motions to adjourn, and two for a call of the House all rejected, Wm. F. Giles, of Baltimore, moved to go into committee of the whole again, which was refused— Two of the Bills reported from the Committee, were put upon their passage, upon which objection was made to them—a question arose—whether objection could be made after the Bills were reported, without deciding which the House adjourned— Mr. Asa Whitney was here this evening—very earnest for his project, for constructing a Rail-road to the Pacific for the accomplishment of which I assured him of all the support, that I could give him

6. IV—  My Son arrived here, from Boston this morning, with his Son Charles, immediately after breakfast— They left Boston last Wednesday, with his daughter Louisa, with whom they returned to Lexox, at Mr. Sedgwicks. Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, still without assignment to any Station, as a Navy Chaplain— At the House, James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, Chairman of the Committee of Private Land Claims, reported back, two Bills from the Senate, one with and one without amendments, relating to preumptions— This Committee might be called, the Committee of Distribution, of the public Lands.— There is not one Member from New England, upon it, and only one, from New York, South of Maryland—six of the nine are from the States, where the Public Lands are situated, and the Speaker himself is from Indiana, one of them— They have a glorious propensity, to give away the Lands. The two Bills reported by Bowlin, were referred to the committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Garrett Davis of Kentucky, asked leave to introduce a resolution of enquiry of the Heads of Departments, whether their job printing stationary and binding, have been let, to the lowest bidder, according to Law— Objection was made, Davis moved a suspension of the rules, upon which the vote by yeas and nays, was 72 to 66. not two-thirds and so the enquiry was suppressed— Robert. C. Winthrop from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Bill, providing for the distribution of the addition of the Laws and Treat of the United States, published by Littel and Brown; which was twice read, and left on the Speakers Table. Haralson Chairman of the Military Committee, renewed the motion yesterday made to appoint a member, of that Committee in the place of Archibald Yell of Arkansas, who has left this City, not intending to return during the present Session— Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio said that Edward. D. Baker of Illinois another member of the same Committee, had gone off in the same way; both of them intending to raise Troops to go as Volunteers to the War against Mexico. After some discussion on the irregularity of this proceeding, Haralson moved to excuse Yell, from further service on military Committee, which was adopted— The Speaker said that he would have it so entered on the Journal, that it should not be referred to as a precedent, hereafter— Both of these members have gone away, without notice to the House, and without intending to return— This though in direct violation of a rule of the House, and a gross violation of the duty of the Member to his Constituents and to his Country, has become a very general practise, and the motive for it, is as mean, as the practise itself, is vicious— The rule is, “that no member shall absent himself, from the service of the House, without its permission, but if he asks and obtains permission his pay is suspended, during his absence”— If he goes without permission, his pay continues without suspension, and Members absent themselves for weeks, and sometimes for months, and receive pay, as if their attendance had been without interruption— Two or three private Bills, reported yesterday from the committee of the whole House, were then passed, and Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, asked leave to introduce a Joint-resolution to close the Session on Monday the 20th. of July, upon objection made, he moved to suspend the rules, and the vote was 84. to 73. not two thirds— Lynn Boyd, asked leave to make a motion that the daily hour of meeting should henceforth be, ten o clock A.M. the vote on suspending the rules was 111. to 64. not two thirds, but the House agreed to meet at ten o clock next Monday morning— A few more private Bills, were acted upon, until shortly after two o clock the third or fourth motion to adjourn was finally carried— Evening visit from Mr. John Pope, who is going to join the Army in Mexico— I received from the Pension Office two pension Certificates for Sarah. B. Lake, and Hannah Manchester, children of Susannah Borden deceased, widow of Josiah Borden a Seaman of the Revolution.

I attended public worship, with my Son and Grandson, at the Hall of the House of Representatives, Mr. Tustin, was the Preacher, but before the service commenced, a Stranger Clergyman, came into the Hall, and took a seat on the floor of the House, whereupon Mr. Tustin came down, from the Clerks stand, and invited him, to go up with him and take part in the solemnity, which he did and made the prayer, preceding the Sermon, that was preached by Mr. Tustin from Acts 26.28. “Then Agrippa said unto Paul, almost thou pursuadest me, to be a Christian”—and the comment upon the text was as usual, was a reproach, upon the men of the world, of being only almost Christians and an exhortation to the Auditory, to be wholly so— After dinner at Saint Johns Church, Mr. Pyne, read the evening Service for Trinity Sunday and preached from 1. John 5.7—“For there are three, that bear record in Heaven, the Father, the Word and the Holy Ghost. and these three are one.” The Sermon was of not more than ten minutes length, and the Preacher without scruple, declared, his implicit faith in the doctrine of the Trinity— He said, that there was no more, of reason, or argument, against it, than there was against the Omnipotence, and Omnipresence, of God— This is not, the most ingenious expedient, of escaping from the question, and I felt some compassion, for Mr. Pyne, in the necessity under which he found himself, to confess his faith, on the authority of a text universally admitted by all candid Biblical critics to be spurious— He made a lame attempt to explain the meaning, of the three in one, but left it, in all its inexplicable darkness— We had no visitors this evening—

8. V—  I answered this morning the Letter from Asa Grey of Tiverton Rhode Island  informing him, that I had received from the Pension Office, two Certificates for Sarah B. Lake, and Hannah Manchester, but having no authority from them, to receive them, I must request, orders from them, to whom they are to be delivered— Mr. Gray’s Letter to me, does not, assert, any authority in him to receive the certificates, but is merely a statement of facts, indicating the point of evidence required at the Pension Office, to substantiate the Claim, and inquiring, if I could furnish it. I found it, in the sixth volume, of the fourth series of American Archives, published by Peter Force. And upon referring the Commissioner of Pensions, to that authority, he immediately issued the Certificates— My Son and his son, went with me, to the House.— The reading of a great part of the Journal, was dispensed with Lynn Boyd, who had been appointed, to fill the vacancy on the Military Committee in the place of Archibald Yell, claimed to be excused, as being already a member of two standing Committees, on the Territories and on Roads and Canals; he was excused, from service not on the Military Committee, but on the Committee on the Territories, and Kaufman, the new member from Texas, was appointed in his place— This Mr. Kaufman, came to my Seat, and with much politeness, which I returned in kind, introduced himself to me The Territorial business, being the special order for the day, was taken up, in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Robert McClelland of Michigan in the Chair, and a Bill to grant Lands, for the improvement of the Fox and Wisconsin rivers, being laid aside, a Bill to define the boundaries, of the state of Iowa, and to repeal the boundaries, described in the Act of 3d. March 1845— was taken up, and very earnestly debated by Julius Rockwell, Stephen. A. Douglass—George Rathbun, Augustus. C. Dodge the Delegate from Iowa, Samuel F. Vinton, and James. B. Bowlin— Then came a Bill, to enable the people of the Territory of Wisconsin, to form a Constitution and State Government, and for the admission of the State, into the Union— Upon which a question arose, whether it was competent for Congress—to divide the Territory of Wisconsin, so as to form from it more than one State— The ordinance for the North Western Territory had prescribed that that in process of time it should be divided into States, not less than three, nor more than five In fulfilment of this stipulation the states of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, and Michigan have already been formed, and admitted into the Union. The Territory of Wisconsin constitutes the remainder of the North Western Territory— They are all, large States, embracing, from 50. to 65,000. square miles, each— The Territory of Wisconsin is much larger still, and it becomes a question whether the whole of it must be included in the new State—this was not however finally decided— The Bill with some others was reported to the House, after which they adjourned to ten oclock tomorrow morning— This evening, we all went to see R Winters Illuminated Chemical Dioramas, in the style of Daguerre—being successive exhibitions of the Milan Cathedral, Belshazzar’s Feast—The destruction of Babylon, with a view of the Tower of Babel, and the Funeral and Tomb of Napoleon—at the Hospital of Invalids at Paris. After our return home, we had an evening visit from Major Graham, Mr. Archibald Campbell, and Mr. Isaac Hull Adams. A political revolution has taken place, in the State of New Hampshire— John. P. Hale, elected to the Senate.

9. IV—  I received a Letter from Archibald Campbell Chief Clerk of the War Department returning the two Letters from Otis Drury which I had left with him, and stating, that the amount due to Mr. Drury, would be transmitted to him this day Also a Letter from the Quarter Master General Thomas S. Jesup. with the same information— At the House, Samuel. F. Vinton now Chairman of the Select Committee to investigate the charges, made by Charles. J. Ingersoll against Daniel Webster for malversation in Office, when Secretary of State, presented the report of the Committee to the House— The appointment of this Committee had been made, at the motion of John Pettit of Indiana, with the avowed purpose of impeaching Mr. Webster; but Pettit, had demanded to be excused from serving as Chairman of the Committee on the pretext, that the House refused to allow them a Clerk, by which means Vinton, had become, Chairman of the Committee and Seaborn Jones of Georgia, was appointed as a Member of the Committee in the place of Pettit. The report was, that there was no ground for impeaching Mr. Webster, and it concluded with two resolutions, one that the testimony, should be sealed up, by the Clerk under the supervision of the Committee, endorsed confidential, and deposited in the Archives of the House, not to be opened, unless by its order, the other, that the report be laid on the Table and printed, and the Committee discharged, from the further consideration of the subject— The report was signed, Samuel F Vinton, Jefferson Davis—Daniel. P. King and Seaborn Jones. Jacob Brinkerhoff presented a minority report, as the fifth member of the Committee, in which report he had introduced, a copy of a Letter from F. O. J. Smith, to Mr. Webster, which was part of the testimony to be sealed up, and kept secret, according to the resolution, reported by the majority of the Committee— Upon this a somewhat testy debate, arose, which finally closed by a motion, to lay both reports on the Table, with an order that both should be printed— Inquiry was made, whether Ingersoll had been before the Committee, Brinkerhoff said he had not and Vinton said that he had not requested to appear before them— Garrett Davis asked leave to make a report, from the select Committee on public printing; but it was refused 72. to 99. The remainder of the day, was occupied in the discussion, of sundry Territorial Bills, and Bills from the Senate, also, on a report, of Samuel Gordon, from Select Committee on the purchase—and distribution of the tenth volume of the Laws—till at last, George. S. Hopkins, moved a resolution requiring the Sergeant-At-Arms Lane, to re-instate, a messenger named Wm. T. Stuart, whom he had displaced, without any sufficient cause, known to the House. This resolution after a hot debate, was adopted by yeas and nays 75 to 46, but John Henley of Indiana, immediately moved a reconsideration of that vote, and then the adjournment of the House, which was carried— We had a small company to dinner as named in the margin, besides whom Erastus. D. Culver, of the fourteenth Congressional District of New York, had been invited; and promised to come, but sent by Mr. Hudson an excuse, being detained by a visit from one of his Constituents— In the evening we had visits from Mr. Theodore Lyman Moody, and Isaac Hull Adams— My wife went to hear the Harmoneans this evening.

10. V.  My Son left us, with his son Charles to return to Boston. I called at the Office of Mr. David. A. Hall, and he took the acknowledgement of the Deed, which we had executed yesterday, and I gave it to Fuller, to deliver to my Son, before his departure. Which he did. They left the City in a train of Cars for Baltimore at 1/2 past twelve at noon, expecting to reach Philadelphia, this evening— At the House, Timothy Pillsbury, appeared, as the second Representative from the new State of Texas, and took his Seat—as a member of the House. Seaborn Jones, from the select Committee on the charges, of Charles. J. Ingersoll, against Daniel Webster, offered a Resolution for printing all the evidence, which the report, of the Committee, had recommended, should be sealed up and kept secret— But objection was made, and the resolution was not received. Thomas. J. Henley’s motion, to reconsider the vote of yesterday, ordering the re-instatement of William. T. Stuart as messenger to the Sergeant-at-Arms. was debated. and then laid on the Table, 85. to 80— John A. Rockwell of Connecticut, had yesterday moved to re-consider, the vote, passing the Bill to enable the people of Wisconsin Territory to form a Constitution and State Government, and its admission into the Union— After some debate the re-consideration was carried 125 to 45. Rockwell then moved, to reconsider the vote for the engrossment of the Bill; which was carried— He then moved to reconsider, a proviso, authorizing the State Convention, to adopt boundaries including the whole Territory— This was also carried. the proviso was struck out M. M. Martin a Delegate from the Territory then moved to lay the Bill on the Table, which was refused, the Bill was passed, without the proviso and sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon Bills, relating to the District of Columbia. The Bill to regulate the appointment of certain Officers, in the Executive Departments of the Government at Washington and for the more general and equal diffusion of such Offices, among the several States, and Territories, and the District of Columbia, was taken up, and debated chiefly upon two principles, one for the distribution of the Offices, according to the representation from the States, and the other, of limiting the duration of the Offices— Ashman moved an Amendment, that the appointments should be made, without regard, to political Party, or Religious Denomination Stephen. A. Douglass of Illinois, made a Speech, somewhat peremptory against the whole Bill which he believed to be altogether impracticable and was answered in a tone equally domineering by George Rathbun of New York and William Sawyer of Ohio who told a lamentable tale of his labors, urging the President, and the Heads of Departments, to turn out, Whig Clerks from their Offices, and appoint, Democrats, and among them numbers of his Constituents, in their places— He represented them, as very clamorous, for the Offices, but he had been able scarcely to obtain appointments for any of them, and he had been obliged, to put his hands in his pocket, and furnish them with money, to go home, after they had been waiting here, two, four, or even six months, in expectation of receiving Offices, and with final disappointment— He said he held, to the doctrine that “to the victors belong the spoils” but complained, that all the Offices, were absorbed—by the States of Virginia and Maryland, and the District of Columbia— Dromgoole, reminded him, that “if the spoils belong to the victors” the State of Ohio, not having voted for the Democratic President, could have no claim, to a share of them. Sawyer replied, by boasting, of his own exertions, in the cause of the Democracy, and said that Ohio, had given more votes, for the Democratic President, than Virginia. The committee rose. Jacob Collamer, reported from the Committee on Public Lands, a Bill further to extend the time, for locating, Virginia Military Land warrants, which Bill was passed without opposition— George. S. Houston of Alabama, introduced a joint-resolution, to institute a Board of Commissioners to ascertain the Amount of Claims, of citizens of the United States against Mexico Referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.— Jefferson Davis of Mississippi presented a remonstrance, from sundry Ladies of New York against a passage in the report of the Committee on the Militia, in the House, made on the 9th. of January 1846—reflecting upon the superannuated soldiers of the Army. Remonstrance was read and after a short discussion laid on the Table and the House adjourned. Evening visit, from Mr. Washington Hunt, Member of the House from the 34th. Congressional District of New York—

11. IV.  At the House George W. Jones, of Tennessee, moved to discharge, the committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, from the Bill for the distribution of Offices at Washington but William. Sawyer of Ohio, under colour of making a personal explanation, made up an issue, with Andrew Stuart, about the number of Democrats, who voted, for raising the pay of the Soldiers, to ten dollars a month, and finished by moving a resolution to that effect— The Speaker declared it out of Order— Jones motion to discharge the committee of the whole on the state of the Union from the Bill for the distribution of Offices, was rejected, and a motion of Tibbatts, to close the debate upon it, in two hours, was laid on the Table, Haralson, from the Committee of Conference, on the Army Pay-Master Bill reported a compromise arrangement, agreed upon by the Joint Committee, which was accepted, 84 to 34.— Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, on the Navy Appropriation Bill Hamlin of Maine in the Chair— A proviso moved by Daniel. P. King, excluding Spirit rations was adopted— Stanton by direction of the Naval committee moved an Appropriation of five thousand dollars for computing, and publishing under the direction of the Superintendant of the Observatory, the American Nautical Almanac, to be calculated, for the meridian of Washington City— A long debate ensued, in which I took a part which terminated in a vote, sustaining, the proposed appropriation. Lewis. C. Levin, moved an Amendment, appropriating for the Construction of a Dry Dock at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, and another at the Pensacola Navy Yard Two-hundred-thousand dollars each— A Long debate upon this till the committee rose— McKay reported, on the Amendments of the Senate to the Indian Appropriation Bill, and a resolution, authorizing the Secretary of War, to refund, to the Governors of States, the expenses, of calling out, volunteers and militia, under calls from General Taylor, and General Gaines, with a proviso, disavowing the Call of General Gaines, without authority of Law. After some debate, this joint-resolution was adopted and the House adjourned— Mr. Healey the Painter and Mr. Hart a Sculptor from Kentucky were here this evening— Mr. Hart, is occupied in a Statue of Mr. Henry Clay— Mr. Healey did not leave the City, at the time he intended.

Healy here and Hart sculptor from Kentucky.  H.R.U.S— W. Sawyer’s personal explanation, and discussion with A. Stewart— Office rotation bill— Army Paymasters— Navy Appropriation bill— Nautical Almanac. 5000.— Navy Yard Brooklyn— Wall under frigate Sabine— Dry—floating and sectional Stone Dock— Philadelphia, Pensacola— Kittery— Indian appropriation bill— Expenses of rotation and militia

12— V—  I received this morning, a Letter from, H. E. Insley, dated at New-York, with a Daguerreotype likeness, of my dearly beloved sister, long since deceased, taken from the Portrait of her, by Copley, which I gave to her daughter, Mrs. De Windt, and now in her possession.— It is a beautiful miniature, and retaining in great perfection, the likeness of the original Portrait, and is one of the most pleasing Daguerreotypes that I ever saw— At the House, the message from the President, enclosing the detailed dispatches, from General Taylor, and his subordinate Officers, upon the Battles, of the 8th. and 9th. of last month, at Palo-Alto, and Resaco De La Palma, were published this morning, in the National Intelligencer, and excluded the reports of the proceedings, yesterday in both Houses of Congress— Haralson, Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, made a personal explanation, in defence of that committee, charged by an editorial paragraph of the Union Newspaper, with neglect, or inefficiency, in making provision, for the wants of General Taylor’s Army— Thomas B. King, from the Committee on Naval Affairs reported a Bill authorizing and requiring, the Secretary of the navy to contract, for the transportation of the United States mail, in Ocean Steamers— The Amendments proposed by the Senate, to the Supplementary War Bill, against Mexico, were considered, some of them adopted, others, disagreed to, and the Bill was returned to the Senate. Robert. C. Schenck, Chairman of the Select Committee, on the invasion by Charles. J. Ingersoll. upon the secrets of the Department of State, made a report, closing with a resolution that the report and record of proceedings of the committee, and all the testimony be printed for the use of the House, that the Speaker be directed to furnish copies of the Documents when printed to the Presi-dent of the United States and to the Secretary of State and that the committee be now discharged from further consideration of the subject— The report was laid on the Table and ordered to be printed Ingersoll himself was not in the House. He and his brother Joseph, having been called to Philadelphia by the decease of their mother— The report of the Select Committee, on the purchase and distribution of the 10th. volume of the Laws was resumed and debated till the expiration of the hour for receiving reports— McClernand, made an ineffectual attempt, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the union, on the Land graduation Bill. Allen. G. Thurman of Ohio, from the Judiciary Committee reported a Bill, concerning Claims, against the United States— Washington Hunt moved to suspend the rules for a joint resolution to give medals to General Taylor, and his Army, but failed.— Andrew Stuart, moved to suspend the rules, for a joint resolution to adjourn the Session on the 24th. of July, vote 87. to 82. not two thirds. Howell Cobb, moved to suspend the rules, for a resolution, to meet hereafter daily, at 10. oclock A.M. Collamer moved an Amendment to adjourn daily at three. P.M. This failed but the resolution to meet at ten in the morning was carried— Brinkerhoff, again proposed a Bill to give ten dollars a month pay to the Soldiers of the Mexican War and again failed— Jefferson Davis repeated the attempt of Washington Hunt to vote, medals, to General Taylor and his Soldiers, and Swords to the Officers but with no better success— Consideration of Private Bills, followed after a Call on the Secretary of War for reports, concerning the Mineral Land on Lake Superior— Several Private Bills were passed and the House adjourned. No evening visitors, I took as usual an hours walk between sunset and dark—

13. V—  I received this morning a Letter from Otis Drury at Boston dated the 10th. very impatient to receive his money. He must have received it the day after or at the latest yesterday. I received also, a Letter from Mrs. Maria Weston Chapman, of Boston, inviting me, to a great Meeting of Anti-Slavery, Friends of Liberty, to be held at Dedham on the 4th. of July next— At the House, Gordon’s report on the Distribution of the Tenth Volume of the Laws, was resumed and postponed and the Navy Appropriation Bill was taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hamlin Chairman, and the debate about Navy Yards and dry docks, recommenced afresh— Lewis C. Levin, modified his Amendment, to an appropriation, for the construction of the dry dock at the Philadelphia Navy Yard. The hundred & fifty thousand dollars; a sectional floating dry dock, basin and Railways according to the plan, recommended, by the Secretary of the Navy in his report to Congress, dated Feb 12. 1844. . . . Thomas. B. King gave notice of an Amendment, to be moved by him two hundred thousand dollars for a Navy Yard, in the Harbour of Savannah, in Georgia. W. H. Brockenbrough of Florida gave notice that he should move for an appropriation of two hundred thousand dollars, for a dry dock at Pensacola Navy Yard— Jacob Brinkerhoff intruded upon this debate a new argument for increasing the pay of the Soldiers, Winthrop called him to order the Chairman, Hamlin, said it was undoubtedly, out of Order, but so uniformly the practise, that he decided, the gentleman from Ohio, Brinkerhoff, was in order— Ashmun appealed, and after some altercation this decision was confirmed by the Committee 76. to 56. and Brinkerhoff concluded his argument for the increase of the pay of the Soldiers, in a debate upon a construction of dry docks, David. S. Reid of North Carolina moved the committee to rise, which was carried and then he moved to close the debate in committee of the whole at 1/2 past 2. oclock, this day— John. A. Rockwell, moved to lay the resolution on the Table, to take up Private Bills— Several votes were taken, without a quorum, Lynn Boyd was in the Speakers Chair— The majority grew . . .thy at the repeated lack of a quorum, George. W. Hopkins, wisely inquired if members who did not vote though in their Seats might not have a vote of censure passed upon them, but he had not discovered how a vote of censure could be passed without a quorum to pass it. Chapman of Alabama was ferocious for censuring, with the severest displeasure of the House any non-voting Member and was ready, to demand of the Chair that if the majority of a quorum, voted to second the Previous Question, to decide that the question was carried in the affirmative— Preston King moved a call of the House, and asked for the yeas and nays; they were ordered, and a call was made though King offered to withdraw it, and the House refused it 53. to 115. There were all this time 168. members in the House 112 being a quorum— John A. Rockwell moved again to go into Committee of the whole on Private Bills—69. to 107.—lost. Reids resolution to close the debate, at half past two was finally carried and Hamlin resumed the Chair on the Navy Appropriation Bill— Henley moved to strike out the Appropriation, on the Navy Yard at Memphis, Tennessee—which brought up a blast against all the Navy Yards Darragh of Pennsylvania moved $50000. for completing the Marine Hospitals commenced at Pittsburgh, Louisville, and Cleaveland, to which Crozier of Tennessee, added Paducah— But they were all rejected— There was a proviso attached to the item for the pay of the Marine Corps, that no payment shall hereafter be made to the Colonel or any other Officer of the Marine Corps. by virtue of a Commission of Brigadier General by Brevet R. C. Winthrop moved to strike it out; but failed 57. to 84. Isaac. E. Holmes, moved to increase the Corps fifty Sergeants fifty Corporals, thirty Drummers, thirty Fifers, and five-hundred Privates, and moved increased appropriations for pay, provisions and so forth; in all which he failed— Hugh White moved that all Cordage Sail Cloth, Hemp and flax, and armaments and equipments required for the Navy of the United States, should be of home produce— Other amendments, were proposed and rejected— The Bill was reported with the amendments to the House, the previous question was called and the House adjourned—

Letter from Otis Drury, 10 June—had not received his money— Must have received it ere this— Letter from Mrs Maria Weston Chapman Invitation to Dedham 4. July, close at hand.  H.R.U.S— Debate on purchase and distribution of the 10th volume of U.S. Laws postponed. Navy Appropriation bill in Comee. of the whole on the State of the Union.— Levin, dry dock at Philadelphia— Hardin, at Kittery. I. E. Holmes at Charleston— T. B. King at Savannah— Stanton Navy-Yard at Memphis— Appropriations for the Marine Corps— Henderson Brevet Brigadier General— R.C. Winthrop— Brockenbrough and Pensacola— Numerous amendments rejected— Bill reported to the house. I. E. Holmes moves previous question— Adjourned

14.— V— At the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning I heard the Revd. Mr. Anderson—an Orthodox Clergyman, from Salem, Mass. preach from Hebrews, 12. 2— “Looking unto Jesus, the author, and finisher, of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him, endured the cross, despising the shame and is set down, at the right hand of the Throne of God”— The discourse, was a very earnest exhortation, to the preachers Auditory to take the example of Christ, for their imitation with an ingenious argument, that the crosses and persecutions, which may be endured by them and of which they must despise the shame, will themselves be the very sources of the joy, set before them, in a future life which is very conformable to the reasoning of the Apostle in the sequel of the Chapter— Mr. and Mrs. Christopher. Pierce Cranch the latter of whom was Elizabeth De Windt, are here upon a visit to his Father. I went over to his house, and took up Mrs. Cranch, who came home with me, and they dined with us., and spent the day— Their usual residence now, is at New York, and I believe he has abandoned his profession as a preacher and taken up that of a painter— They propose to visit Italy in the course of the Summer— In the afternoon, at Saint John’s Church, Mr. Pyne read the evening Service, for the first Sunday after Trinity, and preached, from 1. Corinthians 7.31. the latter clause of the verse, “For the fashion of this world passeth away.” At the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, now destitute of a Pastor a Mr. Craighead from Pennsylvania preached morning and Evening— I did not hear him, but attended at the Church at four oclock in the afternoon the usual time of the service there, but retired on observing that the Communion was about to be administered— The preacher had not arrived This Church is once more a flock without a shepherd.

15. IV.  Mr Thomas. H Hopkins was here this morning, and referred to a note which he had written me, on the 28th. of last month inquiring for Mr. Wm. K. Hoyt what had been done by the Commissioner of Pensions concerning the Claim of Mrs. Maria Blauvelt— I told him that on the day after I received his note, the 29th. of last month, I had enclosed to Mr. Hoyt a Pension Certificate for Mrs. Blauvelt and that I had since then recd. a Letter from Mr. Hoyt informing me, that she died on that same 29th. day of last month. I answered the Letter of W. W. Story a Son, of the late Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States, Joseph Story, who is about preparing, a Biography of his Father, and inquires of me, for any correspondence, I may have had with him— At the House, Lewis C. Levin, of Philadelphia, by a personal, explanation, complained of an attack upon him in the Union newspaper by one John. S. Gilbert, charging him, with offering to speculate in partnership, in sectional, floating, dry and stone docks. The Navy Appropriation Bill was finally passed 191. to 2. but the five thousand dollars for an American nautical almanac, the Philadelphia dry-dock, and sundry Navy Yards, were struck out, leaving nothing, but a rope walk, at Memphis Tennessee. The Bill appropriates, seven millions seven-hundred and forty one thousand, eight hundred and forty two dollars, Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Howell Cobb Chairman. McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, called up the Tariff Bill— Orvil Hungerford of the 19th. Congressional District of New York offers a substitute for the whole Bill.— A message was received from the President. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Erastus D. Culver of the 14th. Congressional District of New York made an hour Speech, keen and bitter against the Mexican War. A resolution was adopted to close the debate on the Indian Appropriation Bill, at 2. P.M. tomorrow— This evening Mr. Charles Phillips, Secretary of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, called on me, with an introductory Letter from Mr. Daniel M. Barringer, member from the 2d. Congressional District of that State who gave me, the promised Copy, of my Father’s “Thoughts on Government”—now in possession of that Society— He also left with me, unintentionally a Memorial to Congress, from that Historical Society

16— V—  I answered the Letter from Asa Gray, and enclosed to him two Pension Certificates, for Sarah. H. Lake, and Hannah Manchester, and I went with Levi Lovering to the Pension Office, and left him there, with two Pension Claims, one for Elizabeth McFarland widow of Walter McFarland and one for Lovering himself and his sister children of Jessy Lovering a Soldier of the Revolution.— I called on my way to the House, at Plumbe’s Gallery where a Daguerreotype Likeness of me, was taken, for Mr. Williams the Swede, from Cincinnati. At the House Joseph. J. McDowell of Ohio moved a suspension of the rules to offer three resolutions against the Treaty now before the Senate for the settlement of the Oregon Boundary— The suspension was refused 27. to 115— George W. Hopkins asked leave to give notice of a resolution that no motion should during the remainder of this Session be entertained for a suspension of the rules, unless seconded by a majority of the Members present; but his notice was not received— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Howell Cobb Chairman, Senate’s Amendments to the Indian Appropriation Bill, were taken up, and Timothy Pillsbury the new member from Texas, made an hour Speech, to settle the Boundary of the State, at the Rio Grande— Alexander Stephens of Georgia made a pungent hour Speech against the Mexican War— He was answered, with equal tartness by Shelton F. Leake of Virginia, Wm. L. Yancey of Alabama, and John. A. McClernand of Illinois. The hour of two came, and the voting of commenced, till the committee rose, Haralson, from the Committee of Conference, on the disagreement of the two Houses, upon the Supplementary Bill, to the declaration of War against Mexico, reported a compromise, which after some debate, was accepted by the House, and the Bill was passed 94. to 54. The Amendments, of the Senate to the Indian Appropriation Bill, were then resumed, and further discussed, without conclusion till the House adjourned— I gave to Mr. Barringer the memorial, from the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, which Mr. Charles. Phillips had inadvertantly left with me.—

Williams, a Swede from Cincinnati— I went with Levi Lovering to the Pension Office, He has two pension claims, one for Elizabeth M’Farland widow of Walter M’Farland and one for himself and his sister children of Jesse Lovering. Left him with his documents at the Pension Office— Plumbe’s Gallery— Daguerrotype taken for Williams the Swede from Cincinnati— Letters to Asa Gray, enclosing two pension certificates for Sarah B. Lake and Hannah Manchester— HR.U.S. Joseph J. M’Dowell of Ohio moved a suspension of the rules to offer three Resolutions against the Treaty for the settlement of the Oregon bounary now before the Senate— Suspension of the rules refused 27 to 115— G. W. Hopkins asked leave to give notice of a resolution that no motion should during the remainder of this session be entertained for a suspension of the rules, unless seconded by a majority of the members present— Not received. Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Howell Cobb in the Chair— Indian appropriation bill— T. Pilsbury from Texas—hour speech. Alexander Stephens of Georgia, hour speech against the War.— Shelton F. Leake of Virginia hour speech in reply.— William L. Yancey of Alabama, and John A. M’Clernand of Illinois same and same— Committee rose— Haralson from the Committee of Conference on the supplementary war bill against Mexico repeated that the house should recede from the amendments to which the Senate had signed. Report after some debate accepted 94 to 54— Senate’s amendments to the Indian appropriation bill resumed and further debated till the adjournment— I gave D. M. Barringer a Memorial from the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina to Congress which Mr Charles Phillips had left with me.

I answered the Letter of Mrs. Maria Weston. Chapman, and declined the invitation to attend the meeting at Dedham on the next 4th. of July, being detained here upon the Public Service— Levi Lovering was here, He needs some further evidence, to substantiate his Claims at the Pension Office, and must go home to obtain it, at Canaan in the state of New York. But without absolutely begging he told me he was so poor, that he had not money to get home and I lent him ten dollars, which he promised to repay within three weeks— He said he was intending, to remove back to Hopkinton or Holliston Mass, where he originally lived— At the House, Daniel Pope King, rose and said this was the anniversary, of the Battle of Bunker’s Hill, for which reason he wished to call up, a Bill, now before the House, for erecting a monument, to General Joseph Warren, promised by a resolution, of the Revolutionary Congress in the year 1777. but the deaf adder turned his ear away— In the course of the day, Mr. King repeated his attempt to call up this Bill, but the adder had not come to his hearing— Gordon’s report, from the Select Committee, being a resolution that the Clerk of the House, cause to be distributed, the tenth volume of the Laws of of the United States, in the same manner as the eighth and ninth volumes were distributed was resumed, but not adopted.— The amendments of the Senate, to the Indian Appropriation Bill, reported yesterday from the Committee of the whole—on the state of the Union, after discussion there are now again debated in the House, and at the third call, for the previous question were passed upon and sent back to the Senate— Three other Bills from the Senate were referred to Committees, and the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Andrew Kennedy of Indiana Chairman, on their Amendments to the Post Office Appropriation Bill— They were all concurred in, and the Bill, was passed. $8500. were appropriated for printing a new edition, 18000. copies, of the table of post offices and Laws and regulations of the Post Office— The remainder of the sitting was occupied in calling the Committees for reports—and between three and four oclock the House adjourned. George McDuff was this day at the thirteenth ballot chosen Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs of the Senate, in the place of William Allen of Ohio—resigned— Evening walk, music in the grounds of the Presidents House, where I met the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith and Mr. Greenhow, with whom, I came out from the Garden and had some conversation about Mr. Benton’s charges against his Book on the History of Oregon—

Answered the Letter of Mrs. Maria Weston Chapman inviting me to a meeting at Dedham on the 4th. of July—declined— Sent Levi Lovering 10 dollars to pay his expenses in going home. Anniversary of Bunker hill battle— Daniel P King made two attempts to call up the bill for erecting a monument to General Joseph Warren—both failed.— The Select Committee on the purchase of the 10th. volume of U.S. Laws reported by Samuel Gordon, a Resolution for distribution to the Members of Congress, as the 8th and 9th volumes were distributed— Indian Appropriation bill. Amendments of the Senate disposed— Previous Question— those . . . moved, and at last carried— Post-Office Appropriation bill— Senate Amendments all concurred in—8500 dollars appropriated for printing a new edition 18000 copies of the table of Post Offices and Laws and regulations of the Post-Office— Bill passed— Reports called from all the Committees— Hamlin from the Committee of Elections reported a Resolution to pay C J. Ingersoll for a contested election of the 26th Congress, up to 15 Jany 1848—and John Taliaferro for 1. Session of 13th. Congress to 2. August 1813, and 2d. Session of 13 Congress to 17. Feby 1814— Laid on the table 113 to 39— Seaborn Jones from the Select Committee on C. J. Ingersoll’s charges against Daniel Webster offered a Resolution to print all the sealed up testimony— Carried after a struggle— W. W. Campbell from select Committee reported a bill to move the Consular system of U.S. read and committed— Report on lake Superior Mineral Lands— Message from P.U.S. With Reports from the Secretary of the Navy, and correspondence between Commodore G. J Pendergrast, and the Government on the Rio de la Plata, and the foreign naval commanders and the United States Minister at Buenos Ayres and the Navy Department— Evening within the President’s house grounds— Revd M. Hale Smith— Robert Greenhow— Oregon Treaty ratified 41 to 14—

Morning visit from Mr. Franquinet, who has a small collection of old pictures of supposed Italian and Flemish masters suspended in the Rotunda— Visit also from Mr. Kavasales, who remains still unemployed. He says Mr. George Rathbun, takes much interest in his favor, and applied in his behalf to the Secretary of the Navy, who promised him to station Kavasales, at Norfolk, but has not done it— I received a Letter from John. D. Mumford of Richmond Virginia, Son of the late William Mumford the translator of Homer’s Illiad in blank verse; of which I have received a copy, as a subscriber— Mr. Mumford requests me, to review the work, and publish my opinion of it—an arduous, and very unpromising task which I am almost equally unwilling, to undertake or to decline— At the House, about half the Journal of yesterday was read and the remainder was dispensed with A bitter and absolutely scurrillous personal altercation ensued between Stephens of Georgia, and Yancey of Alabama, the latter a pious professor of religion, and worthy of the prize among the foulest mouthed slanderers of the House. Stephens is in person a fac-simile of what John Randolph of Roanoke, was, in his youth, but he is a man of talents, of good principles, and gentlemanly manners.— Committee of the whole on the state of the union, the Tariff Bill was taken up, Elias B. Holmes of the 28th. Congressional District of New York hitherto a quiet and silent member, made a vehement, and powerful speech, against the Mexican War— Abraham. R. McIlvaine, of the 7th. Congressional District of Pennsylvania made an hour Speech against the Tariff, after, Seaborn Jones of Georgia had opened the debate instead of McKay, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means— Bryan R. Young of Kentucky took the floor, but the Bill was laid aside and the Navy Pension Bill was taken up. There was an appropriation of $3000 of privateer pensions. McKay moved to strike it out Daniel. P. King and Isaac. E. Holmes, warmly supported the appropriation—The debate was continued till it was found there was no quorum in the House and they adjourned at half past three. I took an evening walk round the Octagon Square

Received a Letter from John D. Munford H.R.U.S. Reading of half the journal dispensed with, Bitter personal altercation between Stephens of Georgia and Yancey of Alabama— Comee of the whole on the state of the Union— Tariff Bill— Elias B. Holmes 28th Congressional District of New-York speech against the Mexican War Abraham R. M’Ilvaine 7th. Congressional district of Pennsylvania Speech against the Tariff-bill.— Speech first of Seaborn Jones of Georgia instead of MKay.— Bryan R. Young of Kentucky took the floor— Comee rose after taking up navy pension bill— M’Kay moves to strike out 3000 dollars for privateer . . . Debate— D. P. King— Isaac E. Holmes, support the appropriation— No quorum— Adjourn 1/2 past 3. Evening walk round Octagon square.

I received a Letter from Benjamin Matthias and six others, a committee of the whig, citizens of Philadelphia, inviting me to a public dinner, there on the 4th. of July, which I must decline as well as those from the City Government of Boston and from Mrs. Chapman for the meeting at Dedham— At the House Brinkerhoff moved to suspend the rules for a motion to print all the testimony in the Webster investigation case— Refused 60. to 77. McKay moved a resolution, to close the debate on the Tariff Bill on Tuesday the thirtieth instant;—laid on the Table— Committee of the whole on the state of the union Cobb Chairman on the Tariff Bill. Bryan R Young of Kentucky made an hour speech, against the Bill and for protection— Robert Dale Owen of Indiana, from Scotland, John F Collin of the 11th. Congressional District of New York, and John. S. Chipman of Michigan, delivered anti-protective speeches. Collin read his from a manuscript— Alexander Ramsay of the 14th. Congressional District of Pennsylvania, made a strong protective speech and especially for the Coal trade— The Bill was laid aside a preemption land Bill from the Senate and two others, were reported to the House—adjourned— Yesterday the Senate advised and consented to the ratification of the Oregon partition Treaty, concluded by James. Buchanan Secretary of State and Richard Pakenham minister from Great Britain.— This day Mr. William. A. Pratt Daguerreon Artist took a type of me, in the Committee room, of the Committee of Post Offices and Post Roads of the House— He succeeded tolerably well, at the third trial, the first and second were failures— I received a Letter of political casuistical inquiries from Jessy Torrey junior of Montezuma Cayuga County New York. 16. June 1846—

I received a Letter from Benjamin Matthias and 6. others a Committee of the whig Citizens of Philadelphia—inviting me to a public dinner on the 4th. of July.— H.R.U.S. Brinkerhoff moved to suspend the rules for a motion to print all the testimony in the Webster investigation case—refused 60 to 77.— M’Kay moved a resolution to close debate on the tariff bill— Tuesday the 30th. laid on the table— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Cobb—Chairman—on the Tariff Bill— Speech of Brian R Young against the Bill and for protection— Robert Dale Owen— John F. Collin of New-York, read, and John S. Chipman of Michigan, per contra Alexander Ramsey for protection and the coal trade, Bill laid aside—pre-emption land bill from the Senate and two others reported to the house—and adjourned—  The Senate yesterday advised and consented to the ratification of the Oregon partition Treaty— Mr William A. Pratt Daguerrean Artist this day took a type of me in the Committee room of the Committee of Post Offices and Post roads of the House— At the third trial he succeeded tolerably well— The first and second trials were failures.— I received also a Letter of political casuistical enquires—from Jesse Torrey junr. of Montezuma, Cayuga County New-York— 16. June 1846.

20—  I enclosed this day an order from the Bank of the Metropolis, on the Merchants Bank, Baltimore for thirty dolls in my favor, endorsed by me, payable to James Cortlan and son in payment for the Refrigerator ordered by Mrs. Adams, and received— At the House, Robert McClelland of Michigan presented, proceedings of a meeting at Detroit, and George. W. Jones of Tennessee resolutions of the Legislature of that State. Samuel Gordon called up his motion to reconsider the vote rejecting the distribution of the tenth volume of the Laws reported by him as Chairman of the Select Committee, no quorum. Seaman of New York moves a call of the House refused. 31. to 96. a straggling debate ensued, till a quorum appeared the rejecting vote was re-considered 99. to 45, and the distribution resolution was adopted 100. to 59. The consideration of Private Bills was superceded, committee of the whole on the state of the union Cobb Chairman. Tariff Bill taken up Cornelius Darragh of Pennsylvania, 21st. Congressional District and William Sawyer of Ohio, 5th. Congressional District, made a Tariff and an anti-Tariff speech on the Mexican War, boundary of Texas, and the Oregon partition Treaty— Sawyer’s lamentations upon which, were ludicrous, A discussion followed between Andrew Johnson, George. W. Jones, and Seaborn Jones, whether Tea and Coffee are necessaries of life, or mere comforts suitable for taxation— Jacob Collamer, moved to lay the Bill aside which was refused but the Committee rose and the House adjourned— Evening visits from Mrs. Madison, Madison Cutts and Mary Cutts— Richard. P. Herrick member from the 12th. Congressional District of New-York, died this evening.

I enclosed this day, an order from the Bank of the Metropolis on the Merchants Bank Baltimore for 30 dollars, in my favour, endorsed payable to James Cortlan and Son, in payment for the refrigerator, ordered by Mrs Adams, and received— H.RU.S— Robert M’Clelland of Michigan, presented proceedings of a Meeting at Detroit and George W Jones Resolutions of the Legislature of Tennessee— Samuel Gordon called up his Reconsideration of the vote rejecting the distribution of the 10th volume of the Laws reported by him as chairman of the select Comee. No Quorum Seaman moves a call of the House—refused 31 to 96— Straggling debate— Rejected distribution reconsidered 99 to 45—and distribution resolution adopted 100 to 59— Private bills superseded— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill, Speeches of Darragh and Sawyer on the Mexican War, the boundary of Texas, and the Oregon boundary treaty— Sawyer’s ludicrous lamentations. discussion between Andrew Johnson, George W. Jones and Seaborn Jones whether Tea and Coffee are necessaries of life or mere comforts and suitable for taxation— Collamer moved to lay the bill aside, rejected but the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Evening visits from Mrs Madison and Madison and Mary E. E. Cutts Richard P. Herrick member fromCongressional district of New-York died.

21. IV.30.  Mr. Milburn Chaplain of the House of Representatives, preached this morning in the Hall, from Matthew 16.26. [“]For what is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own Soul, or what shall a man give in exchange for his Soul.” In his prayer, he adverted, to the recent decease of a member of the House, and his Sermon, appeared to be adapted to that occasion, though the selection of the text, did not seem to me, to be very kindly, selected, for it— I did not know while he spoke who the member was, to whose death he alluded. After the Sermon, I inquired of Mr. Severance, who sat near me, and he said it was Richard. P. Herrick, Member from the 12th. Congressional District of New York— I had seen him in his Seat, not far from mine last Tuesday, and had not missed him from it, since. But he was taken ill that day, and died of billious colick last night— I walked from the Capitol home and after dinner attended at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, where the Revd. Joshua Danforth, preached from 1. Thessalonians, 5 17. [“]Pray without ceasing.”— A close argumentative discourse upon the subject of prayer, upon which, a Christian Divine, would do well, to study the second Alcibiades of Plato, the tenth satire of Juvenal, and Dr. Johnson’s Vanity of human wishes— The sentiment first unfolded by Socrates, concerning prayer, is unfolded, forms the theme, of this moral principle, and it considers prayer, only, as its adaptation, to the happiness of man The Christian views it, with referrence, to the duties, of man, to God, to his neighbour, and to himself. Mr. Danforth’s discourse, was logical, and impressive, with a hardness of piety, charachteristic of him— There was no service at St John’s Church this afternoon Mr. Pyne being indisposed— Walter Hellen left us this day, and went to attend on his mother, who is very sick— There was a very sudden change of weather last night, from heat to cold. My wife and Mrs. John Adams, are this day both ill confined to their beds.— Dr. Thomas was here and prescribed for me, as well as for them— Lieut Thom, and Isaac Hull Adams were also here this afternoon—

My wife and Mrs John Adams are both very ill, confined to their beds; and though not myself confined even to the house, Patience and Resignation are my duties— At the Hall of the House of Representatives I heard Mr Milburn from 2. Kings 20.1.— [“]Thus saith the Lord: set thine house in order; for thou shalt die and not live”— Richard P. Herrick member of the house from the 12th. Congressional district of New-York died last night— I walked from the Capitol home— After dinner at the second Presbyterian Church Revd. Joshua Danforth preached from 1. Thessalonians 5.17 Pray without ceasing— Argumentative discourse upon prayer— Walter Hellen went to his mother who is very sick— Sudden change of weather from heat to cold last evening.— Dr Thomas here.— No Service at St. John’s Church this afternoon— Mr Pyne being sick.

22. IV.30.  I received a rattling Letter, from Christopher Hughes, inviting me to go with him, next Saturday and spend a Sunday with him at Baltimore. He mentions also, his meeting, with James Beatty, now eighty years of age, and who has a super cargo of a ship had seen me, at the Hague in 1796, when he was thirty years of age, and I was twenty-nine— We have not met since— The House met at ten this morning Charles. H. Carrol. of the twenty-ninth Congressional District of New York, in a written Discourse, announced the decease of his Colleague, pronounced according to custom his eulogy, and moved the usual resolutions of condolement, with his family, to attend his funeral, at noon to-morrow, to wear crape thirty days, to notify the Senate, and invite them to attend the funeral and to adjourn to twelve to-morrow— These were unanimously carried, and I walked home— George Green, an original who calls himself Father Green, was here, with papers of two pension claims, and unceasing loquacity I took the papers to the Pension Office and the Commissioner Edwards, promised to report upon them— The Revd. Joshua Danforth came and solicited a contribution for the 2d. Presbyterian Church, at Alexandria of which he is now the Pastor— I gave him five dollars. About sunset, I walked round, north of the Franklin rmy wife and Mary are still confined to their beds— I sleep in the northern upper chamber Dr. Thomas, was here, administering pills and potions to us all— Walter Hellen is gone and my Granddaughter Louisa, and I keep house, tête a tête— She also writes for me, which is a pretty good proof, of her exemplary patience— It is now the thirteenth day, since my Son left us, with his son, Charles, and we have not heard a word from them since their departure—

23— IV—30—  Father Green, was again here this morning, with more Pension claims, for which he is Agent— Bradford Lincoln, brought me a Letter of introduction from Thomas Loring, of Hingham— He is desirous of consulting certain books, in the Library of Congress. I promised to meet him at the Capitol at half past eleven this morning, and there I introduced him to the Library, and to the Librarian Mr. Meehan At my request he was allowed to take out a Book, which was charged to me At noon, the House met, and the funeral service was performed of Richard P. Herrick— The prayer was made by Mr. Milburn, the Chaplain of the House, and a discourse delivered by Mr. Tustin the Chaplain of the Senate whose text, was from 2d. Kings 20.1— “Thus saith the Lord, set thine house, in order, for thou shalt die, and not live”— Nothing very memorable in it—and the preacher relieved himself from much personal notice of the deceased, that office having been performed sufficiently by the Members of the two Houses, who had announced his death— The President was there, with the Secretary of State Buchanan, Secretary of Treasury Walker, the Secretary of War Marcy, Secretary of Navy, Bancroft and the Post Master General Cave Johnson. The Attorney General John. Y. Mason was not present being himself confined by sickness— I rode to, and from the Cemetary with Jacob Collamer of Vermont James Dixon and John A Rockwell of Connecticut— Before I reached the Hall of the House the Speaker had returned, resume the Chair, and adjourned till to-morrow at ten— I walked from the Capitol home— I saw this morning Mr. Grinnell just returned from a visit to New Bedford He was in Boston part of a day, and saw Sydney Brooks, who told him, the family were well, but said not a word about my son, or his family— About sunset I walked out again and was overtaken by a sudden shower, near the west end of the Navy Department where I took refuge on the lower floor. Mrs. McKean who resides nearly opposite the Department, saw me, and sent me, by a coloured boy, an umbrella— The shower was short but a steady rain came on after I got home— I found Dr. Thomas here my wife and Mary still in their beds. The cold weather continues and Mr. Grinnell told me, there was snow yesterday morning at New York—

24. IV.30.  St. John the Baptist’s day—  O! grand Saint Jean c’etait alors ta fête This day is memorable as an anniversary, in my life, as being the day, upon which, in the year 1814, in company with Jonathan Russell I reached the City of Ghent in Flanders— Precisely six months after that day, on the 24th. of December, of the same year, the Treaty of Peace between the United States and Great Britain was signed and sealed, and the six months, which I passed in that City, were among the most anxious days, that I ever passed, as they are now, among the happiest in memory—  What scenes have I passed through since that day, how many recollections, are associated with the memory; of my then travelling companion; now the solitary tenant of a grave opposite the House, which was once that of Governor Hutchinson, on Milton Hill— But I have no time for further reflection, and must now come, to the evil, sufficient for the present day— At the House, McKay moved a resolution to close the debate in committee of the whole on the new Tariff Bill. Thursday the 2d. of July, at 2. P.M. allowing two days from his former motion for the death and funeral of poor Herrick— Tibbatts moved a call of the House— It was carried, 146. members answered and further proceedings in the call were superceded— Ashmun moved, to lay McKay’s resolution in the Table; lost 67. to 98.— The previous question was called and McKay’s resolution was carried 101. to 69. Jacob. S Yost. of the fifth Congressional District of Pennsylvania, reported from the Committee on Engraving to print a map, of the Mineral Lands on Lake Superior; and also to direct the Clerk, to purchase a thousand copies of a map, for establishing a Commercial High way, to the Pacific Ocean. the cost not to exceed twelve dollars— Both adopted— Charles. J. Ingersoll, from the Committee of Foreign Affairs, presented a report on the War with Mexico— The subject had not been referred to that Committee, but as a volunteer contribution, from the Committee— Alvan Cullom, of Tennessee, moved the printing of 2000. extra copies, of this report, which lies over for consideration. He is a Member of the Committee— Charles J. Ingersoll. reported also, from the same Committee of Foreign Affairs, the same Bill, which had been reported, on the 16th. of April 1844. with a repetition of the same report then made— The obsequiousness of the Committee in repeating that report and Bill, is a sample of the overruling ascendancy of Slavery, which takes away the possibility of surprise at any thing— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Cobb Chairman, and the Tariff Bill— Collamer of Vermont, made a temperate, argumentative, and eloquent hour Speech, in support of the existing Tariff and the protective policy— J. H. Harmonson, 3d. Congressional District of Louisiana and Asa Biggs, 9th. Congressional District of North Carolina, followed on the other side— Washington Hunt discoursed an hour in his mild and temperate manner for the Tariff. Winthrop took the floor, and moved the Committee to rise unwilling to speak to empty benches. The vote was 44. to 32. Call of the House was moved and lost— Motion to adjourn—lost—39 to 56. Call moved again and lost— Motion to adjourn, carried 43. to 42 Evening walk round the Garden square— Belated for the music— My wife and Mary yet sick in bed— I sleep in the upper Chamber. Daniel Webster made a War and Revenue Speech this day, in the Senate—

Saint John Baptist. Ghent 1814.  Father Green a daily visitor. Pension claim papers of Eunice, widow of John Shepherd— I took them to the pension Office and left them with Mr Edwards, who returned and reported on them this Evening— Received Letter and rect. from James Cortlan and Son Baltimore— Also slip from Eaton Michigan Eagle Newspaper containing notices of John S. Chipman, a member of the house from that State H.R.U.S— M’Kay moved a resolution to close debate on the Tariff bill on Thursday 2 July, at 2 P.M.— Call of the House—146 answer M’Kay’s resolution carried 101. to 69.— C. J. Ingersoll from the Committee of foreign Affairs presented two reports, one of Reasons for the war with Mexico. Though the War Message was not referred to that Committee— The other a repetition of the Amistad Report and bill— Ordered to be reprinted Comee of the whole on the state of the Union Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill— Collamer made an hour speech for the protective system. Harmonson 3d. Congressional district of Louisiana an insolent and abusive anti-tariff speech— Asa Biggs of 9th Congressional District of North Carolina another— Washington Hunt . . . pleasant tariff speech— Winthrop took the floor. Committee rose 46 to 32. no quorum Call of the house moved and lost— Motion to adjourn lost 39 to 56— Call moved again and lost— Adjourn 43 to 42 Evening walk round garden square. My wife and Mary yet sick in bed— Dr Thomas here— I sleep in the upper chamber— Belated for the music.— D. Webster war and revenue speech in the Senate—

25— IV—30—  I have received from Mrs. Macomb widow of the late Major General Macomb, a kind Letter with the Georgetown Advocate newspaper, containing an Article by her brother the Revd. T. B. Balch, being a narrative of the Wedding Party of Mr. Ward, at Commodore Ap Catesby Jones house in 184. and of his conversation with me then, and there—much embroidered Also a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions James. L. Edwards, returning with harsh comments, Father Green’s papers, of Sarah Clark, and Catherine O’Neil— At the House committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cobb Chairman— Tariff Bill— Robert. C. Winthrop made an eloquent hour Speech, against the Bill, and in support of the protective system— Edward. W. Hubard, of the 4th. Congressional District of Virginia on the other side— John. H. Ewing, Richard Brodhead, and John Strohm, of the 20th., 10th. and 8th. Congressional Districts of Pennsylvania delivered three successive Speeches, for protection, and against the Bill. Lucien B. Chase of the 9th. Congressional District of Tennessee, moved the Committee to rise, almost unanimously refused 7. to 76. but no quorum, and of course they must rise— Call of the House; only 92 members answered; alternate motions to suspend the call and to adjourn; lost— Absentees called 27. excused and then the proceedings were suspended and the House adjourned— Evening walk, round the President’s House and the Departments and met the President, taking also a solitary walk— Mrs. Smith dined with us.

I have received from Mrs Macomb widow of the late Major General Macomb, a kind Letter with a Georgetown Advocate Newspaper containing an Article by her brother RevdBalch—a narrative of the wedding party ofWard, at Commodore Thomas ap Catesby Jones’s in 1842 and his conversation with me then and there, much embroidered— Also a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards returning with harsh comment Father Green’s papers of Sarah Clark. At the House—Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cobb chairman— Tariff Bill— Robert C. Winthrop made an excellent tariff hour speech Edmund W. Hubard. 4th. Congressional district Anti-tariff. John H. Ewing 20th. Congressional district of Pennsylvania whig, Richard Brodhead of the 10th and John Strohm of the 8th. democrats all against the bill and for protection. Lucien B. Chase, 9th. C.D. of Tennessee moved Committee to rise— No! 7 to 76. No Quorum—must rise. Call of the House 93 answered— Motions to suspend the call and to adjourn lost—absentees called 27 excused—further proceedings superseded—adjourned— Evening walk— Met P.U.S. alone.

26.  Morning visit from the Revd. Daniel Baker heretofore minister of the 2d. Presbyterian Church in this City now of Holly Springs Mississippi— He brought me five copies, of his Volume of Revival Sermons for which I had subscribed He earnestly entreated to read the 3d. of the number entitled “Christ the Mediator” which I promised to do, and did— Many years ago, I read the Sermon of Masillion upon the Divinity of Jesus Christ, without assent, to its logic or its pathos— It is no disparagment, to the Revd. Mr. Baker, to remain unmoved, by his eloquence after resisting that, of the Bishop of Clermont— Mr. Baker is sincere, in his belief, and so might perhaps be, the amiable, and most ingenious, French Bishop, whose Sermons, are among the most, admirable and persuasive, that I have ever read. The creed is beyond the reach, of my understanding— At the House, George Ashmun, moved a suspension of the rules, for a resolution, directing the Secretary of War, to settle and adjust by arbitration the dispute between the United States and David Ames of Springfield, about Water power in Mill river—motion lost— Bill from the Senate to organize a volunteer force, and for the appointment of their Officers— Haralson, Chairman of the Military Committee moved to put the Bill on its passage, without referrence to any Committee but the Bill, gives the appointment of the Officers, to the President of the United States and Amendments were instantly started for their appointment according to the State Laws or by the volunteers themselves A debate ensued; the previous question was twice moved and failed; the third time it succeeded, and the Bill passed as it came from the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Cobb Chairman— Tariff Bill— Winthrop closed his Speech yesterday by offering five propositions against the repeal of the Tariff and for an emission of 8. or 10. millions of Treasury notes— To-day Lucien B. Chase, 9th. Congressional District of Tennessee and Samuel Gordon 10th. of New York, discoursed Anti-Tariff and John A. Rockwell 3d. of Connecticut, very ably, in favour of the Tariff— Henry Bedinger 10th. Virginia took the floor the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— I took my usual evening walk.

Morning visit from Revd. Daniel Baker, heretofore Minister of 2d. Presbyterian church here now of Holly Springs Mississippi— he now brought me five copies of his volume of revival Sermons for which I had subscribed— He earnestly intreated me to read the 3d. Christ the mediator— H.R.U.S. Ashmun moved a suspension of the Rules for a Resolution directing the Secretary of War to settle and adjust by adjust by arbitration the dispute between U.S. and David Ames of Springfield about water power in Mill river—refused— Bill from the Senate to organize a volunteer force and for the appointment of officers— Haralson moved to pass the bill without reference to Committee of the whole—but the bill gives the appointment of the Officers to P.U.S— Amendments were moved for the appointment of them according to the State Laws or by the volunteers themselves. Previous question twice moved and failed The third time it succeeded and the bill passed as it came from the Senate.— Comee of the whole on the state of the Union— Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill— Winthrop closed his speech yesterday with 5 propositions against repeal of the tariff—and for an issue of 8 or 10 Millions— Treasury Notes— John H. Ewing, 20th and John Strohm 8 Congressional district of Pennsylvania made Tariff speeches yesterday— This day Lucien B Chase of Tennessee, and Samuel Gordon 10 New-York discoursed Anti-tariff, and John A. Rockwell 3. Connecticut Tariff.— Bedinger 10. Virginia took the floor— Comee rose— Adjourned

27. IV.—30—  I received this morning a Letter from Dudley. C. Evans.— Worcester 22d. of June, containing sundry enquiries, of statistical facts, in regard to the subject of Slavery—Enquiries which it would take me much more time and labor, than I can bestow upon them, to answer satisfactorily— I scarcely know even where to refer him, to the Documents which would contain the information that he desires— I met Father Green this morning at the House, and informed him, of the Letter I had received, from the Commissioner of Pensions, with the Pension Claim papers of Sarah Clarke and Catherine O.Neil— He promised to call next week, to take them back. At the House, McKay moved that the Clerk of the House B. B. French, have leave of absence next week, not to exceed four days which was granted— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Cobb Chairman— Tariff Bill— Henry Bedinger 10th. Congressional District of Virginia, made his hour Speech, in favor of the new Bill, followed by Edward H. Ewing 8th. Tennessee the Nashville District against it.— Then James Polluck, 13th. Pennsylvania, made a very warm hour speech, for the protective system generally, and noticed the representations made, in Pennsylvania; during the last Presidential canvass to persuade the People of that State, that James K. Polk was a better Tariff man, than Henry Clay—and he specially charged the present secretary of State Buchanan, with having practised that deception, in Speeches to the people— This occasioned some stir among the Democracy, but was in nowise surprising to me— Towns of Georgia succeeded Mr. Pollock, and was followed by Luther Severance of Maine— Tibbatts took the floor, moved the committee to rise— Sundry motions for a recess and call of the House, the third or fourth motion to adjourn succeeded 50. to 48. We have not received a line from my Son, since he left us on the 10th. of this month and we have been full ten days on tenter hooks, for fear, of we knew not what, but that some great misfortune had befallen him, or his family. I wrote him a Letter yesterday telling him of the agony we were in, but Isaac Hull Adams told us this afternoon that he had received yesterday a Letter from his Sister, who had returned from New York to Quincy and said she had gone out in the Cars from Boston with Charles and his Son, and the family were all well. This gave us relief from most painful suspense

Received a tart Letter from J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions, returning for father Green the pension claim papers of Sarah Clark and Catharine O’Neal— Also a Letter from Dudley C. Evans of Worcester with enquiries concerning the Statistics of Slavery— H.R.U.S. M’Kay moved that the Clerk of the house B. B.
