French have leave of absence next week not to exceed 4 days—granted— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Tariff Bill— Bedinger for the Bill— Ewing of Tennessee against it— Towns of Georgia and Severance of Maine spoke for and against the Bill— Tibbatts took the floor—no Quorum— Motion to take a recess and for a call of the house failed— Adjourn to Monday, Isaac Hull Adams here this Evening— Had a Letter from his Sister Elizabeth Yesterday, from Quincy.

28. IV.30—  In the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning Mr. Tustin the Chaplain of the Senate preached to almost empty benches his text is John 5.40. “And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life”— It was not altogether easy to refrain from a smile upon hearing this text and seeing not one third of the seats of the Members of the House occupied— Mr. Tustin however was in nowise disconcerted at the prospect, but delivered a discourse not according to the severe doctrine, of the Old Presbyterian School, which allows, no free will to man no capacity to work out his own salvation but on the contrary urging earnestly from the text, that it implied, the power of exercising the will, in every individual, by making it a charge upon his Auditory that they would not exercise it— A charge which could of course, have no application to them, if they were denied the power. Mr. Tustin has one advantage, in performing the Religious Services, in the Hall of the House on Sundays, he can set the time, for singing the Hymn, and can sing himself, even if he has no hearer to join in making melody. Other preachers in that place, frequently have not the same power and the singing is entirely omitted— Mr. Tustin gives out two lines at a time, and then sets the time, usually followed by a few of the hearers. After dinner at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, Mr. Charles H. Nourse, a Licentiate of the Presbytery of this District, preached, from Luke 12.8. “Also I say unto you, whosoever shall confess me, before men, him shall the Son of man also confess, before the Angels of God.” 9. “But he, that denieth me before men, shall be denied before the Angels of God”— Mr. Nourse is not a young man nor was there any thing very remarkable in his discourse. We had rain all the evening, and my wife and Mary are still confined to their chambers—

At the Hall— H.R.U.S. Mr Tustin preached from John 5.40. empty benches.— Afternoon at 2d. presbyterian church Revd. Charles H. Nourse preached from Luke 12.8.9. Rain all the Evening— My wife and Mary still confined to their beds.

29. IV.30.  I received some days since a Letter from George Bartol junior, dated Boston, in behalf of Captain Peter Flowry, a man, who has been tried and convicted of being engaged in the African Slave Trade, not of the offense punishable by death, of which I have no doubt he was guilty but of one of the minor offenses, for which he is under sentence of imprisonment for a term of years.— This day I received a second Letter, from Mr. Bartol, but pause before answering either of them. Imprisonment, is a penalty not too severe, for Captain Flowry, nor can I interfere in his favor however desirous of releaving any human being, from that condition— At the House James Thompson of Pennsylvania, moved to take a daily recess of two hours, during the debate on the Tariff Bill. George S. Houston of Alabama moves as a substitute, that it shall not be in order to move the committee to rise, before seven P.M. which was carried and the House sat till that hour. The House went immediately into committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Cobb in the Chair John W. Tibbatts 10. Kentucky. W. W. Payne, 4. Alabama, and James. A. Sedden 6. Virginia thundered in succession, against protection and excepting Tibbatts for the Bill; Charles Hudson 5. Massachusetts made a sound and judicious speech in support of the existing Tariff of 1842. Charles Goodyear 21. New York argued in favor of the substitute for the Bill of the Committee offered by his Colleague Hungerford. Kaufman the new member from Texas descanted, in honor of the War against Mexico, I left him speaking and between four and five came home, dined, and on returning to the House found John Blanchard 17. Pennsylvania closing a speech for protection and the Tariff of 1842. Then followed Orvil Hungerford 19. New York, who read a Speech in support of his own Bill and against that supported by the committee of Ways and means.— Henry J. Seaman 2. New York made a Commercial Speech against the Bill— James Dixon 1. Connecticut took the floor at seven P.M. the committee then rose and the House adjourned. I received this day a few lines from my Son covering a memorial from the Mass. Historical Society to Congress, and I breath

I have received two Letters from George Bartol junr at Boston, soliciting my advice to obtain the release from prison of Captain P. Flowry convicted of Slave trading— H.R.U.S. James Thompson moves for a daily recess of 2 hours during the debate on the Tariff bill— George S. Houston of Alabama moves as a substitute that it shall not be in order to move the Committee to rise before 7. P.M— Carried, and the house sat till 7. P.M. Tibbatts, of Kentucky Payne of Alabama and James A Seddon 6 Virginia made speeches for the bill— Hudson for the Tariff of 1842. Charles Goodyear 21 New York for Hungerford’s substituteKaufman of Texas in honour of the war against Mexico— Between 4 and 5 I came home, dined, and returned to the house, found John Blanchard 17 Pennsylvania speaking for protection and the tariff of 1842— Hungerford 19 New-York read a speech in support of his own bill, and against that reported by the Committee of Ways and Means. Henry J. Seaman 2. New-York spoke against the Bill— James Dixon 1. Connecticut took the floor at 7. P.M. Committee rose— Adjourned

30. IV.30.  I answered the invitation of Benjamin Matthias and six others of a Committee of the Whig Citizens of Philadelphia to a Public Dinner there next Saturday the anniversary of Independence, which I declined, owing to the necessity of my attendance on Public duties here— At the House, the only business, transacted, was in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Cobb Chairman, and the Tariff Bill— Dixon of Connecticut led off, with a very good hour speech, for a Tariff of protection— Jacob Brinkerhoff 11. Ohio made a blustering speech, professing plain talk and telling what Ohio will do, and what she will not do; what he will do, and what he will not do; for example he will not vote for this Bill, whereupon, I whispered to my neighbour Hugh White yes he will, I know him of old. I heard him make precisely such a brag against the annexation of Texas, and then I heard him vote for it; he will do the same now— Thomas H. Bayly 7. Virginia made an Accomac anti-protection speech of an hour. John H McHenry 2. Kentucky an hour speech for protection, Wm. L Yancey 3. Alabama, read Pennsylvania, out of the ranks of Democracy, Bannon. G. Thibaudaux 2 Louisiana pleaded for protection duties upon La sugar— I took Christopher Hughes to his lodgings at Colemans. Winthrop invited me to dine at his lodgings. I engaged for to-morrow then came home, dined and returned to the House— While I was absent, George. P. Marsh of Vermont, made a beautiful protection Speech of an hour, which I lost, but by way of compensation heard Charles. S. Benton 17. New York. read a very dull Anti-tariff speech, and Henry S. Clark 8 North Carolina deliver from memory one equally dull on the same side— James Thompson 23. Pennsylvania replied to Yancey and at 7. P.M. I came home in floods of rain—

I received yesterday a few lines from my Son covering a memorial from the Massachusetts Historical Society to Congress and I breathe freely again— This day I answered the invitation of Benjamin Matthias and a Committee of whigs of Philadelphia to a public dinner there, on the anniversary 4. July declined. H.R.U.S— James Dixon 1. Connecticut. Tariff hour Speech—very good— Jacob Brinkerhoff, 11. Ohio Plain talk— Tells what Ohio will do, and what she will not do— What he will and what he will not do—he will not do—he will not vote for this bill? I whispered to my neighbour Hugh White—he will Thomas H. Bayly 7. Virginia— Anti-protection— John H. M’Henry 2. Kentucky. Protection— William L. Yancey 3. Alabama—read Pennsylvania out of the ranks of Democracy— Bannon G. Thibodaux 2. Louisiana protection for sugar. I took C. Hughes to Coleman’s— R. C. Winthrop invited me to dine at his lodgings— I engaged for to morrow— I came home, dined and returned.— George P. Marsh had made while I was absent a beautiful protection speech—but I heard part of an anti-tariff speech read by Charles S. Benton 17. New-York— Henry S Clarke 8. North-Carolina took the same— Timothy Jenkins 20 New-York, the other side— James Thompson 23. Pennsylvania Erie District replied to Yancey’s excommunication and at 7. P.M the house adjourned— I came home in torrents of rain which continued all night—

1. IV–30.  I have received from Joseph Sturge, from Birmingham, England, a Letter in reply, to my Letter, of the 11th. of April, to him. It is dated the 6th. of this present month, since which, the Oregon Treaty, has superceded all necessity, for further correspondence, on that subject between him and me I received also a Letter from J. D. Reymert, dated at Boston 29 June inclosing a number of Engravings of Articles of Iron Manufacture, and a Catalogue of such articles, sold, by Wm. and C. Young, Manufacturing Iron Mongers and wire Merchants No. 123. High St. Edinburg and Glascow. Mr. Reymert is a Member of that House and recommends J. P. Robinson Esqr. as their Agent, in Boston. He encloses also Cards of the House and of J. P. Robinson He says they have received great encouragement, from several of the first Gentlemen, of the State and are using their endeavours for the extension of their business in this Country, and have for that purpose established several Agencies in the different principal Cities— I answered an invitation from E. B. Edwards Chairman of a committee of Whig Citizens of the County of Philadelphia, to a public Dinner on the Anniversary day next Saturday, declining as I had done to the invitation from the Whigs of the City of Philadelphia— At the House the debate on the Tariff Bill in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, again absorbed the day— James Thompson 23. Pennsylvania, finished his reply to Yancey whose excommunication from the Democracy he resented with much worthy indignation— R. M. T. Hunter 8. Virginia, hammered out, a common place, invective against protection and the tariff of 1842. R. Toombs. 8. Georgia made a pleasant, protection, tariff Speech. W. W. Wick of Indiana, a Speech on the other side. He said he was called by his Constituents, Billy Wick, and had once been a bit of a Federalist himself and was as honest then as he is, now which I readily believe: but now he was better informed. Charles H Carroll, 29. New York, supported the tariff of 1842. and opposed the Bill— But David Wilmot 12. Pennsylvania, delivered a vehement Anti-tariff invective; immediately succeeded by Felix G. McConnell 1. Alabama to the same time “par nobile fratrum”— I left him speaking, and went and dined with Mr. Winthrop, Mr. & Mrs. Grinnell and the party at Mrs. Whitwells— It was passed six when I returned to the House where I found, Daniel M. Barringer, 2. North Carolina, speaking against the Bill, and in favor of the Tariff of 1842. Orlando. B. Ficklin 3. Illinois, and Joshua F Bell, 4. Kentucky, alternated for and against the Bill. Between 8. and 9. O’clock. Thomas Perry, 2. Maryland. took the floor, when wearied out, I left the House— I found my carriage, was not at the door, and making a mis-step, from the entrance of the Hall, I fell, and struck the left knee-pan, slightly bruising it, but not so as to disable me from walking— On coming out from the Capitol I met Thomas Dumphy with the carriage in which I returned home— Gardiner Fuller, our Coachman, left us yesterday returning to Boston, with his wife who is in the last stage of Consumption— I settled with him, for his wages, and took his receipt in full— I called this morning at the Bank of Washington for a Dividend, on City Corporation Six per cents but they had not received it from the City Hall—

Letter from Joseph Sturge, Birmingham . . .  Letter from J. D. Reymert Boston 29. June of the house of William and Charles Young Ironmongers and wire Merchants Edinburgh and Glasgow, recommends J. P. Robinson . . . agent at Boston— With cards, catalogue and engravings of iron and wire articles.  H.R.U.S— Tariff Bill in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Cobb Chairman James Thompson of Pennsylvania closed his tariff speech and reply to Yancey’s excommunication— Robert M. T. Hunter followed against the Tariff— Then Toombs of Georgia for it. Then Billy Wick of Indiana, bitter upon Brinkerhoff the Ohio braggart. Charles H Carroll a Marylander transplanted to 29 New-York a Tariff whig contrasted by David Wilmot 12 Pennsylvania the solitary but serious anti tariff man from that State— Felix G M’Connell of Alabama decent? against the tariff I left him speaking and at 4 PM went and dined with Winthrop and the party at Mrs Whitwells—returned after 6. and found Barringer of North Carolina, speaking against the Bill.— Albert Smith 33 New-York for the tariff and Frederick P— Stanton 10 Tennessee against it had spoken while I was absent.— Barringer was followed by Orlando B Ficklin 3. Illinois, anti-tariff—then Joshua F. Bell 4. Kentucky. Tariff About 9 P.M Thomas Perry 2. Maryland took the floor for the Tariff— I was wearied out, left the house, missed a step in descending from the outer porch, fell prostrate and struck my left knee pan on the stone— Slight bruise Walked out of the yard. Met Thomas Dumphy with the Carriage and rode home.— After I left the house—Root of Ohio, Miller of New-York Daniel of North-Carolina—Hough of New-York, Hampton of New-Jersey, Houston of Delaware and Lewis of New-York kept the house in Session till Midnight when they adjourned to . . . the morning

2. IV—  George Green was here again this morning and I gave him a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions to me, concerning the Claims of Sarah Clark and Catherine O’Neil together with their papers— The Commissioner calls for further testimony. Green insists, that their declarations contain, all that the Commissioner requires, and complains much, of his decision, but he said he must submit to them, and thanked me, for the assistance I had given him on sundry of the Claims, for which he said “he was under a compliment to me” an expression which he often repeats, but which I never heard from any one else. By the word compliment, he means an acknowledgment of obligation— I wrote to Mrs. Macomb a note of acknowledgment and thanks, for her note to me, with the Georgetown Advocate of the 18th. June last, containing the Article written by her brother.— At the House, the Speaker took the Chair, precisely at nine. But there was a call of the House to make a quorum James McDowell 11. Virginia, moved to suspend the rules for a resolution, that after closing the debate in committee of the whole on the Tariff Bill at 2. P.M. this day members offering Amendments—should be allowed, to discuss them by remarks not exceeding fifteen minutes each; but the House refused to suspend the rules. I found Meredith P. Gentry 7. Tennessee speaking for the Tariff of 1842— Cobb the Chairman, next gave the floor, to George Ashmun. Rathbun 25. New York claimed against Cobb’s peremptory decision and Ashmun yielded; he thought that Rathbun would be ferocious; against the Bill which he was, but nevertheless, voted for it, just like Brinkerhoff of Ohio. Joseph R. Ingersoll 2. Pennsylvania, Moses Norris of New Hampshire and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi brought the debate to a close, at 2. P.M. Voting on Amendments then commenced and continued till seven when the committee rose, without concluding and the House adjourned to 10. to-morrow morning—

I wrote a note of acknowledgment and thanks to Mrs Macomb for her kind note with the Georgetown Advocate of 18 June headed with my name and written by her brother Balch— H.R.U.S. Speaker took the chair at 9. Call of the house to make a quorum— James M’Dowell moved to suspend the rules for a resolution, that after closing the debate at 2 P.M discussion upon the proper amendments should be allowed, each member not to exceed 15 minutes, referred— I found Meredith P. Gentry 7 Tennessee speaking for the Tariff of 1842— The chairman next gave the floor to Ashmun— Rathbun 25 New-York claimed it against Cobb’s peremptory decision, and Ashmun yielded— He thought Rathbun would be valiant against the Bill, and he was—but voted for it. Brinkerhoff’s doubler Joseph R. Ingersoll 2 Pennsylvania, Norris of New Hampshire, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi brought the debate to a close at 2. P.M.— The voting on amendments was commenced and continued till near 7—when the Committee rose without concluding and the house adjourned to 10 tomorrow morning— The Senate this day passed by a vote of 32 to 13. the bill which on the 8th of May last the House had passed retroceding the County of Alexandria to the State of Virginia— John Davis of Massachusetts voted for it— Daniel Webster was absent— The Constitution is waste paper— The District of Columbia was a delusion. The link of continuity to the chain of the Union is dissolved and the next step will be the removal of the seat of Government to a Slave State

3. IV—30—  I received yesterday, a Letter from Wm. Tyson, for himself and Jonathan Seaver a Committee of the Society of Friends, requesting an interview with me, to obtain the Right of Way through my Land, near Rock Creek to the Grave Yard of the Society— I agreed to see him this morning, and he came— With his Letter there was a Diagram, of the Land, marking, the Road which is desired for the Way— I referred him to Mr Nathaniel Frye, who manages my real estate in this City and said that I was willing to have a survey made by a competent person or persons to lay out the way and estimate the value of the Land to be conveyed by me and I would execute the conveyance upon such terms as should be decided to be reasonable, by such Surveyor— I receive almost every day, Letters from strangers asking, for Documents, or Autographs or Money, loans from ten to five hundred dolls. I have a Letter from Curtis and Rall Cincinnati 13th. June 1846. making enquiries concerning certain Pension Claims for which I applied to the Office of the Clerk of the House, but no record of them was found— Christopher Hughes, came to the House and urged me, with friendly importunity, to with him, to Baltimore dine with the Society of Cincinnati, there to morrow go to Church with him on Sunday and return here on Monday morning in time for the Meeting of the House. But I perseveringly declined having no feeling for festivity to-morrow. In the House this whole day was consumed in voting upon Amendments, to the Tariff Bill, first in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, by Tellers, and after the Bill was reported with Amendments to the House, by yeas and nays— The struggle to strike out 20. per cent duty, on Tea and Coffee, was successful that to make salt free succeeded in Committee, but finally failed in the House; the fishing bounties, and drawback on Salt, used in the Fisheries were carried in committee and restored in the House— The duty of 20. per cent on salt, was carried by the casting vote of the speaker, but there was a mistake of the Clerk, in counting the votes, and the speaker’s vote was nullified but a re consideration was carried, and the duty of 20. per cent made, a fixed fact all amendments proposing specific for ad valorem duties, were rejected— The new Bill levies 100 per cent upon spirituous liquors increased from 75. reported in the Bill of the Committee. Then came classes of Articles with forty, thirty, twenty, fifteen, ten, and five per cent— The Bill was finally passed by a vote of 114 to 95. All the democracy whipped in Tibbatts moved the reconsideration to clinch the Bill and the democracy sing “io triumphe.” Adjourned at six oclock P.M. over to Monday— Incessant showers throughout the day. I received an invitation from the Mayor and City Council of Boston to the Anniversary celebration, there to-morrow but supposed no answer necessary. The Senate yesterday passed by a vote of 32 to 13. the Bill, which had already passed the House retroceding the County of Alexandria to the State of Virginia— John Davis of Massachusetts voted for it Daniel Webster was absent. The Constitution of the United States is waste paper, and the District of Columbia was a delusion. The link of continuity to the Chain of this Union is shivered to atoms, and the next step will be the removal, of the Seat of Government to a Slave State— Notwithstanding the South Carolina slave monger John. C. Calhoun assured the Senate, there was no sort of danger of that, for it was proposed at the Memphis Convention and answered by a universal shout, No

I receive almost every day Letters from entire Strangers, asking for documents, or autographs or money.— I have a Letter from Curtis and Rall, Cincinnati 13. June 1846 making enquiries concerning certain pension claims, for which I applied to the Office of the Clerk of the House without success. C. Hughes urged me to go with him to morrow to Baltimore dined with the Society of Cincinnati and go with him to Church on Sunday but I declined— H.R met at 10— The whole day was consumed in voting upon amendments first in Committee of the whole by tellers and after the bill was reported with amendments to the house by yeas and nays— The struggle to strike out 20 per Cent on tea and Coffee was successful—that to make salt free finally failed fishing bounties abolished and restored— Casting vote of the Speaker against freedom of Salt— Mistake of counting votes— Reconsideration 20 per cent on salt— All amendments proposing specific for ad valorem duties rejected—100 per cent for spiritous liquors—final vote on the bill 114 to 95— All the democracy whipped in— Tibbatts moved the reconsideration to clinch the bill Democratic Io Triumphe— 6. O Clock P.M. adjourned over to Monday— Rains incessant. Invitation from the Mayor and City Council of Boston to the Anniversary celebration there to-morrow— I cannot attend— Answer I suppose unnecessary.

4. IV—30—  Independence Day—  Seventy years since that day have passed. This from the time of the song of Moses is the average limitation of the life of man— The Pathé Celebrations recommended, and foretold by my Father, in his Letter to my mother of the 3d. July 1776. have been constantly held, and are still continued, throughout the Land. But in a succession of Anniversaries of a glorious day there seem in the process of time days of a far different character The 4th. of July has been made to me, by more than one incident, the saddest day of the year and among them is, that 20. years from this day it was the day of my Father’s death To others I need not refer— But yesterday was a day, of which I would gladly blot out the memory from the record of my life. In contemplating the future and approaching fortunes of my Country— This day was itself passed in comfortable tranquility, diversified by friendly visits from Mr. & Mrs. J. J. Crittenden and Mr. & Mrs. Joshua. F. Bell of Kentucky Mr. & Mrs. Kaufman of Texas, Mr. Wm. A Moseley of Buffalo, New York and Capt. John C. Casey in the evening— Mr. Nahum Capin of Boston was also here, with a Prospectus for the publication of a periodical Journal of Statistics; for which I subscribed— Dr. John M. Thomas, was here and informed us, of the sudden death of Mrs. Julia Maria Dickinson Tayloe, wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, of this City. She fell in a fit, upon taking a shower bath, this morning.— She was the only daughter of the late John Dickinson of Troy New York, long a Member of Congress, and with whom, while he lived, and with his family including this Lady and her family, we have enjoyed a friendly and intimate acquaintance

Independence day— 70 years are gone— The average limitation of the life of man. Public celebrations as recommended and foretold by my father were held throughout the land, but not with so much hilarity and bustle as usual in this city— A noon walk for exercise of an hour was my only excursion from the house. The day was showery and sultry Mr and Mrs J. J. Crittenden, Mr and Mrs Joshua F. Bell of Kentucky Mr and MrsKaufman of Texas, Mr. William A— Moseley of Buffalo New-York, and Dr John M Thomas were our visitors.— Nor this nor any other day can ever pass over my head without cordial gratitude to the giver of all good for all the numberless blessings of his bounty thoughout my life, with supplication for the continuance of his mercies, and deep humility at my own errors and sins— A solemn admonition of the frailty and precarious tenure of human life occurred this day in the sudden death of Mrs. Julia Dickinson Tayloe, wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe of this city—in a fit while taking a shower bath— She was the only daughter of the late John Dickinson of Troy New-York, and was a woman of fine understanding, a cultivated mind, engaging manners, lovely temper, and active, bountiful charity— I received the New-York Sun Newspaper of yesterday containing honorary verses upon my name, with the signature of Felix Farley—and a Letter from the Author C. W. Holden

5. IV.30  At the Hall of the House of Representatives the Revd. Daniel Baker, formerly Minister of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church in this City and now of Holly Springs Mississippi, preached this morning from Matthew 28.6. “Come see the place, where the Lord lay”— The subject of course embraced a commentary, upon the crucifixion, and the Resurrection, topics, rather too massive, for Mr. Baker, to handle, without notes— Mr Baker discourses, much as he did in former days, but with more self confidence and more, as one having authority— He has grown fat— The Auditory was very thin, but the President, and Mrs. Polk, were there— About noon Dr. Thomas called, and mentioned, that at 4. o’clock this afternoon, there would be an informal funeral service, at the house of Mr. Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, over the remains, of his deceased wife, and that they would be immediately afterwards removed to the Railway Cars, and transported, to the residence of her mother, Mrs Dickinson at Troy in the State of New York— I accordingly attended, with my wife, Mrs. John Adams, and her daughter Louisa, at the house— A small company, of relatives and friends of the two families were there, and Mr. Pyne, after a short Address, to the Company assembled, read several of the appropriate prayers, from the Episcopal Prayer Book, after which he Coffin, was removed, to the Hearse, and carried, to the Railway Depot, of the Cars for Baltimore— Mr. Tayloe goes, with the remains—also Mr. Hubbard, a Member of the House from Connecticut, a Kinsman of Mrs. Tayloe. There was no procession of Carriages. Major Graham and Lieut Thom, were here this evening

Revd. Daniel Baker of Holly-Springs Mississippi preached this morning in the Hall of the house of Representatives from Matthew 28.6— Come see the place where the Lord lay— Mr Baker discourses much in the same as he did in former days, but with more self confidence and a more authoritative tone. The auditory thin but the President and Mrs Polk were there— Dr Thomas came at noon, and mentioned that an informal funeral service would be performed at 4 O’Clock this afternoon at the house of Mr Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, over the remains of his deceased wife, and that they would be immediately afterwards removed to the railway Cars, and transported to the residence of her mother Mrs Dickinson, at Troy, in the State of New-York— I attended accordingly, with my wife, Mrs John Adams and Louisa, at the house— A small company of relatives and friends of the two families were there, and Mr Pyne after a short and feeling address to the company assembled read several of the appropriate prayers from the episcopal book of common prayer, and the coffin was then removed to the hearse and carried to the Railway depot of the Cars for Baltimore— Mr Tayloe himself goes with the remains: also Mr Hubbard, member of H.R. from Connecticut a kinsman of Mrs Tayloe. There was no procession of Carriages.— We returned and spent the Evening at home—

6. IV.30.  I received a Letter from J. D. Clark, Elyria Loraine County Ohio, dated 1st. July 1846. and annexed to which is a Petition from William Ricke of Carlisle Township Loraine Co. Ohio, formerly ofVermont In as he states of John Ricke a warrior of the Revolution, and of the preceeding French War who died 5th. of August 1797. and left him Continental paper, Money Bills to the Amount of 196. 1/3. of which with interest he claims payment— This is the money, funded, by the system of Alexander Hamilton, at 100. for 1. and of which there are still parcel, in the possession of persons, simple enough, to claim payment, at their nominal value, with interest to this day— At the House, Edward. W. McGaughey 7. Indiana, moved an Amendment of the Journal, stating the facts, of the Speakers management, last Friday about the duty upon Salt, first made free, and finally saddled with a duty of 20. per cent— But the Speaker had suppressed all that part of the proceedings, as Null and void.— He ruled McGaughey’s motion out of Order. McGaughey appealed from his decision, Cobb moved to lay the Appeal on the Table, which was carried 90. to 52.— Jacob Brinkerhoff, asked to make a personal explanation, for which, he obtained a suspension of the rules— Explanations from him, W. W. Wick, and from George Rathbun— A Letter from Wick, dated 12. of June, and published in a Western Newspaper, occasioned much diversion— He boasted of his intention to pummel the New York Loco Foco’s and whip them in to the Democratic ranks, which he did and at which Rathbun, was very indignant— All ending in smoke, and a silly epigram from Washington Hunt— Augustus Dodge Delegate from the Iowa Territory presented a new Constitution in that State, adopted in May 1846. Not the same, as that presented last year— It was ordered to lay on the Table. The Select Committee, on the Public printing of Congress presented majority and minority Reports. Upon which there was debate, between Henley of Indiana Garrett Davis of Kentucky and Benton of New York— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Orlando. B. Ficklin of Illinois Chairman on the Bill to reduce and graduate price of Public Lands: that is to say to give them away— A skirmishing debate followed Brodhead, of Pennsylvania, and Hoge of 6th. Congressional District of Illinois, offered joint resolutions for closing the Session, on the 27th. of this Month— A Message from the President was received, transmitting copies, of the correspondence, with the Governor of New York; in the case of McLeod— McKay reported war appropriation Bill and Treasury note Bill Adjourned about four oclock.

I received a Letter from H. D. Clark, Elyria Lorain County Ohio 1. July 1846 annexed to which is a petition from William Ricke of Carlisle Township Lorain County Ohio, formerly of Sudbury Vermont, son as he states of John Ricke, a warrior of the Revolution and of the preceding French wars, who died 5. Augt 1793 and left him continental paper money bills 196 1/3 dollars, of which with interest he asks payment.— H.R.U.S. Edward W. M’Gaughey 7. Indiana moved an amendment of the Journal, stating the facts of the Speaker’s escamotage on the votes for making salt duty free and then imposing upon it a duty of 20 per cent—but he had expunged all that part of the proceedings as null and void— He ruled M’Gaughey’s motion out of order— M’Gaughey appealed. Cobb moved to lay the appeal on the table which was carried, 90 to 52— Jacob Brinkerhoff asked to make a personal explanation, for which the rules were suspended— Explanations from Wick and Rathbun. Wick’s Letter 12. June— Sharpshooting and pummeling of New-York Loco Focos. All smoke— Washington Hunt’s epigram— Augustus Dodge presents a new Constitution of Iowa—adopted May 1846: to lay on the table and be printed— Reports, majority and minority of the select Committee on the public painting of Congress. Henley—Garrett Davis and Benton of New York. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Orlando B Ficklin of Illinois chairman— Bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands— Skirmishing debate— Brodhead and Hoge— Motions for the close of the Session. Message—M’Cleod correspondence, War Appropriations Treasury Notes— Adjourned—

7. IV.30.  Mid-Summer weather sets in, very intense— I received a Letter from Charles. A. Davis New York 3. July, 1846. Some what modifying his new, low Tariff doctrine of counteracting Foreign cheapness of labour, by internal facilities of transportation— A new theory. Also from George. M. Justice Philadelphia urging, the importation of Telescopes, for learned Institutions duty free— From M. J. Grove Fredricksburg Lebanon Co. Pennsylvania—3. July 1846. An Iron monger, enquiring my opinion whether the Tariff of 1842, will be modified— He says if it is, his occupation will be gone— Received also a Sermon of War, by Theodore Parker, Minister of the 28th. Congressional Church in Boston delivered 7. June 1846. The Protestant Quarterly Review, and George H. Coltons American Review with a Portrait of Daniel Webster, both for July 1846— At the House Ashmun moved, to amend the Journal by inserting in it, at full length the Motion yesterday, made by McGaughey. The Speaker decided Ashmun’s motion not in order— Joseph Hoge, 6 Illinois this morning modified his joint resolution to close the Session on the 3d. of August instead of the 27th. this month— The rules were suspended to receive his resolution—on which he moved the previous question— The House refused to lay it on the Table 59. to 105, and the resolution was carried, but Andrew Stuart moved a reconsideration to propose an earlier day of adjournment, say the 20th. inst— Long and desultory debate, till Stuart withdrew his motion for reconsideration and Hoge himself renewed it whereupon the Question was postponed to this day two weeks— The Land graduation Bill was debated in committee of the whole on the state of the Union till there was no quorum Then came a Call of the House and an anarchy of two hours and a half— The call did not procure a quorum. The absentees were not sent for as by the rule they should have been, but McKay moved a resolution that they should be required to account for their absence, at the meeting of the House tomorrow morning—or when they should first resume their seats— The speaker pronounced this motion out of order, but the majority present, reversed his decision— At half past six they adjourned without obtaining a quorum— We had evening visits from Mr. Healey, Major Graham, Lieut Thom, Mr. & Mrs. Stockton with Miss Mary McKnight

Midsummer weather set in— Letter from Charles A. Davis, 3. July 1846. Modifying his new low tariff doctrine, of counteracting foreign cheapness of labour, by internal facilities of transportation. From George M Justice, Philadelphia, urging the importation of Telescopes duty free— From M. L. Grove—Fredericsburg Lebanon County Pennsylvania 3. July 1846 an Ironmonger enquiring my opinion whether the Tariff of 1842 will be modified.— A Sermon of War, by Theodore Parker, Minister of the 28th. Congregational church in Boston 7. June 1846— The Protestant Quarterly Review, and the American Review with a portrait of Daniel Webster—both for July 1846— At the House Ashmun moved to amend the journal by inserting in it the motion of M’Gaughey made yesterday— The Speaker decided Ashmun’s motion not in order— Joseph P. Hoge 6 Illinois had yesterday moved a joint Resolution to adjourn 27. July— This morning he modified it to 3. August.— Previous Question— Motion to lay on the table rejected—59 to 105— Rules had been suspended 98 to 48— Linn Boyd moved the gag on the Land graduation bill at 2. P.M— this day— His motion laid on the table— New debate on the adjournment— Andrew Stewart moved a reconsideration and finally withdrew the motion— Hoge himself renews it. Carried—question postponed to 21. July— Land graduation bill debated in Committee till there was no quorum; Call of the House, Anarchy of 2 hours— M’Kay’s Resolution adopted that the absentees shall account for their absence to-morrow morning. Adjourned at 1/2 past 6. without obtaining a Quorum— Evening visits from Healey, Major Graham and Thom.

8. IV.30. I received a Letter from my son to his Mother dated1846. and accounts for delay in writing hitherto from the excess of his occupations— He has undertaken to by the Editor of the Boston Daily Whig newspaper. I fear too heavy a task. I received also, the July number of Redwood Fischer’s National Magazine and a concise view of Oregon Territory &c by Elijah White. Also Wesley and Putnam’s Library News Letter and Monthly Register of New Books Foreign and American. published on the 1st. of every month at 165 Broadway New York. July 1846. Volume 5 no. 56. This is a very valuable, Monthly notice of new publications— At the House, two hours were again consumed, in reversing the proceedings of less than a quorum yesterday to compel the attendance of the absent Members— The Absentees then, were now the majority of a bare quorum, and they nullified the reversal by the majority yesterday, of the Speaker’s decision that the Motion of McKay, requiring the Absentees to account this morning for their absence yesterday, was not in order— Tibbatts moved to expunge from the Journal, all the proceedings of the less than quorum yesterday— This failed, but the reversal of the Speakers decision against McKay’s motion, was now reversed, and all the proceedings with the call, annulled— McKay moved, to suspend the rules, for him to offer two new rules, one to enter the names, of the Absentees upon lack of a quorum in committee of the whole, upon the Journal, and the other to publish them in the newspapers The House refused to suspend the rules 71. to 86. Robert Dale Owen, asked leave to introduce a Bill to free from postage all correspondence with the Army of occupation— Refused— Haralson, from the Military Committee asked leave to report a Bill granting Land to the Soldiers and Volunteers of the Army, refused Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Orlando. B. Ficklin 3. Illinois, Chairman on the Land graduation Bill— Speeches by Collamer Henley, Vinton, and Gordon, Committee rose at 1/2 past 3. the House adjourned— I took an evening walk and heard the Music, on the grounds of the President’s House. Met Waddy Thompson there and many others.

FahrenheitLetter from my Son to his mother received— [symbols] Received also the July number of Redwood Fisher’s National Magazine— A concise view of Oregon Territory &c by Elijah White and Wiley and Putnam’s Literary Newsletter, and monthly Register of New Books Foreign and American published on the first of every Month at 165. Broadway—New York July 1846. Vol 5. N. 56— At the House two hours were again consumed in reversing the proceedings of less than a quorum yesterday to compel the attendance of the absentees— They were now the majority of a bare quorum and nullified the reversal by the majority yesterday of the Speakers decision that the motion of M’Kay requiring the absentees to account for their absence this morning, was not in order Tibbatts moved to expunge from the Journal all the proceedings of the no Quorum yesterday— This failed, but the reversal of Speakers decision against M’Kay’s motion was reversed, and the proceedings on the call annulled— M’Kay moved to suspend the rules, for two new rules, to enter the names of absentees on the journal, and publish them in the newspapers—but the house refused to suspend 71 to 86. Owen asked leave to introduce a bill to free from postage all correspondence with the army of occupation—refused, Harallson from the Military Committee asked leave to report a bill granting land to the soldiers and volunteers of the army of occupation—refused. Union Committee—Ficklin—Collamer, Henley Vinton, Gordon— Committee rose 1/2 past 3. Adjourned. Evening walk. Music on the grounds of the Presidents House— Met Waddy Thompson.

9. IV.30.  I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis a check for $112.50. received yesterday at the Bank of Washington a Quarterly Dividend with interest on City Corporation 6. per cent stock $7,500.— Nathaniel Chick 86 years old, and a pension Claimant of the Revolutionary and last English War came with a man named Donovan, to ask for my assistance— I took his papers to the Pension Office and this evening received from the Commissioner, J. L. Edwards, a report, rejecting his claim as spurious— At the House Alvan Cullom 4. Tennessee moved to consider a motion made by him, to print an extra number of the report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs the Volunteer War Manifesto against Mexico Lost. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Ficklin Chairman, Land graduation Bill from the Senate, opposed by Samuel Gordon 10. New York, and ably, by Robert. C. Schenck, 3. Ohio—but dragooned along by W. W. Payne of Alabama. The Bill from the Senate was brought just as Schenck finished his Speech, Against that of the House, whereupon the Committee rose the Bill from the Senate was immediately referred to it, the House went into committee again and the Senate Bill was substituted for debate— The object of both Bills being the same, to give away away the Public Lands, to poor men, declaring themselves so, under the name of graduation and reduction of price— Cornelius Darragh, 21. Pennsylvania, opposed the Bill, and Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, Samuel. F. Vinton 12— Ohio, took the floor. John A McClernand, 2. Illinois, moved to close the debate at noon to-morrow— Adjourned without taking the question— The heat was so intense that I was compelled to intermit my evening walk and to languish for my old Potomac Baths, which I must renounce for age—

I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis the draft for 112.50. received yesterday at the Bank of Washington, the quarterly dividend of interest on City Corporation 6 per Cent stock 7500 dollars. Nathaniel Chick 86. years old and a pension claimant of the Revolutionary and last English Wars came with a man named Donovan for my assistance— I took his papers to the Pension Office, and this Evening received from the Commissioner J— L— Edwards a report rejecting his claim as spurious— H.R.US. Alvan Cullom 4 Tennessee moved to consider a motion made by him to print an extra number of the Report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs the volunteer War Manifesto against Mexico, lost— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Land graduation bill— Opposed by Samuel Gordon 10 New-York, and most ably by Samuel F. Vinton 12 Ohio— Robert C. Schenck 3— Ohio, and dragooned on by W. W. Payne of Alabama— When Schenck finished the Committee rose, and received a Bill from the Senate for the same purpose, to give away the public lands under the name of graduation and reduction of price— The bill was immediately referred to the Committee, and there at once substituted for the house bill— Darragh 21. Pennsylvania opposed and Jacob Thompson of Mississippi supported it— Vinton took the floor— John A. M’Clernand 2— Illinois moved to close the debate at Noon to-morrow, adjourned The heat was so intense that I was compelled to intermit my evening walk, and to languish for my Potowmac baths which I must renounce for age—

10. IV.30.  I received a discourse on the Life and character of Sir Walter Raleigh, delivered before the Maryland Historical Society 19th. May 1846. the third annual address to that association by J Morrison Harris; and a Letter from Thomas S. Donoho, of enquiries, about the last line of the Sonnet to the Sun eclipsed and beclouded, on the 25th. of April 1846. Misprinted and made perfect nonsense, in a New York Newspaper. When I began to write that Sonnet at my seat in the House, while the eclipse, was in its passage, Mr. Thomasson of Kentucky passing by my Seat saw me writing it, and observing the words “to the Sun eclipsed” followed by some verses, his curiosity was excited, and he asked me, for a copy of it to send to his daughter— I accordingly gave him a copy, which was seen by a reporter for the Courier and Enquirer and sent to that City— But he murdered the last line by writing it  instead of  And so, it was published, in the New York Courier and Enquirer, and from that, in several other newspapers, much to the amazement of Mr. Thomas. S. Donoho, and of course quite unintelligable to him, and to all other readers— So much for dealing in Poetry. At the House, McClernands motion to close debate on the Land graduation Bill, modified from noon, to 2. P.M. this day, was adopted and they went immediately into Committee Vinton spoke with the voice of the charmer to the adder. Brockenbrough of Florida, R. Chapman, of Alabama, Dodge, the Delegate from Iowa, Stephen Adams of Mississippi all worthy Representatives of the Anglo-Saxon Land-robber, answered Vinton, and of course abused him for his honesty— James. McDowell of Western Virginia had but five minutes to offer a substitute Bill of his own. At the voting commenced Houston of Alabama, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and Darragh of Pittsburgh, offered amendments, to give away the Lands to poor men, maids or widows, 60. Acres each— John. H. Ewing 20. Pennsylvania white or black. Andrew Stuart, moved to give 500000. Acres of Land to each of the Old States. All these amendments were rejected. Sam. Gordon moved to lay the Bill on the Table; which was rejected on the question of engrossment of the Bill for a third reading the vote was 84. to 98. and the Bill was rejected— But Daniel of North Carolina immediately moved a reconsideration— McClernand of Illinois asked what was his motive, he answered to amend the Bill which was clear enough without needing enquiry— The vote upon reconsideration was 89. to 89. The Speaker gave the casting vote in its favor— Adjourned 81. to 80. Intense heat— Evening visit from James. D. Westcott one of the Senators from Florida.

I received a Discourse on the life and character of Sir Walter Ralegh delivered before the Maryland Historical Society 19— May 1846 the 3d. annual Address to that Association—by J. Morrison Harris— And a Letter from Thomas S. Donoho, of enquiries about the last line of the Sonnet to the Sun, eclipsed and beclouded on the 25th. of April 1846— Misprinted in a New-York Newspaper— H.R.U.S. M’Clernand’s motion to close debate on the Land graduation bill, modified to 2 P.M this day was adopted—and they went immediately into Committee— Vinton spoke the voice of the charmer to the adder.— Brockenbrough of Florida Reuben Chapman of Alabama, Dodge the Delegate from Iowa, Stephen Adams of Mississippi Representative of the Anglo-saxon Land robbers answered Vinton, and abused him for his honesty— James M’Dowell of Western had but five minutes to offer a substitute bill of his own. At 2— the voting commenced— Houston of Alabama, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee and Stewart of Pennsylvania, offered amendments and Darragh of Pittsburgh— Stewart to give 500000 acres to each of the old States—the rest to poor settlers.— All were rejected Samuel Gordon moved to lay the bill on the table—lost. Yeas and nays on the question of engrossment for a third reading—84 to 98. Daniel of North Carolina immediately moved a reconsideration— M’Clernand asked him what was his object— He said to amend the bill. yeas and nays 89 and 89. The Speaker gave the casting vote—ay— Reconsidered. Rockwell of Connecticut moved to adjourn 81 to 80— Carried. what became of 17 votes— Intense heat, no evening walk. Visit from James D Westcott of Tallahassee— Florida—

11. IV.30—  I enter upon my eightieth year—with thanksgiving to God, for all the blessings, and mercies, which His Providence has bestowed upon me, throughout a life extended now to the longest term alloted to the life of Man— With supplication for the continuance of those blessings and mercies, to me and mine, as long, as it shall suit, the dispensations of His wise Providence, and for resignation to His Will, when my appointed time shall come— On going to the House this morning I ordered my Coachman, Thomas Dumphy to come with the Carriage for me at 1/2 past 3. oclock, expecting the House would adjourn about that time— But they adjourned before 2. I went into the Library, and amused myself by looking over Books and Engravings; till 1/2 past 3— I met there Mr. John Connell and several others— I then left the Capitol, and soon met the carriage in which I returned home— At the House the first question that arose, was upon a call of the House, moved by George Rathbun, and upon which, after a second call of absentees, 177. Members answered to their names— I arrived in time to answer to the 2d. call. The Land graduation Bill, from the Senate, was still before the House after having been once rejected, and restored by reconsideration— Cobb of Georgia had moved a substitute, upon which Collamer of Vermont, moved to lay the Bill on the Table— Which was carried by yeas and nays 92. to 87. and Samuel Gordon, immediately moved a reconsideration of that vote. The vote for reconsideration was 91. to 90— The motion to lay the Bill on the Table was lost 89. to 91.— Private Calendar was taken up and several private Bills passed. McKay, gave notice that he would next Monday, call up that Bill for the issue of Treasury notes and the loan, and the House adjourned.

I enter upon my eightieth year. [symbols]  On going to the house this morning I ordered the Coachman Thomas Dumphy to come with the Carriage for me at 1/2 past 3. expecting that the house would adjourn about that time— But they adjourned before 2— Fahrenheit behind the Speaker’s chair 92— I went into the library and met there Mr John Connell— I inspected sundry pictorial cartoons of Wilkes’s exploring expedition, and also of a buffalo-hunt—disgusting, bulky animals suffering death by torture. At 1/2 past 3 I left the capitol, . . . . under shade of trees, till I met Dumphy with the carriage and came home— At the House Rathbun moved a call of the house 177 answered— Further call suspended 146 to 17— Motion to lay the bill on the table rejected 92 to 87. Henley moved to postpone the reconsideration till next Tuesday—lost 91 to 96. Charles S. Benton 17— New-York asked to be excused from voting, as he had paired off with James B. Hunt 3. Michigan— The house refused to excuse him and he voted— The motion to lay the bill on the table was again rejected, 89 to 91— Cobb withdrew his motion for the previous question— The house took up the private calendar—made some sluggish progress and adjourned before 2 O’Clock— Fahrenheit at 93— In the evening I had an intense longing for a warm bath— Dumphy took me to the baths in the rear of Brown’s hotel. They had no hot water, but said they would have some if I would wait, a half an hour—which I declined and rode home—but it was a sore disappointment. My birthday closes in debility but in unceasing blessings [symbols]

12. IV.30.  The continued intense heat of the Season, has produced, a personal debility, which I never before knew.— I feel, like a living ruin with the power of vital agency extinct; a plant withered at the root, a tree, dying downward from the top. I feel above all the want of a bath and was disappointed last evening, in going to the Public hot baths of this City, to be told that they had no hot water—but could have some if I would wait half an hour. Which however I declined— There was no preaching this at the Hall of the House of Representatives of which notice was given in the National Intelligencer of yesterday, and the reason assigned for it was that the Chaplain of the Senate Mr. Tustin, whose turn it was to officiate was indisposed. Of Mr Milburn the Chaplain of the House, no account was given. I attended Church this morning at St John’s with my Grandaughter Mary Louisa— My wife and Mrs. John Adams, were not well; unable to attend— Mr. Pyne read the Service for the fifth Sunday after Trinity, and preached, from Psalm. 38.18. last clause of the verse, “I will be sorry for my Sin”— At five in the afternoon I attended again at the same Church, alone. Mr. Pyne read the evening Service of the day, and preached from 1. Corinthians 9.26. last clause of the verse, “So fight I not as one that beateth the air.” Mr. Pyne’s discourses are ingenious, argumentative, and well seasoned, with the benevolence, if not with the humility of the Christian faith Mr. Pyne’s Christian, must be sorry, according to the rubric of the Church, and must expect pardon for his sins, through her intercession. I closed the day, as it had begun with resignation— I attempted to read, in The Philosophy of the plan of Salvation, but gave it up. Tried a few pages of Sarto resartus. The evening melted away without leaving a trace behind.

I rose with resignation to the will of God a living ruin, with the power of vital agency extinct—a plant withered at the root— A tree dying downward from the top— There was no preaching at the Hall of the Representatives, the Chaplain of the Senate Mr Tustin being sick—of Mr Milburn the Chaplain of the house, no Account. I attended Church this morning at St. John’s with my granddaughter Mary Louisa— My wife and Mary were not well enough to attend Church. Mr Pyne read the service for the 5th. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Psalm 38.18.—last clause of the verse— [“]I will be sorry for my sin”— At 5 in the afternoon I attended again at St. John’s church alone— Mr Pyne read the evening service of the day, and preached from 1. Corinthians 9–26. last clause of the verse [“]so fight I not as one that beateth the air”— Mr Pyne’s discourses are ingenious, argumentative, and well seasoned with the benevolence, if not with the morality of the Christian faith— His Christian must be sorry according to the rubric of the Church, and must expect his pardon through her Intercession— He fights not as one that beateth the air, and his Church is the church militant conquering and to conquer. In hoc signo vinces— He never for an instant loses sight of his church— I close the day as it had begun—with resignation—still longing for a bath and unable to collect my spirits for reading anything beyond the 3— chapters of the book of Job—25–27. with which I began the day— I made an attempt upon the philosophy of the plan of Salvation, but gave it up— Tried a few pages of Sartor resartus, and loathed it— Evening melted away without leaving a trace of existence behind.

13. IV  I rose this morning with the dawn, and drawn by an irresistible impulse walked over the lower Tiber bridge, to my old bathing spot, on the margin of the Potomac—and there, under the shelter of the high bluff yet remaining, I bathed and swam, from five to ten minutes, came out, dressed myself, and walked home. As I went down the Hill, to the edge of the water, I found three young men, neither of whom I knew, already in the river, and heard one of them say, there is John Quincy Adams— They had their clothes, at one of my old standard rocks, but without noticing or disturbing them, I found another rock, a few rods higher, towards the Potomac bridge, where I left my clothes. The tide was low, and the time not convenient, for entering the river, but I succeeded, in obtaining the bath, for which I panted— The time consumed, was as in former days, about one hour and a half—half an hour going to the river, 1/2 and hour to bath, swim, and dress, and half an hour to return— The Thermometer was at 84. the water warm, the atmosphere calm, and the Sun clear— The exercise, washing, the sensation of personal cleanliness, were as of old, but the nervous agitation throughout the day, was not sensibly relieved and the weariness of the evening, threatened a restless night— Francis Richmond, was here, with Thomas. L. McKennie Memoirs—about Indians. 2. Octavo Volumes, in one, of which I took a Copy— And Father Green, with papers of W. Roberts, which he wished me to deliver, to Preston King, Chairman of the Committee on Invalid Pensions—which I did— At the House, Hugh. A White 16. New York, moved for a Select Committee of five, to examine the accounts, of the 5th. Auditor Pleasonton, but the House refused, to suspend the rules, to receive his motion.— George— C— Dromgoole, of 2d. Congressional District Virginia moved a message to the Senate; to remind them, of four Bills, passed by the House and sent to them, and to recommend their action upon them— A very unusual Message, not without example, in both Houses of the British Parliament, once, practised by the Senate of the United States, to the House, much to their indignation— The vote to suspend the rules, for Dromgoole was 39. to 72. Among the Bills of which he wished to remind the Senate, was that commonly called the River and Harbour Bill. One or two of Dromgoole, Party associates, enquired why, he had omitted that, from his memento— He said he had included four Bills, and that he thought sufficient— Several Bills from the Senate were passed or referred to Committees Harralson, reported a Bill, for granting Lands to the Soldiers. Numerous other reports from Committees were received. Sawyer moved to suspend the rules, for a call on the President for the correspondence, on the Oregon Treaty. Refused, without even allowing the yeas and nays. Land graduation Bill was taken up Call of the House—173. answered— McKay moved an amendment to the Bill and Cobb an amendment upon that. Cobbs amendment was rejected 87. to 95. and McKay’s 88. to 93. Motion to lay the Bill on the Table, 90. to 89. The Speaker voted made a tie and the motion was lost, moved again and lost 91. to 92, and again 86. to 92. Rathbun moved to adjourn which was carried 89. to 85—

I rose this morning with the dawn, and drawn by an irresistible impulse walked over the lower Tiber bridge, to my old bathing spot on the margin of the Potowmac—and there under the shelter of the high bluff yet remaining I bathed and swam from 5 to 10 minutes, and came out, dressed myself and walked home—a tour of an hour and a half— The exercise, the washing, the sensation of personal cleanliness, were as of old time, but the nervous agitation throughout the day was not sensibly relieved, and the weariness of the evening threatened a restless Night— Francis Richmond was here with T. L. M’Kenney’s Memoirs about Indians 2 volumes in one, of which I took a copy and father Green with papers of W. Roberts which he wished me to deliver to Preston King chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions H.R.U.S. Hugh White, moves a Committee of five to examine the accounts of the 5th. auditors—refused Dromgoole moves a message to remind the Senate of 4 bills sent them from the house— Vote to suspend the rules 39 to 72. Sundry bills from the Senate were passed or referred— Harralson reported a bill for granting lands to the soldiers—numerous other reports of Committees. Sawyer moved to suspend the rules for a call for the correspondence on the Oregon Treaty—refused—no yeas and nays. Land graduation bill. Call of the House—173 answer. Cobb’s amendment M’Kay’s amendment were rejected 87 and 95—and 88–93— Motion to lay the bill on the table 90 to 89. lost by the Speaker’s vote making a tie— Moved and lost again 91 to 92—and again 86. to 92. Rathbun moved to adjourn. Carried 89 to 85

14. IV—  Second day’s Bath, and swim, in the Potomac, the weather still continuing at intense Summer heat. The success of these experiments, is doubtful, but my repose of the last night was not unsettled, but rather improved, by the bath, of yesterday— At the first Meeting of the House the Stern chase of re-considerations, was renewed— The Amendment moved by Cobb, and the Amendment of that moved by McKay after being both rejected, had both been re considered. The previous question on the Land graduation Bill had been ordered, and McKay had moved to reconsider that; he now withdrew this motion, and moved a Call of the House, which the Speaker pronounced not in order— Truman Smith, as a back-handed Call of the House moved to adjourn, and asked for the yeas and nays—which were 6. to 163. Schenck moved to reconsider this vote but the Speaker decided that a motion to adjourn could not be reconsidered Schenck appealed from this decision, and stood alone in his glory McKay’s Substitute for Cobbs Amendment was then adopted 96. to 86. and McKay’s Bill substituted for that of the Senate, was passed 92 to 90— Ewing of Pennsylvania, inquired of the Speaker, whether every Member, present in his Seat, was not bound to vote? The Speaker said, that by the rule of the House, he was, but that very frequently Members did abstain from voting without notice from the House. Ewing replied that his Colleague Charles. J. Ingersoll was in his Seat, but did not vote, on the passage of this Bill— A motion to reconsider was made pro forma and laid on the Table. Sundry Bills were received from the Senate, among which one for the relief of Elizabeth Widow of Alexander Hamilton— Hoge, Illinois, moved to lay it on the Table—lost 69. to 81— The Bill was referred— A Bill for the improvement of the Ohio, Missouri, Mississippi and Arkansas, inland Seas, a notable device of the political Mountabank John. C— Calhoun, came next— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, moved to lay it on the Table— The Speaker said, that on the first reading of a Bill if opposed, the only question was shall the Bill be rejected—whereupon Hamlin moved that it be rejected, Rathbun moved the previous question, carried. Jacob Thompson moved a call of the House—the Speaker said it was too late, the previous question having been seconded. The main question was ordered, Tibbatts moved to adjourn and asked for the yeas and nays which were refused, and also the motion to adjourn— The question, shall the Bill be rejected, was taken by yeas and nays, 120. to 48. a majority formed by the sense, of the House that the Bill itself was a swindlers trick— McClelland of Michigan, moved a re-consideration and the previous question, the reconsideration was refused without division— The Treasury Note and loan Bill, was then taken up, in committee of the whole, on the State of the Union. Samuel Gordon Chairman, Garrett Davis offered an Amendment, and discussed the Mexican War, Tilden, Giddings Thurman, of Ohio and Douglass of Illinois racketed the lie, that the War began by the Act of Mexico— Tibbatts took the floor, and the committee rose— McKay moved a resolution, to close the debate, on the Treasury Note and loan Bill, in Committee of the whole to-morrow at noon. The House adjourned without taking, the question The decisive vote of the House, upon the Western River Bill, from the Senate, indicates some indignation, at the attempt, to appropriate monies, for Southern Rivers, to the exclusion of all others—

IV— Second bath and swim in the Potowmack the weather still continuing at intense summer heat— My repose of the last Night was not impaired, but rather improved by the bath of yesterday. H.R.U.S. The race of reconsiderations was renewed at the first meeting of the house— The amendment moved by Cobb, and the amendment of that moved by M’Kay, after being both rejected had both been reconsidered— The previous question had been ordered, and M’Kay had moved to reconsider that— He now withdrew that motion and moved a call of the house which the Speaker pronounced not in order— Truman Smith moved to adjourn, and asked for the yeas and equivalent to a call of the house. 6 to 163. Schenk moved to reconsider the motion just rejected. The Speaker decided that a motion to adjourn could not be reconsidered— Schenk appealed, and stood alone in his glory— M’Kay’s substitute for Cobb’s amendment was then adopted 96 to 86— And M’Kay’s Bill substituted for that of the Senate was passed 92 to 90. Ewing of Pennsylvania remarked that C. J. Ingersoll did not vote— A motion to reconsider was laid on the table. Sundry bills received from the Senate one for the relief of Elizabeth Hamilton. Hoge moves to lay it on the table 69 to 81— Referred— Bill for the improvement of Ohio, Missouri, Mississippi and Arkansas inland Seas— Rejected 120 to 48. Treasury Note and loan bill. Garrett Davis discusses the Mexican War and offers an amendment to the Bill; Tilden, Giddings, Thurman of Ohio and Douglas of Illinois racketed the lie that the War began by an act of Mexico Tibbatts took the floor and the Committee Samuel Gordon chairman rose— M’Kay moved a Resolution to close the debate at Noon tomorrow— Adjourned without taking the question.

Third bath and swim in the Potomac at five oclock this morning, still with a clear sky, and a bright rising Sun, but with a fall of ten degrees of Fahrenheit’s from 84. to 74—and a brisk breeze ruffling the surface of the river, so that when I came out, I shivered while dressing at my old rock, but warmed in walking home and suffered no after inconvenience. Nathaniel Chick was here again this morning—86. feeble, tottering at death’s door— I took his papers, to the Pension Office, and entreated the commissioner Edwards, to re-examine them, & reconsider his decision— He sent them back to me this evening with a Letter saying that he has no confidence in them, and sees no evidence that Chick is entitled to a Pension for Service, either in the War of the Revolution or in the last War, with England— He considers Chicks Statements as false, and says they are at variance, with notorious Historical facts; but does not specify in what that variance consists at the House McKay’s motion, to close debate, on the Treasury note and loan Bill at noon this day, was adopted— Garrett Davis, Stanton of Tennessee, Graham of North Carolina, moved amendments which were rejected, as was an additional section moved by Andrew Stuart— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of $50,000. to pay certain old Treasury Notes, once paid, but stolen and reissued at New Orleans— This was carried, and the Bill passed 118. to 47. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Norris Chairman— Volunteer appropriation bill—$16.347.000. the estimate. $12000000 appropriated. Garrett Davis, Thurman, Rathbun, Vinton, J. J. McDowell, Henley and Houston of Alabama debated the Bill, and the Mexican War— Solomon Foot, took the floor, the committee rose and the House adjourned. I walked, this evening in the Grounds of the Presidents House, and heard the Music.— I met there Mr. John. A. Rockwell, Member from Connecticut, who came home with me, and took tea with us.

Third bath and swim in the Potowmack, at 5 O’Clock this morning: still with a clear sky and a bright rising Sun; but with a fall of ten degrees Fahrenheit from 84 to 74, and a brisk breeze ruffling the surface of the river so that I shivered while dressing at my old rock when I came out, but warmed in walking home, and suffer no after-inconvenience. Nathaniel Chick was again here this morning, 86. feeble—tottering at the gate of death— I took his papers to the Commissioner of Pensions and intreated him to re-examine them and reconsider his decision. He returned them this Evening with a Letter saying that he has no confidence in them and sees no evidence that Chick is entitled to a pension for service either in the war of the Revolution, or in the last War with England— H.R.U.S. M’Kays motion to close the debate on the Treasury Note and loan bill at Noon this day was carried— Garrett Davis, Stanton of Tennessee, Graham of North Carolina moved amendments which were rejected as was an additional section moved by Andrew Stewart. Joseph R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of 50000 dollars to pay certain old Treasury notes, once paid but stolen and reissued at New-Orleans—carried and the bill passed 118 to 47. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Morris Chairman— Volunteer appropriation bill 16,34347000— Garrett Davis, Thurman, Rathbun, Vinton, J. J. M’Dowell Henley and Houston of Alabama, debated the Bill and the Mexican War. Solomon Foot took the floor— Committee rose and house adjourned. Evening walk. Music in the Grounds of the President’s House. Mr John A— Rockwell came home with me, and took tea with us—

16— IV—  Fourth bath, and swim, in the Potomac— Water and atmosphere cold, but smooth with a clear sky. The effect of this exercise, and ablution upon my health, is yet somewhat doubtful.— The tides is still rising, but not yet, high at five in the morning— Mrs. Burnet of Cincinnati, and her son, were here as visitors— Nathaniel Chick, came again— I could only tell him, of the inflexibility, of the Commissioner of Pensions, Edwards— But as a last resource, I offered to go with him to the Office, He said he was so feeble, that he prefered waiting till tomorrow morning, when he would call on me again for that purpose; to which I agreed— At the House the day began, by an explanation of Tibbatts repelling, attacks upon him by Stanton of Tennessee, and Billy Wick of Indiana— McKay, from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Supplemental Appropriation Bill, for the pay of Members of Congress, and for the Indian Department, a coincidence, with which Dromgoole, made merry insisting that in this association the Congressmen must be provided for first— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, moved a joint resolution, authorizing and requesting the President, to cause Medals to be struck from the trophies of the Battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma, to be distributed to every individual engaged in them, which was carried without opposition— McKay moved a resolution to close the debate on the additional Army Appropriation Bill at 2. P.M. this day, which was adopted, though Ashmun moved to lay it on the table— Cranston presented resolutions of thanks, of the Legislature of Rhode Island, to General Taylor, for the victories of the 8. and 9th. of May— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Norris Chairman on the additional Army Appropriation Bill— The precise amount appropriated, is $11.812.015.09. to support 25000 Volunteers for the year and additional Officers to the Army Debated by Foot, Caleb. B. Smith, Hilliard Cobb, and others.— Reported to the House without amendment and passed 160. to 4. of whom I was one— A joint resolution came from the Senate, to adjourn the Session on the 10th. of August, which was immediately adopted— The Bill to provide further Supplies, for Congressmen and Indians, was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the union, John Wentworth Chairman A tumultuary and burlesque debate, followed till about four oclock, when the Committee rose, in utter confusion and inextinguishable laughter, and the House adjourned—

Fourth bath and swim in the Potowmack. Water and atmosphere cold, but smooth, with a clear sky— Still doubtful of the physical effect of this exercise and ablution— The tide still rising, but not yet high at 5 in the morning.— Mrs Burnet of Cincinnati and her son were here Nathaniel Chick came again— I could only tell him of the inflexibility of the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards; but as a last resource offered to go with him to the office— He said he felt so feeble that he preferred waiting till to morrow, to which I agreed— H.R.U.S. The day began by an explanation of Tibbatts against Stanton and Wick. M’Kay from the Committee of Ways and Means reported a supplemental appropriation bill for the pay of members of Congress and for the Indian Department Joseph R Ingersoll moved a joint Resolution authorising and requesting P.U.S. to cause medals to be struck from the trophies of the battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma to be distributed to every individual engaged in them—carried nem con— M’Kay moved a Resolution to close debate on the additional army appropriation bill at 2 P.M. Carried though Ashmun moved to lay it on the table— Cranston presented Resolutions of thanks of the Legislature of Rhode-Island to General Taylor for the victories of 8 and 9 May.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Norris chairman on the additional army appropriation bill— 11,812015.09. to support 25000 volunteers for the year, and additional Officers to the army. Debated by Foote, Caleb B— Smith, Hilliard, Cobb &c reported to the house without amendment and passed 160 to 4 of whom I was one— Joint Resolution from the Senate to adjourn the Session 10. August—passed— Bill of more supplies for members of Congress and Indians resumed Wentworth Chairman— tumultuary and burlesque debate till about 4 when the Comee rose. Adjourned—

17. IV.  Fifth bath and swim, between four and five oclock in the morning in the Potomac. This day Thomas Dumphy, went with me— The weather cool and cloudy, the river smooth and the water cold the time of tide beginning to serve. Returned—along the strand—from which all the old trees have been Swept away by the encroaching tides, and by the border of the Tiber— Nathaniel Chick came again but still wished to postpone going with me to the Pension Office— He said he had written to the Governor of Pennsylvania, for a Certificate of character and wished to wait for his answer. I observe he is unwilling to be confronted, with Mr. Edwards. I took him with me, to his lodgings at Donovons next to the Railway Depot— Mr. Kavasales was here, still without a favourable decision from the Secretary of the Navy, notwithstanding the energetic interposition of Mr. Rathbun. Mr. Giddings went yesterday on a short tour to Boston and Portland. At the House, the day was devoted to the Private Callendar— Sundry reports from Committees were received, and variously disposed of. The House then took up the Bills, heretofore reported from the committee of the whole, and what with motions, to lay Bills on the table, adopted or rejected as if by lot, with motions to reconsider, carried and postponed, with calls of the House to make a quorum adopted and superseded with motions to adjourn repeated and rejected 49. Private Bills were passed, and sent to the Senate for concurrence. The vote to lay the Bill for the relief of William Pool on the table was adopted and reconsidered; but when the Question on the passage of the Bill came, there was no quorum voting and about three the House adjourned— I commenced my walk homeward and met, with a young man named, I think Derry?, from Cincinnati; a painter, who he said was going to Europe, for improvement in his profession, and for whom he requested from me Letters of introduction, to any of my friends— I met the carriage, with Thomas Dumphy and rode part of the way in Pennsylvania Avenue but he had to stop, at a shop whereupon I got out, and walked home I began this morning to read the Psalms, five every day—

Fifth bath and swim in the Potowmack—and this day Thomas Dumphy went with me. Weather cool and cloudy. Water smooth and cold— Time of tide at 5 A.M. beginning to serve— Returned along the strand and the border of the Tiber— Nathaniel Chick came again, but still wished to postpone going with me to the pension office— He said he had written to the Governor of Pennsylvania for a certificate of character and wished to wait for his answer— I see he is unwilling to be confronted with Mr Edwards— I took him with me to his lodgings at Donovan’s next to the Railway depot. Kavasales here— Still in suspense— Mr Giddings went yesterday on a tour to Boston and Portland. H.R.U.S— The whole day was devoted to the private calendars— Sundry reports from Committees were received and variously disposed of— The house then took up the bills heretofore reported from the Committee of the whole, and what with motions to lay bills on the table, adopted and rejected seemingly as if by lot with motions to reconsider carried and postponed—with calls of the house to make a quorum adopted and superseded—with motions to adjourn reported and rejected 49 private bills were passed and sent to the Senate for concurrence— The vote to lay the Bill for the relief of William Poole on the table was reconsidered but when the question on the passage of the bill came there was no quorum voting and the house adjourned, about 3. I commenced my walk homeward and met judge Burnet with a young man named I think Derring an artist (Painter) who he said was going to Europe for improvement in his progression and for whom he requested from me Letters of introduction to any of my friends— I met the Carriage with Thomas Dumphy and rode part of the way in the Pennsylvania avenue, but he had to stop some time at a shop wherefore I got out and walked home— I began to read the Psalms 5 every day

18. IV.15.  There was rain in the night and this morning was cloudy and cold— I concluded therefore reluctantly to intermit my river baths— I received an invitation from Mr. Mullady President of the Georgetown College to attend at their Commencement on Tuesday the 28th. instt. at 1/2 past nine oclock A.M. but it interferes with the sitting of the House, for which reason I shall not be able to attend— At the House, sundry Bills were received from the Senate, and referred to Committees. The consideration of private Bills occupied the remainder of time till the adjournment, at three. First in committee of the whole Thomas Butler King Chairman, and then, in the House. Among the Bills taken up was that for the relief of the Heirs of Robert Fulton, an appropriation of $76.300. to be paid them, in full of all his claims. Reported by Robert C. Schenck from the Committee of Naval Affairs—when the Bill came up Schenck the reporter, was not in the House, and several attempts were made, to pass over the Bill to defeat it— Mr. Connell was in the passage way to the House in great distress, and consternation— Orvil Hungerford 19. New York, moved to strike out $76.300. and insert $16.300— Lost. Samuel Gordon moved to insert $20.000. which the Chairman pronounced not in order, but the Committee reversed his decision. Gordon then modified his motion to insert $40.000. Joseph. J. McDowell quoted a Speech of Silas Wright in the Senate against the Claim, which I answered Rathbun moved to report the Bill with recommendation to reject it— Lost— I moved to rise and report the Bill— Carried— Passed to a third reading by yeas and nays 90 to 67. and passed. Reconsideration refused— I had a visit from Mr. Perry of South Carolina, son of a man, who many years ago, migrated to that State from Sherburn, Massachusetts, he is now going to inquire, for Kindred of his own name. Evening visit from our neighbour Mr. Buchanan—Secretary of State—

IV.15— There was rain in the Night and this Morning was cloudy and cold— I concluded therefore reluctantly to intermit for some days my river baths. I have received an invitation to attend at the Commencement of Georgetown College on Tuesday the 28th. instant at half past nine O’Clock A.M. At the house sundry bills were received from the Senate and referred to Committees. The consideration of private bills occupied the remainder of time Till the adjournment at the adjournment at 3. first in Committee of the whole; Thomas Butler King Chairman, and then in the house— Among the Bills taken up was that for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton—an appropriation of 76300 dollars to be paid them in full of his demands Reported by Robert C. Schenk from the Committee on Naval affairs— When the bill came up, Schenk the reporter was not in the house, and several attempts were made, to pass over the bill to defeat it— Connell was in the passageway to the house in great distress and consternation.
