Hungerford moved to strike out 76300 and insert 16300. lost. Gordon moved 20000 which the chairman announced not in order, but the committee reversed this decision— Gordon then modified to 40000 Joseph J M’Dowell cited a speech of Silas Wright in the Senate which I answered— Rathbun moved to report the bill with recommendation to reject it—lost. I moved to rise, and report the Bill— Carried— Passed to a third reading by yeas and nays—90 to 67. and passed and reconsideration refused— It has yet to go through the ordeal of the Senate— Visit from Mr Perry of South Carolina, son of a man who migrated to that State, from Sherburne, Massachusetts— He is going to enquire for kindred of his own name— Evening visit from our neighbour Mr James Buchanan Secretary of State—

19. IV—  The Revd. E. Yulee, of Woodward College Cincinnati Minister of the New Jerusalem Church and brother of the Senator from Florida, performed the Service of Public Worship in the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning. He is an Israelite converted to Swedenborg Christianity— He read some passages from the Bible made a short and fudged prayer, gave out by two lines at a time to be sung the hymn  read the 53d. Chapter of Isaiah, and delivered a cold address of half an hour, upon the 4th. verse of that Chapter—“Surely he has bourne our griefs, and carried our sorrows, yet we did deem him striken, smitten, of God, and afflicted”— Upon this text, he engrafted the Doctrine, and material and spiritual correspondencies, so as to make it, more unintelligible, than it is by Swedenborg himself— There were not more than fifty persons, in the Hall, and among them was his brother, the quandam David Levy, with his wife, who spoke with him after the service was over— I received a pamphlet, on this correspondence, of natural things to spiritual, by Thomas H. Perry Professor of Mathematics in the United States Navy— At five this afternoon, I went to Saint Johns church, but found all the doors closed—there was no evening Service, there. I read the first, of the Revd. Daniel Bakers Revival Sermons, on the truth, and excellence of the Christian Religion— Mr. Baker, is an excellent, and very amiable man, not very profound—as a reasoner. He complains, that Infidels, are not satisfied, with reasonable evidence, but we must at last recur, to faith. Mr. Moseley, Member of the House, from Buffalo New York, made us an evening visit, as also Mr. Larned, Mrs. Newman, Mrs. Talbot, and her daughter Mary— My health and spirits, very much drooping.

The Revd. E. Yulee of Woodward College, Cincinnati a Minister of the New Jerusalem Church, performed the service of public worship in the Hall of the house of Representatives this morning— I suppose him to be an Israelite, converted to Swedenborg Christianity— He read some passages from the Bible—made a short and frigid prayer—gave out by two lines at a time to be sung the hymns With one consent let all the Earth, To God their cheerful voices raise— Read the 53d chapter of Isaiah, and delivered a cold address of half an hour, upon the 4th. verse of that chapter.— “Surely, he hath borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; yet we did esteem him stricken, smitten of God, and afflicted.” Upon this text he engrafted the doctrine of correspondences so as to make it more unintelligible than it is by Swedenborg himself— There were I think not fifty persons in the hall, but among them was the Senator from Florida, the quondam David Levy—with his wife— He spoke to his namesake the preacher after the Service. I have received a pamphlet on this correspondence of natural things to spiritual by T. H. Perry professor of Mathematics in U.S. Navy— At 5 this afternoon I went to St. John’s Church, but found all the doors closed— There was no evening service there— I read the first of the Revd Daniel Baker’s revival Sermons—on the excellency of the Christian Religion; but the argument of the discourse is rather upon the evidence than the excellence of Christianity— Mr Baker complains of the unreasonable calls of unbelievers for evidence— It is strange that all professed arguments upon the Evidences, result in exciting and multiplying questions in my mind— We must recur to Faith. Mr Moseley the member from Buffalo made us an Evening visit— Spirits much discomposed

20. IV.  The time for the morning bath, in the Potomac now suits exactly, for five oclock in the morning but I am discouraged, by admonitory symptoms, following upon my baths of the last week and dare not repeat them. I met at the Capitol Mr. Healey the Painter, and went with him, to Plumbe’s Gallery, where they took two, Daguerreotype full-length likenesses, of me. Both very indifferent Mr. Healey wanted to introduce me as a spectator into the Historical Picture of Daniel Webster answering Robert Y. Hayne in the United States Senate on Footes Resolution in 1831—which picture he is to paint for certain Whigs of Boston to be suspended in Fanuel Hall I told Mr. Healey, that I must decline being introduced into that picture, not having been at that time, in the Senate, nor in public Life at all, nor present in the Senate chamber at the scene I was residing in this City in private life from 3d. March 1829. until December 1831. when I first took my Seat as a Member of the House of Representatives— Healey told me that he was engaged also, to paint an Historical Picture of John. C. Calhoun, in some Oratorical attitude as a counterpart, to this illustration of Daniel Webster, to be hung up somewhere at Charleston South Carolina, and that these two works, would be henceforth, a great labour of his life— He said he should leave this City next Thursday—and after stopping at Philadelphia, to paint a copy of Inman’s portrait of Chief Justice Marshall, he should proceed to Boston and embark, in the Steamer of the 16th. of August to return to France, and after thus accomplishing, his Commission from King Louis Phillipe, he intends to come back here, to execute his two great Historical pictures. I met Judge Burnet at Plumbe’s— He was a Member of the Senate at the time of Foote’s resolutions, and is to form a prominent figure in the picture It was strange, that he told me, he did not meet me last Friday or recommend to me the young Artist from Cincinnati— I returned to the House— They were on the point of adjourning— The Supplementary Appropriation Bill for Congressmen and Indians, the Senates amendments to the Second Army Appropriation Bill, the Navy Pension Bill, and the special order, on the public printing, of Congress, were discussed, by Garrett Davis and others— I came home, very unwell, and more—

The time for morning bath in the Potowmack now suits exactly, but I am discouraged by a drooping state of health, and symptoms admonitory which I dare not disregard— I met at the Capitol Mr Healey the painter, and went with him to Plumbe’s gallery where they took two Daguerrotype full lengths likenesses of me, both very indifferent— He wanted it to introduce me as a spectator into the historical picture of Daniel Webster answering Robert Y. Hayne in the debate in the U.S. Senate on Foote’s Resolutions in 1831—which he is to paint for certain Boston Whigs to be suspended in Faneuil Hall— I told Mr Healey that I must decline being introduced into that picture, not having been a member of the Senate at that time, nor present at the scene— I was residing in this City in private life, from 3. March 1829. until December 1831. when I took my seat as a member of the House of Representatives Healey told me that he was engaged also to paint a historical picture of John C. Calhoun in some oratorical attitude, as a counterpart to this illustration of Daniel Webster, to be hung up somewhere at Charleston S.C— and that these two works would be the great labour of his life— He said he should leave this city next Thursday and after stopping at Philadelphia to paint a copy of Inman’s portrait of Chief Justice Marshall should proceed to Boston and embark in the Steamer of the 16th. of August to return to France and after thus accomplishing his Commission from king Louis Philippe he intends to come back here, to accomplish his two great historical pictures— On my return to the house, they immediately adjourned— The supplementary appropriation bill for Congressmen and Indians— The Senate’s amendment to the Army appropriation bill, and the navy pension bill, and the special order on the public printing were discussed. Garrett Davis. I came home quite unwell

21. IV—  My indisposition continues and increases— I am all but totally disabled for action or for thought— I passed a nearly sleepless night.— Dr. Thomas much indisposed himself administer to me advice, and medicine, in profusion, and I am barely able, to attend at my Seat, in the House of Representatives.— This morning Allen. G. Thurman 8. Ohio, the Chilicothe District moved to discharge the committee of the whole, from the consideration of the Bill relating to the payment of Claims against the Government this was carried: the Bill was taken up in the House, passed and sent to the Senate.— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Lynn Boyd Chairman, upon a joint resolution from the Senate regulating the printing for the two Houses of Congress. A perpetual source of wrangling between the Democratic and Whig Parties each underbiding the other for economy, and each lavish without stinct to fatten their favourite printers with jobs Garrett Davis finished his Speech commenced yesterday and was answered by Thomas— H. Bayly, with an hour of dull invective and self-laudation— Rathbun emitted a Speech, against speech-making and moved the Committee to rise, for a resolution to close the debate this day, which was done. He moved in the House the hour of 1 P.M. Dromgoole moved 5. Cobb 3. both rejected Cobb moved to lay the resolution on the Table—lost— Rathbun’s hour of 1. prevailed Committee again Boyd in the Chair. Henley, Bayly, Garrett, Davis, Douglass, and McKay, moved amendments, all rejected and the resolution as it came from the Senate was reported to the House, engrossed passed, the reconsideration refused 100. to 55— Houston of Alabama asked to be excused from voting; but was refused— J. J. McDowel asked to be excused gave silly reasons, and withdrew his request. Committee of the whole again Dunlap Chairman Thurman Holmes, Jenkins, debated till the committee rose and the House adjourned— I came home with prostrated strength and passed the evening in convulsive agonies—

IV.15— My indisposition continues and increases—till I am all but totally disabled for action or for thought— Dr Thomas himself much indisposed administers to me much advice and medicines in abundance, and I still attend at my seat in the house of Representatives.— This morning Thurman moved to discharge the Committee of the whole from the consideration of the Bill relating to the payment of claims against the Government. This was carried, and the Bill was taken up in the house, passed and sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Linn Boyd Chairman, upon a joint Resolution from the Senate regulating the printing for the two houses of Congress, a perpetual source of wrangling between the democratic and whig parties, each underbidding the other for economy, and each lavish without stint? to fatten their favourite printers with jobs— Garrett Davis finished his speech commenced yesterday. Thomas H— Bailey answered him with an hour of dull invective, and self laudation— Rathbun emitted a speech against speech making, and moved the Committee to rise for a Resolution to close the debate this day—which was done— He moved in the house to close the debate at 1. P.M. Dromgoole moved 5— Cobb 3. both rejected. Cobb moved to lay the resolution on the table—lost— Rathbun’s hour of 1— prevailed— Committee again Linn Boyd Chairman— Henley, Bayly, Garrett Davis Douglass, and MKay moved amendments, all rejected, and the Resolution as it came from the Senate was reported to the house, engrossed, passed, and reconsideration refused 100 to 55— Houston of Alabama asked to be excused from voting, but was refused— J. J. M’Dowell asked to be excused, gave silly reasons, and withdrew his request. Committee again Dunlap chairman Thurman, Holmes, Jenkins debated till the Committee rose and the house adjourned.

I had a disturbed and almost sleepless Night. My strength like the Proteus of Virgil in liquid lapse away. My appetite turns to loathing, and without pain I feel as if all my bones were extracted from my body— Yet I write and notwithstanding earnest remonstrances attend my daily duties in the house— Mr Yulee the preacher of last Sunday morning in the Representatives Hall was this day introduced to me— He is of the new Jerusalem church or in other words a Swedenborgian—to me the most senseless of infatuated mysticisms— I have received a pamphlet by Thomas H. Perry, a professor of Mathematics in U.S. Navy, on the Correspondence of natural things to spiritual—republished from the New Jerusalem Magazine— Upon Geology. At the house Yost from th Committee on engraving reported a Resolution for 5000 extra copies of the map accompanying document 211, relating to mineral Lands on lake Superior—adopted— Houston afterwards moved to reconsider but failed. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dunlap chairman on Charles S. Benton 17 New-York’s report from a select Committee of a joint Resolution directing the manner of procuring the printing for the two houses of Congress— Committee soon rose, and a resolution passed to close the debate at 1 this day— Accordingly at 1. O’Clock the voting commenced and the Resolutions were adopted— Committee of conference on the conflicting votes on the second army appropriation bill. M’Kay, Black of S.C and Ashmun Committee of the whole on the State of the Union upon the bill from the judiciary Committee to increase the duties that is the Salary of the Attorney General from 4500 to 6000 dollars— Debate, but no conclusion. I failed to get the floor. Came home sick.

A disturbed and desolate Night— Prostrate—desponding—weary of existence—but never ceasing praise to God for the numberless blessings of his Providence throughout my life, and so many of which I still enjoy—never ceasing to pray for his sustaining hand through the dispensations yet in reserve, and especially for the controul of my own heart for Patience, and Resignation— I still attend the Meetings of the house and yesterday made several attempts to get the floor without success— This morning Douglass his motion to close debate on the Bill to increase the duties of the Attorney General in one hour—modified to One O’Clock was adopted Joseph R. Ingersoll offered a joint Resolution—argumentative and verbose, advising the President to propose to Mexico a Negotiation for Peace, and hinting at an arbitration, but the house would not receive it— The Bill to increase the duties, that is the powers and salary of the Attorney General was riddled in Union Committee debate, till one O’Clock then strip’d of its noxious parts, and loaded with others by successive amendments; a substitute offered by Tibbatts was at last reported to the house, and then at the motion of Roberts laid on the table Its only real object was to give an enormous increase of power and of profit to the Office of Attorney General— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Richard Broadhead 10 Pennsylvania Chairman, Bill for erection and repair of certain defensive fortifications— Tibbatts moved to authorize P.U.S to suspend all works of fortification during the Mexican War Long speech of Henry J. Seaman 2. New-York. Amendments were proposed by Giles of Maryland Elias B Holmes 28 New-York, Grinnell, Massachusetts W. W. Campbell 6 New-York, and Joseph R. Ingersoll to refer the Pea Patch question to Chief Justice Taney. Hungerford moved an amendment for Sackets harbour, Committee rose. Letter from P. M. Butler, about treating with Camanche Indians. Burt’s motion and adjourn.

I have an occasional, or rather annual outscouring to go through, usually in the month of July, in which I was born, and its operation, has been this year more severe than usual but I hope the crisis of it has now passed, and I am this day convalescent, for the present— I received this morning a Letter from James. R. Snowden, Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Treasury Office Harrisburg, 20th. July 1846, enclosing a draft on the Bank of Pennsylvania, of 20. dolls. in favor of Nathaniel Chick or? order, which he had requested, should be forwarded to me, but Chick did not appear this day— At the House, Lynn Boyd, moved a joint resolution that the hour for adjournment of the Session on the 19th. of August, should be noon adopted— Armistead Burts resolution moved yesterday, was for a select committee of five to enquire into and report on the legality and proprietary of the expenditures of Butler, and Lewis Commissioner to the Camanchees and other Tribes of Indians— The resolution was adopted, and afterwards reconsidered, and laid on the Table— Butler is an ex-Governor of South Carolina. McKay, had made some free remarks, on the extravagance of the expenditures of these Commissioners, whereupon they bristled up, and through Burt, called for this Committee of investigation and enquiry— It was a South Carolina Dragooning, and whipped McKay back into the traces— Joseph. R. Ingersoll moved to suspend the rules for a joint resolution recommending to the President, to negotiate for Peace with Mexico; fudge suspension of rules refused. Numerous reports received from Committees. D. P. King, moved a resolution to allow each Member $30. for the long and $15. for the short Session—instead of Stationary. Laid on the table. Warehousing Bill received from the Senate— Question of its commitment, postponed till Monday— Private Bills— Eighty-five passed— 93. objected to and passed over. Committee of the whole rose and the House adjourned at three—

I have an occasional or rather annual outscouring to go through in the month of July, in which I was born, and its operation has been this year has been more severe than usual; but I hope the crisis of it is now past, and I am this day convalescent for the present— There is another subject of reflection in my condition upon which it becomes me to commune only with myself.— I received this morning a Letter from James R. Snowden Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.— Treasury Office Harrisburg 26 July 1846. enclosing a draft on the Bank of Pennsylvania of 20 dollars in favour of Nathaniel Chick or order, which he had requested should be forwarded to me— But Chick did not appear this day— At the House Linn Boyd moved a joint Resolution that the hour for adjournment of the Session on the 10th. of August should be Noon— Adopted. Armistead Burt of S.C. moved a select Committee of 5. to enquire and report on the legality and propriety of the expenditures of Butler and Lewis, Commissioners to the Camanches and other tribes of Indians— The Resolution was adopted and afterwards reconsidered and laid on the table. It was a South Carolina dragooning and whipped M’Kay back into the traces— Joseph R. Ingersoll moved to suspend the rules for a joint resolution recommending to the President to negotiate for Peace with Mexico. Fudge. Suspension of rules, refused. Numerous Reports from Committees received— D— P— King moved a Resolution to allow each member 30 dollars for the long and 15 for the short Session instead of Stationery. Laid on the table. Warehousing Bill received from the Senate— Question of its commitment. Postponed to next Monday. Private Bills. 85 passed and sent to the Senate 93 objected to and passed over— Committee of the whole rose, and the house adjourned at 3. O’Clock.

Recovering from the total prostration of my faculties of body, and almost as total of the energies of mind I endeavour once more to resume some useful occupation—in vain. The house confined itself almost entirely to the consideration of private bills—taking up first the bills from the Senate reported yesterday from the committee of the whole— Among these was the bill for the relief of Amos Kendall, upon which there have been repeated decisions against him, and on which he was for years within prison bounds. The last decision was in his favour, and uncle Sam pays the piper— There was also a bill granting a small sum to Mrs Pike, widow of Zebulon Montgomery Pike, killed in an invasion of upper Canada in 1813 during the last War with Great Britain— But this was for services of exploration in 1805 and 1806 after the purchase of Louisiana. Daniel of N.C. Chairman of the Committee of Claims opposed it tooth and nail— So did Atkinson of Virginia, and Houston of Alabama, who moved to lay it on the table. But it was supported by Gordon and Culver, and passed 88 to 64— This day closed with a bill for the settlement of the accounts of John Garnett an Indian agent, which was read a third time, but on the question of its passage no quorum voted, and after an ineffectual motion for a call of the house they adjourned before one O’Clock— I went into the Senate chamber, and heard Daniel Webster speak about two hours against the bill to reduce the import duties and repeal the Tariff of 1842. The hall was crowded and he has the faculty of claiming the attention of his auditory—but his argument was dull, tedious and commonplace. I left him speaking after 3— Mr John Connell was here this Evening.

The Revd Flanders a Universalist from Saint Louis Missouri preached this morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives— His forms of worship are those of the Congregational church, but his mode of prayer seemed to me not quite sufficiently devotional. He gave out two hymns, from the collection used by the unitarian Society, in the city and they were sung by persons of the auditory present, which was not large— The text of Mr Flanders was Genesis 1.28. [“]And God blessed them, and God said unto them, be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it”— The preacher probably did not know, that this was precisely the passage cited by me on the 2d. of January last as the primitive foundation of our title to the Oregon Territory— The Doctrine deduced from it by Mr Flanders was that Man was by the Constitution of his Nature was created a laborious animal— That the condition of his existence in the Garden of Eden, before the fall was labour He gave notice that the Revd. Mr Yulee would preach at the Unitarian Church this afternoon at 4 O’Clock, and he himself this Evening at 8— There was no evening service at St. John’s. I wished to attend in the afternoon at 4 at the Unitarian Church, but was forbidden owing to the intense heat of the weather I did attend at 8 in the evening, and heard Mr Flanders, from John 8.32. [“]And ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free”— But what is truth? The Sermon was a very earnest discourse to prove the universal salvation of all mankind— As in Adam all died, so in Christ shall all be made alive— I hope so, and still find some consolation in attendance upon public worship— I am encouraged with continued symptoms of convalescence

V.— Fahrenheit 82—the temperature of the Night Life seems returning to me, and with it the longing for the Potowmac bath and swim— But I have not the command of my own limbs and cannot go— Nor can I yet keep along with the current of my correspondence, or of the public business with which I am concerned— I answered three Letters from a man named Sizer, enquiring concerning a petition presented originally by Osmyn Baker, and against which the Committee of claims reported last March— I have received also a Letter from J. Bigelow agent for the heirs of Francois Cazaux, in whose favour there is a bill before the house—and a report from the judiciary Committee— Also a printed Circular from Wiley and Putnam 26. July 1846. New York, enclosing another to the Secretary of State of the several States proposing to purchase public documents and books for the Managers of the British Museum— At the House the Speaker announced the Warehousing bill as the special order of the day but it was postponed till next Wednesday, and a Resolution was adopted to close the debate on the fortification bill at Noon this day— The Bill was immediately taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Orville Hungerford Chairman and Ashmun made an hour speech against the President for the War with Mexico. M’Kay took no notice of it but talked about the fortifications— Burt wasted some ten minutes and 12. O’Clock came. Numerous additional amendments were proposed and rejected— That offered by Joseph R. Ingersoll authorising the President to settle for the Pea patch Island was adopted and the Bill passed— The Postage bill was next taken up and debated till for lack of a quorum the Committee rose and the house adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber and heard Mr Jarnagin.

IV:30— The remnant of my life is a long disease— A succession of complaints disable me for all active exertion of mind or of body and I no sooner seem to recover from one, than I am stricken down by another— I am especially deprived of that continuity of application to particular subjects indispensable for the transaction of business public or private. The course of Legislation carried on by the present administration of the Government is vicious and pernicious, but it is sustained by the will or the acquiescence of the People— The Nation is plunged into an unjust and wicked War—and not only submits to it, but wages it as if it were a War of self defence: I still receive numerous applications from individuals to assist them in the prosecution of their claims but am often unable to follow them up with that unintermitting attention without which it is impossible to carry them through— At the house, Strong and Culver moved Resolutions concerning the distribution of document books to the new members which failed for lack of two thirds majorities to suspend the rules— The Postage bill was taken up in Union Committee David S. Reid 3. North Carolina—with a long rigmarole episode, about the resignation of W. H. Haywood a Senator from that State. Briggs, Barringer, Dobbin Dockery discoursed about it and about it—all a-propos of the Post office bill, till soon after 2. the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber where John M. Niles Senator from Connecticut was blowing the last blast against the Tariff bill—in vain— The engrossment of the bill had been carried by the casting vote of the Vice-President George M. Dallas, and the bill passed 28 to 27.— Mr John Connell here this Eve.

I received 26. Letters, printed, all of one tenor but signed by different individuals, from Nantucket, invoking my influence in support of the bill to indemnify the sufferers by French spoliations before 1800. The appeal to my feelings is most impressive—but the day of my strength is past, and an atmosphere at 90 degrees of Fahrenheit annihilating. A Scotchman by the name of Stewart was here— A benevolent undertaker to promote the migration of his poor Countrymen to the United States, and soliciting money for himself which I declined to give— At the House the new tariff bill was received from the Senate with an amendment striking out the 9th. Section— The special order of the day, the Warehouse bill was postponed till to-morrow. Call of the house 211 answered 10 absent 4 vacancies— The question to suspend the special order and take up the Message from the Senate was carried 108 to 100. Winthrop claimed that it could be carried only by a two thirds vote— The Speaker said it was too late to raise the objection— Winthrop appealed and the appeal was laid on the table. 102 to 98. Stewart moved to lay the bill with the Senate’s amendment on the table, lost 96 to 113.— A second motion to lay the bill on the table was rejected 99 to 113—and the concurrence with the amendment of the Senate was carried 115 to 92— And thus perishes the Tariff of 1842. Carried by a majority of one John White then Speaker of the House, and now repeated by the casting vote of George M Dallas Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Post Office Bill, debated till of the 210 who had voted on the Tariff bill there was not a quorum of 113 left, and after some convulsive throes, the Committee rose, and the house adjourned.

My colleague Benjamin Thompson, member from the 4th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, put into my hands a Letter to him from Elijah Clark of Brighton 27. July—stating that he had forwarded to me a pension claim of Lydia Weston to which no answer has been received— It is one of many cases received from Mr Clark, and the circumstances of which have escaped from my memory— I received also a Letter from John Barrett, Waggoners Ripple Post Office Adams County Ohio soliciting for a pension claim of an old widow named Mary Taylor, daughter of William Flood or Floid—Revolutionary Soldier, and Mr Barrett encloses a Letter of 3 June 1846 to him from the Commissioner of Pensions importing that Mrs Mary Taylor has no claim at all— At the house the special order of the day was again postponed and after Thomasson had introduced a bill to establish a post road from this city to the Columbia river in the Oregon territory Hopkins’s new Post-Office bill was resumed in Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union David S. Reid 3. North Carolina Chairman— A snarl of debate followed upon swarming amendments till Hopkins took a vote upon his substitute for the whole bill which was rejected 81 to 96. Then Owen moved to reconsider that rejection— The Committee had risen for lack of a quorum and been discharged from consideration of the bill Rathbun moved to lay Owen’s motion of reconsideration on the table This was carried 94 to 84—and Dromgoole as Speaker, decided that it carried the bill with it— Bill about Java Coffee and duties on Spanish vessels—passed with an amendment from the Senate— French spoliation bill outbreak of Allen Y. ThurmanOhio against it He had not finished when the Committee rose and the house adjourned

I received a Letter from Rufus W. Griswold dated yesterday at Philadelphia enclosing a printed notice of 3. octavo pages headed John Quincy Adams—and asking copies of my Oration at Cincinnati, and my speech against the admission of Texas— At the house instead of resuming the consideration of the French spoliation bill, they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Warehousing system bill, which was the special order of the day. M’Kay moved a Call of the house and 165 answered to their names— Hilliard of Alabama opened the debate, by moving to strike out the first section, except the enacting clause, and he spoke an hour against the bill, and about the Tariff of 1842 and its repeal just consummated, for which he voted though he had many objections to the new bill— Truman Smith of Connecticut followed with a heavy and bitter invective against the repeal of the Tariff of 1842.— Thomas H. Bayly and W. W. Payne of Alabama consumed two successive hours in railing not in good fat terms, but in hectoring commonplace against the tariff of 1842. Andrew Stewart of Pennsylvania replied to them both in a tone somewhat like their own though much more spirited— John G. Chapman 3. Maryland took the floor— The Committee rose and the house adjourned— William H. Haywood junr. published this day in the National Intelligencer a notice to the People of North-Carolina, that he intends to publish in a few days an address to them in justification of his recent resignation of his Seat as a member of the Senate of the United States.

I received a Letter from George H. Derby, brevet second Lieutenant of the Ordnance, whose admission as a Cadet at the West Point Academy, I had obtained by the favour of John Bell, Secretary of War in 1842, and who has recently graduated 7th. of his class, soliciting my influence to obtain for him a transfer from the Ordnance to the Corps of Topographical engineers I called this morning at the Pension Office with some additional papers in support of the claim of Eleanor Shepherd, which I left with the Commissioner. Then on Coll. J. J. Abert and was referred by him to Genl Scott, who after some pourparler sent for Coll. Talcott and finally promised to me that Lieutt. George H. Derby should be transferred to the corps of Topographical engineers— In the house a Resolution was adopted to close debate on the Warehousing bill at Noon this day— The debate itself was a mockery— The engrossment of the bill was carried 117 to 52— Grinnell and Winthrop voting for it— Ashmun, Hudson— D. P. King, Rockwell, and Thompson with me voting against it— Abbott did not vote— It is the golden key to f. . . on the revenue—The Bill was passed and returned without amendment to the Senate— Private bills from the Senate were then taken up, 4 of which were passed— A bill for the relief of Harriette Ward, widow of a Lieutenant in the Navy produced a perfect anarchy of two hours in the house and then was passed without further struggle— Army appropriation Bill— Disagreements between the two houses— Conference could not agree— Senate adhere— Ashmun move to recede lost 67 to 69— Dromgoole excused from voting— House insist and ask a second conference— Amendments of Senate to the subtreasury bill referred to the Committee of Ways and Means—Adjourned—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives, the Chaplain of the House preached his last Sermon for the Session from Ecclesiasts 9.10 [“]Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might: for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge nor wisdom in the grave whither thou goest” Mr Milburn is said to be blind, but he has no appearance of it at the Clerks table whence he speaks—and he walks without a guide— He was brought here from what is called the far West and among the worshipers of the wilds passes for eloquent— His discourses consist of commonplace Calvinism without intolerance or dogmatism— Quiet, inoffensive, pious, moral, but to my judgment so far from eloquent that from my constant attendance upon his ministrations on the Sabbath through this long Session, there is not a thought which I have heard from him remaining in my Memory. There was this morning a dedication of a new Baptist Church in E Street East of the Post-Office to which I received a printed circular invitation from the Trustees, but which I did not attend— There was no service this afternoon at St. John’s church—and I believe none at the second Presbyterian which is now without a Pastor The change from the Summer to the autumnal atmosphere commenced this day a full fortnight earlier than usual—and with the change a corresponding one is promised of my health— I read a few pages of the philosophy of the plan of Salvation—Calvinism in extremis— But I am yet under the influence of indolence— Is it strenua inertia?

I received this morning from the adjutant General Roger Jones a copy of an order from the War Department transferring Brevet 2d. Lieutenant George H. Derby from the Ordnance Department to the Corps of Topographical Engineers. Letter of 1. Augt. from my Son— Offer for my house in Hancock Street— H.R.U.S. Washington Hunt New-York moved to suspend the rules for an amendment of the Constitution to make the President ineligible for a second term and to prohibit the appointment of Members of Congress to Office— Suspension of Rules and even yeas and nays refused Dodge of Iowa moved a gratuity from the contingent fund to the officers, clerks, messengers, pages and labourers, like that bestowed by the Senate on theirs— Lost 75 to 77— Garrett Davis moved to suspend the rules for a Committee of enquiry whether the Treasury Department is issuing paper money.— Suspension of the Rules refused. Martin of Wisconsin moved a distribution of books to the members of this Congress which have been furnished to the members of the last— Dromgoole moved to lay the Resolution on the table—lost—69 to 96. Distribution carried 89 to 73. Ligon moved to close debate on the French spoliation Bill at 2. P.M this day— Motion laid on the table— Veto of the River and Harbour Bill received from P.U.S. Moderate debate thereon till the adjournment at 4.— Visit from Elliot C. Cowdin of Boston, with an invitation on behalf of the Boston Mercantile Library association to deliver a Lecture before them next October, which I promised conditionally—my health permitting. Subject our Country. Evening visits from Theodore Moody. Archibald Campbell and his brother from Albany.

I received a Letter from J. B. Howard, of 31. July Walpole, Massachusetts, with a petition from him and 4 others with an alternative of separation by Mason and Dickson’s line— And a Letter from Mr Washington Hunt, requesting an Autograph for Mrs. Hunt. H.R.U.S. The Veto Message was resumed— John Wentworth had moved an amendment to Dromgoole’s motion to print the Veto Message, to print with it parts of the President’s annual message, to shew his inconsistency.— After some debate the previous question was carried on the Vetoed Bill, the vote on which was 95 to 93. a majority but not two thirds so that the bill was lost.— French spoliation Bill Hamlin moved to close the debate in one hour. Cobb moved to lay the bill on the table lost 68 to 113— Thurman, M’Clelland, Cobb occupied the whole hour against the bill and when the time for voting came a swarm of amendments to defeat the bill followed, all rejected.— It was reported without amendment, under the previous question, passed for engrossment 93 to 88—passed for enactment 94 to 87—and reconsideration refused 79 to 95. Relief from long and deep agitation— I went this Evening to the astronomical Observatory to take a glance at the moon near full (7th. 1.10. A.M.) through. the Frauenhofer Refractor. Lieutt. Maury was not there— Mr Hubbard was— I saw the Moon, Antares and Saturn— Three Gentlemen, one of whom was a member of Congress with three Ladies were also there. I came home about 10 in the Evening. The Steamer Hibernia arrived yesterday morning at Boston— Left Liverpool 19. July Whig ministry in England— Lord John Russell, premier— Oregon Treaty ratified.

I received a Letter from Ben P. Green a son of Duff Green soliciting my aid to carry through the house an item of appropriation for compensation as Chargé d’Affaires U.S. at Mexico.— And a Letter from George Jay 18 July Pentonville. H.R.U.S. Among the Bills and Amendments from the Senate were Amendments to Amendments of the house upon the Senate Bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands to actual settlers— Brodhead moved to lay the Bill on the table— M’Clernand moved a call of the House—refused 56. to 113. and the bill was laid on the table 184 to 59. This was retaliation for the veto upon the river and harbour Bill—but nothing more— It will not save the public lands—but abandon to ruin the Northern and Eastern harbours— I reached the house immediately after the vote was taken, and did not vote upon it—the Amendments of the Senate to the Subtreasury, were after a feeble struggle all concurred in, and after the rejection of a motion by George Ashmun to lay the Bill on the table it was finally passed. 101 to 77— A bill from the Senate to remit duties on the importation of Rail road iron was at the motion of Roberts of Missouri laid on the table 131 to 41. M’Kay moved several resolutions respecting the distribution of books to members Navy Appropriation Bill— Committee rose for lack of Quorum— Adjourned by yeas and nays. 74 to 63. Conversation with Elisha Whittlesey about judge John M’Lean— Evening visits from Mr and Mrs Francis B. Stockton and from Mrs Talbot and her daughter Mary— I went to Mr Frye’s with a Letter from J. M. Poe Baltimore proposing to rent the Columbia Mills for a Cotton factory—

Fahrenheit 86. at Sunrise— Blazing Sun all day long— Flat calm day and Night: The very calenture of the Summer. Its effects upon me, body and mind I cannot describe— I received a note from Miss Milligan, with the present of a miniature painted by her of my dear wife; Also a Letter from Thomas J Smith Hendrick’s Mill, Russell Co. Virginia—with a Newspaper the Virginian 11. July 1846. published at Abingdon— Also from M’Lane the Serjeant at arms, my account of compensation for the Session At the house the Report of the Committee of Conference upon the bill for the relief of Richard Elliott was received and adopted and the bill passed That of the second Committee of conference on the army appropriation bill was also adopted and the bill passed— The Civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill and the West Point Academy Bill were before the house upon amendments between the two houses. A joint Resolution to pay for Militia called out by General Gaines with out law, passed as it came from the Senate, rejecting an addition proposed by Jacob Thompson— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Boyd chairman on the Bill reported by Hopkins for the establishment of 185 new Post routes— Bill to establish a Government in the territory of Oregon—debate on the boundary— None in the bill— Anti Slavery clause carried. Grant to Mary widow of Captain Gray failed 73 to 77 The bill passed— Comee. of the whole Union. Tibbatts chairman Peruvian indemnity bill debated— Committee discharged and bill passed— I spoke 10 minutes on the bill to establish the Government of the Oregon Territory— Mrs. Albion K. Parris and her daughter Julia spent part of this Evening with us.

I received a Letter from my old friend John Davis, late, and many years judge of U.S. District Court Massachusetts— It is all in his own handwriting and almost illegible—but encloses 8 lines of verse full of calm, philosophical and pious resignation under the decays of nature in the last stage of human life— My sympathies with him are more than fraternal. At the House the report of the second conference on the army appropriation Bill was accepted and the bill passed— The civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was labouring with amendments pile upon pile between the two houses— While discussing these Amendments the house took a recess from 3 to 5 P.M. and at the invitation of Mr Grinnell, I went and dined with him and his fellow lodgers at Mrs Whitwells— Mrs Grinnell Mrs Davis and all the Ladies of the party are gone— There was a light shower with distant thunder while we were at dinner. On returning to the house at 5 O’Clock; I found the Speaker had resumed the Chair, but there was no Quorum— I moved a call of the House which was carried— At the first roll call 109 and at the second 140, when further proceedings were suspended The civil and diplomatic appropriation bill was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hopkins chairman and debated till 10 at night when the Committee rose—the previous Question was moved—a motion by Dromgoole to adjourn was lost and the same motion immediately after by Hamlin was carried— I went and took up the Ladies, at the lodgings of Mr and Mrs Stockton where they had spent the Evening.

Morning call from Lund Washington senior with an engraved portrait of General George Washington which he seemed to think a novelty, and wished a certificate from me of it as a likeness— It was the engraving of Trumbull’s Trenton portrait of which I told him I possessed a copy purchased at the Hague in May 1795. but I could not certify it as a strong likeness. C. P. Montgomery and George Green were also here. H.R.U.S— The usual intercourse of conferences upon disagreeing votes between the two houses upon several bills occupied great part of the day, but the event, was a Message, asking an appropriation of two millions of dollars, to negotiate a Peace with Mexico— Referred on Dromgoole’s motion to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Moses Norris of New-Hampshire Chairman— M’Kay introduced a Bill. Close debate— Recess from 3 to 5— Limitation of the debate— Whig vacillation— Queer speeches on all sides mixed motives and impulses David Wilmot’s proviso— M’Kay at my suggestion modified his proposed bill. Jos R. Ingersoll’s substitute. David Wilmot’s proviso again— M’Kay’s modified Bill with Wilmot’s proviso reported to the house 77 to 59.— Tibbatts moved to lay it on the table lost 78 to 94— Wick—Barringer Grider Bill engrossed 85 to 73— PassedRefusal to reconsider 70 to 83— M’Kay voted against the Bill and all the South—Whig or Democrat— Massachusetts Adams Hudson, Rockwell, Thompson Winthrop vote for the bill— Abbot, Ashmun, Grinnell, D. P. King did not vote— M’Kay move to suspend 16th. joint rule to send the bill to the to the Senate—Carried. Adjourned ten minutes before 11— French spoliation bill vetoed When I came home I found Archibald Campbell, and Isaac Hull Adams here. Proclamation of the Oregon Treaty—

There was no preaching at the Capitol— I attended the morning service at St John’s church where Mr Pyne read the prayers for the ninth Sunday after Trinity, and preached from John 3.18 [“]He that believeth on him is not condemned: but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.” The discourse was upon Faith and disclosed to my mind no new idea.— On Saturday 5. August 1809—I sailed from Charlestown for St. Petersbourg with my wife, and child Charles F. and others— The next day 6. August 1809 was the ninth Sunday after Trinity and I read to my wife on board ship the service of that day, with an impression which is not effaced— And all the while we were in Europe we continued the practice— Mr Pyne’s discourse was upon saving Faith—a perplexing subject— At 4 this afternoon I attended at the second Presbyterian church, where the Revd. Mr Patten of the Columbian College, preached from Philippians 4.6 [“]Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known unto God.”— The Sermon was upon prayer—supplication with thanksgiving— Mr Patten made no remarks upon the injunction to be careful for nothing—which deserves and perhaps requires a qualifying commentary— The spirit of the gospel is frequently monitory against the excess of worldly cares but it is only the excess that is forbidden, to which the more selfish morality of Solomon might lead— To be careful for nothing is a hyperbole a figure of speech often used by Jesus— We had evening visits from Mr Moseley to take leave from Mr M’Rea and Lieutenant Thom.

Close of 1 Session 28. Congress.  The House met at 8 O’Clock A.M. The adjournment was fixed at Noon for the convenience of members many of whom departed in the Railway Cars for Baltimore at that hour— The day like all the last days of a Session of Congress was a Chaos of confusion— It began by a Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Howell Cobb chairman upon an amendment of the Senate to the Navy appropriation Bill— There was a large majority to disagree to the Senates amendment but no quorum voting— Cobb declared the disagreement carried though Garrett Davis had called for a division and remonstrated that there was no quorum. Cobb rode rough shod over Garrett Davis, and was sustained in his false report, by the Speaker John W Davis who in mockery of Garrett Davis’s remonstrance said he could receive nothing as done in Committee but the Report of the Chairman— He put the question of concurring with the amendment of the Senate which was rejected 84 to 48— The Bill afterwards passed, by a report from a Committee of Conference, so did the civil and diplomatic appropriation bill— A joint Committee was appointed to inform P.U.S. that the two houses would adjourn at Noon but they made no report— Sims of S.C. and W. W. Campbell of New York moved to take up the bill for the relief of Elizabeth Hamilton—but failed— As the hand of the Clock was on the line of 12. the Speaker declared the house adjourned to the first Monday in December. At that moment John Davis was prosing in the Senate about, the two Million Peace bill with David Wilmot’s anti-slavery for proviso—which thereby fell through G. Ashmun had a letter from Captain Geisinger. Kavasales was here— My Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs Talbot’s— I joined them there and met there Mrs Newman and Mrs Thornton— Walk home— Mr Larned was also there.
4 January 1848

Sommerauer is a petitioner to Congress for a pension—for services and sufferings in the last War— A bill for his relief passed the house at the late Session but slumped in the Senate and he now comes as a mendicant— Mrs Royalls Sally came upon the same errand— I called at the Department of State and claimed my copy of the 6th. Volume of the American Archives 4th. series, which Mr Markoe promised to send me to my house— We had some talk about the Smithsonian bequest act—just passed— At the National Intelligencer Office I saw Mr Gales—directed the paper to be sent to me after next Thursday at Quincy, and enquired if he had Yancey’s address to his Constituents on resigning his seat in Congress. He had not, but promised to publish it— At the Hall of the house of Representatives I withdrew from my table draw the remnant of my papers which I had left there yesterday; and made enquiries without success for the Peaslee petition and papers— In the Evening we had numerous visitors and music— Various singing with accompaniment of the Piano— Miss Lagniel and Mary Louisa Schroeder Campbell and I. H. Adams— At dinner I felt a hoarseness and sore throat coming upon me which increased all the Evening till it went with me to bed— My ailments frequently change their seats but allow me no respite—

5.30. Restless Night— My sore throat turns to my old catarrhal cough— Tussis senilis. Kavasales came almost despairing of his prospect. I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and settled my account there. deposited the Speaker check for 102.60 the balance of my pay for the Session and drawing my own check for 460.10—the balance to my credit in the bank 460.10— I went next to the Navy Department, where the Secretary Bancroft gave me an order Kavasales to proceed to Norfolk Va and report to Commodore Wilkinson for duty at the Navy yard— We had some conversation concerning the Letter of Captain Geisinger to Mr Ashmun— Commodore Morris came in while I was there. Next to the Pension Office— Nathaniel Chick has not been there since I went with him— Mr Bancroft spoke to me of my father’s papers, and particularly of the note from Samuel Adams to him respecting the answer to Hutchinson’s message— I sent a copy of Fremonts Report to J. Carpenter—Blissfield Lenawee County, Michigan— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and Mary dined at Mr. and Mrs Stockton’s The Ladies rode out this evening, and took tea at Mrs Seaton’s— She sent us a basket of very fine fruit—Pears, plums nectarines and peaches— We had several evening visitors; but I was so unwell with cough and headache, that I had retired to bed and did not see them— The preparations for departure, and the unrelenting heat of the dog-days aggravate my complaints— I finished reading the Book of Psalms in a course commenced of the Bible 1. December 1845

Mr Kavasales came again and I delivered to him the order from the Secretary of the Navy to proceed to Norfolk Va. and report himself to Commodore Wilkinson for duty at that station as Chaplain, which Mr Bancroft had put into my hands yesterday and for which Kavasales expressed himself warmly grateful— After the bustle of a Caravan departure with my wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary Louisa at 5 this afternoon I repaired to the train of Railway Cars for Baltimore— They started at 1/2 past 5. and in two hours landed us at the Depot in Baltimore; whence a hack immediately conveyed us to Barnum’s Hotel, in Monument square. With us as attendants are Thomas Dumphy, Coachman and Margaret Dulany housemaid— Mrs El. Goods also came with us, going with her daughter Janeto visit her daughter Catherine married to Jacob Carr at Quincy— Dr Thomas came with us to Baltimore. Mrs Goods with her daughter Jane and Margaret Dulany proceeded by the Night Steamer to Philadelphia We passed the Evening at Barnum’s Hotel with more than usual relief from the canicular Sun and Nights of Washington where the average of Fahrenheit has for the last three weeks has been with the exception of 3 cold days 86.— I left the draft of the Treasurer of Pennsylvania Snowden on the Bank of Pennsylvania in favour of Nathaniel Chick with Lieutt. Thom who promised to deliver it to the Commissioner of Pensions tomorrow— I suppose Chick will apply there— It is more than 3 weeks since he last came to me and I have been expecting him every day since.

Mr Kavasales came again and I delivered to him the order from the Secretary of the Navy to proceed to Norfolk Va. and report himself to Commodore Wilkinson for duty at that station as Chaplain, which Mr Bancroft had put into my hands yesterday and for which Kavasales expressed himself warmly grateful— After the bustle of a Caravan departure with my wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary Louisa at 5 this afternoon I repaired to the train of Railway Cars for Baltimore— They started at 1/2 past 5. and in two hours landed us at the Depot in Baltimore; whence a hack immediately conveyed us to Barnum’s Hotel, in Monument square. With us as attendants are Thomas Dumphy, Coachman and Margaret Dulany housemaid— Mrs El. Goods also came with us, going with her daughter Janeto visit her daughter Catherine married to Jacob Carr at Quincy— Dr Thomas came with us to Baltimore. Mrs Goods with her daughter Jane and Margaret Dulany proceeded by the Night Steamer to Philadelphia We passed the Evening at Barnum’s Hotel with more than usual relief from the canicular Sun and Nights of Washington where the average of Fahrenheit has for the last three weeks has been with the exception of 3 cold days 86.— I left the draft of the Treasurer of Pennsylvania Snowden on the Bank of Pennsylvania in favour of Nathaniel Chick with Lieutt. Thom who promised to deliver it to the Commissioner of Pensions tomorrow— I suppose Chick will apply there— It is more than 3 weeks since he last came to me and I have been expecting him every day since.

After a Night of calm repose, I rose at half past 4. this morning. Fahrenheit 86. We breakfasted at 8 and took the train of Railway Cars which started at 9. A.M. from Baltimore for Philadelphia From Barnum’s hotel to the Dipot we went in a hack, then in the Cars drawn by horses to the borders of the City, where the horses were dismissed and the Locomotive took their place— At 3. P.M we reached the outskirts of Philadelphia where horses again took the place of the Locomotive and landed us at the depot in Market Street— Thence we proceeded to Jone’s Union Hotel in Chesnut Street— There we dined at the Lady’s ordinary and at half past 4. proceeded to Walnut Street Wharf and embarked in the Steamer which in an hour and a half landed us at Bristol— There we entered the train of Cars and passing through Trenton, Princeton, New Brunswick, Rahway, and Elizabeth Town and Newark at 9 in the Evening, brought us to Jersey City safe— We crossed the ferry and taking a hack at the fort of Cortland Street at 9.45 reached the Astor House New York. The transportation of this day from Baltimore to New York was but a trivial incident now common to hundreds every day in the year, and many days to thousands— I met on the way—Sundry fellow travellers with whom I had previous slightly remembered or forgotten acquaintance— The only remarkable one of which was the late Vice President of the United States John acting and self styled President of the United States John Tyler and his eldest son Robert— Civilities very polite but on my part cool passed between us— We had two German women with harps who played and sung popular songs accompanied by a Male Clarion, and made delightful music and pleasant pastime—

After a Night of calm repose, I rose at half past 4 this morning— Fahrenheit 86— We breakfasted at 8. and took the train of Railway cars which started at 9 A.M from Baltimore for Philadelphia— From Barnum’s hotel to the depot we went in a hack—then in the cars drawn by horses to the borders of the city, where the horses were dismissed: and the locomotive took their place— At 3. P.M we reached the out-skirts of Philadelphia where horses again took the place of the locomotive and landed us at the depot in market street— Thence we proceeded in a hack to Jonas’s Union Hotel in Chesnut street There we dined at the Lady’s ordinary and at half past 4 proceeded in a hack to Walnut Street wharf, and embarked in the Steamer which in an hour and a half landed us at Bristol— There we entered the train of cars, and passing through Trenton, Princeton, New Brunswick, Rahway, Elizabeth town and Newark, at 9 in the Evening, brought us to Jersey city safe— We crossed the ferry and taking a hack at the foot of Cortland Street at 9.45—reached the Astor house New-York. The transportation of this day from Baltimore to New York, was but a trivial incident now common to hundreds every day in the year and many days to thousands— I met on the way sundry fellow travellers with whom I had previous slightly remembered or forgotten acquaintance, the only remarkable one of which was the late Vice-President of the United States acting and self styled President of the United States, John Tyler, and his eldest son Robert Tyler— Civilities, very polite, but on my part cool passed between us. We had two German women with harps who played and sung popular songs accompanied by a male Clarion, and made delightful music and pleasant pastime—

properties.dateline: New York. Saturday 15 August 1846—Long Island. Norwich. Worcester. Boston. Quincy.
properties.text: V. I rose after a good night at 5. Breakfasted at 6.15. Left the Astor house at 6.45. Crossed the battery ferry at 7. Took the Long Island train of Railway Cars from Brooklyn to Greenport 95 miles. Straggely barren strand all the way— Almost suffocated with dust. embarked at 11 in the Steamer Cinderella In company with Mr. & Mrs. John— A— Rockwell to Norwich their residence where they took leave of us— Cool rain from Norwich to Worcester. Then through Framingham Natick, Newton, Brighton, to Boston where just before 6 P.M. we alighted at the United States Hotel immediately opposite the Rail road Depot— Tea at the United States Hotel— At 1/2 past 7. the train of Cars of the Old Colony Railroad start— My Son was at the depot to meet us with his Son John Quincy— Both of them came out with us; as did Ex President of Harvard University Josiah Quincy—and Captain Dimmock a new resident of the town— The Stations where the Cars stop are at Savan Hill, Dorchester, Neponset, and Quincy each of which was announced by the Conductor as the Cars reached the Station— At the Depot at Quincy there was a considerable assemblage of persons, to whom as we alighted Captain Dimmock announced with a loud voice the arrival home of John Quincy Adams Representative in Congress of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, whereupon there was a shout of three cheers. I apologized for not returning thanks, in a speech by the extinction of my voice— Our Carriage took us from the Depot home, where we found my Son’s wife with her two sons Charles and Henry to receive us— margaret Delany the waiting maid had reached here before us with Mrs. Eleanor Goods and her daughter Jane Goods— John Kirk and his wife Elizabeth were also here and welcomed us home—

V. Blessing, praise and supplication to God on first rising from bed, on returning to my earthly home, after an absence of nine months in the public service of my Country— Some discouragement of Soul follows the reflection, that my aspirations to live in the memory, of after ages, as a benefactor to my Country, and of mankind, have not received the sanction of my Maker— That the longing, of my Soul through a long life, to be numbered among the blessings bestowed by the Creator on the race of man is rejected, and after being trammelled and counteracted and disabled, at every step of my progress my faculties are now declining from day to day into mere helpless impotence— Yet—at the will of my heavenly Father why should I repine? Dr. John Pierce of Brookline preached at the Stone Temple this day by exchange with the Revd Mr. Lunt His morning Sermon was from Deuteronomy— 1—21— “Behold the Lord thy God hath set the land before thee; go up and possess it, as the Lord God of thy fathers hath said unto thee, fear not, neither be discouraged”— Dr. Pierce was not thinking of Texas, Mexico, or Oregon, but of the Reports of Caleb and Joshua on returning from their exploration of the Land of Canaan and of the heavenly land set before the Christian of the present age for his exploration and possession All his applications to our times were spiritual— Dr. Pierce dined with us— His afternoon Discourse was from Acts 11.26—“And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch” This is an incident of historical fact very curious, and interesting upon which the commentary might have been broader and deeper Dr. Pierce is of the salt of the earth— I commenced reading the Book of Proverbs and with a view to go through the remainder of the Bible by the close of the present year I propose to read henceforth 4 chapters every day—

V.— Blessing praise and supplication to God on first rising from bed, on returning to my earthly home after an absence of nine months in the public service of my Country— Some discouragement of Soul follows the reflection that my aspirations to live in the memory of after ages as a benefactor of my country and of mankind, have not received the sanction of my maker— That the longing of my Soul through a long life to be numbered among the blessing bestowed by the Creator on the race of man is rejected, and after being trammeled and counteracted and disabled at every step of my progress my faculties are now declining from day to day into mere helpless impotence— Yet—at the will of my heavenly father why should I repine? Dr. John Pierce of Brookline preached at the Stone Temple this day by exchange with the Revd. Mr Lunt— His morning Sermon was from Deuteronomy 1.21. “Behold, the Lord thy God hath set the land before thee: go up, and possess it, as the Lord God of thy fathers hath said unto thee: fear not, neither be discouraged”— Dr Pierce was not thinking of Texas Mexico or Oregon, but of the Reports of Caleb and Joshua on returning from their exploration of the Land of Canaan, and of the heavenly land set before the Christian of the present age for his exploration and possession— All his applications to our times were spiritual— Dr Pierce dined with us— His afternoon discourse was from Acts 11.26. “And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch.” This is an incident of historical fact very curious and interesting upon which the commentary might have been broader and deeper— Dr Pierce is of the salt of the earth— I commenced reading the book of Proverbs, and with a view to go through the remainder of the Bible by the close of the present year I propose to read henceforth 4 chapters every day—

IV.30.  I return to a quiet home, and to more than voluntary repose My health apparently firmer than at any time within the last fifteen months, but shaking more and more. I rose with coming daylight but the sky was beclouded, and I could get neither a first sight of Sirius nor of the rising Sun— The first thing that riveted my attention to the progress of civilization and Society in my native Village was the rush by my windows of the train of Cars from Boston to Plymouth at 5.45. followed at 6.45 by the return train from Plymouth to Boston— I was all day thinking of a fixed steady specific occupation for the Season during the recess of Congress— I had an unexpected but only momentary morning visit from William. Clarkson. Johnson, from Utica, New York where he says he has opened a Lawyer’s Office, and has as much business as he can do— My only excursion this day was about sunset when I walked up to my Son’s House where I found them at tea—He went to bathe at Daniel Greenleaf’s landing and his wife came to my house with me— My wife was quite ill and almost the whole day confined to her bed. My Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith came out from Boston to spend the Summer with us— Evening visit from Ex President Josiah Quincy, who left me an invitation from his Son Mayor of Boston to attend at the breaking ground of the Aqueduct at Long Pond next Thursday— Also an invitation from William D. Parker, Loring Norcross and James Whitney Subcommittee of the City Council to the same celebration I have received also an invitation from the President of Harvard University Mr. Everett to the Commencement on the 26th. of this month— I have also a printed Circular from William Mitchell President of the Trustees of the Nantucket Athenaeum, 8th. mo. 12 1846. soliciting contributions—

IV:30.  Johnson William C  Quincy Josiah  Louisa Catherine Smith  I return to a quiet home, and to more than voluntary repose My health apparently firmer than at any time within the last fifteen months, but shaking more and more— I rose with coming dailight, but the sky was beclouded and I could get neither a first sight of Sirius nor of the rising Sun— The first thing that riveted my attention to the progress of civilization and Society in my native village, was the rush by my windows of the train of Railroad cars from Boston to Plymouth at 5.45—followed at 6.45 by the return train from Plymouth to Boston— I was all day thinking of a fixed steady specific occupation for the Season, and during the recess of Congress— I had an unexpected but only momentary morning visit from William Clarkson Johnson—from Utica, New-York where he says he has opened a lawyers office, and has as much business as he can do— My only excursion this day was about sunset when I walked up to my Son’s house, where I found them at tea— He went to bathe at Daniel Greenleaf’s landing, and his wife came to my house with me— My wife was quite ill, and almost the whole day confined to her bed— My Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith came out from Boston to spend the Summer with us. Evening visit from Ex President Josiah Quincy, who left an invitation from his Son, Mayor of Boston, to attend at the breaking ground of the Boston aqueduct at Long Pond next Thursday. Also an invitation from William Parker, Loring Norcross and James Whiting Sub committee of the city Council to the same celebration— I have received also an invitation from the President of Harvard University—Edward Everett to the Commencement on the 26th of this month— I have also a printed circular from William Mitchell President of the Trustees of the Nantucket Athenaeum 8th. mo. 12 1846. Soliciting contributions

IV.30. Change of Season— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 72.  The expectation of leisure is a delusion— I received by mail a Letter from Oscar F. Keeler Columbus Mississippi Augt. 6. 1846. with the fragments of a small glass vial encased in a tin cylinder open at both ends and crushed out of shape; under a paper cover torn into pieces, which had been sealed and addressed Hon John Quincy Adams Quincy; Mass. Glass with care— Postmarked Columbus Mississippi—6 August, and under the words glass with care— Broken on its way from Columbus Miss to Montgomery Al.— The Letter was rolled round the cylinder and as well as the paper cover, is stained all over with the cordial that was in the vial, and is of claret colour— But the Letter itself is in handsome hand writing and not at all defaced— Mr. Keeler says the cordial is a vegetable compound of his own invention, which has cured him of bleeding at the lungs and may others of asthma, bronchitis, and sundry other complaints— That he wishes to make money of it, and sends me a specimen to try, and write him my opinion of it— Harvey Field came to trade with me in land for which I shall refer him to my Son— William. C. Johnson’s was a visit of reconsideration but was as short as that of yesterday—he would not stay to dine— Mr. Lunt’s was a pastoral call— Dr. Parkman came out in his gig and declined staying to tea— The ladies of Mrs. Miller’s family came for half an hour about Sunset— I found Charles and his family at tea— He and his wife walked down with me and spent the short evening with us My wife continues unwell but was able to leave her chamber this Evening— Mrs. John Adams and Mary Louisa are also slightly indisposed—

IV:30. Change of Season— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 72  The expectation of leisure is a delusion—  Field Harvey  Johnson William C.  Lunt. Revd. William P  I received by mail a Letter from Oscar F. Keeler, Columbus Mississippi Augt. 6. 1846 with the fragments of a small glass vial, encased in a tin cylinder open at both ends and crushed out of shape; under a paper cover torn into pieces, which had been sealed, addressed Hon. John Q. Adams. Quincy; Mass— Glass with care— Postmarked Columbus Mi. Augt. 6—and under the words Glass with care Broken on its way from Columbus Miss to Montgomery Al— The Letter was rolled round the cylinder and as well as the paper cover is stained all over with the cordial that was in the vial and is of claret colour— But the Letter itself is in handsome hand writing and not at all defaced— Mr Keeler says the cordial is a vegetable compound of his own invention which has cured him of bleeding at the lungs and many others of asthma, bronchitis and sundry other complaints That he wishes to make money of it, and sends me a specimen to try, and write him my opinion of it.  Parkman Dr George  Mrs Edward Miller.  Mrs Smith  Mrs George T. Bigelow  Miss Caroline Spooner.  The visitors of the morning are in the upper margin— Those of the afternoon this lower one— Harvey Field came to trade with me in land for which I shall refer him to my Son— William C. Johnson’s was a visit of reconsideration but was as short as that of yesterday—he would not stay to dine— Mr Lunts was a pastoral call— Dr Parkman came out in his gig and declined staying to tea— The Ladies of Mrs Miller’s family came for half an hour about Sunset— I found Charles and his family at tea— He and his wife walked down with me and spent the short evening with us. My wife continues unwell but was able to leave her chamber this Evening. Mrs John Adams and Mary Louis are also slightly indisposed.

IV.30— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50. at the outer door—  I took yesterday morning a seidlitz powder, which put me on the sick list for the day, which continues this day of transition from intense dog day heat to Autumnal frigidity— I received a diploma in the Latin Language from the Societas Philozetiana of the College of the Westernat Hudson in the Republic of Ohio constituting me an honorary member of that Society in consideration of my Labours for Science and Letters and of my friendly regard for such institutions— There is a large Seal appended to a blue silk ribband to this diploma which is signed by R. O. Hammond Scribe, but is not signed by the President of the Society— What the Societas Philozetiana is I am not advised and do not understand the etymology of the word—Philozetiana— Afternoon visit from Peter P. F. Degrand who brought with him a budget of newspapers, and Evening visits from our neighbours, George. W. Beale—with his daughters Ann Beale and Caroline Beale, and Mr. Emmons who invited me to join a party for an excursion to Fall River and Newport by Railway and Steamer the day after tomorrow— The British Steamer arrived this day at Boston— Sailed from Liverpool on the 4th. I walked up to my Son’s house to see the setting Sun— They spend the Evening here— My—is troublesome and the state of my mind gives me concern— My powers of thought scatter like the wind sparks of an exploding sky rocket and I feel as if I were awaking from a nightmare dream—

IV:30. Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50 at the outer door.  66 in my chamber.  Andrews Samuel. with Halibut and Mackerel  Ambush William Edward, Shaver.  Mr and Mrs Minott of Neponset village— Mrs Josiah Quincy. with her two daughters Susan and Anna—and the two Miss Tufts’s Susan and Mercy from Weymouth— I took yesterday morning a Seidlitz powder which put me on the sick list for the day, which continues this day of transition from intense dog day heat to Autumnal frigidity.— I received a diploma in the Latin language, from the Societas Philozetiana of the College of the Western Reserve at Hudson in the Republic of Ohio, constituting me an honorary member of that Society in consideration of my Labours for Science and Letters, and of my friendly regard for such institutions. There is a large Seal appended to a blue silk ribband to this diploma which is signed by R. O. Hammond Scribe, but is not signed by the President of the Society— What the Societas Philozetiana is I am not advised, and do not understand the etymology of the word Philozetiana— Afternoon visit from P. P. F. Degrand who brought with him a budget of Newspapers— And Evening visits from our neighbours George W. Beale with his daughters Ann and Caroline andEmmons.— Who invited me to join a party for an excursion to Fall River and Newport by Railway and Steamer the day after tomorrow.— The British Steamerarrived this day at Boston— Sailed from Liverpool on the 4th. I walked up to my Sons house to see the setting Sun— They spent the Evening here— My Tussis senilis is troublesome, and the state of my mind gives me concern— My powers of thought scatter like the sparks end of an exploding skyrocket, and I feel as if I was awaking from a Nightmare dream

Fahrenheit at Sunrise 44—  He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both are abomination to the Lord.  —Proverbs 17.15.  At eight oclock this morning I walked to the Quincy Station depot of the Old Colony Railroad where I met my Son— Took my Seat in the train of cars which then came in from South Braintree for Boston—25 cents a ticket— Josiah Quincy late President of Harvard University and his Son in Law Waterston were also in the Cars— There are three Stations on the way—Neponset, just beyond the river. Dorchester, and Savin hill— We reached the depot opposite the United States Hotel about 8.45. I walked with Mr. Quincy and Mr. Waterston to the house where Mr. Waterston now resides in ——— street. Here I passed an hour, chiefly inspecting an Album sent from England by Mr. Coleman, the jewel of which was an original Letter from Edmund Burke to Sir William Hamilton at Naples. How the hour passed away I know not but a quarter before ten we walked to the depot of the Providence Railroad and found there Josiah Quincy junior Mayor, and the City Council of Boston with whom I went to Long Pond in Wayland to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct to the City of Boston— This ceremony of striking the spade foot into the ground was performed by the Mayor after a short address to him from Nathan Hale in the name of the Water Commissioners and a handsome speech of about ten minutes from him— He threw up the first shovel full of earth and then with a compliment invited me to strike the second which I did and his father 3d. Passed Mayor of Boston struck the third. The spade had been made for the occasion and had on its handle a Silver inscription recording in advance the transaction— The company then repaired to a temporary Shed a tabernacle at hand and sat down to the number of about 300. to a temperance cold collation at which the Mayor presided— The company then returned in the cars to Boston just in time for me to take the Cars of the Old Colony Railroad at 5. P.M. for Quincy. I alighted with my neighbor Mr Emmons, at the Bridge close to my remaining barn, and found my dear wife ill in bed— Charles came home in the 7. oclock train, and with his wife passed an hour of the Evening here— My health continues to promise, but my Memory, where is it?

Fahrenheit At Sunrise 54. with rain—  To do justice and judgment, is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice  Proverbs 21.3  Say not, I will do so to him, as he hath done to me; I will render to the man according to his works—  24.29–  The Newspapers from Boston contain full reports of the excursion yesterday of the Mayor and City Council, to Lake Cochetuitte otherwise called Long Pond to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct, to furnish Boston with water. I drank a glass of the water on the border of the pond drawn from 20 feet beneath the surface, fresh, cool, pure and soft as I ever tasted. I received a small duodecimo volume entitled Norman’s New Orleans and Environs, containing a brief historical sketch of the Territory and State of Louisiana from the earliest period to the present time, presenting a complete guide to all subjects of general interest in the Southern Metropolis, with a correct and improved map of the City, pictorial illustrations of public buildings in New Orleans—published by B. M. Norman. 1845— Degrand sent me out from Boston Wilmer and Smiths Liverpool European Times of theinst, containing a voluminous account of the visit of Prince Albert, the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland’s husband to Liverpool to lay the corner stone of a building to be called the Sailors home not a hospital, but a boarding and lodging house for Seamen— I slipped through the hours from Breakfast at 8 till Noon, in reading the narrative of this princely pageant— Degrand sent me also, a Map shewing the proposed Railroads from Bridgewater to the Old Colony Railroad, extracted from Bordens State Map. By T. J. Carter Engineer— Towards Sunset I walked out and visited Elizabeth C. Adams, and there met Mrs. Stebbins her late mothers sister, Mrs. Archibald Campbell with her two infant children, Mrs. Boyd another daughter of Mr. Charles Harrod, and two Misses Morgan, sisters of his present wife— I called also to see Mrs. Edward Miller at her house, but she was at her Son in Law George. T. Bigelow’s— I walked home my Son and his wife were here an hour of the Evening— My wife was still confined by sickness all this day to her bed— The weather deterred me from joining in the excursion to Newport proposed by Mr. Emmons and Mr. Beale—
