IV. 15  Thick fog— Fahrenheit after Sunrise 58.— “Boast not thyself of tomorrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.” Proverbs 27.1  Morning visitors— Dr. Woodward— The Holbrooks are sons of Ichabod Holbrook a Lieutenant in the Army of the revolutionary War, a pensioner under the Act of 1818, till he died in 1823— These are his children, claimants. The two Holbrooks, Howard in the right of his wife Hannah, a sister of the Holbrooks, and another sister named Elizabeth Kennedy—there was another sister named Relief Ryan, who died since last November when they applied to me before. See my Diary for 25 November 1845. Vol. 19. p. 310. But I could tell them nothing of the state of their claim not knowing where to look for their papers— I found however a Letter from Nathaniel Holbrook, Randolph 6. January 1846. with enquiries concerning his claim in right of his father Nathaniel Holbrook who he says drew a pension from 1818, to June 1845, when he died— These are two distinct claims— Walter Hall was here with lobsters. I took one for eight cents— My wife is convalescent and was up part of this day— I began an attempt for a generall assortment of my papers which are in a Chaos of confusion, and which I would fain put in order for my Execution— They embrace a period of seventy years, besides those of my father which extend to twenty years more— This movement must be systematic, continuous, and persevering, and includes the making of my last Will, to supersede that of 14th. October 1832—since which, great changes have taken place both in my family and my property— Relying on divine Mercy for the continuance of my life, and health I propose to postpone the makings of my Will till next Summer, and to avail myself of this Season to set my house in order— Charles and his wife spent their Evening hour here—

IV:15. Thick fog— Fahrenheit after Sunrise 58—  Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth. Proverbs 27.1. Holbrook Randolph 6. Jany 1846 with enquiries concerning his claim in right of his father Nathaniel Holbrook who he says drew a pension from 1838 to June 1845 when he died— These are two distinct claims— Walter Wall was here with lobsters of which I took one for 8 cents.— My wife is convalescent and was up, part of this day— I began an attempt for a general assortment of my papers which are in a Chaos of confusion, and which I would fain put in order for my Executor— They embrace a period of seventy years, besides those of my father which extend to twenty years more. This movement must be systematic, continuous and persevering and includes the making of my last Will to supersede that of 14 October 1832—since which great changes have taken place both in my family and my property— Relying on divine Mercy for the continuance of my life and health I propose to postpone the making of my Will till next Summer, and to avail myself of this Season to set my house in order— Charles and his wife spent their Evening hour here

Fahrenheit at Sunrise 65— Sprinkling of rain—  Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him—  —Proverbs 29.20—  The 30th. Chapter of Proverbs (the words of Agur the Son of Jakeh) and the first 9 verses, of the 31st the words of King Lemuel, are not in the Septuagint—  At the stone Temple Mr. Lunt preached this morning from 2 Peter 1.3. “According us his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue” This was a good Sermon, upon the ordinary tune of Mr. Lunt’s compositions never coming down to the level of mediocrity; and never of faltering interest but the discourse of this afternoon from John 14.16. “And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you, another Comforter, that he may abide with you forever 17. Even the Spirit of Truth whom the world cannot receive because it seeth him not neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you”—was transcendant and one of the remarkable discourses that I ever heard He began with a brief historical narrative of the festival days celebrated by the Roman Catholic and English Episcopal churches—Christmas—Easter—Ascension day, and Pentecost, or Whitsunday, when the Holy Ghost descended upon the Apostles— He did not approve of the annual celebration of these days, thinking it tended to superstition, and preferring the simplicity of the puritan worship; but he described with glowing eloquence the transformation of the Apostles in the fifty days between the day of the Crucifixion and the day of the descent of the Holy Ghost—and his application of the subject to the duties of the Auditory was highly solemn and impressive— As I came out of Meeting this afternoon Mrgave me a small pamphlet entitled “Search the Scriptures” by Joseph Adams of the City of Roxbury aged 96. written in support of the Religion brought by our forefathers the pilgrims to Plymouth and against the Unitarian Doctrines—dotage— Charles and his wife here— My wife up this Evening—

IV— Shower bath— Fahrenheit 56. At Sunrise 5:16. Sunset 6—  “To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.”  Ecclesiastes 3.1.  Baxter George—Parish tax collector, with my parish tax—25 May 1846. Poll 1:50. Real Estate 139. Personal Estate and income 100— Total 240.50 They tax me for 69.500 real and 50000 personal Estate— I took the Bill ad referendum—  Ward James, a claimant for a revolutionary pension—86 years old says he was at the Battle of White Plains, and served in the Deane Frigate in 1780.—born in New York— Has no papers Rufus Davis made affidavit to his service afore Elias H. Derby Justice of Peace Boston— Lives in Derne Street— To ascertain tomorrow where E. H. Derby’s Office is, and if testimony for Ward can be obtained there— I took to the shop of Caleb Gill Stationer and bookbinder the manuscript 9th. volume of my Diary from 1. Jany. 1845 to 10. August 1846— closing with the first Session of the 29th. Congress, to be bound— Mr. Gill was not there, but his young man promised that the volume should be bound uniformly with the 18th. volume which was bound there— About half this volume is in hand writing other than mine, chiefly of my Granddaughter Mary Louisa to whom I am greatly obliged for her assistance, cheerfully rendered— I make very slow progress in the assortment of my papers, and an yet unable to begin to write any other than this Diary— I walked up the Hill and saw the sunset clear at 6.16.15. by my Chronometer, and by the American Almanac 6. My Son and his wife spent the Evening hour here— I received by Mail a volume in small 8vo. An Exposition of the weakness and inefficiency of the Government of the United States of North America— Printed for the author 1845. I have an indistinct remembrance of this book; and of some conversation with Joseph. R. Ingersoll concerning it— There is some affectation of mystery in its publication, and in the transmission of this copy of it to me—Anonymous—Without name of place or of printer, and sent me by Mail from Boston—

IV. Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise 5.16. Sunset. 6.  “To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.” Ecclesiastes 3.1.  Baxter George Parish tax collector, with my parish-tax 25 May 1846— Poll 1:50. Real Estate 139. Ward James, a claimant for a revolutionary pension 86 years old says he was at the battle of White Plains and served in the Deane Frigate in 1780—born in New-York— Has no papers— Rufus Davis made affidavit to his service before Elias Hasket Derby Justice of Peace Boston. Derby’s Office is, and if testimony for Ward can be obtained there— I took to the shop of Caleb Gill Stationer and book binder the manuscript 19th. volume of my Diary from 1. Jany 1845 to 10 August 1846. closing with the first Session of the 29th Congress to be bound— Mr Gill was not there, but his young man promised that the volume should be bound uniformly with the 18th. volume which was bound there— About half this volume is in hand writing other than mine—chiefly of my granddaughter Mary Louisa to whom I am greatly obliged for her assistance cheerfully rendered— I make very slow progress in the assortment of my papers, am yet unable to begin to write any thing other than this Diary— I walked up the hill and saw the Sun set clear at 6.16.15 by my Chronometer, and by the American Almanac 6: My Son and his wife spent the Evening hour here— I received by Mail a volume in small 8vo. An Exposition of the weakness and inefficiency of the Government of the United States of North-America— Printed for the author 1845— I have an indistinct remembrance of this book, and of some conversation with Joseph R. Ingersoll concerning it— There is some affectation of mystery in its publication, and in the transmission of this copy of it to me— Anonymous— Without name of place or of printer, and sent to me by mail from Boston—

IV.  Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50 Earthquake— Shower bath— Be not rash with the mouth and let not thine heart be hasty to utter anything before God: for God is in heaven and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few—  —Ecclesiastes 5—2—  Early breakfast, and as the Temple Clock eight, I reached, walking the Depot of the Old Colony Railroad behind French’s Tavern— Ticket to Boston 25. Cents— My Son and his wife and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa went also, but not in company with me— They were bound on a joint party to Mr. Gorham Brooks’ at Medford— We parted at the Depot in Boston— I walked to Number 222 Washington Street and was shaved by Cadmus— Then to my Son’s Office 23 Court Street; where as one of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Exe I executed and acknowledged beforeSpooner Justice of Peace, a deed of part of Wechusett Hill— At the Office of Elias Haskett Derby Justice of Peace, I made enquiries of the papers to support the Revolutionary Pension claim of James Ward— He said they had been all sent, ten or twelve years ago, to the Pension Office at Washington, and his own books, had been burnt— At the Emancipator Office I had a conversation with Joshua Leavitt— Call, at Abbott Lawrence’s, Counting house, but he was not there— Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at noon— James Savage the President and 10 members constituted the Meeting— Call on Robert. C. Winthrop—on C. Hughes at the United States Hotel— Saw Miss Hughes and Miss Paterson Then at James. H. Foster’s— He went with me to the Depot— Railway Cars to Quincy— 32 minutes— Mrs. Stebbins, Mrs. Campbell and Elizabeth. C— Adams were here after dinner— Ex Senator Haywood’s Address to the people of North Carolina— Mary Louisa returned by the train at 8. P.M. with Mrs. Charles from Medford—

IV.15— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 55— Rain— Commencement—  Or ever the Silken cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel, broken at the cistern, 7. There shall the dust return to earth as it was, and the spirit shall return unto God, who gave it. 8— Vanity of Vanities, Saith the Preacher, all is vanity—  —Ecclesiastes 12.67–8—  I want an exposition and commentary upon this passage— I received yesterday from John. G. Palfrey, Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, an invitation to attend at the Council chamber in Boston at 8 O’clock, this morning to accompany the Governor, to Cambridge, to the exercises of Commencement, at Harvard University— Had the weather been fair or indifferent my purpose was to go— But on rising at four oclock, I found the rain, which commenced last Evening still continued with a northeast wind— At seven, notwithstanding the rain, I walked to the Depot, but the train was gone, twenty minutes before, and the next train went at six minutes past eight, too late for me— At nine, came the mail, and brought a rattle from Christopher Hughes, written yesterday morning at the United States Hotel—Boston— I spent the whole morning in examining the condition of my papers, with the purpose of assorting them, and found them in confusion inexpressible— I have to devise even a principle of arrangement for them— I had received on the 17th. of July, a Letter from Stephen— P— Hill and Franklin Wilson Committee of the first Baptist Church. Baltimore, inviting me, to deliver a Lecture, in the course of next Winter, before that Society— The disorder of my correspondence is the unfailing test of my— This Letter has remained, on my file, unanswered, till this afternoon— I now of course decline the invitation, not knowing what a day may bring forth— I received a Pamphlet copy of William. H. Haywood Junr. Address, to the people of North Carolina, under a cover directed by himself, but I did not find time to read it— Charles and his wife spent an evening hour with us— My wife was able to leave her chamber but is yet very much indisposed—

Fahrenheit at Sunrise 55. Rain— Commencement.  Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain or the wheel broken at the cistern. 7. Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was; and the spirit shall return unto God, who gave it. 8 Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, all is vanity. Ecclesiastes 12.6.7.8—  I want an exposition and commentary upon this passage. I received yesterday from John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth an invitation to attend at the Council chamber in Boston at 8 O’Clock this morning to accompany the Governor to Cambridge to the exercises of Commencement at Harvard University— Had the weather been fair or indifferent my purpose was to go— But on rising at 4. I found the rain which commenced last Evening still continued with a Northeast wind— At 7. Notwithstanding the rain I walked to the depot, but the train was gone 20 minutes before, and the next train went at 6 minutes past 8—too late for me. At 9 came the mail and brought a rattle from Christopher Hughes written yesterday morning at the United States Hotel—Boston— I spent the whole morning in examining the condition of my papers with the purpose of assorting them, and found them in confusion inexpressible— I have to devise even a principle of arrangement for them— I had received on the 17th. of July a Letter from Stephen P. Hill and Franklin Wilson Committee of the first Baptist Church of Baltimore inviting me to deliver a Lecture in the course of next winter before that Society— The disorder of my correspondence, is the unfailing test of my caducity— This Letter has remained on my file unanswered till this afternoon— I now of course decline the invitation, not knowing what a day may bring forth— I received a pamphlet copy of William H. Haywood Junr, Address to the People of North-Carolina under a cover directed by himself, but did not find time to read it— Charles and his wife spent an evening hour with us. My wife was able to leave her chamber but is yet much indisposed.

I received last evening from the Revd. L. D. Dewey of New York a Letter intreating me to contribute my opinions on the Bible and the Sabbath, to be published with an account of the Sabbath convention for the District of Columbia held at Washington last December and of which I presided Mr. Dewey was present at that Convention and mentioned his intention, to publish in a pamphlet, at New York, an account of its proceedings, together with a Treatise of Sir Matthew Hale and the opinions of other eminent laymen concerning the Bible and the observance of the Sabbath. He requested a copy of my address to that Convention which was very brief and extemporaneous. But a Reporter for the Baltimore Sun had asked of me a copy of it for publication in that paper— I wrote it out the next morning and gave it to the Reporter who kept it, but it was not published in the Sun, nor at all— There is no other copy of it extant, and it has faded irrecoverably from my memory.— Mr Dewey has repeatedly reminded me of my promise, but all that I can now do, will be to write something for his publication as a substitute for my Address to the Convention— Ruth Turner the seamstress was here this day, and John De Windt departed for an excursion to Boston or Somerville— Charles and his wife were here this evening—

Cloud after rain—  And it shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of the Lord’s house shall be established in the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills and all nations shall flow into it.—  Isaiah 2–2.  I have been watching every morning since I got home for a sight of the rising Sirius the dogstar at his heliacal morning appearance, but there has not been yet an unclouded morning eastern sky, on which he could shew his face— This morning gloomed with fog— I took a Letter for Baltimore to the Post Office and was told that the Southern Mail went out at 5 P.M. Returning home I stopped at my sons house and found him with his family at breakfast— Wild Jonathan of Braintree, came for a pension claim of his mother Deborah Wild, widow of Jonathan Wild a pensioner of the revolutionary War who died in 1840. There came as afternoon visitors a young man named Jamesa Welshman from Swansea, who said he had been about a year in this Country, and expected to return next Summer to Wales— His only object in his visit was curiosity to see hime, and his companion a young man residing in Boston had no other— Then came Naaman L. White, of Braintree, who in behalf of sundry citizens of that Town, invited me to a Pic Nic party at Spring grove in South Braintree next Tuesday at 2 oclock P—M, for the benefit of the sufferers by the recent fires at Nantucket. I declined attending this party though fully approving its objects. Mr Benjamin. V. French is to preside— Mr. White had a further motive for calling on me— He charges Fischer Ames, Kingsbury Postmaster at Weymouth with gross official misconduct in frequently annoying him with anonymous Letters, written by him and conveyed by the Post Office and for which he exacts the postage— Mr. White wishes to complain of this to the Postmaster General Cave Johnson, and asked my advice how to proceed—which I gave him— Mary Louisa, went to riding School at Boston— Charles and his wife were here this Eveg.

II.45. IV.10. Fahrenheit 65 at Sunrise  How art thou fallen from Heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! how art thou cut down to the ground, which didst weaken the Nations  Isaiah 14.12.  This Lucifer son of the morning is the dogstar, Sirius. I rose this morning before him, but saw him, about three quarters of an hour high, and then from the eastern corner of Charles’s house I saw the Sun rise at 5.  The Lucifer of this passage of Isaiah denotes also the king of Babylon—but whether Nebuchadnezzar or Belshazzar, is not apparent.  In the 7th chapter of this book of Isaiah is a distinct prophesy that within three-score and five years, Ephraim shall be broken, that it be not a people— Ephraim is the kingdom of Israel—the ten tribes, and the prophet foretells the Assyrian captivity.— The Lord commands Ahaz king of Judah to ask a sign to prove that the confederacy of Ephraim and Syria shall not prevail against Judah— Ahaz refuses to ask a sign, or to tempt the Lord. Whereupon the Lord says he will himself give a sign—and what is the sign?— [“]Behold, a Virgin shall conceive, and bear a Son, and shall call his name Immanuel.” and in the subsequent verses the destruction of both the kingdoms of Israel and of Judah is predicted to happen before this child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good— The whole prophesy relates to the wars and alliances of the kingdoms of Judah, Israel and Syria in the days of Ahaz—742 years before the birth of Christ— But in the first chapter of Matthew v. 18–23. it is said that the angel of the Lord appearing to Joseph in a dream, announced to him that Mary was with child by the holy Ghost, and the evangelist says all this was done, that this prophesy of Isaiah might be fulfilled. A prophesy to Ahaz king of Judah, announcing the failure of an actual confederacy of Israel and Syria, against Judah, but predicting the impending destruction of both the Jewish kingdoms, is the casket in which is enchased, the birth 700 years after of the Saviour of the world, begotten by the holy ghost upon a woman and son of God the father, from whom and from the son, the same holy ghost is said in the Athanasian creed to proceed— It were an exercise perhaps more curious than profitable to collate all the passages in the old testament which are quoted in the new as prophesies fulfilled by the advent of Jesus Christ— I received a Letter from Nathaniel Frye at Washington 28 August with a Bill of lading for four boxes, one chest and one leather trunk, shipped at Georgetown in the Schooner Forest king, Kelley Master for me. The day slipped away, and left no rembrance behind— I walked up the hill at the approach of Sunset, and rode with Mrs Charles down to the Mount Wollaston House to meet and take home my Son, and his Sons Charles and Henry returning from bathing at the beach— And Charles and his wife spent an Evening hour here— Mary Louisa went to Boston for a riding school lesson.

At the meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams temple, and school fund on the 16th. of last October, it had been voted, that there should be a yearly meeting of the board on the first Monday of September, at 11. O’Clock A.M. at the chamber of the selectmen in the new Granite town Hall. There had usually been a meeting once a year since the decease of my father at my house, but it had not been specially prescribed, and in 1844 had from inadvertence been omitted— The permission of the Selectmen for the use of their chamber had been obtained and the Meeting was held this day. All the members of the board present— Thomas Greenleaf President, Josiah Quincy, George W. Beale, my Son, Charles Francis Adams, and myself. Mr Greenleaf presented the report of the Committee to examine the accounts of the Treasurer John Briesler also Treasurer of the town, which was accepted and ordered to be recorded— Mr Greenleaf communicated also a paper signed by William B. Duggan, Harvey Field, and sundry others addressed to the Selectmen requesting them to call a town meeting to see if the town will take any measures for carrying into execution my father’s purpose of establishing a classical school in this place— One of the Selectmen had put this paper into the hands of Mr Greenleaf as an advisement to the Supervisors— I thought it should be entered on the minutes and a vote should be taken to notify the Selectmen that the Supervisors had no objection to the call of a town meeting, but had no wish for it and were specially desirous, not to encumber the town with any charge whatever, on account of this trust— But my Son and the other members of the board thought that no notice of the paper should be taken of the paper on the minutes, but that it should be returned by Mr Greenleaf to the Selectmen, with a verbal assurance that the Supervisors have no objection to the town meeting, but will take no part in calling it— Mr Greenleaf, alledging his age and infirmities, invited the Supervisors to elect another President, and expressed a wish that I might be chosen, but I pleaded the same disabilities, in at least equal degree—and requested that the consideration of Mr Greenleaf’s proposal should be postponed till the next annual meeting, which was formally moved by Mr Quincy and unanimously voted— About one O’Clock the meeting was dissolved, and I walked home— Mr Greenleaf, Mr Quincy and Mr Beale dined with us together with Mr Lunt, Dr. Woodward and my Son. His wife would not come. I walked up the hill about Sunset, but the Orb buried himself in haze.

I awoke a few minutes before the entry clock struck two—returned to bed in confusion of thought in consciousness awake, till I heard the Clock strike four— The intermediate hour of three having escaped my sense of hearing— I rose, repaired to my writing chamber, and saw Orion, Procyon, Sirius—the twins, and Venus as Morning Star. Took my shower and foot-baths, dressed and went up the hill; but the eastern horizon was bordered with haze intercepting the sight of the rising Sun, though within five minutes he peered out upon a clear sky.— Received yesterday  Everyone of these papers would require a written return from me, if it were in my power— I shall probably be unable duly to notice any one of them  This day I received a Letter from my old friend George Joy 19. John Street Pentonville, London 18. August 1846. brought by the Steamer—Britannia Captain Hewitt which arrived at Boston yesterday at Noon from Liverpool— She brought 165 passengers to Halifax and 99 to Boston— Among them Louis M’Lane the Minister of the United States at the British Court with his family. She made her passage in 16 days; but the Cambria which departed from Boston on the first of August, reached Liverpool in ten days and 16 hours the shortest passage ever yet atchieved— I rode this afternoon with my daughters Mrs John and Mrs. Charles with her infant Mary— We went to Milton and returned by the way of the quarries. Mr Jonathan Wild of Braintree was here again—inquiring concerning the state of the claim of his mother Deborah Wild, widow of Jonathan Wild a pensioner of the Revolutionary War— I was not able to tell him, my chest of papers and books not yet having arrived from Washington— I requested him to call again in about a fortnight, which he promised— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here—

I saw Venus Morning star— Orion, Sirius, and Procyon, but the Sun rose beclouded— One of the hottest of Summer days succeeded with the mitigation of a strong western breeze— My Son went into Boston in the train of Cars from South Braintree starting from the Quincy station at 7.40. A.M. I went with my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa in the Old Colony train from Plymouth which started from that town at 7.30— A.M. and should have reached the Quincy station at 9. but was twenty minutes belated— We passed the Neponset, Dorchester, and Savin Hill stations, and reached the depot in Boston opposite the United States Hotel at 10 minutes before 10. Mr Emmons was with us in the Cars— I walked with Mary Louisa to the riding School in Franklin Street where she was to take her lesson, and leaving her there proceeded to the counting house of Abbot and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street. I found Mr Abbott Lawrence there, and agreed to go with him next Wednesday to the Meeting of the Committee of the board of Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory to Cambridge— The Meeting is to be at half past 2. P.M at University hall, where they are invited to dine and to take the afternoon for examining the Observatory— I agreed to go into Mr Lawrence’s house in Boston by One O’Clock P.M. and at half past one to go with him in his Carriage to Cambridge, and to return with him to Boston in time to take the Evening train of Old Colony railroad Cars for South Braintree to be landed at the Quincy station. I had no conversation with Mr. Lawrence upon politics, on which our views no longer harmonize— They have been disappointed in not receiving the large Frauenhofer Refractor from Munich, which was to have been delivered in Cambridge last June when it would have been duty free— They now only hope to receive it before the first of next December, after which it must come charged with an import duty of between five and six thousand dollars— From Mr Lawrence’s counting room I went to my Son’s office, where I met Mr Henry Wilson of Natick and Mr George Odiorne, who did not speak to me of the republication of my Letters on Antimasonry— I purchased a small Night lamp and lantern— Precisely at Noon, I met my son and Granddaughter at the Old Colony Railroad depot, and came out in 27 minutes to Quincy.— The Barouche and Albert Putnam were in waiting and took us home. I received a curious Letter from Dutee J. Pearce— After dinner I rode with my two daughters and little Mary round through Braintree— Charles and his wife here this Evening— Summer heat with a refreshing breeze.

P.M at University hall, where they are invited to dine and to take the afternoon for examining the Observatory— I agreed to go into Mr Lawrence’s house in Boston by One O’Clock P.M. and at half past one to go with him in his Carriage to Cambridge, and to return with him to Boston in time to take the Evening train of Old Colony railroad Cars for South Braintree to be landed at the Quincy station. I had no conversation with Mr. Lawrence upon politics, on which our views no longer harmonize— They have been disappointed in not receiving the large Frauenhofer Refractor from Munich, which was to have been delivered in Cambridge last June when it would have been duty free— They now only hope to receive it before the first of next December, after which it must come charged with an import duty of between five and six thousand dollars— From Mr Lawrence’s counting room I went to my Son’s office, where I met Mr Henry Wilson of Natick and Mr George Odiorne, who did not speak to me of the republication of my Letters on Antimasonry— I purchased a small Night lamp and lantern— Precisely at Noon, I met my son and Granddaughter at the Old Colony Railroad depot, and came out in 27 minutes to Quincy.— The Barouche and Albert Putnam were in waiting and took us home. I received a curious Letter from Dutee J. Pearce— After dinner I rode with my two daughters and little Mary round through Braintree— Charles and his wife here this Evening— Summer heat with a refreshing breeze.

6. III.35— IV: Fahrenheit 74 at Sunrise 5.30.  The wilderness, and the solitary place, shall be glad for them; and the desert shall rejoice, and blossom as the rose. Isaiah 35.1.  And the ransomed of the Lord shall return, and come to Zion with songs, and everlasting joy upon their heads: they shall obtain joy and gladness, and sorrow and sighing shall flee away 35.10.  Bishop Lowth and subsequent commentators consider the 34th. and 35th. chapters of Isaiah as a distinct prophesy, and a complete and beautiful poem apart from the rest of the book— They are immediately followed by the narrative of the invasion of the kingdom of Judah by Sennacherib, King of Assyria— Pope has made great use of this 35th. chapter of Isaiah in his Messiah.  Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. John 3.2. [“]Beloved, now are we the Sons of God; and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know, that when he shall appear, we shall be like him: for we shall see him as he is— 3. And every man, that hath in him purifieth himself, even as he is pure.”— We are the sons of God? how then is Jesus Christ the only begotten Son of God? He declared himself times without number to be the Son of God, and spoke of God always as my father— But he taught all his disciples to address God, in prayer as our father, and he habitually called himself the Son of Man— He was born of a woman, born under the Law, according to the narrative of the Evangelists nine months after the miraculous conception, and in the same manner as other children are born— But God is a Spirit, and it is in a spiritual sense only that God is the father of Jesus Christ, though not in the same sense that he is the father of all mankind— Jesus Christ suffered crucifixion, for declaring himself to be son of God and sent on a mission to mankind by his father and Christians have involved themselves in confusion? inextricable by making Jesus himself a God. The whole doctrine of Trinity in Unity, and of the God Man Jesus Christ is a mass of absurdities as revolting to my intellect as the whole fabulous Pantheon of the Grecian Mythology. The apostle in Mr Lunts text of this morning admits that it doth not yet appear what we shall be— The state of the human soul after death is yet a mystery— It was so to St. John after the Resurrection and Ascension of Jesus— It was equally so to St. Paul whose description of the Judgment day and his distinction between the corruptible, and incorruptible body, leaves us precisely where we were— In the afternoon Mr Lunt preached from 1 Corinthians 15.15. Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God because we have testified of God that he raised up Christ; whom he raised not up, if so be that the dead rise not? The subject was a sequel to that of the morning discourse. Mr Lunt observed that the resurrection of Jesus Christ was the most important of all the tests of the truth of the Christian Religion and he delivered an elaborate argument in support of the Resurrection, by adducing sundry analogies in the successive changes in physical nature by alternations of life and death, in the mutations of corporeal substances— This was the hottest day of the Season; the Sun poured forth one continuous blaze throughout the day— I saw him set from the Northern porch of my Son’s house at 6.21— He and his wife were afterwards here.

7. III.30— IV. Fahrenheit 74 at Sun rise 5.31.  [“]Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God. Isaiah 40.1.— The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight in the desert a highway for our God. 4. Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low: and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough places plain 5. And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together; for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it.”  This is the transcendent prophesy of the mission of John the Baptist, and of the Advent of the Saviour, and as such expressly recognized by all the four evangelists. It is difficult to imagine, and much more to believe the connection between the prophesy and its fulfilment— At the time when the prophet wrote the kingdom of Israel had been conquered by the king of Assyria Tilgath Pileser, and the ten tribes dispersed no one knows where— Sennacherib second successor of Tilgath Pileser was then invading Judea and besieging Jerusalem. This invasion failed, but the prophet even then foretold the approaching destruction of the kingdom of Judah and the Babylonian captivity— So little apparent connection is there between the historical condition of the kingdom of Judah at that period, and the advent and personal biography of Jesus Christ that it requires a profound investigation of Chronology to bring the two periods into any relation with each other— The old testament closes with the extinction of the kingdom of Judah—with an interval of 70 years and a restoration of the Jews to the city of Jerusalem, and the rebuilding the temple under the direction of Ezra and Nehemiah— The next step brings us per saltum, to the birth of Jesus Christ at Bethelem in Judea, a Roman Province under the dominion of Augustus Caesar— In the mean time they had been successively subdued by Egyptian and Grecian Princes, successors of Alexander of Macedon, and were then governed by Herod a despotic monarch, and Caiaphas a high-priest— What possible relation was there between this state of things and the prophesy of the Messiah by Isaiah?  I received this day 1. A Letter from Charles Sumner, Boston. 2— Fisher’s National Magazine 3. George H. Colton’s American Review N. 21 all for September. 4. W. H. Chase pamphlet on fortifications 5. Wiley and Putnam’s Literary News-Letter Vol 5. N. 58— 6. B. B. French—Register of Cadets June 1846. 7. Sundry Patent Office Documents and sundry Newspapers. My daily supply for reading— I dined with my Son on the hill. His wife’s brother Sidney Brooks was there— He came out from Boston, and returned by the Railway Cars— He returns to-morrow or the next day, to New-York where he now resides.
Taylor Mrs Ann for her Son— Charles.

8. II.50— IV. Fahrenheit 70 at Sunrise 5.32.  A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench: he shall bring forth judgment unto truth— Isaiah 42.3— till he send forth judgment unto victory— Matthew 12.20— Instead of smoking flax the Septuagint has it a dimly burning taper— This is one of the prophesies of the old Testament expressly said in the New to have been fulfilled in the person of Jesus Christ. I awoke ten minutes before 3. and returning to bed lay sleepless till my patience was exhausted waiting for the clock to strike four— Weary of waiting I left my bed, and the Clock struck as I was passing through the entry to my Library— I saw Orion, Sirius, Procyon, and Venus as Morning Star— I took a pleasant shower bath, dressed and on the hill saw the Sun at 5:32— Another day of intense unrelenting heat. Mrs Anne Taylor, widow of Brigadier General Taylor of this town, came, in trouble, with a statement that her son, Charles Taylor a young man who for the last two years has resided at Philadelphia, has been convicted and sentenced for a crime of which she said he was not guilty— I enquired what the crime was—she said Rape, which of course made it difficult for me to talk with her on the subject. She had no copy of the indictment, the verdict or the sentence; all she knew was that he was not guilty of the crime— A Petition had been presented to the Governor of Pennsylvania, she apparently knew not from whom for his pardon, and the Recorder had told them that if I would interpose the pardon would probably be granted. I wrote a Letter to the Governor of Pennsylvania, stating the application of Mrs Taylor to me, and that in consideration of the great respectability of her character and the reputation hitherto unsullied of her family, I had complied with her request.  Vinton John Adams— There was a light and partial Thunder shower this afternoon during which the Revd Mr Vinton was here, a clergyman who after several temporary settlements in this State and Maine is now casually living in New Hampshire— He claims to be descended from John Alden, and his granddaughter Hannah Bass, my great grandmother and made enquiries concerning the family of Vinton which I was not able to answer.— We consulted Farmer’s Register and the list of early settlers in Savage’s edition of Winthrop’s journal in neither of which the name is found.— There is but one of the name in the Catalogue of Harvard College—Benjamin Vinton 1795. and star’d. Mrs Taylor came again this afternoon, and I gave her the Letter to the Governor of Pennsylvania, which I had written at her request. The atmosphere was cooled by the thunder shower, and the Summer closed after four days of heat as intense as I ever witnessed.

9. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 56 at Sunrise 5.33 Shower bath  That saith of Cyrus, He is my shepherd, and shall perform all my pleasure: even saying to Jerusalem, thou shalt be built: and to the temple, thy foundation shall be laid Isaiah 44.28.  This prophesy is said to have been delivered 712 years before Christ. The birth of Cyrus was 599 and his death 529 years before Christ— The prophesy therefore names Cyrus 113 years before he was born— The proclamation of Cyrus for rebuilding the temple was 536 before Christ— The building of the temple was then commenced, but was soon after suspended by command of Artaxerxes until the second year of the reign of Darius—then resumed and finished 515 before Christ— But it was not until 457 before Christ, that Cyrus went to Jerusalem, and not till 445. that Nehemiah went up— There is much obscurity and perplexing uncertainty in the chronology of these books.  The first daily train of Cars from the Quincy depot of the Old Colony Railroad to Boston coming from South Braintree only, start 20 minutes before 8. A.M. the second is the train from Plymouth, which leaves that place at half past 7—and the Quincy depot at 9. I took this to day and reaching Boston at half-past 9 first visited my shaver Cadmus 222 Washington Street— He asked me if the gloves I wore were those upon which I wrote the verses he had read in sundry newspapers? I said they were the same— They were first published in a Baltimore paper, and have been copied into several others, but I have never seen them in print. I called upon Dr Frothingham and spent an hour with him— He asked me where the Latin line “Miraturque novas frondes et non sua poma” was to be found, I said in the Georgics of Virgil. He said he had sought for it there without success—but he got the volume of Hoyne’s Virgil containing the Georgics, and found it line 82 of the second Book— I asked him if he had Lowth’s translation of the Book of Isaiah, he said he had, and also that of professor Noyes, and promised to lend them both to me— I called at the Emancipator office, but Mr Leavitt was gone to Springfield— I passed to my Son’s Office 23. Court-Street where I saw Mr Charles Sumner and Mr Nathaniel Curtis— As the hour of one approached I walked to Mr Abbot Lawrence’s house, where I saw Mrs Lawrence, and Bishop Eastburn whom I had not seen before— At half past one, I went with Mr Lawrence in his Carriage to Cambridge— We alighted at the President’s house; and Mr Everett immediately accompanied us to the University Hall where we met Mr Robert Treat-Paine, Professors Walker and Pierce, Mr W. C. Bond and his Son George with whom we dined, and then visited the Observatory and received Reports from Professor Pierce and Mr Bond, which were read and I took with me— Mr Paine returned with Mr Lawrence and me to Boston, and after a call at Mr James H. Foster I came out from half past 6 to 7—in the last train of the day for South Braintree I found Albert and the Barouche in waiting, and came home—

10. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 54 at Sunrise 5:35 Shower bath—  “How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth!  Isaiah 52.7.  I received this day 1. A Letter from Henry S. Baird, Attorney at Law, Green Bay, Wisconsin Territory, informing me of the decease of George Boyd, husband of my wife’s sister Harriet, aged about 65. They were married at Washington on the 14th. of March 1805. and I was present at their marriage— They have had a chequered, and not fortunate life— She was an admirable woman— He was a man of generous heart and good principles, but upon whose head Imprudence drew down the calamitous consequences of vice. They removed in 1818 from Washington to Michillimackinac, and he was many years an Indian Agent under the Government of the United States— 2. A. Letter from Henry Gassett, Boston dated yesterday, proposing to furnish copies from my Letterbooks of papers of the anti-masonic controversy a republication of which is proposed. 3. From John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth, three bound Volumes of Public Documents of this State, one of the House of Representatives, one of the Senate and one Executive prepared by the Secretary, all in the present year 1846— This afternoon three young Ladies named J. Adams, E. P. Trenchard M. M. Howens came with a subscription paper from an Association styling itself the Cold Water Army, proposing a Pic Nic to be held some day next week— They had a meeting last Saturday and chose this committee to report at an adjourned Meeting next Saturday, the time and place— The highest subscription was of one dollar and I added my name to the list, with a promise to attend if I can. I rode with Miss Louisa Smith, Mrs Charles and her child Mary, and my granddaughter Mary-Louisa round by the Railway-house, along by the quarries, to Braintree and over Penn’s hill homeward— I alighted at Gill the Stationer’s shop and purchased a shilling vial of Maynard and Noyes’s Ink; a supply of which for me is a prime necessity and my stock of powders for making the Article is exhausted— Mr Daniel Baxter called on me this day and spoke of the application to the Selectmen of Quincy for an immediate call of a Town-meeting for commencing the erection of a Schoolhouse as required by the donation of my father to the Town— He said Harvey Field had told him I was for having the Town-Meeting right off.— I said I should leave the Town entirely to their own discretion, and would suggest nothing that could bring on the town any charge. He said he thought the Town meeting for the next annual elections would be time enough for taking up this matter, in which I concurred— There was a primary meeting of whigs last evening at Boston.

11. III.45— IV. Fahrenheit 60 at Sunrise 5:36 Shower-bath—  Ho, every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money; come ye, buy and eat; yea, come, buy wine and milk, without money, and without price Isaiah 55.1.  Mr Edward J Penniman, now a resident of Philadelphia, brought me a Letter of introduction from Josiah Randall of that City— Mr Penniman is a native of Braintree and comes now on a visit to visit his relatives in that and the neighbouring towns— The name of Penniman is very familiar to the memory of my childhood, and existed in numbers of various conditions in the North and middle precincts of old Braintree— It has now totally vanished from Quincy where it was not respectable, and whether any remnant of it is left in Braintree I am not informed— Mr Penniman’s visit to me was of mere curiosity— MrsDerby with her son Brevet second Lieutenant George H Derby came to present personally their thanks to me for the services which I have fortunately been able to render him— Mrs Derby is the daughter of a friend of my youth, Horatio Townsend, a fellow student with me in the Office of Theophilus Parsons at Newburyport in 1787–1788 and 1789—more than 30 years after this his daughter married a worthless man namedDerby, who at the time when I was a candidate for the Presidency, and about the time when this young man was born, was used as a tool against me by false and treacherous representations of conversations held by me with Mr Townsend nearly twenty years before—and which he pretended Townsend had told him— Townsend denied having told him any such thing but the slander had its run, and when Jackson’s Collector came into the custom house Derby obtained a petty office under him— He afterwards quarreled with his Masters of Jackson’s kitchen cabinet, and published one or more libels upon them. In the mean time he had deserted his wife and children, and left them to shift for themselves— In 1841. John Bell of Tennessee being Secretary of War, Mrs Derby wrote me a Letter, earnestly soliciting a warrant of Cadet at the West Point Academy for Son, and by the kindness of Mr Bell I obtained it from the appointments at large. He was admitted in June 1842, and was graduated last June 7th. on the roll of his Class. He was then assigned to the Ordnance department, but wrote to me intreating to be transferred to the Corps of topographical Engineers which I also obtained from the kindness of General Scott— I asked him where he was stationed— He said he had not yet received his orders but expected to receive them next week— In the afternoon Elizabeth C. Adams was here with Lieutenant George Thom, fresh from Washington and on the eve of returning there— I rode round to Milton and Braintree, with Mrs Charles and her infant daughter only. After we returned, Mr Thomas Loring was here, and I agreed with him to go on a fishing party to Cohasset next Tuesday week, the 22d if the weather should be fair, and if not, the first fair day afterwards. I received a note from Messrs Welch and Mann proprietors of the National Circus which came here for this day only to attend their exhibition, which I did with my granddaughter Mary-Louisa, and Charles two sons, Charles and Henry.

12. II.55— IV. Fahrenheit 66 at Sunrise 5.37. Shower-bath.  Is not this the fast that I have chosen? to loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens, and to let the oppressed go free, and that ye break every yoke? Isaiah 58.6.  I received from Edward Everett, President of Harvard University, the triennial Catalogue of 1845, and a pamphlet containing the Rules and Statutes of the Professorships in the University at Cambridge, a title page in my judgment exceptionable— It is so denominated in the Constitution of this Commonwealth, by which it was recognized as a University but was also styled Harvard College— The University of Cambridge is in England—and to avoid all misunderstanding as well as to render all due honour to the founders of our cradle of education, the name of Harvard University should invariably be applied to it— Mrs N. L. Frothingham called before dinner to see our Ladies. She came out in the Railway Cars with her two daughters at noon, dined at her Sister’s, and returned to Boston with the train of 5. PM. Mary Louisa went to Boston at 9. took her lesson at the riding school, and returned with the Cars at Noon— In the assortment of my papers, my progress is backward rather than forward I answered the Letter of Henry S. Baird at Green Bay communicating information of the death of Mr Boyd— This volume of copies of my Letters is missing, and I know not where to look for it— I felt this afternoon the necessity of commencing the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of the University, upon the Observatory—but entered upon it with so little spirit that I almost despair of ever finishing it.— I merely read the reports to the Committee of Professor Peirce, Perkins professor of Astronomy and Mathematics; and of William Cranch Bond, Observator—and wrote the introductory sentence of the Report of the Committee— I find that in the pamphlet sent me by President Everett of Rules and Statutes of the Professorships in the University of Cambridge there is no notice of the Perkins professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics. In the second volume of Quincy’s history of Harvard University pages 392. 566 and 637—all the proceedings for the construction and establishment of an Astronomical observatory until the publication of that work in 1840 are contained, and in page 430 is noticed the bequest of James Perkins at his death in August 1823 to the President and fellows of Harvard College of 20000 dollars for the purpose of founding such a professorship, as they with the consent of the Overseers of the College should judge most useful to the university and the public—a Question remains, how and when it was decided that the Perkins professorship should be a professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics— This is a lacuna or gap to be filled up in preparation for the report of the Committee: and there is another for the measures in process of execution to procure a Frauenhofer Refractor of the largest size— I received from Dr Frothingham Lowth’s translation of Isaiah, and the first volume of professor Noyes’s translation of the bible prophets including Isaiah; which will furnish me with occupation enough till next winter— I went up the hill to see the Sun set but he went down in a thick cloud

13. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 60 at Sunrise 5.38. Cloudy.  The Spirit of the Lord God is upon me; because the Lord hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek; he hath sent me to bind up the broken hearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to them that are bound. Isaiah 61.1. Luke 4.18.  In the year 1841. George Brown then of Beverley and a stranger to me, but since then sometime Commissioner of the United States at the Sandwich Islands wrote me a Letter requesting me to versify in English this passage of the book of Isaiah, which I did and the lines were published by him in some Newspaper. A day or two since I looked for them among my papers—but found them not, and I know not where to search for them.  Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. Chronicles 16.37. [“]So he left there before the Ark of the covenant of the Lord, Asaph and his brethren to minister before the ark continually as every day’s work required” And 1. Peter 2.5. “Ye also, as lively stones, are built up a spiritual house, an holy priesthood, to offer up spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God, by Jesus Christ.” Mr Lunt appears to have a fondness for double texts, taking one from the old and the other from the New testament— His object was to illustrate them one by the other— But the verse from the Chronicles is the institution by David of the great musical establishment by David, in the worship before the Ark of the Covenant, when he brought it up from the house of Obed-Edom and placed it in a tent, preliminary to the building of the Temple— The history of this establishment of Music vocal and instrumental, as forming a part of the daily service of divine worship is highly interesting, but was not noticed by Mr Lunt— The instruments named in the common English Bible are (ch 13 v. 8) Harps, Psalteries, timbrels, cymbals and trumpets— [(]ch. 15. v 28.) cornet— Psalm 98 Shawms. Daniel 3.4. Sackbut, flute and dulcimer— Thomson’s Septuagint calls Psalteries and Harps Nablas and kinyras— But there is little connection between this institution for the daily religious concert of music, by David, and the exhortations of Peter, to all his disciples, converts to Christianity to become an holy priesthood to offer up spiritual sacrifices— Yet the analogy between them is not unnatural— In the afternoon Mr Lunt’s sermon was from 1. Thessalonians 1.5. [“]For our gospel came not unto you in word only, but also in power, and in the holy Ghost, and in much assurance.” The argument was upon the miracles performed by Jesus Christ and the Apostles, considered as evidences of the truth of Christianity— Towards evening I rode with my Son down to Ex President Quincy’s, and found him at the old family mansion, to which he has returned for a Summer family residence. I inquired about the papers which passed between us last Summer relating to the Observatory at Cambridge— He said he had them all and would send them to me— On my return home I found P. P. F. Degrand here, who soon returned to Boston.

14. II.55— IV. Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise 5:39. Douche.  And it shall come to pass, that from one new moon to another, and from one sabbath to another, shall all flesh come to worship before me, saith the Lord.  Isaiah 66.23.  For my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed them out cisterns, broken cisterns, that can hold no water  Jeremiah 2.13—  I executed with my wife a warranty deed of my house in Hancock Street Boston tofor 8300. dollars, witnessed by P. P. F. Degrand, and my Son— I had purchased it in 1806 of Isaac Davis for 6000 dollars. I received this day with the daily Boston Newspapers, Atlas Courier and Daily whig, and the National Intelligencer from Washington Littell’s living age N. 122 and a pamphlet of 86 pages 8vo. being a Statement of the controversy between Lewis Tappan and Edward E. Dunbar— These daily Newspapers and pamphlets furnish reading from day to day so copious and absorbing of time, that it leaves little or none for writing or for reading of permanent interest—day after day slips imperceptibly away, and nothing useful is atchieved— This afternoon Mr Charles Sumner, and Dr Howe came out from Boston, and invited me to attend, and preside at a public Meeting proposed to be held at Boston, a week from to-morrow Tuesday the 22d of this month, with a view to pass Resolutions expressing the public feeling at the recent kidnapping and abduction of a negro man who had escaped from his master at New-Orleans and landed in the neighbourhood of Boston— He was pursued, captured and ship’d off for New Orleans, by the Captain of the vessel in which he made his escape, unknown to the captain— But for retaking him the Captain had no authority from the owner of the Negro. There was a meeting last evening of a few persons indignant at this outrage upon the Laws of the Commonwealth and upon the rights of human nature, who resolved to call a public meeting, and these gentlemen came out as a Committee from this primary meeting to give me the invitation— After expressing my sense of the honour done me, I suggested some difficulties, owing to the state of my health, and especially the near extinction of my voice, disqualifying me, if not from attending at least from presiding at such a meeting, I finally promised to attend the meeting if my health would permit; and to preside, if I should be able to rely upon my voice for a hearing— From my house the Gentlemen went up the hill to my Son’s but he was out for a Sea bath, and they did not see him— Mrs John and Mrs Charles went to Boston, this afternoon, and came back at 9 this Evening with my granddaughter, Louisa Catherine, who finally comes home from Mrs Sedgwick’s school at Lenox, where she has passed two years in the course of her education. She was 15 on the 13th. of last Month—

15. I. III. V. Fahrenheit 68 at Sunrise 5.40 Douche  The prophets prophesy falsely, and the priests bear rule by their means; and my people love to have it so: and what will ye do, in the end thereof?  Jeremiah 5.31—  The day commenced with a continuation of Summer heat, beclouded. About 9 in the morning there was a light shower of rain, immediately after which the wind came round to the Northwest, with a clear sky, and autumnal cold increasing through the day, the bright sun notwithstanding— I rode this afternoon with Mrs John and Mrs Charles and little Mary to Weymouth— We stop’d at Mr Minott Thayer’s house but he was not at home. I requested his niece to inform him that in calling to pay my respects to him, I had intended also to remind him that some years since (19 May 1841) Mr Asa French and Mr Benjamin V. French in behalf of the inhabitants of Braintree had borrowed of me a volume, being a copy made by my father’s direction for him, and left by him to me, of the original record of births marriages and deaths in the town of Braintree, from its first settlement in 1640.— The original itself was in the possession of the town Clerk of Braintree, but so mutilated and defaced, that he wanted my copy made some twenty years before to aid them in having a fair copy made for themselves—after which they promised to return mine to me— Upwards of five years have since passed away, and although I had occasionally missed the book I had almost forgotten the loan of it, till a few days since casually looking over my diary of 1841—I found in it the entry of this incident—the thousandth memento for me of the usefulness of keeping a diary— We visited also Mrs Mercy Tufts and her two unmarried daughters Susan and Mercy— Mrs Tufts is 83 years of age, and is confined to the house by the infirmities of age. At this time her bodily health is good and she lives cheerful and contented. We returned by the old County road over Penn’s hill which never fails to bring to my memory with a pleasing and tender melancholy the many walks over the same ground of my childhood from 1774 to 1778. when I first went to France— On my return home I found that Ex President Quincy had been here, and left the Papers relating to the Observatory at Cambridge which had passed between us in the Spring and Summer of 1845. These were all intended as preparatory materials and vouchers for a report of the Committee to the board of Overseers to be presented at their meeting during the Session of the Legislature in January 1846. The decline of my health towards the close of the Summer, and through the autumn of 1845 disabled me for the composition of the report, and none was made at the winter Session— The same Committee was continued for the present year and on my return from Washington last Month I found the subject precisely where we had left it this time last year— In the meantime the whole subject had so far faded upon my memory that I am more unprepared for writing the report to the overseers than I was then and although my health is partially restored, I am in deep concern for the perseverance and energy my only hope of which is in the passage from holy writ on the next page—

16. I.55. IV. Fahrenheit 44. at Sunrise 5.41.— Sunset 6.8.  O Lord, I know, that the way of man is not in himself; it is not in man that walketh to direct his steps. Jeremiah 10.23.  Morning visit from the Revd. Dr John Pierce of Brookline, with Mr Littell, the publisher of a weekly pamphlet of 48 large 8vo. pages selected from 22 English periodical magazines and Reviews, forming a continual exposition of the current literature of the English language— He brought with him and gave me the 123d. number of this compilation, dated 19. September 1846.— It has already been continued upwards of two years, and he has sent me a complete series of the preceding numbers— He wrote to me last December requesting my opinion upon the character of his undertaking to which I returned a favourable answer—which he publishes on the cover of every successive number— The price of this work is only 12 1/2 cents for each number and 13 numbers form a volume of 620 pages. Mrs Frothingham and Mrs Everett were also here before dinner, and dined with their sister on the hill— I walked up there, and found beside them a young lawyer namedAdams, who keeps an Office in Boston, N. 23. Court Street opposite that of my Son— He returned to Boston in the Cars from Plymouth which should have reached the Quincy Station at 20 minutes past 5— O’Clock P.M. but did not till the Temple Clock struck 6— Mrs Frothingham and Mrs Everett had already departed in the Carriage of the latter, and I remained to see the splendid Sunset of a cloudless sky at 8 minutes past 6— Charles and his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine passed the evening here— I have not yet taken firm hold of the papers relating to the Observatory, but am idling away hour after hour upon questions what were the musical instruments mentioned in the Old Testament, and how far they agree with those of modern times— It is said Genesis 4.21. that Jubal son of Lamech was the father of all such as handle the harp and organ— The Hebrew words are kinnar and hugab— The first a stringed and the second a wind instrument— The words in the Septuagint are ψαλτέριον και κιθάραν translated by Charles Thomson psaltery and kithara. The french protestant bible of Ostervald has le violon et les orgues, and the German Bible of Luther has die Geiger und Pfeifer— In Exodus 15.20 Miriam is said to have taken a timbrel in her hand, which the Septuagint calls τυμπανον and Thomson translates timbrel— Silver trumpets. Numbers 10.2— The Septuagint calls them σαλπιγγας— Ram’s horn Trumpets Joshua 6. I consulted the English translation of Calmet’s Dictionary in the third volume of which among the fragments illustrating scripture, p. 337. &c is an Article on Musical Instruments, and three plates with nearly thirty engraved representations of antient musical instruments among which a harp from Herculaneum, and two other specimens of harps closely resembling the modern forms of that instrument. But after all it is admitted that there is no certainty what was the form of any one of the musical instruments mentioned in the old Testament

II.55— V. Fahrenheit 40. at Sunrise 5.42  Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots? then may ye also do good, that are accustomed to do evil— Jeremiah 13.23.  Mr Johnson came out from Boston with Mr Lothrop the Minister of Brattle Street Church— Mr Whitney is the projector of a Railroad from Lake Michigan to the pacific Ocean, about which I had several conversations with him during the late Session of Congress— On the 31st. of July last Sidney Breese of Illinois, chairman of the Committee of the Senate on the public Lands presented to the Senate, a Report, in favour of this project, and a bill to set apart a portion of the public lands with which to construct a railroad from Lake Michigan to the Pacific Ocean— The adjournment of Congress on the 10th. of August suspended all further action upon this report and bill, and the subject will come up again for consideration in both houses at the approaching Session— Mr Whitney left with me copies of Senator Breese’s report and bill, which he requested me to read, and I promised him I would— Mr Johnson dined with us— Mrs Charles went to Medford to spend the day at her father’s— Charles went with her— Mary-Louisa went in the Cars to Boston, took a lesson at the riding School and returned to dine— After dinner, my wife and Mary went to Boston in the Carriage to meet and come home with Charles and his wife returning from Medford— Mr Johnson went with them to Boston, proposing to return to-morrow to New-York It was half past eight this Evening when my wife and Mary, with Charles and his wife returned from Boston, in the Carriage— Charles’s son John Quincy had returned from the Latin School, by the Cars at 7— Thomas Dumphy departed this day on his returning to Washington— Before he went, I settled with him, and paid him 45 dollars in full for two and a half months service as Coachman— I received this afternoon a Letter from Dr. Howe notifying me that they had been unable to obtain the use of Faneuil Hall for the public meeting on what is called the Slave case until next Thursday Evening the 24th. but still urging my attendance, which I answered promising to attend if possible— I received also a Letter from Samuel M. Chisom, Portland Septr. 15. requesting an autograph and a Letter from Joseph M. Edmonds, Portsmouth New-Hampshire Septr. 14. inviting me to deliver the opening lecture for the coming Season before the People’s Lyceum in that place— The Report to the Board of Overseers is not yet in embryo. The papers with the Reports 1. of W. C. Bond the Observator and 2— Benjamin Peirce Perkins Professor of Astronomy and Mathematics to the Committee are 3. A printed Article in the Memoirs of the American Academy, “The Latitude of the Cambridge Observatory, in Massachusetts, determined from Transits of Stars over the Prime Vertical observed during the Months of December 1844 and January 1845[”] by W. C. Bond, Major James D. Graham George P. Bond and Benjamin Peirce.

18. II.30. IV. Fahrenheit 48 at Sunrise 5–43.  The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it? Jeremiah 17.9.  Cloudy Morning— Before Sunrise I walked round the square passing between the Temple and Townhouse, by the Railway bridge over which the Cars pass, and returning through the cross street and over the hill on which my Son’s house— Time of the walk 31 minutes distance 1 1/2 mile and 40 Rods. From my house to the Temple and Town house 11 minutes—to the Railway bridge 15 minutes—18 minutes to a mile— Mr Jonathan Wild of Braintree was here again with enquiries concerning the Pension claim of his mother Deborah Wild, which I was yet unable to answer, my chest of books and papers ship’d at Washington on the Schooner Forest King not having yet arrived at Boston—and begins to be out of time— Mr Wild promised to call again in about a fortnight— I received a Letter from Theodore Kellogg Committee of the general Cold Water Army embracing the four districts of the town of Quincy, inviting me with sundry other persons to attend at a Pic-Nic at the town Hall on Tuesday next at 1. O’Clock P.M—  On examining the papers delivered to the Committee of Overseers of Harvard University, on the Observatory, with the Report of William Cranch Bond the observer, I find them  Of these numbers 1. 3. and 9. though referred to in Mr Bonds’ report were not delivered to the Committee.  The papers incidental to the Committee of the board of Overseers of the last year and now returned to me by Ex-President Quincy are

Dr Frothingham came out from Boston this afternoon and with Charles and his wife spent the Evening here—he lodges at Charles’s house and is to preach by exchange for Mr Lunt to-morrow— I received this day  The Letter from Mr Joy came by the Steamer Cambria which sailed from Liverpool the 4th. of this month, and arrived at Boston yesterday  I continue the list of Papers returned to me by Ex-President Quincy relating to the Observatory at Cambridge—
