Moreover, I will take from them the voice of mirth and the voice of gladness the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the sound of the millstones and the light of the candle Jeremiah 25.10.  Instead of the sound of the millstones and the light of the candle, the Septuagint reads the odour of myrrh and the light of the lamp.  Dr Frothingham preached at the Temple this morning from 2. Chronicles 15.15—last clause of the verse “and the Lord gave them rest round about.” This text lead to the expectation of a discourse upon the blessings of Peace, and the comforts of tranquility to Nations—but after a general allusion to the bearing of the text upon that condition of human Society, and remarking how happy the lot of ever Nation must be in the enjoyment of rest all about, Dr. Frothingham said that the Sentiment of the text was quite as applicable to individuals as to Nations, and that he should confine his consideration of it to that view of its Operation— He then enlarged upon rest all about as essential and indispensable to the well-being of man, and pointed out the various sources from which rest round about must be derived— The Greek and Roman philosophy upon the blessing of rest is painted in Horace’s Ode to Grosphus 2.16. Otium Divos rogat impotenti Prensus Egaeo, and the Hebrews both of the Old and New Covenant regard rest as the consummation of all happiness in Heaven as well as on Earth. The Bible tells us that almighty God, after labouring six days in the creation of the world and of man, rested the seventh day and hallowed it— This was the institution of the Sabbath, and consecrated to religious sanctity the alternation of labour and repose as a condition of human existence embracing all its relations and dependencies.— Mr Frothingham made however no allusion to the Sabbath, and understood the words rest round about in this passage as imparting only a state of peace and quiet. He dined with us, together with my Son, and in the afternoon preached from 2 Chronicles 15.17—the last clause of the verse— “Nevertheless the heart of Asa was perfect all his days.” Mr Frothingham dwelt upon the sacred regard to truth in all the narratives of the Scriptures—noticing the plain simple manner in which they relate all the errors and vices and crimes of the most exalted personages of their histories exemplified in the persons of Adam, Noah, Abraham, David, Solomon and Asa himself. He explained the qualified sense of the word perfect as applied to the heart of Asa all his days; and noticed the exceptions of deviation from rectitude with which he is charged by the historian of the Chronicles himself. He cautioned his hearers also against the error of concluding that perfection of conduct necessarily follows from perfection of the heart— Mr Loring of Hingham was at Meeting this afternoon, and called here after the service. I agreed to go with him on a fishing party to Cohasset next Tuesday if the weather should be fair— Dr. Frothingham with Charles and his wife and we had visits from George T. Bigelow, and John P. Hale of New Hampshire— Also from Mrs Stebbins, with Isaac Hull Adams, and his Sister Elizabeth— Sunset at 6.1—

21. IV:45. Fahrenheit 56 at Sunrise 5.46. Equinoctial day. Thick fog.  Behold the fury whirlwind of the Lord, goeth forth with fury; a continuing whirlwind; it shall fall with pain upon the head of the wicked Jeremiah 30–23.  Mr Henry Wood called on me this morning and enquired if I had among my papers the original Deed of agreement between the several proprietors of the lands overflowed by the Mill pond in this town to support the mill which was kept many years by William Veazie, and the Deed by which the lands were restored to their several original proprietors, when the Mill was abandoned— He wants it now for a suit at Law, which he has pending in the County Court at Dedham, against George Veazie for a portion of these Lands— I have some recollections of these deeds, and believe that I have them or copies of them somewhere among the private papers of my father, but I know not where they are— It has been the constant labour of my life to keep my books and papers in such systematic order that I may know where to find any one of them at five minutes notice, and for many long years I was enabled to do so with tolerable success—but I have now to go back for files and vouchers an documents of seventy years standing: during four several residences in Europe—in France, Holland, Russia, England, and Prussia, besides travels, in Spain, Germany Sweden and Denmark; and eight passages across the atlantic, and repeated navigations in the British Channel the North Sea and the Baltic in Europe, and in the Long Island Sound, the Northern Lakes and many of the rivers in America. I have passed successively through the conditions of a School boy, a student at Harvard University, and at Law in the Office of Theophilus Parsons. of a practicing Attorney and Counsellor—of a Secretary of Legation Minister Resident, Plenipotentiary and Envoy Extraordinary in five European Countries of Professor at Harvard University, member of the Senate of Massachusetts and of the Senate of the United States—8 years their Secretary of State—4 years their President, and now 15 years a member of their house of Representatives— My changes of residence have multiplied in proportion to the diversity of my occupations and I now pass twice at least every year from one to the other at 500 miles distance from each other— With all my papers, public and private vouchers, files of Letters, Letter-Books and Journals I have now the custody and care of those of my father, and they are falling into utter and inextricable confusion— I told Mr Wood I would look over my papers and see if I can find the deed for which he is searching— I received also a Letter form the Revd. Theodore Parker, enquiring for papers, which he says he sent me in July 1845. from Dr Flugel, Consul of the United States at Leipzig, and of which I had lost all recollection— I sent my answer to Mr Kellogg, declining to attend at the Cold water army Pic Nic tomorrow for previous engagement— Charles and his wife were here this evening.

22. III— IV. Fahrenheit 52 at Sunrise 5.47. Cloudy N.E.  Therefore thus saith the Lord, ye have not hearkened unto me, in proclaiming liberty, every one to his brother, and every man to his neighbour: behold, I proclaim liberty for you, saith the Lord, to the sword, to the pestilence, and to the famine; and I will make you to be removed into all the kingdoms of the earth  Jeremiah 34.17—  I had agreed with Mr Loring, that I would be at his house at 7 O’Clock this morning to go upon a fishing party to Cohasset, if the weather should be fair— I rose as usual at 4. went through my usual lustrations frictions and dressing, except the cold shower bath— The wind was at North-east, the sky heavily beclouded, with every aspect of a coming storm— So it continued till after breakfast. At 6 O’Clock when I intended and had prepared to start for Hingham the whole firmament still threatened a tempest— I walked round the railway square, and saw no relaxation of the atmosphere— Breakfasted at 8 and the firmament began to soften its frown;—after 9 it was apparent that the clouds were dispersing and late as it was I ordered out Albert and the Carriage, and started for Hingham— I had barely crossed the railway bridge near my gate when I met Mr Loring in his chaise with a present of two fine mackrel, and a box of Seek no further Apples— He said there had been a heavy gale of wind off the coast last night and the surf on the beach this morning was so boisterous, that it was impossible to get the boat in which we were to embark for fishing out from her moorings. So that our fishing party must be postponed to some future day, and if I had gone to Hingham as I had proposed this morning we still should not have been able to go out— Mr Loring proceeded to Boston, and was succeeded here by an Old man named James Ward a claimant of a pension for services during the revolutionary War in the Deane frigate, and at the battle of White Plains— He had been here on theof last Month, and referred me to Elias Hasket Derby Esqr. Justice of Peace in Boston, who had heretofore had charge of his papers, and transmitted them to the Pension Office at Washington but had obtained nothing— This was confirmed by Mr Derby to whom I applied at his office on the— Ward says that the pension due to him, he believes has been obtained by a man named Stephen Ward fraudulently in as much as he Stephen Ward was not born at the time of the battle of White Plains— I told him that as I knew not the reasons why his claim for a pension had been disallowed I saw nothing that I could do for him but upon my return to Washington to represent his case to the Commissioner of Pensions which I promised to do— In the meantime I advised him to have a petition or written statement of his claim drawn up, and furnished to me to take with me, and he promised that he would— The weather cleared up bright and I rode in the barouche with my daughters and the child— There was a whig meeting at Boston this Evening preliminary to the Convention for the nomination of Governor tomorrow—

23. II. III. IV— V.— Fahrenheit 40 at Sunrise 5.48. Clear—  Then Zedekiah the king sent, and took him out; and the king asked him secretly in his house, and said, is there any word from the Lord? and Jeremiah said There is: for, said he, thou shalt be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon Jeremiah 37.17.  I had a sleepless Night— Was up between two and three O’Clock of the morning—returned to bed, and lingered without repose till five when I rose for the day, with a sore throat, a voice nearly extinct, a redoubled agitation of nerves, and a tremor little short of absolute disqualification for writing. My Socratic demon, whispered to me authoritatively not to attempt to preside at the Meeting at Faneuil hall tomorrow evening upon the case of a Slave who had escaped from New-Orleans, in a merchant vessel from this State commanded by a Captain Hannum— The Slave had secreted himself in the vessel unknown to the Captain, and succeeded in a getting to land at South Boston Hannum pursued and found him there—seized him without warrant or authority of any kind—ship’d him onboard of another vessel bound to New-Orleans and sent him back to his Master— Attempts were made to follow the vessel in which he was ship’d with a writ of Habeas-Corpus but without success— The meeting in Faneuil Hall is called to ascertain the facts of the case and to consult upon measures to be taken for preventing the repetition of similar cases, and I had promised if possible to attend and preside at this meeting. I am disabled by the act of God, and was obliged to write to my Son, requesting him to give notice of the fact to Dr Howe, and Mr Charles Sumner, the Committee who had given me the invitation— Unfortunately my Letter to my Son was not sent— The Convention of the whigs for the nomination of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the year 1847. was held this day at Faneuil Hall, and George N. Briggs was unanimously nominated for re-election as Governor, and John Reed as Lieutenant Governor. A set of Resolutions prepared by Daniel Webster was adopted, and another offered by Stephen C Phillips was rejected— There are two divisions in the party, one based upon public principle and the and the other upon manufacturing and commercial interest— I had a morning visit form Mr Lunt, and confined myself to the house for the day. I make no progress in the Report of the Committee of the Overseers upon the Observatory and am even diverted by debility from the searching examination of the papers upon which the report must be founded. I received this day a note from President Edward Everett proposing the immediate publication of W. C. Bond’s Report and Observations which the American Academy have offered to have performed; upon which it will be necessary for me to consult Mr Abbott Lawrence. I received also a Letter from Edward C Delavan Ballston Centre Septr 15 1846. with a pamphlet containing ten Lectures by Dr Eliphalet Nott President of Union College Schenectady on the use of intoxicating liquors—which he requests me to read and of which he proposes to have numberless copies published in Stereotype

24. V. Fahrenheit 50 at Sunrise 5.49— Clear  5 Then they said to Jeremiah, The Lord be a true and faithful witness between us, if we do not even according to all things for the which the Lord thy God shall send thee to us 6 Whether it be good, or whether it be evil, we will obey the voice of the Lord our God to whom we send thee; that it may be well with us, when we obey the voice of the Lord our God. Jeremiah 42.5.6.  This is one of the passages illustrative of the fundamental principle of the Hebrew Religion, Politics and Morals— Obedience to the will of God, whether good or evil was sure to be rewarded with prosperity—and this will of God was to be revealed to them by the prophet whom they sent to God, to learn his will. The will of God, revealed to the prophet’s ear by the word to his eye in vision, or to his Memory in a dream, was the summum bonum for which the Grecian philosophers made such long, painful, and fruitless research— Thomson’s translation from the Septuagint of this 6th. verse, reads—Whether it be agreeable, or disagreeable we will hearken to the voice of the Lord our God in respect to that for which we send thee to him that it may be the better for us.  I received this morning a Letter from Dr Howe again urging my attend at the Faneuil Hall meeting this Evening. I had a good night’s sleep last Night and this morning the sore throat had passed away—the hoarseness much subsided and the voice almost entirely recovered though still very feeble. Ever since the day when Dr Howe and Charles Sumner came with the invitation, and I had given them the conditional promise to attend, the notification of the meeting in all the daily newspapers had stated that it would be presided over by me— As this day advanced I felt returning strength and immediately after dinner I concluded to go at all hazards— I went up the hill, and found my Son who had been into Boston and returned, was with his family at dinner. Dr Bowditch came in soon after from Boston to request that I would write a note approbatory of the meeting to be read there and account for my absence— I told him I had concluded to go, and agreed to meet him at his house at 6 this Evening— I went accordingly with my Son, and found assembled at Bowditch’s house a small tea party of the gentlemen who had called the Meeting— At 7 we went to Faneuil Hall where a great crowd of people were assembled filling every nook and corner of the room, including numbers of ladies filling the galleries— The chair was assigned to me by acclamation. Stephen C. Phillips and Samuel May were chosen Vice-Presidents andAndrew Secretary to the Meeting. It continued till about ten in the Evening, sundry Resolutions were adopted with inconsiderable opposition. Among the Speakers was my Son, and when he rose I resigned the chair to Mr Stephen C. Phillips— The meeting closed with a vote of thanks to me moved by Edmund Quincy and carried not without opposition— With my Son I returned from the Hall to Quincy, and reached home after 11 at Night.

25. V. Fahrenheit 54. at Sunrise 5.51. Cloudy Clear.  As I live saith the King, whose name is the Lord of hosts, surely as Tabor among the mountains, and as Carmel by the sea, so shall he come  Jeremiah 46.18.  I had a comfortable night’s rest, and slept this morning until near 5. at the striking of which by the Clock I rose—but my principal complaint hung by me all this day. Gibbon remarks in the Memoir of his own life, that the greatest discomfort of his old age was that in proportion as he advanced in years, the power of hope over his mind gradually declined— My principal annoyance in the decline of years is that I rise in the morning with thoughts occupied exclusively with concern for my health, and the encroachments of gradual decay—the flickering of the light in the socket.— We had a morning visit from Ex-President Josiah Quincy with his eldest Son’s wife, and his eldest daughter Miss Elizabeth Susan Quincy— Mr Quincy has returned for his Summer residence to the family mansion in this town which he inherited from his grandfather Coll. Josiah Quincy who built the house, after that in which John Hancock was born, and which he had purchased and dwelt in after the death of Hancock’s father the minister, was burnt. I say inherited; but it was bequeathed to him by his grandfather’s will, subject to the right of dower of his third wife Ann Marsh, who survived him. Coll. Josiah Quincy died in 1783 and his widow dwelt in the house, until after the marriage of the devisee in 1800, she by a composition of mutual agreement she relinquished it to him. He made it his summer residence for many years residing in Winter at Boston, until in 1829—being elected President of Harvard University he necessarily resided the year round at Cambridge— Having resigned that Office on the 1st. of October 1845, he returned to Boston for the winter, and to what the Revd. Mr Clark calls the Quincy hive for the Summer. His eldest Son Josiah junr is now Mayor of the city of Boston, and his wife prefers Nahant for a Summer residence to Quincy— But she is now on a visit to her beau-pere and belle mere— I read Dr Gilman’s reminiscences of New England at the close of the 18th. century, and especially of the Revd. Stephen Peabody of Atkinson New-Hampshire, and of his second wife my mother’s sister Elizabeth— If the protestant creed tolerated canonization, those two persons would have deserved to stand among the foremost on the Calendar. I read also Dr Lamson’s discourse in defence and support of the congregational form of worship— He extols it for its simplicity— I prefer it to the Roman Catholic which admits, and to the English Episcopal which seems to admit the power of the Priest to grant absolution for sins— But there is no Christian Church with which I could not join in social worship— I received a Letter from Misses Kilburn and Healy late of Boston, now keeping a boarding and day school for young Ladies at Baltimore, with their prospectus.

26. Fahrenheit 64. at Sunrise 5.52. Cloudy Clear. Heavy dew.  Cursed be he that doeth the work of the Lord deceitfully, and cursed be he that keepeth back his sword from blood. Jeremiah 48.10.  The prohibition of War, as a religious and moral principle belongs exclusively to the Christian dispensation, if indeed it is included in that— War so far from being discountenanced in the old testament is frequently commanded, and the total destruction of the Canaanitish Nations, was not only enjoined upon the children of Israel, but their disobedience to that command by sparing a remnant of the victims, was held and declared to be a crime for which their own destruction was doomed— For the same offence Saul forfeited his kingdom and his life, and here the prophet Jeremiah a captive in Chaldea denounces a curse upon every man who keepeth back his sword from blood—  The day slip’d again from under me.— I had seen in the ship news of yesterday’s Boson Newspapers, the welcome announcement of the arrival from Alexandria and Georgetown D.C. of the Schooner Forest king Captain Kelly, in which my chest of books and papers, with many other valuable articles had been ship’d— This day my son procured the delivery of them in Boston—they were brought out in the freight train of railway Cars, and landed at our own house this evening— The vessel was much out of time, and I had almost despaired of ever hearing from her more—especially after we knew she had sailed from Alexandria, there had been two destructive gales of wind on our coast fatal to great numbers of vessels— But Captain Kelley had evaded them by putting into Norfolk, and waiting there for fair weather.— My health is still unsettled, capricious and wavering— My nights restless and dispirited— I concluded my Letter to Dr. Alvan Lamson to return Dr Gilman’s Reminiscences, and to take friendly notice of the Discourse upon the Congregational mode of worship, which I have preferred to all ever since Dudley Atkins at Newburyport republished an old dialogue between a blacksmith and a student of divinity, to prove the super-excellence of the Church of England’s book of Common prayer— In my mind the blacksmith’s argument recoiled upon himself— Yet I have joined in worship with the episcopal church both in England and in this country, down to the present day, though without ever subscribing to the creeds of that church even as confined in this Country to the Apostle’s and the Nicene-creed, and discard in the Athanasian altogether. I rode this afternoon in the Coach with my two daughters and little Mary over Milton hill, and over the Bridge to a shop where Mrs Charles stop’d two or three minutes. On returning home we found Mr and Mrs Thomas P. Smith, with two small children a boy and a girl. Mrs Smith brought with her a beautiful bunch of flowers, and requested of me a contribution for a volume of miscellaneous essays which she is about to publish, and I promised to furnish one.

27. V. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise 5.53 Cloudy Clear  Thou art my battle axe and weapons of war: for with thee will I break in pieces the Nations; and with thee will I destroy kingdoms—  Jeremiah 51.20—  This is expressed with so much obscurity that it is not clear who is intended by the battle-axe— It may be Nebuchadnezzar—or Cyrus—or Jacob—or figuratively Christ— In the Septuagint—the energy of the image and the image and the image itself is lost— The Genevan French and Luther’s German translations substitute for the battle-axe a hammer, and as the battle-axe itself is a type of all possible weapons of aggressive War, to name it, followed by weapons of War generally without specification rather weakens the idea it would convey if it stood alone— But the battle-axe is a weapon far more terrific than a hammer.  The Revd. Joseph Henry Allen, a graduate at Harvard University of 1840, a grandson of my long cherished friend and sometime chum, not long since deceased, professor Henry Ware, now pastor of the third Congregational church of Roxbury at Jamaica Plains preached at the Temple this day, by exchange with Mr Lunt— His morning text was from Ecclesiastes 1.8. “All thing are full of labour, man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing nor the ear filled with hearing.” He drew from his text a parallel between the lives and characters of David and of Solomon— The father and the Son both persons of transcendent renown among the children of men Seated on the pinnacle of glory— Tarnished with the pollution of shame— Mighty Monarchs. Holy prophets, Sublime Poets, venerable sages— David from a stripling Shepherd’s boy, rising through the gradation of a minstrel page to Saul, a commander of his army, the husband of his daughter, a banished fugitive from his kingdom, and a leader of the Philistines—then Captain of a band of outlaws— King of the tribes of Judah and Simeon after the death of Saul, and then thirty three years king of all the tribes. Solomon receiving from him the kingdom as a bequest—reigning forty years; endowed with wisdom specially from heaven, prosperous and happy beyond all other men yet falling in his old age beguiled by fair idolatresses, into the foulest worship of the heathens— This parallel and contrast are deeply impressive and were well handled but might have more widely extended— Mr Allen dined with us and after dinner preached from Luke 10.29.—“And who is my neighbour?” This text naturally introduces the parable of the good Samaritan, of which Sterne has made such admirable use— Mr Allen barely alluded to it, and meddled not at all with the narrative— The subject embraces the origin and history of the feuds and divisions between the Jews and the Samaritans— I suppose them to have arisen as early as the elevation of Saul to the kingdom; and though smothered during his reign, and those of David and Solomon, broke out broke out and became perpetual, on the revolts of the ten tribes from Rehoboam under Jeroboam the Son of Nebat— I was present as a delegate from our Temple Church at the Ordination of Mr Allen at Roxbury on the 18th. of October 1843.

28. IV. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise. 5.54.  25. The Lord is good unto them that wait for him, to the soul that seeketh him— 26. It is good that a man should both hope, and quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord. 27. It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth  Lamentations of Jeremiah— 3.25.26.27.  I am involving myself in scriptural enquiries beyond my depth and the possible consequences of which begin to discourage me in the pursuit—and absorb too much of my time— This conviction bears upon me especially since I have come to the reading of the prophets— From beginning on the first of last December to read every morning two chapters of the common English Bible without note or commentary, I have come to read four chapters every day—the corresponding chapters of Charles Thomson’s version of the Septuagint— Hewlett’s and Scott’s notes and commentaries—consulting occasionally Ostervald’s French and Luther’s German Bible, the translation of Calmet, and even the original Septuagint— I have barely touched upon Lowth’s Isaiah, and Noyes’s translation of the prophets— These have started multitudes of new questions that I cannot stop to investigate and I must discard, and give up the chase of the inaccessible mountaintops— The transpositions of the chapters of the Book of Jeremiah, as scrupulously followed by The Septuagint of Thomson is so perplexing that it is like a dislocation of all my limbs—  I slept this morning till near four, and rose at that hour— The constellation of Orion shone full in the Meridian, with his outposts Procyon and Sirius— Venus rose after five hastening to her conjunction with the Sun and her station as evening Star. Before Sunrise I walked round the Railroad square but the Sun rose beclouded— My symptoms are convalescent, but my weakness still has the mastery over me. I did not cast a look over the Observatory papers, or write a line for the Report of the Committee— Mr George Newcomb was here this afternoon but I could give him no encouraging account of his Petition before the House of Representatives of the United States for the bounty upon his lost fishing Schooner Rosanna— I told him there had been no Report from the Committee to which the petition was referred, and promised I would give all possible, and proper attention to it if able to attend at the approaching Session of Congress. My Letter to Dr Lamson was despatched— I received from my friend Christopher Morgan, a former member of Congress from theCongressional District of New in a duodecimo pamphlet of 51. pages the Argument of William H. Seward sometime Governor of New-York in defence of William Freeman on his trial for the murder of a whole family named Van Nest, husband, wife and children The trial was at Auburn, where Mr Seward resides, on the 21st. and 22d. of last July— The defence was insanity, and on that ground the man was acquitted— I went up the hill, and from the Northern porch of my Son’s house Saw the Sunset at 5.47. My Son, and his wife, and their daughter Louisa Catherine spent a short evening here.

29. IV. Fahrenheit 40 at Sunrise 5.55.  As an Adamant, harder than flint, have I made thy forehead: fear them not, neither be dismayed at their looks, though they be a rebellious house.  Ezekiel 3.9.  Adamant. It is remarkable that this beautifully sonorous word, has in the English language has no definite meaning or rather has three distinct and separate meanings— It is an imaginary stone, harder than flint as in this passage of the common Bible— It is the diamond, and so called in the French and German translations of this passage. And it is the loadstone. The Septuagint does not name it— No progress with the Report to the Overseers on the Observatory. Quite convalescent from my late Sore throat and debility— Voice still somewhat hoarse— Barely returned my recent arrears of Journal— I have received 1. A Letter from Mr Frye Washington— 24 Septr. mentioning an application to purchase a site for an ice house on the margin of the mill pond of the Columbia Mills— This Letter must be answered. 2. A Letter from J. M. Elam Baton Rouge Louisiana Septr. 1846—enclosing a printed paper signed by him, proposing sundry questions concerning Texas and the Western boundary of Louisiana, upon which he desires me to give my opinion with regard to a line of boundary, such as the pretension of France could have urged, and he says that in order to sustain President Polk for sending an armed force on the Rio del Norte an appeal has been made to all I have ever said as to that rivers having been claimed by France as the Western limit of antient Louisiana— This Letter also should be answered; but no pretensions of France to the Rio del Norte, as the boundary of Louisiana could extend inland from the mouth of that river, which could itself be claimed only as a half way point from La Salle’s landing at the Bay of St. Bernard, and the small detachment which he left there when he went Northward in search of the Mississippi and was murdered on his way. Which detachment was exterminated within two years whether by Spaniards or by Indians has never been ascertained, and was never after heard of— Nor has it ever been proved where the spot of La Salle’s landing and Settlement was, the name of the Bay of St. Bernard not having been given by him— The appeal of Mr Polk’s partizans to my arguments in discussion with the Spanish minister in the Negotiation for the Florida Treaty is a dishonest subterfuge to escape from the obligation which fixed by solemn agreement of both parties the boundary line at the Sabine where it had been already fixed in 1805 by a military convention between General Wilkinson and the commander of the Spanish troops in Mexico— 3. A printed circular from L. V. Badger and Co. Boston advertising and recommending Leighton’s Patent Enema Chair— The word enema is not in Johnson’s nor in Webster’s Dictionary.— I did not know its meaning, and resorted to Rees’s Encyclopaedia where I found it. I saw the Sunset from the Northern porch of Charles’s house at 5.46— For he rises before 6 in the morning and sets before 6 at Night— My Son was here this Evening—

30. IV. Fahrenheit 55 at Sunrise 5.56.  And behold, the man clothed with linen, which had the ink-horn by his side reported the matter, saying I have done, as thou hast commanded me.  Ezekiel 9.11.  This man clothed with linen and with an inkhorn at his side, is called in the Septuagint a man clothed in a long robe, and a girdle of sapphire about his loins— The clothing of linen is said by Scott to denote a Priest, and not a Soldier— The inkhorn may be of the same import, but Hewlett thinks the inkhorn out of place, and that ink was not used in those days; but how a man could be girt with a sapphire girdle is more questionable than that he should have an inkhorn at his side— In the vision of Ezekiel this man was charged with two distinct offices—the first was to set a mark upon the foreheads of the righteous persons who lamented and abhorred the crimes and corruptions of the people, and were therefore to be saved from the general destruction of the city: and this was what he reported he had performed: the second was to go in between the wheels and the Cherubim of the Sapphire throne, and fill his hand with coals of fire and scatter them over the city— He was at once a minister of Justice of Mercy, and of Vengeance—  We had a visit this afternoon from this Lady one of the three maiden daughters of my Mother’s cousin Quincy Thaxter of Hingham. I received a second Letter from Frederic Oxnard of Portland Maine Septr. 25. 1846. requesting an Autograph— I receive multitudes of such Letters from entire Strangers none of which I have answered for several years— I have not been without questions of the minor morals whether this course is perfectly right— In good fellowship and good neighbourhood, a civil request is entitled to a civil answer— But no one has the right to ask an autograph of an entire stranger, and the subscription of a name, which collectors of autographs generally desire, is liable to dangerous accidents, and to possible monstrous abuses— A discussion upon the right, would be useless, and exposed to ridicule so that I have consider the omission to answer such requests as a prudent and justifiable mode of declining to gratify them I am not however perfectly with my own conclusion— A request for an autograph from a stranger is an act of personal respect and kind feeling— It deserves return in the same spirit though not necessarily witch compliance— Were I not disabled for writing I would in every case comply, and in the omission to answer, my apology to myself is disability controuling my will. I received also a Letter from Daniel Adams of Keene New-Hampshire September 24. making enquiries of the genealogy of the Adams family, to ascertain whether he is consanguineous, as Sir Toby Belch says with us; but from the account he gives of himself he appears not to be a chip of the Old block— The Great Western Steamer arrived at New York in 17 days from Liverpool.

1. IV. Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise 5.57.  Lo, when the wall is fallen, shall it not be said unto you, Where is the daubing wherewith ye have daubed it? Ezekiel 13.12.  The reading of this passage in Thomson’s version of the Septuagint is—[“]Now when the wall is fallen, will they not say to you, Where is the anointing with which you anointed it”— But the discourse is of cement and not of ointment—not of salve but of untempered mortar— The daubing of the common bible is better than the ointment of the Septuagint— My wife went to Boston this afternoon, with Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa— I dined with my Son and his family up the hill, and about Sunset paid my first visit to my neighbours Mr and Mrs. N. Emmons in their new house. I found them just ready for tea, with two of their six children— Mr Emmons’s business is in Boston to which he goes by the morning Railway Cars, and returns between 4. and 5 in the afternoon— The Steamboat and the Railway are working out a revolution in the domestic life of the people of this and of many other Countries, the extent of which it is impossible to foretell. Its tendency here is to concentrate and multiply population— The Railway travel and transportation is of infinite importance to this town, both in its manufacturing interests almost coeval with its first settlements, and to its treasure richer that Mines of diamond or gold—its granite rocks, deemed worthless, little less than half a century ago, but now duly appreciated—and assiduously worked Mr. Emmons walked home with me but declined to come it— The Ladies went to Boston in the Coach and returned home all safe between 7 and 8 O’Clock, but we were kept till near 9 in painful suspense for my grandson John Quincy, who goes every day to school at Boston, and returns with the evening train of Cars.— By an unlucky and careless accident an engine without any cars attached to it, ran off the railway bridge at the draw, which was raised, and fell into the river— The cars coming from Boston at 7 in the evening were thus arrested at the Neponset Station two or three hours— John Quincy was a passenger in one of them— As soon as the Ladies came home they sent the Carriage back in search of him— He had undertaken to walk from the Neponset Station home, and met the Carriage going for him near Mr Quincy’s house— He got here safe to my grateful relief, before nine. I received a Letter from Thomas Cowperthwait and Co. printers at Philadelphia, with the present of a copy of a new Edition of Sanderson’s Biography of the signers of the Declaration of Independence in one large Octavo volume handsomely bound— The first edition of this work in nine 8vo. volumes was gotten up with great difficulties and many delays— But it was eventually prosperous. It dragged heavily along for a series of years till completed; but was then soon disposed of— A second Edition in three volumes was equally successful, and this I believe is the third; said to be revised and edited by Robert T. Conrad— It is well printed, on good paper, but the engraved portraits are miserable.— Those in the original edition were no better than indifferent. The life of my father was by Edward Ingersoll.

2. III. IV. Fahrenheit 50 at Sunrise. 5.58. Cloudy Wind E.  But he rebelled against him in sending his ambassadors into Egypt that they might give him horses and much people. Shall he prosper? Shall he escape that doeth such things? or shall he break the covenant and be delivered? 16. As I live, saith the Lord God, surely in the place where the king dwelleth that made him king, whose oath he despised, and whose covenant he brake, even with him, in the midst of Babylon shall die— Ezekiel 17.15.16.  The kingdom of Israel, that is of the ten tribes, often called in the prophetic books by the single name of Ephraim, was conquered by Shalmanezer king of Assyria, and Hoshea its last king with the mass of his people were carried into the Assyrian captivity 721 years before Christ— Hezekiah was then king of Judah, and he and his kingdom were miraculously delivered, from the Assyrians, whose Capitol was Nineveh, and 180000 of whom perished in one night—slain by the angel of the Lord— The kingdom of Judah continued in the line of David—from Hezekiah—through Manasseh, Amon and Josiah in lineal descent, till Josiah was vanquished and slain by Pharaoh Necho king of Egypt. The people of the land then made his son Jehoahaz king, but he reigned only 3 months— Pharaoh Necho carried him away to Egypt where he died. Pharaoh made his brother Eliakim king and turned his name to Jehoiakim— He was tributary to Pharaoh Necho, who in his turn was vanquished by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon— Jehoiakim then became his tributary, but after three years rebelled against him and was carried by him in fetters to Babylon— His son Jehoiachin succeeded him, but after a reign of 3 months surrendered himself to Nebuchadnezzar who carried him to Babylon where he remained in captivity 37. years.— Nebuchadnezzar then made Mattaniah a third son of Josiah king, and changed his name to Zedekiah and he reigned 11. years in Jerusalem— In the 9th. year he rebelled and Nebuchadnezzar after a siege of three years took and destroyed Jerusalem, abolished the kingdom of Judah, carried Zedekiah to Riblah, slew his sons before his eyes, put out his eyes, bound him with fetters of brass and carried him to Babylon. 588 years before Christ.— 133 years after the extinction of the kingdom of Israel— Zedekiah had sworn allegiance to Nebuchadnezzar—and rebelled against him— This prophesy of Ezekiel predicted the punishment that awaited him— This word of the Lord is said to have been announced by the prophet six years before the accomplishment of the prophesy— Mr William Cranch Bond, the Astronomical Observator at Harvard University came from Cambridge this morning to enquire concerning the printing of his observations which were submitted with his and professor Peirce’s report to the Committee of the board of Overseers at their late Meeting— I had received a Letter last week from President Edward Everett on the subject, but was not aware of Mr Bond’s impatience for the printing of his observations— I had intended to take the advice of Mr Abbott Lawrence for accepting the offer of the American Academy to pay the expence of the printing, but have postponed from day to day my visit to Mr Lawrence.— I promised Mr Bond to make it if the weather will permit to-morrow, and to advise with him for making a permanent arrangement with the American Academy for printing the future observations, as well as those already made to which Mr Bond readily assented— My Son and his wife and daughter were here this evening.

3. III. IV. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise 6. Clear.  Thus saith the Lord God, Remove the diadem and take off the crown: this shall not be the same: exalt him that is low; and abase him that is high. 27. I will overturn, overturn, overturn it; and it shall be no more, until he come whose right it is; and I will give it him— Ezekiel 21.26.27.  This prophesy is again pointed at Zedekiah four years before the final catastrophe, and one year before Nebuchadnezzar commenced the siege of Jerusalem— It is understood to predict the total and final overthrow of the line of David, but to allude obscurely to the advent of Christ—  I went in to Boston this morning in the special train of Cars from South Braintree, which left that place at half past ten, and the depot at Quincy a quarter before eleven— We passed the Stations of Neponset, Dorchester and Savin Hill and alighted in Boston at a quarter past 11. Half an hour is the regular average time for the passage between the Station at Quincy and Boston. My Granddaughter Mary Louisa went with me in the Cars, but on alighting at Boston we parted. She to go and take her riding lesson; I to visit Mr Abbott Lawrence at his counting house in Milk Street, where I found him— I had taken with me the papers prepared for the Report of the Committee of the board of Overseers last year, which owing to my indisposition at that time was not made, and the Reports of Professor Peirce, and Mr W. C. Bond with the observations and calculations annexed to them submitted to the Committee of Overseers at their late Meeting— Mr Lawrence told me that a subscription of 2500 dollars had been raise to provide a compensation for Mr W. C Bond as Astronomical Observer for two years, and that to raise a further and permanent fund for the support of the Observer, it was thought advisable to wait for the reception of the two great instruments bespoken, but not yet arrived, the Frauenhofer refractor from Munich, and the Transit instrument from Simms at London— We agreed to accept the proposal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences to have printed at their expense, all the Observations made and to be made by Mr. Bond and Mr Peirce, since the erection of the Observatory—and that I should send the papers to President Edward Everett as he has requested— From this interview with Mr Lawrence I went to my Son’s Office N. 23. Court Street— I afterwards called at Dr N. L. Frothingham’s and at the ex judge John Davis’s to see them but neither of them was at home, or perhaps visible— At Mr James H Foster’s I saw Mrs Foster and their daughters Louisa and Mary— At a quarter past 2 I returned to the cars for Quincy, and with my Son, my two granddaughters Mary Louisa and Louisa Catherine, and my grandson John Quincy came out in the special train— We found Albert and the Carriage waiting for us at the station and reached home to dine before 3— Mrs Stebbins and Elizabeth C Adams were here at Tea—and spent the Evening
