4. III. IV. Fahrenheit 34. at Sunrise 6–1. Cloudy Clear.  For thus saith the Lord God, Because thou hast clapped thine hands, and stamped with thy feet, and rejoiced in heart with all thy despite against the land of Israel; 7. Behold therefore, I will stretch out mine hand upon thee, and will deliver thee for a spoil to the heathen; and I will cut thee off from the people, and I will cause thee to perish out of the countries: I will deliver thee; and thou shalt know that I am the Lord. Ezekiel 25.6.7.  This is said of the Ammonites the descendants from Lot, by one of his daughters— This chapter contains similar denunciations against Moab, the progeny of Lot by his other daughter, and against Seir the Land of the Edomites the descendants from Esau— They are threatened with destruction, because they exulted at the subjugation of the children of Israel— All these Nations had nothing in common with the Philistines or any of the Canaanitish Nations, which were descended from the son of Ham Canaan.  This was communion day at the Temple, and the day when the hours of the morning and afternoon service are changed for the Season to begin henceforth at half past 10 instead of 10 in the morning, and at a quarter before two instead of a quarter after 2 in the afternoon— Mr Lunt’s morning text was Revelation 5.6. “And I beheld, and lo, in the midst of the throne, and of the four beasts, and in the midst of the elders, stood a Lamb, as it had been slain, having seven horns, and seven eyes, which are the seven Spirits of God sent forth into all the earth”— Mr Lunt commented upon the frequent use in the new Testament of the emblematical representation of Christ as a Lamb, of all animated nature perhaps the most characteristic of innocence gentleness and cheerfulness— He referred also to the four other beasts so conspicuous in the vision of the apocalypse with the faces of a lion, a bullock, or as the book calls it a calf a man and an eagle, but he did not remark the identity of the same complex animal in the vision of the prophet Ezekiel, nor did he observe that these four faces are understood to be indicative of the four Evangelists Matthew, Mark, Luke and John— After the Sermon and the dismission of the auditory except the members of the church, Mr Lunt administered the communion of which I partook feeling the obligation of divesting myself of every sentiment of animosity anger and resentment against any and every fellow creature of the human family, and praying for the reign of Justice and Truth upon Earth— Mr Lunt’s text this afternoon was from Romans 10.10. For with the heart man believeth unto Righteousness—leaving out the remainder of the verse— He said believers might be of three classes. 1. Mere believers by the act of the Understanding. 2. believers with the heart, in which the affections are engaged, and 3— Believers unto righteousness, resulting from the engagement of the affections in the belief— My Son and his wife and daughter spent the Evening here—

5. III. IV:45 Fahrenheit 46 at Sunrise— 6.2. Cloudy.  In that day, will I cause the horn of the house of Israel to bud forth, and I will give thee the opening of the mouth in the midst of them; and they shall know that I am the Lord. Ezekiel 29.21.  I will give thee the opening of the mouth is the promise of inspiration. The word of the Lord came to the prophets— They never spoke in their own names— The opening of their mouths was given them from the Lord— They only repeated what they heard and their form of Speech was “Thus saith the Lord.”— There were false prophets, who used the same form of Speech, besides the Priests of the Heathen Deities, Baal, Dagon, Moloch and many others a catalogue of whom may be found in Milton’s Paradise Lost— The false prophet was to be put to death, whether he prophesied in the name of any other God than Jehovah, or in his name without authority. The fulfilment of the prophesy was the test by which the people were to know whether the pretender to prophesy in the name of Jehovah was a true, or a false prophet— Ezekiel, and the other true prophets bitterly denounced and not unfrequently put to death the false ones, who usually prophesied smooth things. The Office of the true prophet was one of extreme danger— They were always persecuted—and often put to death—  Mr Minott Thayer came this afternoon, and introduced a relation of his by the name of Whitney— I reminded him of the Book which Benjamin V. French and Asa French, had borrowed of me on the 19th. of May 1841. with a promise to return it after having a copy of it made— He acknowledged the obligation of the promise to which he had also pledged his word, and again promised that he would see to have it returned but he intimated that by the neglect of Benjamin V. French the copy of it has not yet been made— I received a Letter from James Maguire, a member of the Senate in the Legislature of this Commonwealth, Randolph Octr 2. 1846. informing me that at a Convention of whig delegates of District N. 8. assembled at Dedham Octr. 1. instt. a Committee of five Gentlemen were chosen to make known to me the doings of that body, and requesting me to name a day and hour when the Committee may meet me, and communicate to me the wishes of the Convention— There is no distinct intimation of what they were; but the convention unanimously nominated me by ballot for re-election to represent the district in the 30th. Congress of the United States—and they passed two sets of Resolutions, corresponding with those which were adopted by the State Convention held at Boston last week, and with those there offered by Stephen C. Phillips and rejected—but both sets were adopted at Dedham— The Liberty party of the 8th. District have nominated Appleton Howe of Weymouth as their Candidate for the 30th. Congress. They nominated him for the 29th.— I have taken a bad cold, and have a return of the sore throat.

6. II— IV:30. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise 6.3. Fog—clear.  Say unto them, As I live saith the Lord God, I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way, and live: turn ye, turn ye from your evil ways; for why will ye die, O house of Israel?  Ezekiel 33.4—  Throughout this chapter, the idea constantly maintained is that the reward of righteousness, shall be life, and the punishment of wickedness shall be death— The Lord has no pleasure in the death of the wicked. Why will ye die? let the wicked turn from his way and live— But Solomon says in the Book of Ecclesiastes 9.2 that there is one event to the righteous and to the wicked, and Jesus exhorts his disciples to be the children of their Father which is in Heaven for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.— Equally certain it is, that the evil and the good—the just and the unjust equally die.— Life and death therefore do not depend upon the righteousness or wickedness of the individual, and the words live and die throughout this chapter must be understood in a figurative and spiritual sense— Nor can I understand it in any other sense than as a promise of future life to the righteous, and a warning of total extinction to the life of the wicked— Why will ye die? The threat of punishment after death—death itself is the penalty—as life is the reward— Not life in this world—but life in the world to come. Life and punishment in the future world was not the doctrine of the Mosaic dispensation but was denounced with emphatic and awful solemnity by Jesus Christ— My health continues to droop, and my hoarseness and sore throat still return— I answered the Letter yesterday received from Mr. James Maguire, and named next Saturday or Monday to receive the Committee from the whig Convention of the 8th congressional District— I wrote also to President Edward Everett, and enclosed the Reports to the Committee of the Overseers—of Professor Peirce, and Mr William C Bond, with the papers annexed to them— Mr Jonathan Wild was here again to enquire concerning the pension  claim of his mother Deborah Wild, but upon which I could still give him no satisfactory information— My chest of Books and Papers ship’d from Washington by the Schooner forest king has arrived but I have not found in it any papers relating to claims nor the printed sheets of the Journal of the House of Representatives of the United States at their late Session which I expected— Mr Wild promised to call once more before I go to Washington, and If I should not in the meantime find the papers I engaged to make search for them at Washington, on my return to the approaching Session— My wife dined and took tea up the hill at Charles’s, and he and his wife were afterwards here. Mr Emmons also paid us an evening visit, and invited me to join a party of a Committee from the City Councils of Boston, to visit George’s and Rainsfords Islands in the harbour to-morrow: which invitation I accepted, without enquiring into its authority.

7. III. IV. Fahrenheit 46 at Sunrise 6.4. Thick fog  Moreover, thou son of man, take thee one stick and write upon it, For Judah, and for the children of Israël his companions: then take another stick, and write upon it, For Joseph, the stick of Ephraim, and for all the house of Israel his companions: 17. And join them one to another into one stick; and they shall become one in thine hand Ezekiel 37.16.17.  Ezekiel closes the vision of a preceding chapter (20) with an exclamation Then said I, Ah Lord God! They say of me, Doth he not speak parables? which seems to be a remonstrance that the word which came to the prophet was not sufficiently intelligible; and that when he delivered it to the people, they affected not to understand him, and charged him with sporting fables upon them— In the next chapter therefore the same prophesy is pointed expressly at Jerusalem— Almost all the prophesies of the old Testament are parables, and Matthew says 13.34 that all the discourses of Jesus to the multitude, were in parables, and without a parable spake he not unto them— The apostle speaks of this as itself the fulfilment of a prophesy of the utterance of things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world— Is not the secret of eloquence in the parable— This parable of two sticks needed no explanation— It explained itself—immediately following that of the resurrection of dry bones, a figure of surpassing energy.  At half past eight this morning I started in the morning train of the old Colony Railroad from Plymouth to Boston. My Son went at the same time to attend his Office in Boston, and my Grand daughter Mary Louisa to take her riding lesson— Mr Beale and Mr Emmons were also of the company. Alighting at 9. O’Clock at the depot in Boston, I walked to my Son’s Office 23. Court Street where I saw Mr A. C. Spooner and Mr Charles Sumner, and also Captain Nathaniel Curtis— At a quarter before 11. Mr Beale called and I walked with him to the end of the long wharf where we embarked in the Steam propeller. Ralph B. Forbes, with a Committee of the City Government consisting of the Mayor, Josiah Quincy junr. sundry Aldermen and Members of the Common Council upon an excursion down the harbour to near the Lighthouse at its entrance.— We visited George’s Island where the fortifications are in a course of erection by the Government of the United States, and where we met Coll. Thayer who superintends the works; and Rainsford’s Island which belongs to the city, and where we dined upon Chowder and cold water. We returned to Boston, slowly against wind and tide—landed a quarter past 6 on the long wharf, whence with Mr Beale and Mr Emmons, I repaired to the depot of the old Colony Railroad and we came out in the last daily train of cars to Quincy. Found the carriage in waiting and after accompanying Mr Emmons and Mr Beale home came to my own— Mr Loring had been here—

8. III.30. IV.15 Fahrenheit 60 at Sunrise 6.5.  And it was made with cherubims and palm trees, so that a palm tree, was between a cherub and a cherub; and every cherub had two faces; So that the face of a man was toward the palm tree on one side, and the face of a young lion toward the palm tree on the other side: it was made through all the house round about.— Ezekiel 41.18.19—  The vision recorded in the Book of Ezekiel from the 40th. to the 48th. chapter, inclusive to the end of the book is among the darkest and most inexplicable parts of the holy Scriptures— Among the difficulties to me of this book is a very confused Chronology— It begins with a vision in the 30th year in the fourth month in the 5th. day of the month, but the 30th. year from what date no one can tell; but the prophet was among the captives by the river of Chebar in the land of the Chaldeans,—but it was in the fifth year of king Jehoiachins captivity— The next vision, is in the 6th. year in the 6th month in the 5th. day of the month Chapter 8. Other visions follow the dates of which are not given till that of the 7th. year the 5th. month and tenth day of the month Chapter 20,— Then in the 9th year, tenth month tenth day—Ch. 24— Then 11th year first day of the month—Ch 26.— Then 10th year, tenth month 12th. day of the month ch. 29.—next 11th. year 3d. month 1st. day of the month ch 31—then 12th year. 12th. month 1st day. ch. 32. Then 12th. year of our captivity 10th. month 5th. day ch 33 v. 21. and lastly in the five and twentieth year of our captivity in the beginning of the year in the 10th. day of the month, in the 14th. year after the city was smitten, came the vision of the holy city and new temple, the report of which occupies the last nine chapters of the book— In this series of visions the chronological order is repeatedly inverted The book is in form an autobiography in fragments of a Jewish priest a captive in Babylon seeing visions and hearing the word of the Lord from time to time through a long succession of years, prophesying destruction to the government of his own Country—and to all the neighbouring nations around her.  We had visits from Ex-President Quincy, his Lady and two of their maiden daughters— Mr Quincy is somewhat indisposed with the influenza, which afflicts also Margaret a female member of our family who came with us from Washington— I rode with my daughters to Braintree, and Charles and his wife. Mrs Stebbins and Elizabeth C. Adams were here this Evening— I received this day a Letter from the heirs of John Paul Jones, at New-York, with a pamphlet containing a Report from the Committee on Naval Affairs by William B. Maclay of New-York on the 10th. of February last with a bill for their relief— Also a Letter from Thomas J. Allen President of the Mercantile Library Association Boston—with a ticket of admission to the exercises at the celebration of their 26th. Anniversary, next Wednesday the 14th. And a Letter from Samuel Hill, Secretary of the Woburn Lyceum, Inviting me to Lecture before that association, between this, and the last of next January.

9 III IV. Fahrenheit 50. at Sunrise 6.6. Fog— Clear.  Thus saith the Lord God, Let it suffice you, O princes of Israel: remove violence and spoil, and execute judgment and justice, take away your exactions from my people, saith the Lord God.— Ezekiel 45–9.  A Fog immediately before Sunrise was succeeded by a day of Summer heat and Fahrenheit at 84.— My daily morning walk before Sunrise is round the Railway Square, from half an hour to 32 minutes. My first visitor this afternoon was Mrs Frost who said she had been twelve years a widow, residing with her father at Littleton in the County of Middlesex in this State—that she had two sons one of whom has already been graduated at Princeton College, New Jersey, and the other has entered this present year at Cambridge. The only reason of her visit to me, she said was the desire to see me— The four succeeding visitors must have been actuated by a similar motive. Miss Pennell residing at Jamaica Plains, and Miss Simson, on a visit to her from Brunswick in the State of Maine— Mr Allen and Mr Morse, as I understood them are inhabitants of Boston. Mr Freeman is a brother of the late Coll. Freeman of the U.S. Marine corps and administrator of his estate— He has a petition before Congress for a claim in this capacity, and came to enquire of its condition— In this as in other cases the want of the Journal of U.S.H.R. leaves me unable to answer his enquiries— All I could say to him was that his petition and that of Mrs Freeman, the Colonel’s widow were both referred at the last Session to the committee on Naval Affairs, of which Isaac E. Holmes of Charleston South Carolina was chairman, and that the Committee made no report; the alternative of which would have been a report against the claim. A part of it however was for pay which John Tyler as P.U.S. had illegally ordered not to be paid— Mr Freeman said he had received this; and I advised that both Mrs Freeman and he should prepare new petitions to be presented at the approaching Session of congress, omitting such portions of the claims as have been already satisfied. This he said they would do; and I promised to take charge of the petitions— My Son received a Letter from John G. Palfrey the Secretary of the Commonwealth—mentioning that Judge Willard Phillips wished to call on me; that he had promised to come with him, and introduce him—and requesting me to fix a time some afternoon of next week to receive them— I desired my son to answer the letter and say, I shall be glad to see them any afternoon of the week, I received also a Letter from Samuel Colman 30. Cornhill Boston 2. Octr. 1846. requesting an interview with me to talk with him about his son William, and to solicit my attention and influence in getting him into the West Point Institution.— A hopeless chance— Charles and his children went to see Signor Blitz.

10. IV. Fahrenheit 42 at Sunrise 6.7. Clear after rain.  It was round about eighteen thousand measures: and the name of the city from that day shall be The Lord is there, Jehovah-shammah.  Ezekiel 48.35.  The visions of Ezekiel are all recorded by himself, speaking in the first person, but whether they were published from time to time as they occurred or were collected together and published at one time is not ascertained by the book itself nor by any of the Commentators that I have at hand— He may be called as Agamemnon in Homer’s Iliad calls Calchas, a prophet of plagues,—for he denounces destruction and ruin to all the Nations upon Earth of which he had any knowledge— But he predicts throughout the restoration to independence and power of his own country which has never yet been realized— Of other nations he foretells the total and final destruction, and that has been fulfilled. Tyre and Sidon, the Ammonites, Moabites, Edomites, Egypt, Assyria, Babylon— The Chaldeans, Medes and Persians are all extinct, and their countries are either desolate or inhabited by other races, while the children of Israel are scattered all over the globe, with the national stamp upon their foreheads and the national character upon their Souls.  In my answer to Mr James Maguire I named this day as one upon which I should be ready to receive the Committee from the Whig Convention of the 8th. Congregational District of Massachusetts, held at Dedham on the 1st. of this Month, but they did not come, and as often happens after a busy day from 4 in the morning till ten at Night there is nothing left on my memory worthy of being recorded as the action or incident of the day— I received a Letter from my old Correspondent George Joy with triplicate copies of his Letters to Messrs. Hogan and Thompson of 1. August and 3. Septr. 1846— His present Letter to me is dated 19 John Street Pentonville 18 September 1846—and complains that his expectation to hear from me by the Mail of 1. Septr that I had received the copy of his Letter, Pacificus of 1. August to Hogan and Thompson was disappointed, and he fears that his Letter to me enclosing the copy of it has been suppressed, a trick which no mortal could have any possible temptation to practise— He should have received my acknowledgment of the receipt of his Letter and copy if I had written and despatched it as I ought to have done— I answered the Letter of Mr Samuel Colman dated Boston 2. October 1846 requesting an interview with me to talk respecting his desire to obtain the admission of his Son William as a Cadet at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point— I readily agree to the interview, but apprized Mr Colman of the Rules of the War Department respecting the admission of Cadets, which leave the chance of success to the application for his son hopeless. I walked this morning round the railroad square before Sunrise—my exercise for the day. My Son with his wife and daughter were here this evening.

11. III. IV.15 Fahrenheit 32 at Sunrise. 6.9. Clear  And this is the writing that was written, MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN. 26. This is the interpretation of the thing; MENE. God hath numbered thy kingdom and finished it 27. TEKEL Thou art weighed in the balances and art found wanting. 28. PERES; Thy kingdom is divided, and given to the Medes and Persians.  Daniel 5.25–28.  It is very strange that in our common english bible the last word of the explanation differs materially from the last word of the handwriting on the wall. The Septuagint reads Mane (without repetition) Thekel, Phares, and the words of the explanation are the same as those of the hand-writing— They were words of no meaning either in Hebrew or in Chaldaic— They were understood by no one, save Daniel, who explained them— Scott’s commentary says that the word Peres, is the same as upharsin only omitting the prefix and termination, but Peres cannot be the same as phar— There was no time for carrying into fulfilment the promised the reward though Belshazar it seems did ordain its fulfilment— Who Darius the Median was seems not to be well settled; but he was maternal uncle to Cyrus, and was perhaps the same as Cyaxares 2. son of Astyages.  Margaret Delany a house maid whom my wife brought with us from Washington, a very worthy and useful young woman has been several days suffering severely with a sore throat, and threatened with a lung fever— At three O’Clock this morning Mrs Kirk came into our bed chamber, and said that Margaret was in extreme pain, and she knew not what to do for her— My wife directed her to send immediately for Dr Woodward, which was done and he came in the course of half an hour— Mrs Adams left her bed, and went to nurse the poor girl, and did not return till after I had risen at a quarter past 4 for the day  Mr Huntington Minister of the South Church in Washington Street, Boston preached by exchange for Mr Lunt, and dined with us— His text at the morning service was John 17.21. [“]That they all may be one; as thou, Father art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us.” It was a discourse upon the unity of the Christian church; but the most remarkable part of it was a keen and severe comment upon a pretended World’s convention recently held in London, for the ostensible purpose of uniting the discordant sects of protestants in a new creed— A new theological holy alliance— The text of his afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 5.47. the middle of the verse, “what do you more than others?[”]— I was present at Mr Huntington’s ordination as a delegate from the Temple church at Quincy— Mr Huntington is a young man of fine talents and distinguished eloquence— After church Mr Loring of Hingham was here and I agreed to visit him next Tuesday if the weather should be fair.

12. IV:10. Fahrenheit 36. at Sunrise. 6.10. Clear  Know therefore, and understand, that from the going forth of the commandment to restore and to build Jerusalem, unto the Messiah the Prince, shall be seven weeks and threescore and two weeks: the street shall be built again and the wall, even in troublous times. Daniel 9.25.  This immediately follows the ever memorable prophesy of the seventy weeks which is said to be the reason of the Jews for excluding the book of Daniel from the Canon of their scriptures. But there are four different opinions as to the time indicated by the going forth of the commandment to restore and to build Jerusalem— The first year of Cyrus— The second of Darius: the 7th. and the 20th. of Artaxerxes.— In the earnest desire to give the assent of my own mind to the faith that all the prophesies of the old Testament are predictions of the advent of the Messiah, there is no passage in it more precise and direct than this— The Messiah is styled the Prince a title little suited to the condition in which Jesus Christ appeared upon earth, but still he was the anointed of the Lord—  These three gentlemen came about 11 O’Clock this morning, and informed me that they, together with Lysander Richards of Quincy and J. J. Richards of Weymouth were deputed by the whig Convention of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts held at Dedham on the first of this month to nominate a candidate to be supported by the whig party to represent the District in the House of Representatives of the United States in the 30th. Congress, to inform me that I was chosen by ballot unanimously as the candidate of the party, and to request my acceptance of the nomination. I answered Mr Maguire the chairman of the committee and who spoke in their name, and said that I accepted the nomination with grateful sentiments for the honour done me by the Convention in presenting my name to the people for re-election to the trust which I hold of representing them in Congress, and with equal sensibility to the kindness of the members of the Committee in taking the trouble to make this communication to me in person. I added that I could not but be highly gratified by the unanimity of the Convention, specially manifested by the form of voting by ballot— I regarded it as a decisive testimony of the approbation of my constituents upon the general course of my conduct as their representative, and I made some remarks in commenting upon which my conduct has been subject to some animadversion and censure— The Oregon question and the Mexican War— They expressed their concurrence with my views and after a short conversation took their leave— There are two nominations by Conventions against me Isaac H. Wright, by the Democracy, and Appleton Howe of Weymouth by the Liberty party— The same persons were nominated against me, by the same parties at the election for the present Congress— They may be stronger now— I rode this afternoon with Mrs Charles. Mary-Louisa went to Boston this afternoon to go this Evening to the Opera.

13. III.15. IV. Fahrenheit 52. at Sunrise— 6.11. Clear with clouds.  And many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt  Daniel 12.2.  No doubt then says Scott, the resurrection of the dead, the day of judgment and the eternal state of retribution are here predicted; and that shame and everlasting contempt, as well as torment and misery which will be the lot of the wicked— The words are—many of them that sleep in the dust—and in the preceding verse—every one that shall be found written in the book— Immortal life and a state of future retribution as foreshadowed here are attributes not of all mankind—but of many, some righteous and some wicked— Life and immortality to all were brought to light only by the gospel of Jesus Christ—  This morning was fair and the temperature of the atmosphere mild— I walked round the railway square before Sunrise, without pinching of fingers as yesterday and the day before. I had promised Mr Loring of Hingham a visit for a tea-party, at his house, and a ride upon a Nantasket beach; if the weather should be fair. But the clouds were gathering all the morning, and by noon it commenced raining; a heavy gale followed and at night, a Tempest approaching to a hurricane, which continued till near midnight before which its violence somewhat subsided— Mary-Louisa returned this morning from her visit to Boston, where she went to the Opera last evening with Mrs Phineas Foster by her invitation and passed the Night at her house— She was unwell this evening. I received a Letter from Charles R. Glynn, New-Orleans 29. Septr 1846—with a map engraved on silk paper, shewing the movements of the U.S. army now engaged in the Conquest of Mexico exhibiting the probable routes of the army, from its departure from Comargo, to Monterey—Satillo &c, the different rivers, streams, and their tributaries, and the distances in leagues from one village or Rancho to another, being an exact copy of the Chart of General Arista taken at the Battle of Resaca de la Palma 9. May 1846— This map is peculiarly valuable at this time, the information having been just now received of the taking of Monterey in New Leon, South of the Rio del Norte on the Rio del Tigre in Latitude 26— by General Taylor and our army— The Reports are that it was taken by Storm and by capitulation; after three days of hard fighting and a loss of 500 men, killed wounded and missing— I received also a second Letter from Mr Samuel Colman, renewing his application for my aid to obtain a Cadet warrant at West-Point for his Son— I had just before receiving it despatched my answer to his first Letter— I answered the Letter of Samuel Hill inviting me to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at Woburn—declining—and commenced an answer to William C. Prime New-York declining the invitation to lecture at Williamsburg—Long Island.

14. II.45. IV. Fahrenheit 54 at Sunrise 6.12— After S.E. Tempest.  12 Therefore will I be unto Ephraim as a moth, and to the house of Judah, as rottenness— 15. I will go and return to my place till they acknowledge their offence, and seek my face; in their affliction they will seek me early.  Hosea 5.12–15.  I abstain from all observations upon the first 5 chapters of Hosea—  I fell asleep last night very soon after retiring to bed at 10 O’Clock, in the very fury of the gale, and awoke before three this morning, and all was calm at 4. I rose and found the atmosphere warm—the thermometer at 54—the moon Orion, Sirius, and Procyon all visible though not very bright, and soon after 5. Venus rising as morning Star— I walked round the Railroad square to meet the rising Sun—but he rose beclouded— Immediately after breakfast Mr Loring came in from Hingham, and urged me with so much earnestness to go to his tea party this evening that I yielded, if the weather should continue fair with a promise of a ride upon Nantasket beach this afternoon; perhaps to pass the night at Mr Loring’s to go in the Steamboat May-flower from Hingham to Boston to-morrow morning, and to return home by the Old Colony Railroad Cars to-morrow— I had visits before dinner from Robert C. Winthrop with Mr Pakenham the British Minister, at Washington, and Joseph R. Ingersoll of Philadelphia— Mr Pakenham is on his return from a short northern excursion of curiosity to see the country and Mr Ingersoll comes to deliver this evening the introductory Lecture to the winter course of the Mercantile Library Association at Boston— I had a special invitation to attend this meeting, but was disappointed first by the engagement at Hingham, and secondly by the foul weather, which disconcerted both purposes: for the clouds continued to gather, and by the time we had finished our dinner it began to rain— After some hesitation I started in the Carriage but before reaching the Bent’s point bridge the rain increased and I directed my coachman Albert to turn back and came home— The rain continued till late in the evening but without a storm, and cleared off before midnight— My Son and his wife passed the evening with us, in spite of the weather.— Mr John G. Palfrey sent me word that he and judge Willard Phillips would visit me to-morrow— I received from Mr Joseph E. Worcester of Cambridge a very kind note with the present of a copy of a Universal and critical Dictionary of the English language, in one large and thick octavo volume—which he has published at Boston during the present year. I answered the Letters of Samuel Hill Secretary of the Woburn Lyceum, and of William C Prime at New-York soliciting the delivery of Lectures at Woburn, and at Williamsburgh near Brooklyn on Long Island— In both cases declining— The Passion for Lyceum Lectures is on the wane; and I can no longer serve to feed it.

15. IV Fahrenheit 32 at Sunrise 6.13. Crystal clear.  My God will cast them away, because they did not hearken unto him; and they shall be wanderers among the Nations  Hosea 9.17.  The prophesies of Hosea, embrace periods from 786 to 723 before Christ—during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and in the days of Jeremiah 2d. king of Israel—whose reign continued from 783 to 742 before Christ forty one years— The prophesy of this chapter was delivered in the year 760. and is a prediction of the Assyrian captivity accomplished by Shalmanezer in 721. The declaration applies to the people of the then tribes, personified in the name of Ephraim; sometimes by that of Israel, and often by that of Samaria— After the revolt from the house of David of the ten tribes, and the establishment by Jeroboam the son of Nebat of the kingdom of Israel, its kings dwelt successively at Shechem, at Penuel, at Tirzah and finally in Samaria, purchased by Omri of Shemer, and thenceforward commenced the inextinguishable hatred between the Jews and the Samaritans—  The morning came on again with a clear sky a bright Sun, and my thermometer at the freezing point. Immediately after breakfast Mr Loring of Hingham came in again, on his way to Boston, with his horse and buggy. I had come to the conclusion to postpone for the present Season my annual visit to Hingham, and party at Mr Loring’s house, but he insisted upon another trial, and proposed on his return from Boston this afternoon to take me in his carriage to his house—to have his tea party there to which he said he had invited at least forty persons for the first fair day—that I should pass the night at his house, and go to Boston from Hingham in the New Steamer the May-Flower to-morrow morning, and thence return home by the railway cars— Mr Palfrey had sent me word that he and judge Phillips would visit me this day and I had promised to receive them— To this objection Mr Loring answered that if necessary he would wait till dark, for that visit be over, and I agreed to go with him— They came immediately after we had risen from dinner, and their visit was not of more than half an hour— They were gone, when Mr Loring came and took me up, and we reached his house at the dusk of evening. The tea party soon followed and an evening company of between forty and fifty Ladies and Gentlemen, all of Hingham, and all friends and neighbours of Mr Loring— A very handsome supper of fruit cakes, and confectionary, with lemonade to drink closed the evening: the company dispersed and about 11. O’Clock I retired to my bed. A mingled reflection of self-sufficiency, and of humiliation remained on my mind in the consciousness of disproportion of my part of the conversation. Mr Stearns, the Minister asked my opinion of the right of the United States to the Oregon Territory, which I answered in something like an address at a political canvass upon what in England they call the hustings.

16. VI.15. Who is wise, and he shall understand these things? prudent and he shall know them? for the ways of the Lord are right, and the just shall walk in them; but the transgressors shall fall therein.  Hosea 14.9—  Hosea is the first of the 12 minor prophets; and his prophesy is chiefly against Ephraim that is the kingdom of the ten tribes— He predicts the Assyrian captivity and the dispersion of the Samaritans— He threatens Judah also with the indignation of Jehovah—but finishes with a promise of restoration to Israel; and with this last cheering sentiment to the wise and the prudent—  In the English, French, German Bibles the prophesy of Hosea contains 14 chapters, and the Septuagint has the same number— Professor Noyes’s translation is in 16 chapters, but his notes are only upon 14. He assigns no reason for the change in the number of chapters.  I took a single cup of coffee at the party last evening and the consequence was the loss of the whole Night’s sleep— Or rather from 1 to 5 in the morning I was in a state of somnambular sleep, consciously awake and yet insensible to the lapse of time— I heard the clock in a room below strike twelve and one, and then lay fretting at my inability to sleep my senses in forgetfulness; till the dawn came upon me by surprize, and I wondered what had become of the Clock at the hours of 2 3 and 4.— I rose at half past 6. breakfasted at Mr Loring’s, and at half past 7. took passage in the Steam-boat May-Flower for Boston. A new boat which has taken the place of the General Lincoln and plies daily between Hingham and Boston. Mr Loring went in the same boat, and a young Lady by the name of Brown who had been at the party last evening and had lodged at Mr Loring’s. As passengers in the boat, I met also the young painter Hudson, who had painted my portrait last year, and an old gentleman about 60. whom Mr Loring introduced to me by the name of Sohier—William Davies Sohier— I found he was the Son of Edward Sohier a graduate of Harvard University of 1781 six years before me, and a senior practitioner at Law, with me at Boston from 1790. to 1793 when he died after a lingering illness of several months; some time before he died he sent for me, and put into my hands the papers of all his business in the courts which I managed for him till his death— I was one of the pall-bearers at his funeral, and then saw this son of his then a child not more than 6 years of age— I had no recollection of having seen him from that day to this; but he said he had seen me at a later date, at Dr Aaron Dexter’s, whose daughter he married— It must have been in 1807 8 or 9. He has a son named Edward Dexter, a graduate at Harvard University in 1829, and now in good reputation as a practising lawyer—but I do not know him— We landed from the Steamboat, at the wharf behind Pearl-Street about a quarter before 9. and I walked to my Son’s office, where I staid till I was ten minutes too late for the train of cars at half past 9— Then visited Cadmus, judge John Davis, Dr George Parkman, not at home— Came out in the cars at half past 2. and dined at my Son’s up the hill.

17. IV:10— Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise— 6.15—  A fire devoureth before them; and behind them a flame burneth: the land is as the garden of Eden before them, and behind them a desolate wilderness; yea, and nothing shall escape them. Joel 2.3.  Professor Noyes commences his translation of the Hebrew prophets with the book of Joel— He proposes to substitute a chronological order instead of that in which the Hebrew and the Septuagint concur. But the internal evidence of the book of Joel does not disclose when it was written; and it can scarcely be called a prophesy. It is rather a terrific description of an existing calamity—a plague of Locusts overspreading and desolating the whole land of Judah— The description is awful— The locusts and the mildew are called the great army of the Lord and the picture of the garden of Eden before and the desolation behind startles the imagination to fill up the interval with a volume of the details of destruction.  To make up of the loss of sleep of the night before last I slept last night for the two, and waking only to hear the entry clock strike 4— I then rose and before Sunrise walked round the railway square— The weather was pleasant and almost warm. In the forenoon, Miss Mary A. Baker of Boston came with two numbers 1 and 7. Volume 5 of the Orphans Advocate and Social Monitor, a periodical monthly publication of 8 quarto pages, by Misses A. and E. C. Fellows— It is devoted to the welfare of destitute children, to benevolence and social improvement— These Ladies superintend also an institution, the object of which is to procure places for indigent children, and homes for the houseless. In each of the two papers were two advertisements, one of places in sundry towns of the Commonwealth, offering to take children—mostly girls as members of the family, or to adopt them, and the other of children, boys and girls needing homes— A third advertisement is of donations received, and a fourth the names of travelling agents, four men and four maiden women, of whom Miss Mary A. Baker is one. I gave 3 dollars as a contribution to the cause, but declined subscribing for the paper— I dined again at my Son’s house up the hill— Mrs Charles after dinner took home Miss Rachel Sampson of Braintree, who has been these two weeks working as a Seamstress at the two houses, but who always at the end of each week goes home to pass the Lord’s day under the orthodox spiritual teaching of her own Pastor the Revd. Richard Storrs D.D— About the setting of the Sun MrsSmith came with her husband for the Article which she had requested of me for her contemplated miscellany— I had it not ready—but promised to send her one in the course of the next week—an engagement which I consider as a corvée.

18. III.25— IV. Fahrenheit 42 at Sunrise 6.17. Drizzling N.E storm  Shall a trumpet be blown in the city, and the people not be afraid? shall there be evil in a city, and the Lord hath not done it? Amos 3.6.  I read this passage in the Book of Amos this morning, and attended public worship at the Temple where Mr Lunt preached morning and afternoon, and in both his discourses suggested reflections and enquiries bearing upon these interrogatories— Shall there be evil in a city and the Lord hath done it? A direct assertion that God is the author of all evil could not so emphatically express the idea as this simple question has done— Thomson translates the corresponding passage in the Septuagint to read “Can there be in a city a calamity which the Lord hath not inflicted?[”] The question whether God is the author of all evil is not quite so salient in this reading as in that of the Hebrew-English Bible. But is as fully included in it— Mr Lunt’s morning text was 1. Timothy 3.16— “And without controversy, great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory.[”]— Mr Lunt analysed the enumeration of particulars in respect to which godliness is said to be greatly mysterious, but they appear to have relation exclusively to the person, and divinity of Jesus Christ— The text of the afternoon sermon was James 1.13—[“]Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man 14.— But every man is tempted when he is drawn away of his own lust and enticed.”— A text which I cannot undertake to reconcile with that of Amos at the top of this page— I only remember reading when I was at the University, the disquisition of Soame Jenyns, on the Origin of evil, whose answer to the objection that his theory makes God the author of evil, is that God must be the author of every thing—  I received a pamphlet printed by J and G. S. Gideon, Washington being the report by Samuel F. Vinton, from the select Committee of the House of Representatives of the United States, at the last Session of Congress upon the charges made by Charles Jared Ingersoll of Official misconduct of Daniel Webster while Secretary of State— The report exonerates Webster from any misdemeanor punishable by Legislative animadversion, but substantiates official transactions not deserving of approbation— The report was laid on the table, and no action was taken upon it by the house—not even an order that it should be printed— This pamphlet must have been published by Webster himself, or some of his friends— Its title is Alleged Official Misconduct of the late Secretary of State—and in addition to the Report, there is an extract from a Speech of Westcott a democrat Senator from Florida, to bolster up the tarnished reputation of Webster; whose private character is notoriously loose in morals and of intemperate habits, both of the table and bed chamber— Less odious however than the vices of his accuser.

19. IV. Fahrenheit 36. at Sunrise— 6.18. Cloudy N.E.  And I will bring again the captivity of my people of Israel, and they shall build the waste cities, and inhabit them; and they shall plant vineyards, and drink the wine thereof; they shall also make gardens and eat the fruit of them. 15. And I will plant them upon their land, and they shall no more be pulled up out of their land, which I have given them, saith the Lord thy God.  Amos 9–14–15—  Amos was a common Shepherd, among the herdmen of Tekoa, and he was charged by Amaziah, the priest of Bethel, with conspiracy against Jeroboam the second king of Israel. Amaziah denied the right of Amos to prophesy against the king of Israel, because he was a subject of the king of Judah, and he ordered Amos to flee away into the land of Judah, and eat bread and prophesy there— Amos replies that he was no prophet nor a prophet’s son—but an herdman, and a gatherer of sycamore fruit—or as Charles Thomson translates the Septuagint—of dates— And the Lord took him as he followed the flock and said unto him, Go, prophesy unto my people Israel— Then he turns upon the priest of Bethel and in defiance of his prohibition, and predicts horrible destruction to him and his whole family—and also the captivity of Israel— And short as the Book of Amos is, consisting of only 9 chapters, he prophesies not only against Israel and Judah, but ruin and destruction to all the neighbouring Nations around them—Damascus, Gaza and the Philistines, Tyre—the Ammonites and the Moabites—he denounces one common ruin against them all—closing however with this glorious restoration of the people of Israel; promising that among other blessings reserved for them they shall plant vineyards and drink the wine thereof  My thermometer this morning was nearly but not quite down to the freezing point and I returned from the walk round the railway square with fingers too much pinched for writing. My wife went to Boston with Mrs Charles, and after their return remained and dined with them up the hill— I found an old paper of Watt’s powders for copying paper ink, and made a pint of it according to the directions with the exception that I made a full pint with the two papers which they describe as sufficient for one third of a pint, and that instead of one tea spoonful of French Brandy to guard the ink from moulding I put in about 2 table spoonfuls of wild cherry rum. I have had the papers of powder from the time when I was in London in 1796. just 50 years— They were hardened into cakes, but melted in the boiling water into ink as black as they could have done when perfectly fresh— I received this day by the mail the Liberty Almanac for 1847. published at New York by William Harned.— Also Wiley and Putnam’s Literary News-Letter for October Vol 5. N. 59. I had already received the Protestant quarterly Review for October. Vol. 3. N. 4—

20. IV. Fahrenheit 26 at Sunrise 6.20— White frost— Aurora Borealis  Though thou exalt thyself as the eagle, and though thou set thy nest among the stars, thence will I bring thee down saith the Lord.  Obadiah 1.4.  Then said the Lord, thou hast had pity on the gourd, for the which thou hast not laboured, neither madest it grow; which came up in a night, and perished in a night: 11. And should not I spare Niniveh, that great city, wherein are more than six-score thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand and their left hand: and also much cattle  Jonah 4.10.11—  The vision of Obadiah is in a single chapter— It is a prophesy of the destruction of the kingdom of Edom, by a league of the two kingdoms of Jacob, that is of Judah and of Joseph, that is of the ten tribes against it— The names of the two kingdoms of Hebrews here are Jacob and Joseph— The names most commonly given them, by the prophets are Judah and Ephraim— Israel is often substituted for Ephraim and after the captivity, passes generally by the name of Samaria— Ezekiel personifies them by the names of Aholah and Aholibah— A strict attention to all this variety of names is indispensable to avoid utter confusion in reading the prophets, and even informing a strict idea of the sacred history— This vision portending nothing more than the total destruction of the Edomites, is said to have been published precisely at the time of the dissolution of the Kingdom of Judah by Nebuchadnezzar and the Babylonian captivity— Who Obadiah was, does not appear— Nothing is known of him, except this record of his vision— But the book of Jonah I suppose to be an allegorical parable—a popular tale invented to illustrate the doctrine that God almighty may be propitiated by repentance and prayer to revoke his own sentence of destruction against a guilty city so as apparently to falsify the prediction of a true prophet— Jonas is a true prophet but his prediction fails to be realized by the discharge of God’s purpose— The disappointment of the prophet by the failure of his prediction drives him to desperation, but his exultation at the growth of the gourd, which shelters him from the heat of the Sun, and his despondency at the withering of the gourd by the visitation of the worm lead only to the antithetical argument of Jehovah that Jonah was wrong in complaining that his prophesy had been falsified by God’s failing to execute his own determination, because it was done in tender mercy to repentance and prayer, and because he himself having felt compassion for a perishing vegetable, could not charge God with inconsistency for sparing from threatened destruction a city of 600000 people—  Notwithstanding the winter cold of the thermometer I walked round the Railroad square before Sunrise to the sharp pinching of my fingers— I was very busy the whole day without interruption of visitors without being able even to bring up the arrears of the last two days in this Journal. I waste too much reading on the newspapers which leave no recollection behind.

21. III. IV. Fahrenheit 36. at Sunrise 6.21.  But in the last days it shall come to pass that the mountain of the house of the Lord shall be established in the top of the mountains, and it shall be exalted above the hills; and people shall flow unto it. 2. And many Nations shall come and say, Come and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, and to the house of the God of Jacob; and he will teach us of his ways, and we will walk in his paths: for the law shall go forth of Zion, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem. 3. And he shall judge among many people, and rebuke strong nations afar off: and they shall beat their swords into plow-shares, and their spears into pruning-hooks: nation shall not lift up a sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more. Micah 4.1.2.3.—and Isaiah. 2.2.3.4.  I hope it may not be presumptuous to remark that as understood by the Jews and by Christians of all denominations this is the distinct and explicit promise of the Messiah and of his kingdom on earth— Its repetition in the same words by two of the prophets may have crept into the manuscripts, but the additional verse in Micah—4. But they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig-tree: and none shall make them afraid: for the mouth of the Lord of hosts hath spoken it, is the most delightful incident of the whole prediction— The cessation of war between the Nations of the earth will be an improvement in the condition of man by perpetual exemption from the greatest of evils— The setting under his vine and his fig-tree with none to make him afraid is improvement of his condition by the enjoyment of blessings never secured to him while he will be exposed to suffer the calamities of War.  I still fail to redeem the arrears of my daily record. My morning walk round the Railway square is the only occurrence of sufficient moment to be noted in my diurnal movements— Passed Midshipman John Quincy Adams was here before dinner— And Mr Augustus Young heretofore a member of Congress from the State of Vermont, and a theoretic assailant of Sir Isaac Newton’s system of the Universe, came and brought with him his 8vo volume of 292 pages, now at length just published and entitled Unity of purpose or Rational Analysis, being a Treatise designed to disclose physical truths and to detect and expose popular errors— This title page does not disclose who is the author of these popular errors: but they are the supposed discoveries of Sir Isaac Newton and especially his theory of gravitation— I had subscribed for this book when Mr Young began to prepare it for publication— He communicated to me then the outlines of his system, and asked my opinion of it. I told him I was not sufficiently conversant with the subject to give or to form an opinion between the conflicting elements of his system and that of Sir Isaac Newton, but I would take a copy of his book, and endeavour to understand it as well as I can. He left a copy with me for which he took two dollars— Its proper price would be about half a dollar— Charles and his wife were here this Evening. Mrs John was confined to her chamber with a cold and sore throat—

22. IV: Fahrenheit 28 at Sunrise 6.22. Crystal clear—  He hath shewed thee, O Man, what is good: and what doth the Lord require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?  Micah 6.8.  This is one of the remarkable passages of the old Testament, placing in contrast with each other the efficacy of sacrifices, and of moral virtue to propitiate the favour of Almighty God— The aspirant enquires by what sacrifice, even the most costly, nay of his own first born Son, he can obtain the blessing of Jehovah? The answer says nothing of sacrifice, but declares that he has been shewn by God himself what is good: and for the enjoyment of it, nothing is required of him but justice, mercy and sincere humility—to walk humbly with his God— There is no rejection of sacrifice not even a word of displeasure at the extension of the question to the sacrifice of a first born Son. The question with regard to sacrifice is left unanswered or rather left to the inference that from the just, the merciful and the humble no sacrifice is required— The whole system of the Mosaic law was founded upon the efficacy of sacrifice as atonement for sin— It was abolished by Jesus Christ himself in the Christian creed a voluntary sacrifice in atonement for the sins of all mankind—  Just after eleven O’Clock last Night about an hour after we had retired to bed my granddaughter Mary Louisa came into our bed chamber and requested my wife to go in to her mother who she said was not very well— My wife immediately rose and went into Mrs John Adams’s chamber, and remained with her the whole Night— It was an attack of Croup or Quinsy— Dr Woodward was immediately sent for and came about midnight and administered the remedy which relieved her from the pressing danger— I passed the Night sleepless, and in agony, but arose upon the stroke of four by the Clock— Al was still in the house and as d— as day-light came I walked round the railway square— At the corner of my Son’s house I saw the Sun rise in all his beauty and splendour with a frost of four degrees pinching my fingers— Mrs Charles who heard me threw up her window, and enquired, what of the night, at the house below I told her how ill Mary had been—she rose immediately and came down to our house and breakfasted with us— The crisis with Mary had passed away and she was left with an ordinary hoarseness and sore throat. I went to Boston with Mrs Charles and her little Mary in the Carriage—was shaved at Cadmus’s shop, called on judge John Davis and had an hour of pleasant conversation with him— Then at my son’s office and at one met Mrs Charles at Dr Frothinghams and we returned to Quincy— I found Mr John Martin Connell at dinner with my family. He returned to Boston and I dined at my Son’s.

23. IV. Fahrenheit 26 at Sunrise 6.23. clear  The Lord is slow to anger, and great in power, and will not at all acquit the wicked: The Lord hath his way in the whirlwind, and in the storm, and the clouds are the dust of his feet Nahum 1.3—  And Huzzab shall be led away captive, she shall be brought up, and her maids shall lead her, as with the voice of doves, tabering upon their breasts—  Nahum 2.7—  The description of the anger of the Lord is grand and terrible— Compare the tempest with that in Virgil’s Georgics 1.327.— I find no satisfactory exposition of the meaning of the word Huzzab, which is understood to designate the Queen of Assyria or Assyria personified— Is the word tabering applied to the maids or to the doves— The image to exquisitely beautiful with either construction, but to my fancy most graphic, applied to the doves— I can find in no English dictionary the word tabering or the verb to taber.  The Revd. John Martin Connell is now a presbyterian Clergyman—not yet settled, but preaching at large— About fifteen years ago his father John Connell introduced him to me as then a promising school-boy— He is now on a short visit to this part of the Country and brought me a Letter of introduction from his father dated 7. October at Tusculum near Wilmington Delaware, where he now resides— While I was absent yesterday, Mr William Lee, son of an old friend of mine of the same name now some years deceased was here with a Miss Scott from Washington— I received yesterday two Letters from George Joy, John Street Pentonville London, 21. Septr. and 3. October 1846. the first enclosing a copy of a Letter to him of 11. August 1846. from Coll. Thomas Aspinwall our Consul at London— This first Letter was endorsed per Great-Britain (Steamer) via Liverpool—but the Great-Britain sailed from Liverpool on the 22d. of September, and on the same night was wrecked on the coast of Ireland—her mail however was saved and both Mr Joy’s Letters came by the Steamer Caledonia which sailed from Liverpool October 4. The Thermometer at 26 this morning discouraged me from going out before breakfast and I lost the usual exercise of my walk. I intended to supply its place after dinner, but Mr William Ellis of Dedham came in and held me till Sunset discoursing upon the pension claims at Washington, patronised and recommended by him, especially upon that of Relief Dunbar the condition of which I was not able to state, for want of the house journal of the last Session of Congress— I have received from Mr John G. Palfrey the pamphlet republication of his 24 numbers on the Slave-power first published in the Boston daily Whig— I have also received a Letter from Augustus G. Randall Passadumkeag, Maine 16. Octr 1846. asking my opinion whether Congress have the Constitutional power to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, and the Territories— He says that Mr Hatch a Baptist Clergyman told him and persisted in maintaing that my opinion was that Congress had not the power—

24 IV. Fahrenheit 42 at Sunrise 6.24. cloudy.  Wo unto him that giveth his neighbour drink, that puttest thy bottle to him, and makest him drunken also, that thou mayest look on their nakedness— Habakkuk 2.15—  On the 6th. of September 1840. passing the day at Kentville in the British province of Nova Scotia I heard the Revd. H. L. Owen a clergyman of the church of England, preach at Cornwallis, a temperance sermon from this text— I then remarked, the gross blunders of grammar, in this text as it reads in the common English bible— In Charles Thomson’s version of the Septuagint—it reads “Wo to him who maketh his neighbour drink a foamy intoxicating draught, making him drunk that he may inspect his caves”— This is grammar, but a prodigious abatement of the picturesque in the conveyance of the thought—the transition from the third to the second person to him that puttest thy bottle is a flagrant breach of grammar—but brings the charge of tempting drunkenness directly to the reader—and observe the difference of the tempter’s motive—in the Septuagint merely to inspect their caves, in the common bible, to look on their nakedness—the transition from the singular to the plural also their nakedness implying that in making one man drunk you tempt a whole company adds aggravation to the charge. It is a curious reflection for a student of composition, that this setting at defiance all the rules of grammar snatches a grace beyond the reach of art and constitutes the beauty of the Style.  Mrs John Adams is still confined to her chamber, but we hope recovering Margaret Delany, housemaid and Mrs Kirke both of whom have been threatened with lung fevers are convalescent— Mary Louisa went into Boston in the 10 O’Clock train of cars for her riding lesson, and came home to dinner— The mildness of the morning air invited me to resume my walk round the railway square before Sunrise. I have received numbers 126. and 127. 10 and 17. October 1846, of Littell’s living age— Wiley and Putnam’s Literary News Letter Vol. 5. N 59. October 1846— The Harbinger, a quarto-periodical of 8. pages—devoted to social and political progress, published by the Brook farm phalanx at New-York and at Boston— This number is dated this day Vol. 3 N. 20— And I received a Letter from Mrs Maria Weston Chapman Boston Octr. 21 1846. requesting me to furnish an Article for the annual Liberty party publication at their Anti-slavery fair soon to be held— Mrs Chapman reminds me of a Sonnet upon the Treaty of Gelon king of Syracuse, with the Carthaginians, mentioned by Montesquieu which I did furnish for the Liberty Bell two or three years since, and which has been long forgotten— Without interruption from visitors, I laboured all the morning and nearly two hours of the evening by Lamplight, retrieving less than half a day of the arrears of this journal— There is no daylight for writing after dinner— The Sunset this afternoon at 5 minutes past 5 but an hour before Sunset the light fails for writing or reading in my chamber— My Son with his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine spent a short evening here.

25. IV. Fahrenheit 32 at Sunrise 6.25 Crystal clear.  Sing, O daughter of Zion; shout O Israel; be glad and rejoice with all the heart, O daughter of Jerusalem 15 The Lord hath taken away thy judgments, he hath cast out thine enemy: the King of Israel, even the Lord, is in the midst of thee: thou shalt not see evil, any more—  Zephaniah 3–14–15—  The period within which all the prophetic books of the old Testament were written was something more than four hundred years embracing the time between 800 and 400 years before Christ— The first in Time by the Chronology of the Bible was Jonah, but this was only a prediction against the City of Niniveh even before the Assyrian captivity, and had no reference to either of the jewish kingdoms. Professor Noyes who undertakes to give them in Chronological order begins with Joel and follows up with Amos, Hosea, Isaiah and Micah—but he acknowledges that the time when several of the prophets wrote is altogether uncertain— The date of the prophecy of Zephaniah on the margin of the English Bible is 612 before Christ—two years before king Josiah was slain by Pharaoh Necho—cotemporary with the 4th. 5th. and 6th. chapters of Jeremiah—  Mr Lunt preached in the Temple this morning from John 21.22— Jesus saith unto him, if I will that he tarry till I come, what is that to thee? follow then me— This is the text upon which all the fables about the wandering Jew have been constructed— The brethren, that is the disciples of Jesus at the time understood him as declaring that the beloved disciple John should not die— The evangelist himself says that Jesus did not say that he should not die, but from what he did say, the brethren could draw no other conclusion, and there are thousands upon thousands upon the roll of Christians at this day who believe that the apostle is yet living and walking the world without being known— It opens a field for the exercise of imagination, in the invention of facts irresistible to the herd of novelists and Romancers of the present age; but the great stress of Mr Lunt’s discourse was upon the query—what is that to thee? and upon the final injunction follow then me.— He expatiated with great eloquence upon this command which he understood as addressed to all the disciples of all ages, and of every nation—and he enumerated many particulars in which he held it the duty of all Christians to follow their Lord and master, and to hearken throughout their lives to his voice addressing them in the words which he spoke to the Apostle Peter, what is that to thee? follow thou me— Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from 1. Corinthians 12.21 And the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee; nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you— I had heard him preach this sermon before, but it is the old fable of Menenius Agrippa. Mr Lunt closed the service with the 8th. hymn, my version of the 67th Psalm— Mr and Mrs Emmons paid us an early evening visit

26. IV. Fahrenheit 24. at Sunrise 6.26. Crystal clear.  The glory of this latter house shall be greater than of the former saith the Lord of hosts; and in this place will I give peace, saith the Lord of hosts.  Haggai 2.9.  There is a Sermon of Archbishop Tillotson, upon this and the three preceding verses. (Sermon 70. vol. 4. p. 256.) which I read many years ago with much satisfaction, and in which he explains this prophesy by maintaining that the greater glory of the second Temple, to consist in the presence of the Messias that is that it was the place in which he revealed himself to the world— This is not directly said by the prophet, nor was it possible for those to whom the prophesy was addressed to form a conception that this was its meaning, but the object of the prophet was to stimulate and urge his countrymen to great exertions to complete rebuilding of the temple, and an indefinite promise of greater glory reserved for the second Temple, than that of Solomon had enjoyed was well suited to kindle into enthusiasm the zeal of the builders to accomplish the work— The advent of the Messiah was foreshadowed in this prophesy, as distinctly as it had been before by Isaiah.  I have been watching every clear morning these three weeks to witness the rising of Arcturus in the East, and saw him for the first time about 10 minutes risen this morning— Orion, Sirius Procyon were shining at the South and Calisto and Helice at the North, and at half past 5 Venus made her appearance in the morning twilight approaching to her conjunction with the Sun— The thermometer at 24 degrees was 2 degrees lower than it had before been this Season, and I sallied forth no farther than to witness the rising of the Sun from the corner of my Son’s house— I pass most of my time in self reproach for doing nothing—though I labour heavily at reading the Scriptures and the Newspapers, and at keeping up with the current of time in this journal— I received this day the Liberty Bell of 1842.— Of 1844 with an engraved portrait of Lucretia Mott, and of 1845 with an etching profile of Wendell Phillips. These Books came with the Letter from Mrs Maria Weston Chapman, but were left at my Son’s office at Boston, and were brought out by him this day.  Mr Minott Thayer called on me this afternoon and told me that Mr Asa French assures him that my copy of the old Braintree Records has been returned to me, and that I had lent it to Mr Allen of Northborough— Of this I have no recollection— Mr George Smith formerly of this town but for the last 12 years of Cincinnati with a Mr Streat of that city and his Son, and a Mr Briant of the Church at East Boston were also here this afternoon, and a mutual recognition occurred between Mr Smith and Mr Thayer—

27— IV. Fahrenheit 54. at Sunrise 6.27. Scattered Clouds. Sunset 5.  Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh unto thee: he is just, and having salvation; lovely and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt the foal of an ass.  Zechariah— 9.9.  In the 21st chapter of Matthew it is related that Jesus sent two of his disciples to fetch him an Ass with a colt for him to ride into Jerusalem, which he did followed by a multitude shouting hozannas to him as the Messiah; and the evangelist says v. 4. All this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying 5. Tell ye the daughter of Zion, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, meek, and sitting upon an ass, and a colt the foal of an ass— The name of the prophet is not mentioned by the evangelist, but the quotation is in words so nearly identical with this prediction of Zechariah, that it can refer to no other— But in comparing the prophesies of the Old Testament with the references to them in the New, questions constantly occur, why incidents so trivial in themselves should be made so prominent in prophesy, so obscure when delivered, and so insignificant when fulfilled— When Jesus sent for an ass with a colt to ride into Jerusalem, he had express reference to this prophesy, and the special purpose to fulfil it, but he did not disclose his purpose to his disciples— But the prophesy was that the king should come riding upon an Ass, that he should be just, and lowly and should bring with him salvation. The Ass with retrospect to the prophesy was equivalent to the assumption of the kingly crown, and so it was understood by the multitude, who hailed it with rapture, and by the Priests and Pharisees who considered it as a compound crime of Treason and blasphemy— But why should this incident be made a subject of prophesy?— If merely emblematical of the humility of the Saviour, it opened no prospect of future justice or promise of Salvation—  Mr Joab Seely, styling himself an inhabitant of Vermont came as a mendicant agent in behalf of the Oberlin college in the State of Ohio— He had no credential of authority from the college itself. Nothing but a small new subscription book in his own handwriting, promising that each subscriber will for five years pay annually the sum affixed to his name. I declined under-writing mine— Mr Daniel Baxter one of the Selectmen of the town came and proposed to call a town Meeting to have a room fitted up in the Town house to hold the Library given by my father to the Town— I readily assented to and advised the call of the Town meeting— Passed midshipman John Quincy Adams was here, and promised to come out from Boston again, and dine with us next Friday.— My wife with Mrs Charles went to Boston, and Mary Louisa to take her riding lesson— They went in the Carriage and returned home to dinner. A severe Letter was published in the Boston whig from Charles Sumner to R. C. Winthrop—

28. III. IV. Fahrenheit 48 at Sunrise 6.28. Mist N.E. Sunset  Behold, I will send my messenger, and he shall prepare the way before me: and the Lord, whom ye seek shall suddenly come to his temple, even the messenger of the covenant, whom ye delight in: behold, he shall come, saith the Lord of Hosts— Malachi 3.1—  Behold I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord: 6. And he shall turn the heart of the father to the children, and the heart of the children to their father, lest I come and smite the earth with a curse. Malachi 4–5.6.  These are the closing verses of the old Testament, which I began to read on the first day of last December and finished this morning— I began with reading two chapters every morning which I increased successively to three and four. And for the purpose of fixing my attention more closely to what I read I have adopted the practice of entering upon this daily journal one or more verses of each days reading. Since I reached home on the 15th. of August I have read every morning the corresponding chapters of Charles Thomson version of the Septuagint, and consulted daily the Notes of Hewlett and of Scott, and sometimes the French Bible of Ostervald, and the German Bible of Luther— My proficiency in Bible learning bears no proportion to the time and study that I bestow upon it— So many times as I have read the bible through I am surprized at the multitude of passages that I had either never noticed or have totally forgotten that I ever had noticed them before.— The only ultimate purpose of reading the Bible is for religious and moral instruction— Its history, its Chronology, its biography and its geography are not more difficult to understand than those of a profane historian, but the more I read the prophetical books, the more I find my understanding perplexed with them— Christians of all denominations consider them all as predictions of the advent of the Messiah; and most of the readers of the English Language consider Pope’s Pastoral as containing the sum and substance of them all.  I have nothing to tell of the incidents of this day— With incessant labour morning and evening I brought up the arrears of journal— I answered the Letter from Mrs Eliza T. P. Smith of Woodvale Roxbury, and enclosed with it the Ode on Justice, which I wrote in England in 1816. and which has never been published— I offer it for publication in her miscellany— There is a sentiment of the ridiculous connected with this multitude of applications, for lectures, and autographs, and lines for Albums from which I cannot escape— Above all are such requests embarrassing yet flattering—from females— Mrs Chapmans call for a chime on the Liberty bell is now on hand, and I have nothing better to contribute than extracts from the fragment of an epistle to the Clio of the National House of Representatives.

29. IV— Fahrenheit 34 at Sunrise 6.29. Snow. Sunset 4.57.  10. The first wrote Wine is the strongest— 11. The second wrote, the king is the strongest. 12 The third wrote, Women are the strongest: But above all things truth beareth away the victory. 1. Esdras 3.10–11–12  I began the reading of the Apocrypha. four chapters a day. And still extract from them one verse more, to introduce the daily Diary— I begin with the curious discussion between the officers of the guards of king Darius of the question of the relative strength of Wine, the King, women and Truth, which led to the rebuilding of the Temple of Jerusalem— This event has an important and indispensable connection with the advent, and history of the Messiah; although it is not easy to perceive why the restoration of the temple should have been necessary to introduce the founder of a system of religion which was to supersede the temple and all its modes of worship and all its sacrifices— There is not the most distant allusion to this in any one of the prophets— Under the doctrines of the Law from Sinai, there was but one lawful place for the worship of Jehovah, and from the days of David that was Jerusalem, to which he had brought the ark of the covenant— The restoration apparently promised by all the prophets was that Jerusalem should again be the only place of worship, not only for the children of Israel, but for all Nations— And that the priesthood, and the worship of sacrifice should be restored as well as the Temple.—  I went to Boston this morning in the train cars which left the depot of Quincy at half past ten— On alighting at Boston I walked first to my Son’s office where I saw Mrs Beck of Charlestown, who has a petition and a claim before Congress, the condition of which I could not inform her—but which I must not forget at Washington next December— At noon I attended the meeting of the Massachusetts historical Society— There were 22 members present, but no business of importance transacted— The meeting adjourned soon after 1. I dined with Judge John Davis. His two widow daughters, Mrs Goodwin and Mrs Plympton two of his grandsons, children of his deceased son John Watson, the Revd. Doctor John Codman of Dorchester and Daniel Appleton White, judge of probate for the County of Essex, constituted the party— After dinner about 4, I called on the Revd. Dr Frothingham, and had a short conversation with him— I asked him the meaning of the word Huzzab Nahum 2–7. which he could not tell me, but he found in Richardson’s Dictionary the word tabering and many old authorities for its use—smiting as upon a tabor. I came home in the train of Cars which left Boston at half past 4 and got home at 5. Met in the Cars the Revd. Mr Miner, baptist minister heretofore at Neponset now at Pittsfield— My Son went to Boston this evening and presided at a meeting where Charles Sumner was nominated as a Candidate against Winthrop to represent the Boston District in the 30th. Congress.

30. II. IV:10. Fahrenheit 38 at Sunrise 6–30. Clear Cloudy. Sunset 4.55.  Now in the second year of Darius, Aggeus and Zacharias, the son of Addo the prophets, prophesied unto the Jews, in Jewry, and Jerusalem, in the name of the Lord God of Israel which was upon them. 1. Esdras. 6.1.  There is another chronological table very desirable, of the prophets and prophesies during the same period, in which accuracy is not attainable— The order in which the prophets are published in all the Bibles is absurd and unaccountable. An attention to their Chronological order is of some use in reading them.  My health is again drooping, and the first Snow has already dashed my pen from my hand— I write with extreme difficulty, and hoarseness and a sore throat are returning upon me— My Son returned at 11. O’Clock last evening from the independent rally of the whig minority at Boston over which he presided, and which resulted in the nomination of Charles Sumner as a Candidate to represent the first congregational District of Massachusetts Boston, in the 30th. Congress of the United states— This schism of the whig party occasioned by Winthrop’s vote for the declaration of War against Mexico—will go far to overthrow the political ascendancy of the whigs in this Commonwealth— The moral issue upon the question of the War is precisely that between Brutus and Cassius in the Shakespear’s Tragedy of Julius Caesar— It is the question between the Epicurean and the Stoic philosophy— It is a severe trial upon the worldly prospects of my Son, who in this case has taken the side of Right, of Justice and of Truth, and for whom I can only implore of the giver of all good, that his strength corporeal, moral, and intellectual may prove equal to this and to every other trial through which he may be called to pass— I walked round the railway square this morning before breakfast and stop’d at Marsh the shoemaker’s, and ordered a pair of slipper shoes. Charles was here an hour this evening without his wife and daughter— There was rain—not so much as is needed—

31. I. IV.15. Fahrenheit 44. at Sunrise 6.2  And the word of the Lord came unto me saying 5. Go thy way, and show my people their sinful deeds, and their children their wickedness, which they have done against me; that they may tell their children’s children— 2. Esdras 1.4–5  On the 30th. of September 1845.
